headline: Unisys Navy Deal
abstract: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -    The Unisys Corporation has been awarded a $509 million Navy contract modification for the production of navigation and other equipment for the Trident missile program, the Defense Department said. Unisys, based in Detroit, was created by the merger of the Burroughs and Sperry corporations.

headline: Shaklee to Buy RJR Nabisco Unit
abstract: The Shaklee Corporation said that it had agreed to purchase the Bear Creek Corporation, a direct marketing company, from RJR Nabisco Inc. for $123 million.

headline: PERELMAN HAS 15% TRANSWORLD STAKE
abstract: Ronald O. Perelman, the New York investor who took control of Revlon Inc. last year, has been secretly amassing Transworld Corporation stock in recent weeks and now owns about 15 percent of its outstanding shares, the company disclosed yesterday.   In a brief statement, Transworld, the owner of Hilton International, Spartan Food Systems and the Canteen Corporation, said it had no other information regarding the acquisition of the stock.   But Wall Street sources say Transworld was recently contacted ''indirectly'' by someone familiar with Mr. Perelman's actions, although the company has still not been able to ascertain the investor's intentions.

headline: GOING FOR NON-CASH BENEFITS
abstract: WORKSITE wellness programs do more than lower medical costs. Here are just a few of the claims that wellness consultants make:    * Excercise perks up lethargic employees.    * Community safety campaigns polish a corporation's ''good-citizen'' image.

headline: Europeans Protest on Chips
abstract: The European Community said today that it would ask the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to investigate the legality of a United States-Japan accord on semiconductor prices.   The community's executive commission said the agreement, reached July 30, violated GATT's fair-trade rules.

headline: DONALD DUCK LEARNS CHINESE
abstract: A large animated mouse and an orange-billed duck in a red bow tie waddled into Peking today to sell Disney's magic kingdom to one billion Chinese.   Chaperoned by the chairman and president of the Walt Disney Company, Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck wandered through one of this city's sumptuous new hotels to mark the announcement that the cartoon adventures of the two would flicker across Chinese television screens beginning this Sunday.   Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, said that 104 episodes of 30 minutes' duration would be broadcast over Chinese national TV over the next two years. 'Three Generations of Children'    And Frank G. Wells, the president and chief operating officer of Disney, said: ''As you know, there are at least three generations of children in China who don't know who Mickey and Donald were. We decided the first move should be to bring the characters to national television.''

headline: Chicago Title Deal
abstract: The Chicago Title and Trust Company, a subsidiary of the Alleghany Corporation, said it had reached an agreement to purchase the Safeco Title Insurance Company, a unit of the Safeco Corporation.

headline: Control Data Planning Acquisition of B.A.R.
abstract: Broadcast Advertisers Reports, which has been monitoring advertising on televison and radio for 32 years and on cable more recently, is about to be acquired by the Control Data Corporation, which already owns Arbitron Ratings, itself a major force in monitoring and measuring broadcasting. No details on the planned deal were released.   Included in the buy will be the B.A.R. subsidiary, Radio TV Reports, which serves the advertising community by supplying tapes and scripts of competitive commercials that it records off the air.

headline: SOVIET ENDS SECRECY ON GRAIN
abstract: The Soviet Union has published figures on the size of the grain harvest for 1985, after five years of withholding information on the annual grain crop.   Figures of the Central Statistical Administration this week showed that 191.6 million metric tons of grain were harvested last year, well below the annual goal of 239 million.

headline: Technology Concerns in Black
abstract: Two of the nation's leading technology concerns, the United Technologies Corporation and TRW Inc., posted profits in the third quarter in contrast to losses in the corresponding 1985 period. But both companies continued to be hurt by problems at various operations, including their military contracting units.   United Technologies reported yesterday that it had net income of $108.2 million, or 80 cents a share, in the third quarter in contrast to a loss of $45.6 million in the 1985 period. But the diversified high-technology concern said that earnings from continuing operations fell 26.6 percent, to $108.2 million, or 80 cents a share, from $147.5 million, or $1.08 a share, in the 1985 quarter. Revenues rose 12.2 percent, to $3.87 billion, from $3.45 billion.

headline: A Different Approach By Voter Campaign
abstract: As a public service effort Grey Advertising has created and taped a bunch of 10-second or 15-second commercials to help Vote America Youth Initiative, a Washington-based nonprofit organization, stimulate the nation's young voters to show up at the polls.   Rather than following the customary practice of depending on time donated by TV stations and networks, the organization has lined up corporate sponsors who will give the group time slots they have purchased.

headline: BELGIUM'S LEADER OFFERS RESIGNATION
abstract: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens offered his resignation to King Baudouin today after failing to resolve a dispute over language that has split his coalition of Dutch and French speakers, a Government spokesman said.   The spokesman added that the King had withheld acceptance of the offer. Mr. Martens unexpectedly went to the Royal Palace after a Cabinet meeting this morning and shortly before he was due to make an address to Parliament.

headline: BANKAMERICA RECALLING CLAUSEN, GONE 5 YEARS, AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: The board of directors of the troubled BankAmerica Corporation, in a special meeting today, named A. W. Clausen, former president of the World Bank, to resume the helm of the banking company he once led.   Mr. Clausen, who is 63 years old, was chief executive officer of BankAmerica from 1970 until 1981, when he left to join the World Bank. He returns as chairman and chief executive officer of both the bank holding company and its subsidiary, the Bank of America.   He will face the task of restoring the giant California bank to health after a long period of huge losses from bad loans, management turmoil and high costs.   The action of the board follows the resignation Friday of Samuel H. Armacost, 47, as president and chief executive officer of the BankAmerica Corporation and chairman and chief executive of its bank. He had presided over the bank since 1981, as its fortunes steadily diminished.

headline: SUDANESE FLEE STRIFE TO FIND NEW DESPAIR
abstract: People of the southern Sudan are fleeing the madness of war, clutching with desperate intensity the fragile promise of something better in the north. What they too often find is a squalid dead end, where life is just as precarious.   Garang Garang fled two months ago with his five wives and children from a village near the town of Wau. The area is one of the most desperate in the south; riots have broken out there in attempts to get what little food is left in stores. A wide segment of the population is threatened with starvation, and chaos prevails. Mr. Garang sold his four cows to afford the six-day journey by car to Omdurman, which involved travel on roads set with land mines.

headline: THE CASE FOR AN S.E.C. IN BRITAIN
abstract: NOT one but two two insider-trading scandals have unsettled London's financial community during the past two weeks. The case of Ivan F. Boesky, whose interests included a British investment fund, came just a few days after Geoffrey Collier, a former top stock trader at a leading London merchant bank, was forced to resign for improperly using confidential information for personal trades.   The two cases have focused attention on the long-neglected problem of insider trading in Britain. Many here claim that the Collier case was merely the ''tip of the iceberg.'' and that the ability of the Securities and Exchange Commission to catch a big-time operator like Mr. Boesky shows the need to replace Britain's system of largely self-regulation with an American-style independent watchdog agency.

headline: Pan Am Profits Down 73.9%
abstract: The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter plunged 73.9 percent on a 12.9 percent decline in revenues, which it attributed in part to foreign exchange losses and to a decline in trans-Atlantic travel. Pan Am, the parent of Pan   American World Airways Inc., said net income dropped to $5.5 million, or 4 cents a share, from $21.1 million, or 18 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Stores Corp. appointed Leonard H. Mogil president and division chief executive of Joske's of Texas, a 27-store department store chain in Dallas. He replaces Robert L. Mettler, who resigned.    * Atlantic Mutual Cos. named Kenneth J. Gorman senior executive vice president and elected Mr. Gorman and George A. von Hassel trustees of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Co. and directors of the Centennial Insurance Cos.

headline: Gelco Ruling On Buyback
abstract: The Gelco Corporation can proceed with its plan to repurchase up to 6 million shares of its common stock, or 46 percent of the company, a Federal District Court in St. Paul ruled on Friday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1986
abstract: Companies    Two large banking concerns in Texas agreed to merge. The combination of Republicbank and Interfirst, to be called First Republicbank, would form the nation's 12th-largest bank holding company, with $35 billion in assets. The announcement came just a day after Chemical announced a $1.19 billion deal for Texas Commerce Bancshares.  [ Page D1. ]  Potential acquirers of Texas banking companies are now left with few desirable choices, experts said.  [ D4. ]    A two-year-old Manhattan tower was bought by a Japanese concern for a record price for New York office space. Kato Kagaku, the world's largest corn syrup producer, will pay $301 million, or $500 a square foot, for the building on East 49th Street.  [ D1. ]

headline: Gillette Shares Climb $4.375
abstract: Shares of the Gillette Company, maker of Gillette razor blades, rose $4.375 yesterday, to $52.50, in the third day of heavy trading.

headline: Cuomo Says He Hopes Reagan Didn't Know
abstract: Governor Cuomo said today that the Reagan Administration was ''in collapse'' because of revelations about arms shipments to Iran and that he hoped the trail would end ''before it got to the very top.''   The Governor called on Democrats to cooperate with investigations to help restore the nation's credibility.

headline: Sakharov and Bonner To Moscow Tuesday
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident whose banishment to Gorky has been lifted, said today that he and his wife, the human rights activist Yelena G. Bonner, expect to travel from that city to Moscow on Tuesday.   In a brief interview by telephone from here, he said that he did not want to meet reporters right after returning to Moscow, and that ''there are no conditions'' on his release from nearly seven years of isolation.   Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Petrovsky announced Friday that Dr. Sakharov's internal exile had been lifted and that Miss Bonner had been pardoned on her conviction for anti-Soviet activities.

headline: Fidelity OTC's New Strategy
abstract: REPLACING an eminently successful mutual-fund portfolio manager is a tough assignment. But Morris J. Smith, who took over the helm of the Fidelity OTC Portfolio on July 1, has settled in to meet this challenge.   ''I feel comfortable now with the way things are going,'' he said in his first interview as the fund's portfolio manager.   Fidelity OTC seeks capital appreciation by investing primarily in over-the-counter securities. Last year, with a total return of 68.99 percent, it ranked second among 768 mutual funds monitored by Lipper Analytical Services.

headline: Picking Stocks Is Kid Stuff
abstract: SEVENTEEN-YEAR-OLD David Allee of Manhattan told his mother he was ''afraid to look'' at how his stocks were doing after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 141 points during one week in September. When David mustered the courage to check prices, they confirmed his prowess as a stock picker: None of his holdings had lost even a point, and one had actually risen. Still, he said, ''that drop really scared me,'' and he decided to take profits in Mattel, which he had held since he was 13.   At about the same time Brian Passikoff, 13, of Highland, N.Y., was pondering how to invest his profits: He had bought Converse Inc., the sneaker maker, for $19 a share in July. In August, Interco made a tender offer for $28 - giving Brian a quick 47 percent return. ''Now I'm looking at day-care centers,'' he said. ''Because the baby boomers are having babies.''   At an age when most youngsters are interested in spending, David, Brian and a growing number of other cub capitalists are hooked on investing.

headline: U.S. ARMS DEMAND CALLED EXCESSIVE
abstract: Some arms control experts said today that the American proposal on medium-range arms was unrealistic because it went too far in seeking reductions in the Soviet missile force in Asia.   Ihe United States intends to hold firm on its arms positions, hoping that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will make new offers in Iceland.   Raymond L. Garthoff of the Brookings Institution said the reductions proposed for Soviet missiles in Asia are ''more than the traffic will bear.''

headline: Saudis Renew Call for Oil-Price Rise
abstract: Saudi Arabia's King Fahd renewed a call today for higher oil prices and was reported to have sent a message to Iran, a traditional rival within OPEC, expressing his readiness to cooperate on the organization's affairs.   His statement came after the decision over the weekend by key ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to meet in Quito, Ecuador, on Friday and Saturday to discuss a Saudi call for prices to be set at $18 a barrel, up from the present price of about $15.   The official Saudi press agency quoted the Saudi Information Minister, Ali al-Shair, as saying in Riyadh that King Fahd told his Cabinet that he was committed to seeking a price of $18 a barrel. It was the first public pronouncement on oil by King Fahd since he removed Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani as oil minister 11 days ago.

headline: Chase Leasing Unit
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Leasing Company, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, has agreed to acquire the Clark Equipment Credit Corporation for $191 million.

headline: BEAR, STEARNS CHIEF FELT HE BOUGHT FOR BELZBERGS
abstract: The chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company, Alan C. Greenberg, has said in an affidavit that he bought Ashland Oil Company stock on the assumption that he was buying it for the Belzberg family investment company.   The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a pending lawsuit, contends that the family's investment company, the First City Financial Corporation, and Marc Belzberg failed to file a timely report with the commission on their accumulation of Ashland shares, and that the lack of a timely disclosure enabled them to continue to buy shares at beneficial prices.   The S.E.C. charges that 29,000 Ashland common shares acquired by Bear, Stearns last March 4 were bought under an agreement for their eventual repurchase by the Belzberg interests. Under the securities laws, such an agreement would result in ''beneficial ownership'' and is subject to the disclosure rules.

headline: 3 Plead Guilty In Bevill Case
abstract: Three principals of a failed brokerage firm pleaded guilty today to a securities fraud that the authorities say cost customers more than $100 million.   Entering pleas in Federal District Court were Robert L. Bevill, the former chairman of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc.; John D. Rooney, the former treasurer, and Stuart Gottlieb, a former senior vice president.

headline: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS A U.S. SITE FOR TRAINING NICARAGUAN REBELS
abstract: American military officials are searching for a site within the United States for training Nicaraguan rebels because countries in Central America have refused to allow such activities on their soil, according to an Administration official.   The official said that El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica had declined to allow the United States to train the anti-Government rebels, known as contras, on their territory. The United States, the official said, has chosen not to press those governments and is instead searching for a suitable location in this country.   ''It's a mutual kind of thing,'' the official said. ''We are trying to respect the position of those governments.''

headline: Consulate's Economic Report Angers Pretoria
abstract: The South African Foreign Ministry today summoned the ranking United States diplomat to protest an economic report from the American Consulate here that depicted this divided land as an investment hazard for American concerns.   The 54-page report, prepared by economic officers at the consulate, said South Africa was ''closer to becoming just another African state.''   The disclosure of the report to South African newspapers and foreign news agencies here coincided with a decision by major American corporations to withdraw from South Africa. The protest the report provoked, moreover, seemed to mark a further deterioration in relations between Washington and Pretoria since the imposition of American sanctions in protest of South Africa's race laws.

headline: PROTESTS IN INDIA AFTER BUS ATTACK
abstract: Rioting and strikes erupted in New Delhi and other northern areas today as Indians reacted with shock, grief and anger to the massacre on Sunday of 22 bus passengers by Sikh extremists.   Here in the farmlands of northern Punjab State, survivors and witnesses described the slaughter in which they said six gunmen hijacked a bus with 75 passengers, most of them Sikhs, forced off all the women and those men they believed to be non-Hindus, then opened fire on those who remained.   Survivors said the gunmen had killed at least one clean-shaven Sikh in the mistaken belief that he was a Hindu. Sikhs generally wear beards and turbans.

headline: First Chicago Chooses 'Doer' as Vice Chairman
abstract: When the First Chicago Corporation elected William J. McDonough vice chairman last week, it was in recognition of his mastery of the bank's nuts and bolts. In his new post, Mr. McDonough, who will retain his position as chief financial officer, will be in charge of strategic planning, credit and systems management, accounting, economic research, treasury and human resources. The 52-year-old Chicago native was also elected to First Chicago's board.

headline: UAL, NOT KLM, TO BUY HILTON INTERNATIONAL
abstract: The Transworld Corporation said late yesterday that its agreement to sell its Hilton International subsidiary to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had fallen through, but that UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, would buy the hotel chain. The price is about $980 million. Transworld said it had been informed that KLM's supervisory board voted not to approve the agreement. That agreement, according to sources, was for $975 million in cash. KLM's offices were closed last evening, and it was not immediately clear why the board had voted against the purchase. $632.5 Million in Cash Transworld's agreement with UAL consists of $632.5 million in cash, 2.56 million common shares of UAL and $200 million of UAL debentures.

headline: Wedding Celebration Blamed For Airliner Crash in Pakistan
abstract: Revelers at a wedding firing rifles into the air may have caused a Pakistani plane crash, a newspaper said today. It said seven bridegrooms had been arrested for ''lethal celebrations during marriage ceremonies.''

headline: Careers; Concern On Ethics Is Growing
abstract: ETHICS has become a common topic of conversation in the Wall Street area now that investment banking, the field chosen by the largest percentage of M.B.A. graduates from leading business schools, is the subject of insider trading investigations.   Outplacement firms, graduate schools of business and industry groups are confronting the ethical considerations raised, as are some beleaguered brokerage firms.   At Drexel Burnham Lambert, the big investment banking and brokerage firm at the center of the continuing investigations, Frederick H. Joseph, the chief executive officer, said last week that he supported stricter rules from the Securities and Exchange Commission and wider surveillance tools for the firms, possibly including wiretapping of employees' telephone conversations.   Drexel has come under scrutiny because of its connections with Ivan F. Boesky, Dennis Levine and others involved in S.E.C. investigations into insider information on takeovers. Just last week, one former securities analyst at Drexel, Robert Salsbury, was sentenced to three years' probation for illegal insider trading.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Jo Anne Lala has joined Scali, McCabe, Sloves as a senior vice president, management supervisor.

headline: Jews Riot in Jerusalem At Funeral for Student
abstract: Jews angered by the slaying Saturday of a religious student set fire to an Arab store and smashed car windows today as they marched in a funeral procession through the Old City in East Jerusalem to a cemetery on the Mount of Olives, the police said.   One man was slightly wounded and several taxi cabs were damaged, the police said.

headline: INVESTING; HOW THE PROS WILL INVEST IN 1987
abstract: PROFESSIONAL investors rarely agree on anything. And when it comes to managing their own investments their choices for 1987 run the gamut.  For instance, four years after the start of the bull market that blasted off in 1982, some of them continue to believe that stocks are the best bet. Ralph Wanger, portfolio manager of the Acorn Fund in Chicago, for one, says stocks will continue to do well. ''At this point, stocks are attractive for the long term,'' he said. Most of his assets are invested in shares of his own mutual fund, as well as in private funds run by other professionals such as Michael Steinhardt and Chris Stavrou in New York.

headline: CLEVELAND COUNTS ON A CLINIC
abstract: Dark and abandoned on the East Side, factories that once helped to make this city one of the most important manufacturing centers in the United States now stand as a symbol of the nation's industrial decline.   But just up the road from this industrial ghost town, a bustling campus-like complex of neat lawns and buildings has become one of Cleveland's great hopes for rejuvenating its economy. This oasis in a desert of urban decay is the Cleveland Clinic, the medical institution that has gained international renown for its treatment of cardiovascular disease and other serious illnesses.   Lately, though, the Cleveland Clinic has earned another distinction: Its 8,879 employees make it the city's largest private employer, edging out the LTV Steel Company, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, which is now in bankruptcy proceedings. A Star in the Service Economy    Economists and political leaders have voiced concern that the transformation of the United States from a manufacturing-based to a service-based economy would leave in its wake a country of hamburger flippers. But a look at the clinic, with its assortment of low- and high-powered jobs and the prominent role it has come to play in the local economy, shows this is not necessarily so.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of electric wire terminals and circuitry, elected James E. Marley president, succeeding Harold A. McInnes, who was elected vice chairman. It also elected Benjamin Savidge chief financial officer and vice president.

headline: NO GLITCHES IN WITCHING HOUR
abstract: Yesterday's ''triple witching hour'' was a unique event in a number of respects, traders and market analysts said.   Not only did more shares trade hands at the close than ever before -over 85 million - but the stock market handled the huge order flow ''without a glitch,'' according to Richard Torrenzano, a New York Stock Exchange spokesman.   Of more interest to professionals were the tactics employed at the close, a time when stock index futures, stock index options and individual stock options all expire.   Generally, on triple expiration Fridays, most of the attention is focused on the relationship between the expiring futures contracts and the underlying stocks. But yesterday, most of the action, and the reason stock prices rose at the close, was due to the relationship between the price of the March Standard & Poor's 500 futures contract and the underlying stocks.

headline: SWISS ACCOUNT LINKED TO ARMS DEAL IS FROZEN
abstract: A major Swiss bank has frozen an account believed to have been used to divert Iran arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels, officials here said today.   The bank acted after a request to the Swiss Government from the United States on Friday, the officials said. It was the first time Washington had asked a foreign government to cooperate in the broadening investigation into the secret arms sales.

headline: Galli Associates
abstract: Anthony P. Galli, who set up a public relations office of Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt in Princeton, N.J., earlier this year, has spun it off from the corporation. It will be known as Galli Associates, and Galli is keeping his previous clients. All was done in a civilized and amicable manner, he said.

headline: SHIITE MILITIAMEN IN LEBANON SAY THEY HOLD ISRAELI AIRMAN
abstract: The mainline Lebanese Shiite militia Amal said today that it was holding an Israeli navigator whose jet fighter was shot down over southern Lebanon on Thursday.   ''The captive has a fractured arm but otherwise he is well,'' a spokesman for the group said.   The statement was issued after press reports had said the Israeli flier had been killed after bailing out of his F-4 Phantom jet.

headline: Getting Ready For Tax Audit
abstract: ANYONE'S Federal income tax return can be audited by the Internal Revenue Service.   And whenever such an examination is scheduled, it can be a traumatic experience.   But a tax audit to verify income, deductions and other items need not be either frightening, mysterious or costly. It could be a relatively brief discussion of certain questioned items on a return. If adequate verification is provided, no additional tax has to be paid. Furthermore, there is an extensive appeals process available both inside and outside the I.R.S.

headline: Mexican Chief in Talks On Fighting Drug Trade
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid opened high-level talks today between the United States and Latin American and Caribbean countries on ways to combat drug trafficking.   This two-day conference between the United States and Western Hemisphere countries that are the main sources of cocaine and marijuana is the first time they have come together to discuss a joint approach.   Countries attending the conference are the United States, Mexico, Jamaica, Belize, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia and Brazil.

headline: Talking Business with Wingfield of CIT Group; Asset-Based Lending Grows
abstract: Corporate borrowing that uses equipment, real estate and other assets as collateral became a $57 billion-plus industry last year and is still increasing its penetration in the business world. Moreover, for those companies that use this asset-based financing, typically private concerns with annual sales ranging from $1 million to $250 million, it is likely to be the only way to finance their growth.   Charles L. Wingfield, chairman and chief executive of the CIT Group, is a leader in providing this kind of financing. CIT, a subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation since 1984, is one of the largest companies in the business, with about $9.5 billion in receivables, around 100 offices throughout the country and some 50,000 accounts.

headline: Market Place; G.P.U. Payout Termed Likely
abstract: ELECTRIC utility stocks are typically prized by investors for their cash dividend payments. But shares of the General Public Utilities Corporation, which pays no dividend, have climbed more than fivefold in the last four years.   After selling as low as $4.50 in 1982, G.P.U.'s price reached a recovery high of $25 in the late summer of this year. On Friday, the stock closed at $22.875, up 50 cents for the week, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: ALL DRESSED UP FOR AMERICA'S CUP (AHOY YANKS)
abstract: This sunwashed harbor town, home to the America's Cup sailing races, abounds with souvenirs, freshly painted storefronts and shopkeepers eagerly awaiting an invasion of American tourists.   The only thing that Fremantle lacks, so far, is the American tourists. Although outdoor cafes and newly designed malls are bustling with visitors, most conversations are in the Australian idiom, with relatively few Americans or Europeans in the crowds.   ''People expected a lot more,'' said Barbara McKeown, manager of the Oasis women's clothing store in Fremantle. ''Before the races started, everybody was saying it was going to skyrocket, and it never did.''

headline: Hicks & Haas To Buy Squirt
abstract: Hicks & Haas said that it had agreed to buy the domestic business of Squirt & Company, the leading producer of grapefruit-flavored soft drinks.

headline: Board of Trade Is Criticized
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has criticized the Chicago Board of Trade for not doing enough investigating of its most actively traded contracts to uncover abuses.   In a report issued this week, the C.F.T.C. also criticized the board for not reporting almost one-third of its trades within the 30-minute time brackets as the commission requires in its efforts to insure an audit trail of trading.

headline: Data Bank: October 26, 1986
abstract: ECONOMY

headline: House Appoints 15 to Panel on Iran
abstract: House leaders appointed 15 legislators today to serve on a special committee to investigate the Iran arms deal, and the top Republican immediately rejected suggestions from the White House that key witnesses be granted immunity in order to compel their testimony.   The Republican, Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, told reporters that President Reagan's suggestion about immunity was part of a ''good faith effort'' by the Administration to dig out the whole story, but that it was largely a symbolic and political gesture, not a serious recommendation.   ''There was no way we could grant it,'' Mr. Cheney said of the immunity idea.   Mr. Cheney made his comments after Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, who will leave his post as chairman of the Intelligence Committee, was named to head the special investigating panel. The nine Democrats included five senior committee chairmen, but the six Republicans included three relatively junior members who are known for their combative, and conservative, views.

headline: Soviet Deals Set With Four American Concerns
abstract: Soviet trade officials said yesterday that four American companies had signed formal agreements for joint business ventures in the Soviet Union under new, liberalized trade regulations that Moscow expects to have in place by next month.   The new regulations are part of efforts by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to overhaul the Soviet economy and would invite creation of joint operations in which the Soviet Union would own a 51 percent interest and the foreign company a 49 percent interest. Foreign companies would be permitted to control prices, repatriate profits and remain free from the Soviet planning bureaucracy.

headline: PROCESSING FOR CHARGIT RESUMES
abstract: One day after Chargit Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection, anxious merchants who had used Chargit to handle their credit-card receipts began to collect some of the money owed them as the Bowery Savings Bank, under a court agreement, resumed processing yesterday for the troubled company.   Bowery officials, who said the bank was considering legal action against the company, said they were temporarily processing Chargit business to help the merchants who had depended on its service. Response to Bowery Charges    In response to the charges made Thursday by the Bowery that the company had used money routed from the credit-card companies to the merchants for ''other purposes,'' Gerald Walpin of Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, an attorney for Chargit executives, said his clients were ''confident the company operated under proper procedures.''

headline: SENATORS' PANEL MAY SUBPOENA 3 EX-U.S. AIDES
abstract: A Senate committee has tentatively decided to subpoena three former White House officials said by the Reagan Administration to know about the diversion of millions of dollars to the Nicaraguan rebels, a Congressional official said tonight.   The White House, meanwhile, said President Reagan would not be questioned in the Justice Department's inquiry into the matter.  [ Page A10. ]  The Congressional official said that among those expected to be asked to testify under oath before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence were Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the aide who the Administration says was responsible for the operation, and Robert C. McFarlane, a former national security adviser. No date has been set for the hearings.  A Request for Names Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said this week that Colonel North was the only Government official who knew of the diversion of money from the sale of arms to Iran to the contras, as the Nicaraguan rebels are known. Mr. Meese said Admiral Poindexter learned of it in the last year, but did not stop it. Mr. McFarlane, he said, did not learn about the aid to the contras until this year, several months after leaving Government.

headline: Leaders of Afghan Guerrillas Say Soviet Attacks Continue
abstract: Afghan guerrilla leaders here said today that Soviet and Afghan Government Air Force jets bombarded and rocketed rebel positions in Nangarhar Province today as ground forces pounded the insurgents' fortifications with artillery and tanks.   Guerrilla officials said Soviet and Afghan troops were continuing their offensive near the Pakistani border.   The rebels have been under attack since last week when Soviet and Afghan Government forces began an assault to try and close rebel supply routes from Pakistan.

headline: IN THE INCAS' LAND, A WAR FOR THE PEOPLE'S HEARTS
abstract: Wearing layers of clothes against the winds that sweep across the Andes, 30 Quechua-speaking men and women carved at a steep slope almost 12,000 feet above sea level. Under their hoes, farming terraces began to take shape, much like those used by their Inca ancestors.   Nearby, another team of Indians from the village of Chuso, including women with babies strapped to their backs, carried mud and stones to build a dike for a tiny reservoir that will provide water to irrigate off-season crops of potatoes and beans on terraces farther below.   In both cases, the Indians were working for themselves and their community, but Peru's new social democratic Government is paying them the legal minimum wage of $53 a month as part of an emergency program to improve living conditions among some 3.3 million Indians scattered over the country's barren southern highlands.

headline: YUGOSLAV FACES IMPRISONMENT
abstract: Milan M. Nikolic, a Yugoslav sociologist sentenced to five months in prison for a thesis he wrote at Brandeis University, said Saturday that unless the Yugoslav authorities acted on his plea for postponement, he might have to begin serving his sentence ''any day.''   Mr. Nikolic, 39 years old, wrote a doctoral thesis at Brandeis on Yugoslav social conflicts and how the authorities there respond to them.

headline: GORBACHEV OFFER DISMISSED BY U.S.
abstract: The State Department today dismissed as propaganda an assertion by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Soviet Union was prepared to be flexible on research and testing for the American space-based missile defense system.   The issue has been an obstacle to achieving an arms reduction agreement. Soviet officials have been telling Americans that there is room for negotiation, but these statements do not appear to have been reflected in the arms talks in Geneva.

headline: CONTRADICTION IS REPORTED IN SHULTZ STATEMENTS ON IRAN
abstract: As recently as Oct. 1, after Secretary of State George P. Shultz had evidence of American arms sales to Iran, he said at a luncheon meeting of Persian Gulf foreign ministers in New York that the Reagan Administration had stepped up its campaign to block such sales. He also criticized the Soviet Union for failing to do so.   The contradiction between what Mr. Shultz knew and what he told the Arab officials came to light today after the luncheon was described by Abdulla Y. Bishara, a Kuwaiti who is Secretary General of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council. The text of Mr. Shultz's public remarks, obtained from the State Department, provided an insight into how the Administration's two-track policy was pursued.

headline: Group's Husky Oil Deal Worries Hong Kong
abstract: When Li Ka-shing and some of his associates bought a stake in Husky Oil in Canada last week, it had reverberations in Hong Kong, which is nervous about capital flight.   Hong Kong is scheduled to revert to Chinese rule in 1997 and such investments outside the British colony suggest that executives involved in big business might be preparing to leave.   Mr. Li, 56, is one of the biggest and most powerful of Hong Kong's business executives. He left China in 1940 and became extremely wealthy in Hong Kong, mostly in property. Last week, a group that includes Mr. Li and family members, negotiated an agreement to purchase a controlling interest in Husky Oil.

headline: IMMUNITY BID SEEN; Bush Concedes U.S. 'Mistakes' In Iran Dealings
abstract: Vice President Bush said today that he had not been aware of the transfer of millions of dollars worth of support to the Nicaraguan rebels from secret arms sales to Iran.   But the Vice President, in his first detailed public statement on the affair, acknowledged that the Reagan Administration's ''credibility has been damaged'' because of the clandestine deals.   He said he had supported the President in the effort to establish contacts with Iran, but conceded that ''clearly mistakes were made.''   ''If the truth hurts, so be it,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We gotta take our lumps and move ahead.''

headline: South Korea Frees 413 in Protest Case
abstract: Prosecutors today dropped charges and freed one-third of the 1,275 students arrested for taking part in four days of violent anti-Government and anti-American protests.   A spokesman said 413 students, half of them women, were released to their parents from six prisons in Seoul and nearby towns today because they ''took part in the demonstrations only passively and repented for their action.''   They were among students from 27 schools who demonstrated against the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan and the United States on Oct. 28 to 31, holed up in five campus buildings at Kunkook University in Seoul.

headline: CBS Action By F.C.C.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would take action Thursday on deciding whether control of CBS Inc. had changed hands.   The specific commission action to be taken Thursday is whether to order a ''by direction letter'' sent to CBS.

headline: SIMON RELUCTANT TO SAY HOW HE MADE FORTUNE
abstract: Barely six years ago, people guessed that William E. Simon might be worth as much as $20 million. Today, according to Forbes magazine, he is worth 10 times that much.   Beyond the simple legend that he made it on Wall Street, how he accumulated his vast wealth is not entirely clear. And Mr. Simon, as he quickly makes clear, has no interest in filling in the blanks.

headline: 'Witching' Trade Inquiry
abstract: A flurry of controversy has sprung up surrounding activities during last Friday's ''triple witching hour.''   In separate developments, the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed dissatisfaction with the way the last half-hour of stock trading went, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said it was ''looking into'' reports that options trading was conducted at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the close at 4 P.M., Eastern standard time.

headline: I.R.S. Blocks '86 Deduction
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service slammed the door today on a widely promoted idea for getting around a provision in the new tax law.   The I.R.S. issued a notice that it would not permit full deduction on 1986 returns of the cost of prepaid multiyear subscriptions to business or investment publications.

headline: NORTH 'ABANDONED BY FORMER FRIENDS'
abstract: As he left home today shortly after 6 A.M., Col. Oliver L. North encountered one of the camera crews that have followed his every public move since the Iran crisis first became known.   Colonel North, perhaps stung by Nancy Reagan's recent comments about the crisis, was more talkative today than usual, even turning to Bible quotations to explain his position to a CBS News reporter.   In an interview with The Associated Press on Wednesday, Mrs. Reagan said Colonel North, a former White House aide, should come forward and testify about his part in the arms sale to Iran and the subsequent diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels. He has so far refused to testify, citing his constitutional right against self-incrimination. Here are excerpts from the CBS News interview: Q. What would you say to Nancy Reagan?

headline: THE CARE AND TENDING OF GREAT IDEAS
abstract: ''Land of Opportunity: The Entrpreneurial Spirit in America,'' by Donald Lambro. Little, Brown & Co., Boston. 176 pages, $17.95.   ''Breakthroughs!'' by P. Ranganath Nayak and John M. Ketteringham. Rawson Associates, N.Y. 371 pages, $16.95.    BILL Bowerman began designing track shoes in the early 1950's, when he was a third-year track coach at the University ofOregon. When the leading American sporting-goods companies showed no interest in his designs, Mr. Bowerman, following instructions given him by a shoe repairman, began making the shoes himself. Today, Nike Inc., the company Mr. Bowerman founded with Philip Knight, is not only a billion-dollar business employing almost 2,000 workers, but is also the shoe of choice for many celebrities as well as runners.

headline: 11 KILLED ON MINDANAO; MOSLEM REBELS BLAMED
abstract: At least 11 people were killed and 5 seriously wounded when armed men thought to be Moslem rebels ambushed a logging truck on Mindanao island, the Philippine News Agency reported today.   The Government agency said the ambush occurred Thursday near Maigo in Lanao del Norte province, 490 miles south of Manila.

headline: German Jailed In Fraud Case
abstract: A West German builder was jailed today for six and a half years and fined the equivalent of $45,000 for defrauding a Saudi Arabian of about $50 million.

headline: World Bank Sets Yield on Notes
abstract: The World Bank is offering in the United States bond market $150 million (Canadian currency) of 9.35 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.80, to yield 9.40 percent, or 1/4 of a percentage point more than Canadian Government securities with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   It is the second financing denominated in Canadian dollars in the American bond market, following the Chrysler Financial Corporation's $100 million (Canadian) deal last May of five-year notes, yielding 9.773 percent, or 9/10 of a percentage point more than Canadian Government securities with a similar maturity.   The World Bank notes, which are noncallable for life, are rated triple-A by Moody's and S. & P.

headline: Glitches Snarl London Trades
abstract: Electronic glitches were the first order of the day as the London Stock Exchange began electronic share trading today.   The most dramatic technical problem involved the price-distribution network, which could not handle the wave of first-day interest of traders and investors hammering merrily on their keyboards to try out the new system.

headline: Pennsylvania Plan
abstract: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Facilities Authority is offering $82.2 million of revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.49 percent for bonds due in 2010 through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust.

headline: LEADERS IN PRETORIA REJECT A PROPOSAL FOR REGIONAL POWER-SHARING
abstract: South Africa's white authorities tonight rejected a proposal for regional power-sharing that had been depicted by moderate blacks and whites as a potential model for racial cooperation to end the nation's crisis.   In other developments, the police shot dead a black protester in violence was reported from three of South Africa's four provinces over the weekend.   At the same time, the white authorities faced a new challenge from educational campaigners demanding black control of the country's schools in the name of what is called ''people's education.''

headline: ITALIAN JUDGE DOUBTS BULGARIANS' ALIBIS
abstract: An Italian court document made public today contends that three Bulgarians who were acquitted after having been tried for plotting to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981 provided suspicious alibis.   The document says the alibis did not refute evidence that the papal assailant, Mehmet Ali Agca, had had dealings with them before he shot the Pope.   In reviewing the 10-month conspiracy trial and the verdict it produced, the document concluded that while no firm evidence emerged to link the defendants in an assassination plot, there were solid indications that Mr. Agca had not acted alone.

headline: JAPANESE AGREE TO CUTS ON ALUMINIM TARIFFS
abstract: After years of resistance, Japan has agreed to make deep cuts in aluminum tariffs, which are expected to lead to more business for American exporters, Clayton Yeutter, the United States trade representative, announced today.   The decision to open trade in the world's second-biggest aluminum market was made after a series of high-level meetings here this week between the two governments.   Aluminum industry officials said they welcomed the action.

headline: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. IS UNITED IN OPPOSING APARTHEID
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told African leaders today that despite the Reagan Administration's opposition to severe economic sanctions against South Africa, Washington was united with them in seeking ''an urgent end to apartheid.''   Speaking several hours before the Senate was to vote on overriding President Reagan's veto of economic sanctions, Mr. Shultz asserted that ''there is a firm commitment in the United States to work for a new South Africa,'' in which all of its peoples will have democratic rights.   For most of the day, Mr. Shultz met with African foreign ministers either individually or in groups. In the morning he conferred with the so-called front-line nations bordering South Africa. At lunch he spoke to more than 40 foreign ministers and ambassadors from the Organization of African Unity. A senior State Department official said several of the African leaders spoke emotionally about the need for the United States to take action to show its opposition to South Africa. He said Mr. Shultz thought the United States could act energetically against apartheid without endorsing economic sanctions.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1986
abstract: Companies    Northwest Airlines' parent may buy up to 100 Airbus planes for as much as $3.2 billion in a deal that could be one of the most extensive steps taken by an American carrier to improve its fleet. NWA Inc. is obligated to buy just 10 of the planes from Airbus Industrie. But some analysts said the carrier would probably order all 100 from the consortium, which is owned by the Governments of Britain, West Germany, France and Spain. NWA is buying the new A320-200 planes, which seat 150 passengers.  [ Page D1. ]    South Korea gave 3 American companies first right to negotiate contracts, worth an estimated $500 million, for work on two nuclear plants to be built by the mid-1990's. The companies are Combustion Engineering, Sargent & Lundy and G.E.  [ D1. ]

headline: Computer Venture Links Honeywell, Bull, NEC
abstract: Compagnie des Machines Bull, France's state-owned computer maker, will become the largest player in a venture to form a new company out of Honeywell Inc.'s faltering computer operations, according to an agreement announced yesterday.   The other partners in the venture will be the NEC Corporation of Japan and Honeywell, which has been retreating from the computer business as its share of the mainframe market has slipped in recent years. Honeywell said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of more than $250 million by writing down the book value of its existing computer businesses, resulting in substantial losses for the quarter and the year.

headline: F.B.I. Uncovers Wider Role by Saudis in Iran Arms Deal
abstract: The investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Iran arms deal has uncovered evidence of wider Saudi Arabian involvement than previously disclosed, according to Federal law enforcement officials.   Today in Switzerland, apparently as a result of these and other discoveries, the United States Justice Department asked Swiss officials to freeze nine more bank accounts, including one for a company named Hyde Park Holdings, American and Swiss officials said.   Congressional investigators suspect that these accounts were part of the complex financial path through which the American Government was paid for the weapons sold to Iran and the surplus was used for other purposes, including support for the rebels fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.   Officials declined to give details on Hyde Park Holdings, but corporate records in Panama show that a company with that name was chartered in March. It is headed by Mohamed Said Ayas, a Saudi Arabian described by an associate and other Saudi sources as the manager of the business affairs of Prince Mohammed bin Fahd bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud, a son of King Fahd.

headline: An Extra Day Off for Many
abstract: Retailers, bankers, the Postal Service and the stock markets will operate this Friday, the day after Christmas, but many other employers will be shut down.

headline: ISRAELIS DISPUTE REGAN TESTIMONY
abstract: Senior Israeli officials today disputed the reported testimony of Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, that Israel did not have President Reagan's approval when it shipped arms to Iran in the summer of 1985.   The Israeli officials, who asked anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter, reiterated that Robert C. McFarlane, who was then President Reagan's national security adviser, gave Israel a clear signal that the President approved of an arms-for-hostage deal before Isreal sent the first load of weapons to Iran.   ''I think what we have here is a difference of opinion between McFarlane and Regan or McFarlane and Reagan, but not between Israel and the United States,'' said one Israeli official. ''We believed that we were working with an administration. That was our first mistake. We didn't realize your Government was just like ours.''

headline: Clearing Inc. Deal
abstract: Hanson Industries North America, a subsidiary of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of Britain, said that it had agreed to sell Clearing Inc. to the Hitachi Zosen Corporation for $64 million in cash and notes. Clearing, which makes hydraulic and mechanical action presses, had sales last year of about $39 million and pretax profits of $3.9 million. Its net asset value is about $64 million.

headline: 6 AMERICAN TOURISTS ARE AMONG 11 DEAD IN PLANE CRASH IN FIJI
abstract: Eleven people, including six American tourists, were reported killed today when a light aircraft crashed while attempting a landing at Fiji's international airport at Nadi.   In addition, three people on the four-engine Riley Heron were injured, two critically, in what airport officials said was Fiji's worst air crash.   The police said a passenger list was not likely to be released until Sunday, after relatives had been notified.

headline: Bonn Records Large Surplus
abstract: West Germany recorded a monthly trade surplus of $5.1 billion in September, its second largest ever after a $5.3 billion surplus in July, boosting the trade surplus in the first nine months beyond 1985's full-year results.   According to preliminary figures released today, German exports last month rose 1.2 percent from the August level, to $21.7 billion.

headline: EL AL DEFENDANT DENIES SYRIAN ROLE IN BOMB PLOT
abstract: A Jordanian accused of trying to blow up an Israeli airliner denied today that Syrian Air Force intelligence agents had directed the plot and speculated instead that Israeli agents had staged the crime.   The defendant, Nezar Hindawi, faced a series of prosecution questions about how he came to write down for police detectives the names of various Syrian officials, including Brig. Gen. Mohammed Kholi, chief of Syrian Air Force intelligence, and his aide, Col. Haitem Said.  Mr. Hindawi replied that he was merely writing them down at the police questioner's suggestion and was in no way confessing to the bomb plot.   The police testified Mr. Hindawi confessed he was directed by Colonel Said in giving luggage containing a hidden bomb to his unwitting pregnant lover, Ann Murphy, to take on an El Al flight to Tel Aviv on April 17.   He denied this repeatedly, suggesting that Israeli officials planted the bomb as an embarrassment to Syria.

headline: Purchases Cited In Borg-Warner
abstract: The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has increased his holdings of stock in the Borg-Warner Corporation, according to Wall Street sources, who also believe that someone else may be accumulating shares in the company. Mr. Jacobs recently told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he owned 5.29 million Borg-Warner shares, or 6.1 percent of the outstanding stock.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Catholic Woman Dies Amid Ulster Strife
abstract: An elderly Roman Catholic woman collapsed and died after her home was attacked early today during renewed outbreaks of violence by Protestant opponents of the British-Irish accord, the police said.   Two men claiming to be from the Protestant Action Force tried to bomb a police station in Belfast early today, but army bomb disposal experts thwarted the attempt, the police said.   The incidents came amid a wave of violence and rioting marking the first anniversary Saturday of the signing of the accord.

headline: Body Care Inserts for Magazines
abstract: THE editorial staffs of Good Housekeeping and American Health are cooperating to produce an insert that will run in the May issues of both magazines with the title ''Body Be Beautiful.'' Unlike many recent similar events in publishing, this insert will not be an ''advertorial,'' but pure staff-created editorial supported by advertising.   The concept was conceived by John Mack Carter, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, as a merely a single-thrust article that incorporated the expertise of both publications, but it found a ready ear on a fellow Kentuckian, T. George Harris, editor in chief of American Health. And as they met and talked, various aspects of their chosen subject kept arising until a separate section with advertising was decided upon.

headline: COMPUTERS A 'BIG BANG' WORRY
abstract: The ''Big Bang'' that will open up London's financial markets starting Monday has been looked upon as largely a regulatory watershed. But as securities firms have scrambled to install the computer systems needed to compete in the new era, it has become clear that a technological revolution is also being unleashed - for which few seem well prepared.   Some are coming around to the view that the real Achilles' heel of London's securities industry, and its individual firms, may be inadequate or unreliable technology, not just the increased competition Big Bang will bring.   ''There has been incredible naivete among the senior management at many firms about what could be achieved in such a short period of time,'' said Gordon Clarke, senior manager of the Information Technology Group at the London office of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the accounting and consulting firm. ''Given the time frame, a lot of corners have been cut in putting the systems together. Some have been lashed up and stitched together in a pretty crude way, and they're vulnerable.''

headline: PRETORIA FAULTED ON INTEGRATION STUDY
abstract: The Progressive Federal Party, the main opposition group in Parliament, boycotted a meeting of the Government-dominated President's Council today in a dispute over a report on segregated neighborhoods.   The Progressive Federal Party accused President P. W. Botha of blocking the report, which calls for some racially mixed neighborhoods. It was submitted by the President's Council, a 60-member advisory body, ''The report was hijacked by the State President,'' a Progressive Federal lawmaker, Robin Carlisle, said in Cape Town. ''He does not have the guts to deal with the issue.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: THE FIFTH AMENDMENT VS. THE CHAIN OF COMMAND
abstract: The decision by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights to remain silent has spurred debate on whether President Reagan can legally force them to abandon those rights - or should at least try to persuade them to do so.   The first question is primarily one of law: Does the President, as Commander-in-Chief, have authority to order active-duty officers to give possibly incriminating testimony about their official actions on matters of great public importance, on pain of demotion, dismissal or even court-martial if they refuse?   The second question goes to the ambiguous place of the privilege against self-incrimination in the nation's hierarchy of values. Some see it as a bedrock principle of liberty, invocation of which should never be penalized or even criticized; others see it as a limited safeguard against official abuse, to be treated grudgingly because it often shields criminals and hides the truth.

headline: ASSASSINATION ATTEMPTS STIR UP FUROR IN INDIA
abstract: Two bold assassination attempts, apparently by Sikh extremists, have shaken the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi this week and exposed major flaws in India's security apparatus, Government officials said today.   The officials said several reviews of the security system were under way, focusing on the lapses that permitted a gunman to shoot at Mr. Gandhi at a memorial service on Thursday. The Prime Minister was unharmed.

headline: U.S. SEEKING AWACS FOR PAKISTAN
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States would seek to provide early warning radar planes to Pakistan ''as quickly as possible'' to help defend against incursions from Afghanistan.   At a news conference after two days of meetings with Pakistani officials, Mr. Weinberger said the possibility was discussed of having American crews fly patrol missions in Pakistani airspace, providing training and deterrence while deliveries of planes to the Pakistani Air Force was awaited.

headline: Poindexter Sign Is Stolen
abstract: A street sign honoring a native son, Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, was stolen here on Thankgiving.

headline: Florida Hospital Bonds Yield From 4% to 7.45%
abstract: A $73.5 million financing by the Dade County Health Facilities Authority of Florida for the Baptist Hospital of Miami offers a maximum yield of 7.45 percent for a 7 3/8 percent bond, due in 2013, at a price of 99.127. The underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alexander's Inc., operator of the department store chain, named Donald J. Trump and Robert S. Trump directors. The move follows the Trump purchase of a 20 percent stake in the company.

headline: TEXAN IN MOSCOW: JOB PROBLEM CITED
abstract: A Houston cancer researcer who has emigrated to the Soviet Union had become increasingly withdrawn and uncommunicative over the past year to the point where he could no longer function at work, his colleagues said today.   Friends and colleagues of Dr. Arnold Lockshin, who went to the Soviet Union with his wife and three children, said they were baffled by his actions. But they said his job problems had nothing to do with any political beliefs and speculated that his reasons for leaving the country probably had more to do with personal problems.   Dr. Lockshin said on Soviet television on Wednesday that he was dismissed from his job because of his disagreement with United States foreign policy. But Dr. John Stehlin, scientific director of the research foundation here where Dr. Lockshin worked for six years, said Dr. Lockshin was dismissed because he had become increasingly withdrawn, inattentive and unable to do his work.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1986
abstract: Companies    Wickes holds an option to buy nearly 10 percent of Lear Siegler as part of a friendly proposal to acquire the company for at least $91 a share, or $1.7 billion, in cash. Only 48 hours earlier, Wickes said it would buy Collins & Aikman for $1.2 billion in cash. Lear Siegler had no immediate response. Lear Siegler's stock rose $1.75 a share, to $92, a full dollar above the proposed offering price.  [ Page D1. ]    BankAmerica plans to sell $7 billion to $8 billion worth of assets in the next two quarters, raising the bank's capital by $750 million to $1 billion, its president said. Thomas A. Cooper also said that by the end of 1987 the bank hopes to cut its loan losses in half. But analysts said even tougher moves would be needed.  [ D1. ]

headline: CAMPEAU SUES ALLIED ON DeBARTOLO FEE DEAL
abstract: The Campeau Corporation turned to the courts yesterday to offset an opposing bid for the Allied Stores Corporation.   It charged that Allied had made an arrangement to pay exorbitant fees totaling some $80 million to Edward J. DeBartolo and Paul A. Bilzerian in the event of a breakup of their merger agreement. Such fees were disclosed in the proxy statement put out by Mr. DeBartolo and Allied. Issue of Financial Data    In a suit filed in the Court of Chancery in Newcastle, Del., Campeau also charged that Allied had failed to make available to others the same financial data and other information that it furnished to the DeBartolo-Bilzerian group. Campeau, a Toronto-based shopping center developer, asked the court to void the breakup fees and to compel Allied to make the same data available to Campeau.

headline: Kaiser Holding
abstract: A group led by Joseph A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor, said it had raised its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to 27.6 percent, from 26.4 percent. The Frates group did not give any reason for the additional purchases in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Rates Up on Treasury Issues
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday as many investors and traders are waiting for fresh economic data to provide more clues to future rate changes.   Inactivity is supporting the trend to lower prices and higher yields for notes and bonds, securities dealers said, noting that they want yields high enough to attract investors later this month and in early November when the supply of new Treasury issues will be very heavy.   In advance of next Wednesday's auction of two-year notes, dealers offered the issue with a yield of about 6.26 percent. Among longer-term issues, the 7 1/4 percent bonds due in 2016 fell more than 1/2 point to an offered price of 93 21/32, to yield 7.80 percent, and are now approaching the low of about 93 1/4 set on Sept. 19.

headline: Unilever Deal Spurred By 'Innovative' Market
abstract: Unilever N.V.'s $3.1 billion deal to acquire Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. is aimed at strengthening its presence in the ''innovative'' American consumer products market, an executive of the giant British company said yesterday.   Unilever N.V. and its subsidiaries have developed many new products outside the United States. But Gordon K. G. Stevens, chairman and chief executive of Unilever United States Inc. said in an interview: ''It just happens you are more likely to come up with the next generation of innovative products if you have a strong base in the United States.''

headline: TO PROLIFIC HISTORIAN, A CHURCHILL BIOGRAPHY IS BUT A CHAPTER IN HIS WORK
abstract: If Martin Gilbert had written nothing but the authorized biography of Winston Churchill on which he has been toiling since 1968, he would have to be regarded as one of the most prolific of British historians.   But considering that his ''Road to Victory'' - the 1,351-page seventh volume of the Churchill biography, just published here - was his third book to appear in Britain this year and his fifth in the last two years, Mr. Gilbert obviously stands in a class of his own when it comes to output. The Churchill tome was preceded by ''The Holocaust,'' an 828-page chronicle of the Nazi effort to exterminate Europe's Jews that in the estimation of The Times Literary Supplement, ''is likely to remain the standard history.''   And that was preceded, by only a few weeks, by the publication of a 412-page biography of Anatoly Shcharansky, the jailed campaigner for the rights of Soviet Jews who was finally freed and allowed to leave Russia early this year. Writing to Soviet Jews   Prodigious as that sounds, it is not the whole story. The historian's published output is nearly matched by a vast private correspondence he maintains with Jews in Leningrad and Moscow who have been denied exit visas.

headline: SWISS TO FREEZE IRAN ARMS ACCOUNTS
abstract: The Swiss authorities said today that they would take further steps early in the new year to freeze accounts controlled by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others involved in the covert arms sales to Iran.   They said they would simultaneously lift banking secrecy regulations covering the accounts.   Officials said these measures would set in motion procedures under which legal objections could be filed against the action, possibly blocking temporarily an investigation of account records.   Study of the records is crucial to United States Justice Department investigators to determine whether proceeds from the arm sales were funneled to Nicaraguan rebels, and if so, how much.

headline: PERES WITHHOLDS DETAILS IN BRIEFING M.P.'S ON IRAN
abstract: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres appeared today before Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee but declined to reveal precise details about Israel's participation in the arms-for-hostages deal with Iran, committee sources said.   Mr. Peres told the committee that he would consider briefing a more secret subcommitee on the exact elements of Israel's contacts with Teheran. But he said that because of secrecy considerations, he could not brief the full committee, which does not have a good record of confidentiality, committee sources said.   In the session today, Mr. Peres would speak only on a general level about Israeli dealings with Iran. He told reporters afterward that ''the committee got a full-fledged report on the logic, principles and dates.''

headline: ANGOLA REBELS SAID TO OPEN NEW FRONT
abstract: United States-backed guerrillas have opened a new front in their 11-year-old war against Angola's Marxist Government, military and diplomatic sources said here today.   They said the broadened new fighting had erupted in the oil-rich northern region of this African nation.   ''We feel that Unita has tried to open a front in the north, supplied from Zaire,'' Angola's highest-ranking military officer, Col. Antonio dos Santos Franca, said today.   In the first nine months of this year, 230 guerrillas of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, were killed in Uige and Zaire provinces, an area 800 miles from the group's traditional stronghold in Angola's southeast corner, the Angolan officer, who is known as Colonel Ndalu, said.

headline: May to Sell Horne
abstract: The May Department Stores Company, which recently merged with the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, said it would sell the 15 Joseph Horne Company department stores to a group of Pittsburgh investors headed by Robert O'Connell, Horne's president and chief executive. The Horne stores, which had 1985 sales of $209 million, had been previously owned by Associated. The division has 3,000 employees.

headline: Noranda Sets Mine Merger
abstract: Noranda Inc., one of Canada's major mining companies, agreed in principle today with three partners to merge their interests in the Golden Giant gold mine and form a new public company.   The Golden Giant mine, in northwestern Ontario, is expected to produce 300,000 ounces of gold a year when it reaches full production next year, making it one of Canada's top three gold producers.

headline: Aloha Inc. Buyout
abstract: Aloha Inc., a regional airline, said a group led by top management had agreed to acquire the company in a leveraged buyout at $28.50 a share, or a total of about $57 million. The group includes Hung Wo Ching, chairman; Sheridan C.F. Ing, vice chairman, and A. Maurice Myers, president. Aloha said the transaction will be made in a tender offer starting next Wednesday that will be followed by a cash merger.

headline: Consumer Borrowing Increased
abstract: Americans, still borrowing heavily to finance new-car purchases, took out $6.78 billion more in consumer debt in October than they paid off, the Government reported today.   The Federal Reserve Board said the October increase followed an even larger $7.72 billion September advance, with both months reflecting heavy borrowing to purchase new cars.

headline: FINANCE OFFICERS' WIDE ROLE
abstract: When Fred Zuckerman, treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation, decided to spread Chrysler's name in the financial world, he turned to Japan. Chrysler cars are not sold in Japan, but as of last month its stock has been. With its shares now listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the name of Chrysler is shouted by traders in Tokyo as loudly as it is on Wall Street.   That means Mr. Zuckerman must stay on top of developments in Tokyo - just as other Chrysler executives do on the manufacturing side. Some day Chrysler may very well issue new equity into the Tokyo market. And the fact that a Detroit company has traveled to the financial markets of one of its arch automobile rivals, shows just how global the world of finance has become.   Technology is shrinking the world of finance so that today it is often as easy for an American company to raise capital in London as it is in New York. And, for executives like Mr. Zuckerman, who masterminds Chrysler's financial strategy, the task of being a chief financial officer means he is called on to make more complex decisions than ever before.

headline: RISING REPRESSION SWELLS THE FLOW OF JEWISH EMIGRATION FROM IRAN
abstract: Persecution of Jews in Iran has reached such intensity that hundreds of them have joined a much larger exodus of Moslem Iranians fleeing the country, according to refugee officials here.   While Jews have been leaving Iran since the popular upheaval that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in early 1979, the officials said the latest outflow was by far the biggest and most sustained since the time of the revolution.   Some refugees who have arrived in Vienna estimated that at any time 500 Jews were being detained in Iran, many accused of being Zionists. Others, they said, have been arrested for purposes of extortion. Other Groups Are Targets   At the same time, however, the refugees stressed that the travails of Iranian Jews were less severe than those of the Bahais, who are regarded as heretics by Moslems.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Big V Supermarkets Inc., Florida, N.Y., named its president, A. Richard Rosenberg, to the additional post of chairman, replacing the supermarket chain's founder, William Rosenberg, who will become chairman of the executive committee. It also named its chief operating officer, David G. Bronstein, to the additional post of president, and appointed Cornelius J. J. Madera and Gary S. Koppele senior vice presidents.

headline: SOVIET DISSIDENT TO STAY IN WEST
abstract: Irina Ratushinskaya, the Soviet dissident poet, met today with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The poet's husband said they would stay in the West.

headline: PRESIDENT IS CRITICAL OF 'LIBERALS' WHO MAY 'CHOP UP' 'STAR WARS'
abstract: President Reagan today accused what he called ''liberals'' in Congress of trying to ''chop up'' the space-based missile defense program and playing into the hands of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   The criticism was the first attempt by Mr. Reagan to use the Iceland meeting as a partisan issue in the election campaign. It came at a rally here for Linda Chavez, the Republican Senate candidate in Maryland,  [ Page B16. ]  In the meeting last weekend, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev reached tentative understandings on a wide range of arms issues, but the talks broke down over Soviet insistence that the American missile defense program be limited to research and testing within the laboratory for 10 years.

headline: WHY IS IRELAND SMILING? IT'S A FINE BOG HARVEST
abstract: A sudden splurge of autumn sunshine has eased the chill of two dismal harvests of cut turf - the primal fuel by which the morbid but merciful boglands of Ireland, sliced, dried and fed into the hearth, have warmed its hardiest souls into modern times.   After sodden weeks of summer that threatened thousands of layoffs in the nation's surprisingly high-tech turf processing industry, the clear weather needed by the cutters has permitted production to rebound.   Out toward Galway in the hallowed smaller bogs still used by farm families the harvest has been fruitful too. And a wanderer can see turf cutting tableaux worthy of Millet. The perennial Irish lyric asks: What more diversion can a man desire Than to sit him down by a snug turf fire? Upon his knee a tidy wench, Upon the table a jug of punch.

headline: MORE EMIGRES SEEK RETURN TO SOVIET
abstract: The Soviet Embassy here presented a dozen more emigres today who said they could not adjust to American society and were returning to the Soviet Union.   The session, at the Soviet Information Office, was the second in 10 days in which emigres, mostly Jews, said they were seeking repatriation.   Since 1971, 270,000 Jews have emigrated, with more than 90,000 settling in the United States and most of the others in Israel. Emigration from the Soviet Union is severely restricted for all, but many Jews and other minorities have been allowed to leave.

headline: Barnett Banks In Georgia Deal
abstract: Barnett Banks of Florida, in its first out-of-state acquisition, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy First City Bancorp of Marietta, Ga.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Recycling Trash
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Where, Oh, Where to Empty the Trash'' (Sept. 14) states that it costs some $70 to $120 a ton to burn trash. Odgen Martin Systems is currently operating two waste-to-energy plants and is building six others, at which the net cost to the communities will range from $15.43 to $59.16 a ton, as projected by several independent consulting engineering firms.   Waste-to-energy plants can be made pollution-free, and all of our facilities are in fact being constructed and operated under strict environmental permits and regulations.  LEWIS OTT WARD   Executive Vice President   Ogden Martin Systems Inc.   Paramus, N.J., Sept. 23

headline: PROTESTS RESUME AT JAPAN AIRPORT
abstract: Large sections of Tokyo and its eastern suburbs were under police siege today as farm families and radical supporters rallied here to protest plans to expand Japan's main international airport.   The demonstration was noisy but peaceful.   About 3,000 demonstrators, nearly all wearing helmets and covering their faces with masks and towels, gathered in a sweet-potato field and pledged to continue the two decades of resistance to the nearby Narita Airport and to recent proposals for new runways.   Speakers warned that they would wage a physical struggle against any expansion. ''We are going to have the hottest autumn and hottest winter in 20 years,'' a protest leader, Koji Kitahara, said.

headline: Capital Group Fills Post
abstract: Michael J. Johnston, who resigned in May as president of Paine Webber Capital Markets, the investment banking subsidiary of Paine Webber Group Inc., has joined Capital Group Inc., Capital Group said yesterday. He will be executive vice president in charge of fixed-income securities.

headline: MILITARY CONTRACTOR IS FINED $5.2 MILLION
abstract: C3 Inc., a small Virginia-based supplier of computer systems, agreed today to pay $5.2 million in fines to settle criminal and civil charges of fraudulent overcharges arising from a 1977 Army contract.   In addition, John G. Ballenger, C3's president and chairman, and John D. Vazzana, a director, will resign and agreed to have no role in the operation and management of the company for two years. Such an action is unusual but not unprecedented, and both men will remain as consultants to the board. There was no indication that the two men received any compensation for participating in the conspiracy.

headline: CALLS DEALS VITAL; Secret Dealings Have Made Use Of Complex Net
abstract: The secret movement of American military equipment to Iran over the last 18 months was accomplished through an international network of ships, planes, middlemen and companies, according to American and Israeli officials, participants and Iranian dissidents.   The operation, linked to the release of American hostages in Lebanon, involved the use of phony passports, travel under assumed names and flights from Israel and Europe by American and Israeli pilots, according to the sources.   A role has also been played by a Danish ship and Danish seamen, and by mysterious fronts, such as a now defunct Nigerian company based in Brussels. Three Shipments Are Known    Three shipments of military equipment to Iran have become known: plane deliveries in September 1985, and last July, and a shipload a few weeks ago. The three deliveries, believed to contain millions of dollars worth of military materiel, coincided with the release of American hostages.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 15, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: INTERNAL STRIFE STIRS IRAN TO RETHINK FOREIGN POLICY
