abstract: The war with Iraq and a desperate economic situation have intensified the internal turmoil in Iran, prompting Iranian leaders to rethink some aspects of foreign policy, according to diplomats and experts on Iran.   In addition, these experts say that some Iranian leaders may be questioning the wisdom of giving unlimited support to radical Islamic groups abroad, and that a campaign has been stepped up to discredit Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, the designated successsor to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian spiritual leader. Mr. Montazeri is a passionate promoter of exporting revolution.   ''Because of very low reserves in hard currency and gold, the regime is in a tight economic bind,'' said Shahrough Akhavi, professor of government at the University of South Carolina. ''Iran needs arms; it needs to sell its oil, and for these reasons it may be trying to project a better image abroad.''

headline: Advertising; Goodyear Pulls Back From Print
abstract: BECAUSE it does not have any specific new features to promote in its tires this year, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is resorting to emotional advertising. And that is bad news for 18 general-interest national magazines that have disappeared from the media advertising schedule. All that is left is television, network television.   The advertising, which will carry the theme line ''Goodyear, Take Me Home,'' will mark the first time that the worldwide company will speak with a worldwide voice. It is something Robert E. Mercer, its chairman and chief executive, has been urging for some time.

headline: Hughes Tool: Its Background
abstract: The Hughes Tool Company was the foundation of the fortune of Howard R. Hughes Jr. It was founded by his father, Howard R. Hughes Sr., to manufacture and lease the rotary bit used for drilling oil wells through rock that the senior Hughes had invented and patented in 1909.

headline: Gunmen on Malta Kill Opposition Backer
abstract: A supporter of Malta's opposition Nationalist Party has been killed by shots fired from a passing car, the police said.

headline: Ex-NBC Head In Gannett Venture
abstract: The Gannett Company, in a major expansion into television programming production, announced an agreement in principle to form a joint venture production company with Grant Tinker, former chairman of NBC Inc. The production company will produce television programming, but may also be involved in television movies, feature films and other types of programming. Mr. Tinker, who stepped down in August after five years as chairman of NBC, will head the company.   Mr. Tinker said in a statement that he would disclose in January the company's plans and the types of programming it would produce. Mr. Tinker could not be reached by telephone for comment late today, but John J. Curley, Gannett's president and chief executive, said that Mr. Tinker would be given a free hand to shape the company's projects.   Gannett, a media conglomerate that owns 93 newspapers and other print and broadcast properties, also said today that it had purchased Laird International Studios in Culver City, Calif. for $24 million and would house the new company there.

headline: PATENTS; Electrical Birth Control
abstract: A BIRTH-CONTROL device that employs an electrical field was patented this week.

headline: TIME INC. NET SOARED IN 3D QUARTER
abstract: Time Inc. said yesterday that net income in the third quarter rose sharply, to $252 million, or $3.98 a share, from $44 million, or 70 cents a share, last year. Revenue jumped 7.9 percent, to $914 million, from $847 million last year.   The big publishing and broadcasting company attributed the sharp increase to a pretax gain of $352 million, which was partly offset by a special charge of $50 million.

headline: PROGRESS REPORTED ON MARCOS'S SWISS MONEY
abstract: The head of a Philippine Government commission seeking to recover money once held by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos says the commission is about midway in its efforts to arrange the return to Manila of money believed held in a number of Swiss banks.   The chairman of the Presidential Commission for Good Government, Jovito R. Salonga, made the comment Wednesday after meeting with three Swiss lawyers hired by the Philippine Government this year to try to find the money, which is estimated to total about $2 billion. Mr. Salonga said most of the money remained in Swiss banks, where its removal was blocked by the Swiss Government in March.   The Philippine Government has charged that the money represents ill-gotten gains and is a legacy of official corruption within the Marcos Government before it was toppled in February. Mr. Marcos, who now lives in exile in Hawaii, refused to answer questions from Philippine Government attorneys inquiring about the funds.

headline: New Sperry Model
abstract: The Sperry Corporation, which has merged into the Burroughs Corporation, yesterday introduced a new mainframe computer that runs high-level software at a lower price and performance level. Sperry said the new computer, dubbed 2200/200, is compatible with all existing Sperry 1100 systems, but is much smaller, uses less power and allows users to run a large number of applications in a mixed processing environment.

headline: Recliner-Chair Maker Picks Bozell, Jacobs
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has landed an account of a rather restful nature, even though the client's name is Action Industries.

headline: Coopervision To Sell Unit
abstract: Coopervision Inc., an eye care company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said today that it had agreed to sell its ophthalmic pharmaceutical products business to Johnson & Johnson for about $260 million. The unit had net sales of about $55 million in the fiscal year 1986.

headline: How Arbitrage Is Practiced
abstract: Arbitrage, a legal and sophisticated method of investment, has been practiced for years.   In its traditional form, it involves little risk to the investor.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Chase Manhattan Picks Chief Financial Officer
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted its controller, Michael P. Esposito Jr., to chief financial officer.   Mr. Esposito, 47, will move into the position Jan. 1 and Lester J. Stephens, a senior vice president, will succeed Mr. Esposito as controller. Mr. Stephens has been the executive in charge of planning, product and financial management for international banking.

headline: DATA BANK: NOVEMBER 9, 1986
abstract: THE ECONOMY Gross National ProductIII Q'86II Q'86Year Ago In billions, annual rate$3,683.3$3,661.4$3,603.8 Real G.N.P. headline: U.S. IN NEW APPEAL; PRESIDENT HOPEFUL
abstract: President Reagan appealed to the Soviet Union today ''not to miss the opportunity'' for a major breakthrough on reducing nuclear weapons, saying such an agreement was ''within our grasp.''   The statement by Mr. Reagan marked the second straight day he has made such an appeal, and it came as he and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, engaged in a public competition to promote their own interpretations of the outcome of the meeting in Iceland.   Mr. Reagan and other Administration officials undertook a major campaign to explain Mr. Reagan's decision to refuse to accept restraints on the development of a strategic defense system against nuclear weapons. Intermediate-Range Arms    The White House also began an effort today to salvage something from the Iceland meeting by asserting that the issue of intermediate range missiles had been effectively resolved in Reykjavik despite the absence of a formal agreement.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: ''For us this is not a festival. Because the Hungarian experience of 30 years ago includes bitter memories, we lower our flags modestly when we mark the day, and we do not make it a holiday.''

headline: THE OUTLOOK FOR AMERICAN PRODUCERS; San Francisco
abstract: In the San Francisco and Silicon Valley region, manufacturers give mixed reports on the condition of their foreign markets. Although semiconductor makers are struggling amid a prolonged industrywide slump, companies that manufacture microcomputers, mainframes and related products report healthy growth and strong sales of products tailored for overseas markets.

headline: Imasco Unit Sold
abstract: Imasco Ltd. said it had sold Genstar Rental Electronics Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., for about $63 million to a company formed by the president of Genstar Rental, William D. Rollnick. Genstar Rental rents electronic test and measurement equipment to a variety of industries, Imasco said.

headline: A SCHOOL GETS UNLIKELY VISIT BY A RUSSIAN
abstract: An unlikely visitor toured a Hebrew day school on Manhattan's East Side last week.   The visitor was Konstantin M. Kharchev, chairman of the Soviet Government's Council of Religious Affairs, which supervises organized religion.   The Park East Day School is the kind of religious school that by law is not allowed in the Soviet Union. But Mr. Karchev saw an elementary-school classroom where children are taught to celebrate Sabbath eve, where a ''father'' blesses the wine and a ''mother'' blesses the flaming candles. He even joined in Israeli dances with 30 youngsters, kicking his legs up, chuckling with pleasure and hugging students.

headline: U.S. WEAPONS BEGIN TO REACH CHAD
abstract: This listless town seemed to shake today as an American cargo plane touched down with the first shipment of United States military equipment since Libya began an offensive in northern Chad.   The shipment arrived as Chadian Government officials announced that Libyan warplanes, flying during a break in desert sandstorms, repeatedly bombed Chadian guerrillas today.   Ahmed Moussa-Mi, chief of staff to President Hissen Habre, asserted that in addition to conventional bombing, Libyan forces had dropped napalm and poison gas near Zouar. The report could not be verified.

headline: AUSTRIA'S 2 BIG PARTIES SET BACK IN VOTE
abstract: Voters handed a major setback today to Austria's two largest parties, while a small nationalist party that recently moved sharply to the right achieved stunning gains.   The environmentalist Green movement also entered Parliament for the first time. It was the first time a fourth party has been in the Austrian legislature since the tiny Austrian Communist Party was voted out in 1959.   The Socialist Party of Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, despite a widespread loss of support in working-class areas of Vienna and Upper Austria, clung to its position as the strongest party in Parliament.

headline: REPUBLICBANK'S MARKET VALUE DROPS OVER MERGER
abstract: The Republicbank Corporation of Dallas lost more than one-tenth of its market value yesterday as investors expressed concern over how its proposed merger with another Texas banking giant, the Interfirst Corporation, would affect Republicbank's prospects immediately and long term.   Republic's stock closed at $19, down $2.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Interfirst finished at $4.85, down 12.5 cents.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * A.H. Belo Corp. is offering $100 million of Baa-2/BBB rated 8 5/8 percent notes due 1996 at 99.50, to yield 8.70 percent, through Salomon Brothers. Noncallable for seven years, the notes yield 1.63 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Terms Set for British Gas
abstract: Britain's Conservative Government took its boldest step yet in reducing the role of the state in Britain's postwar industrial economy when it announced the terms under which it would sell British Gas to the public. About 4 billion shares in the state-owned gas monopoly are being offered at $:1.35, or $1.91, each.

headline: Counting Money
abstract: To the Editor:   You assert that Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf is ''The Wealthiest Woman in America'' (Oct. 26).

headline: Washington Watch; New Study of World Bank
abstract: Some big operational changes could be coming at the World Bank. Barber Conable Jr., the bank's new president, has sent a notice to all employees alerting them to a sweeping internal review to be done with the help of an outside management consultant, Cresap, McCormick & Paget.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * May Department Stores is offering $150 million of Aa-3/AAF rated 9 1/8 percent debentures due in 2016 at 100 through Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yesterday's Closings
abstract: All stock exchanges, most commodity markets and banks and some businesses were open yesterday. But Federal offices and the   New York Mercantile Exchange, New York Cotton Exchange, New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and New York Commodity Exchange were closed.   Because of the holiday closings, the Federal Reserve Board will release its weekly money supply report Monday.

headline: 5 Injured in Pakistan Rioting
abstract: At least five people were injured today in rioting that flared in Karachi immediately after the authorities lifted a curfew. The police said 14 people were arrested after Pathans from North West Frontier Province threw stones at Mohajir immigrants leaving for work in the city's Orangi suburb early today.

headline: Wometco Sale Is Expected
abstract: The sale of the Wometco Broadcasting Company for a price slightly more than $600 million is expected to be announced as early as today, according to a source familiar with the negotiations.   Wometco is a major cable operator, with 348,000 subscribers.

headline: Real Estate; El Barrio Market's Renewal
abstract: FIFTY years ago Mayor La Guardia put a marketplace underneath the Park Avenue elevated train tracks between 111th and 116th streets. The purpose was to clear congested streets of pushcart vendors and to provide clean spaces for small neighborhood businesses.   For decades the city-owned marketplace thrived, especially during the 40's and 50's as the largely Italian East Harlem neighborhood evolved into a Hispanic community known as El Barrio. But in the last 20 years, La Marqueta, as the market is known, lost vendors as the neighborhood declined. Today fewer than 50 merchants operate in a third of the enclosed market's space.

headline: CUTBACKS SET FOR 1987
abstract: Faced with declining profit margins and prospective price cuts by A.T.&T., the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would write down the value of older equipment by $500 million to $700 million pretax in the fourth quarter.   MCI, the second-largest long-distance carrier, also said it would reduce capital spending next year to less than $800 million, from its previously planned $900 million, and consolidate operations in its eight divisions around the nation. Layoffs Planned    The consolidation will lead to an unspecified number of layoffs at the Washington-based company, which has grown in 20 years from the upstart that broke the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance monopoly into a multinational with 16,000 employees and nearly five million customers.   ''We can't say how big the cutback will be, but I'm sure we will end the year with more people than we had at the beginning,'' said Howard C. Crane, senior vice president in charge of corporate affairs, noting that the company had 13,000 employees in January.

headline: Ethan Allen
abstract: Ethan Allen Furniture announced yesterday that it had selected Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos as the agency to handle its broadcast advertising, which should bill between $5 million and $10 million. According to the agency, the business was formerly handled in-house. Ethan Allen did name Gilbert Sandler & Associates to the account in June 1984.

headline: BUMPER CROP OF BRAND NAMES
abstract: To most consumers, Sunkist means oranges, Chiquita means bananas and Dole means pineapples.   But what company stands for the tomato, the carrot or the green pepper? Except for a handful of widely known brand names, the nation's produce sections are teeming with fresh fruits and vegetables of uncertain lineage.   That may be about to change, however. Some of the largest food companies - Campbell Soup, Kraft, Pillsbury, Dole, Del Monte and others -are seeking to enter or expand their presence in the fresh produce business with a host of new brand names.   Within a few years, food companies hope, the brands could account for 10 percent or more of total annual produce sales of $20 billion and in the long run could go much higher.

headline: RETIRED GENERAL SAID TO BE BEHIND CONTRA FLIGHTS
abstract: An American who was a pilot on secret supply flights to Nicaraguan guerrillas says the chief pilot for the flights told him ''several times'' that a retired general, Richard V. Secord, was ''behind the operation.''   In addition to the Secord report, telephone records for ''safe houses'' in El Salvador used by Nicaraguan rebels, or contras, list calls to what appears to be the home an United States Embassy employee in Costa Rica.   An embassy spokesman said the employee could not be named ''for security reasons.'' It is against the law to print the name of an American intelligence agent.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Gannett Co. filed a shelf registration for up to $750 million of debt securities through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.    * Midland Bank is issuing 500 million francs of 10-year bonds at a price of 98.78.

headline: Tisch's Regimen Built Trimmer CBS
abstract: After just three months at the helm of CBS Inc., Laurence A. Tisch has made change commonplace at the once-unshakable network. Cost cutting has become routine, layoffs are the norm and entire departments have been eliminated.   Mr. Tisch, 63 years old, and his brother Preston Robert Tisch, 60, who is the United States Postmaster General, are major stockholders in the Loews Corporation, a diversified conglomerate that owns 24.9 percent of CBS shares. Laurence Tisch, along with the network's founder, William S. Paley, ousted Thomas H. Wyman as chairman and chief executive in September.

headline: REBELS IN BURMA SAY RANGOON USES HERBICIDE AGAINST THEM
abstract: The Burmese Government, under a new opium eradication program, is spraying the crops and villages of a rebellious ethnic minority with an American-supplied herbicide linked to cancer in the United States, according to the rebels.   The herbicide compound is 2,4-D, which was widely used as a weedkiller until findings on its dangers began to raise concern among American consumer groups, the lawn products industry and the Environmental Protection Agency. American officials say that they have supplied the chemical to Burma, but that it does not pose permanent dangers to people or cropland.

headline: Revere Takes $203 Million Bid
abstract: Revere Copper and Brass Inc., the maker of aluminum and brass products that traces its roots back to the American patriot Paul Revere, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by an investment group for $203 million.   The company, whose copper-bottomed pots and pans have been a fixture in American homes for generations, agreed to a $22.50-a-share bid from the JOZ I Corporation and the JOZ II Corporation.

headline: PRESIDENT ADMITS FLAWS IN PURSUING SECRET IRAN POLICY
abstract: President Reagan, adopting a highly personal and apologetic tone, said today that the execution of his secret policy initiatives toward Iran was ''flawed,'' and that ''mistakes were made.''   The remarks by the President, made in his weekly radio address, marked a clear shift away from the defiant stand he had previously adopted in the face of continuing public and Congressional criticism.   Mr. Reagan did not abandon his repeated refusals to call the Iran policy a mistake, and he continued to express belief that the secret diplomatic initiative was proper. At the same time, he did not specify how the execution had been flawed, or who was responsible.

headline: New World Offers Sinking-Fund Issue
abstract: New World Pictures Ltd. is offering $215 million of speculative-grade sinking-fund debentures through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

headline: C.I.A. DIRECTOR LISTED AS STABLE BY HOSPITAL
abstract: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, spent a comfortable day at Georgetown University Hospital and remains in stable condition there, a Central Intelligence Agency spokesman said today.

headline: Letters to French Leaders
abstract: Before his departure, Mr. Bokassa sent letters to President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac announcing his return to his ''country of origin.''   The letters, which were written on stationery marked ''palace of the Central African Republic'' - apparently referring to the 18th-century castle near Paris where he lived - said.

headline: PRESIDENT APPOINTED AT RESEARCH VENTURE
abstract: Steven Lazarus, group vice president of health care services at Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., has been named president and chief executive of the new Argonne National Laboratory/University of Chicago Development Corporation.   Mr. Lazarus, a New York native, will be responsible for developing business uses for scientific discoveries made at Argonne and the university. Mr. Lazarus was also named associate dean of the university's Graduate School of Business so that he could use its facilities to aid the venture, the first of its kind.   ''The three-pronged approach of Argonne, the business school and university's own labs is very unique,'' Mr. Lazarus said in an interview. ''But the business school, that will be the catalyst in making this work.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1986
abstract: The Economy     The nation's trade gap declined for a third straight month, falling $500 million in October, to $12.06 billion, the lowest level since August 1985, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said the figures represented evidence of a turnaround in the deficit. On the negative side, the deficit with Japan rose.  [ Page A1. ]    Navy Secretary Lehman was censured by Defense Secretary Weinberger and his Inspector General for putting pressure on a contractor to stop an executive from criticizing the Pentagon.  [ D1. ]

headline: 'A Lawyer's Lawyer' To Watch Boesky Firm
abstract: Gerald F. Rath, the Boston lawyer chosen by the Securities and Exchange Commission to be special compliance agent for the Ivan F. Boesky Company, was described by a colleague yesterday as ''a lawyer's lawThe colleague, David Boch, went on to describe Mr. Rath as ''a person who demands high-quality work, who pays great attention to detail, who thinks quickly on his feet and is pretty articulate.''   Mr. Rath, 41, is a member of the Boston law firm of Bingham, Dana & Gould, where he is associated with Mr. Boch. Both men came to work for the firm in March after the firm where they previously worked, Herrick & Smith, was dissolved.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ORDERS THE REMOVAL OF 10,000 BLACKS TO NEW SITE
abstract: The South African authorities, apparently tightening again its recently relaxed policy on forced removal of blacks, announced the closing of a black township today and said the 10,000 residents would have to move to a new site 15 miles away.   A protest group in the township, near Brits, north of Pretoria, said the Government action would be contested ''even if it means violence.''   ''We are going to challenge Heunis all the way,'' Sello Ramakobye of the Brits Action Committee said at a news conference, referring to Chris Heunis, the Minister of Constitutional Development and Planning.

headline: DANISH SEAMEN'S UNION TELLS OF ARMS SHIPMENTS
abstract: A global watch on shipments of arms to the Persian Gulf indicated last spring that ''many thousands of tons'' in increased American-made weapons were quietly being sent to Iran, an executive of the Danish Seamen's Union said today.   ''This was far beyond the normal shipments from arms dealers and smugglers, and I would say you cannot have those amounts being shipped without the government of the producing country being aware,'' Henrik Berlau, vice president of the union, asserted.   The union, which tries to track the use of merchant ships in international arms traffic, has no documentary proof of official American involvement, Mr. Berlau stressed. He conceded that private dealers, not governments, traditionally engage in the lucrative weapons trade.

headline: The Clockwork Heart Of London Skips Beat
abstract: Big Ben missed a chime today, and for Londoners it was like skipping a heartbeat.   At 6:45 A.M., when the famous clock above the Houses of Parliament should have been pealing out a melodious ding-dong-ding-dong, it left out the second ding.   Alarmed clock specialists hurried to the belfry and found that a 128-year-old rod had snapped on the bell that plays the note E in the sequence of G sharp, F sharp, E and C. The rod was fixed with a temporary bolt, and at 9:30 A.M. Big Ben was back to normal.

headline: Reviving Manhattan Ladies Mile
abstract: LADIES MILE is the name given an irregular retail strip that extended from 14th to 23d Streets in Manhattan and had its economic heyday between the turn of the century and World War I. On a stretch of the shopping route that ran along Sixth Avenue between 18th and 23d Streets such major retailers of the day as Siegel-Cooper, B. Altman, Adams Dry Goods and Hugh O'Neill built huge, ornate department stores to serve the city's emerging upper-middle class.   Although it has been more than 60 years since these Sixth Avenue retail giants closed their doors for good or followed the migration uptown, most of the ornate structures that housed them have survived.   Over the years, they were turned into light manufacturing spaces or other types of commerical lofts. Now some of the old department stores along that part of Sixth Avenue, which sits at the eastern edge of Chelsea, are being renovated and restored. Among them are the former Adams Dry Goods store at 675 Sixth Avenue, between 21st and 22d Streets, and the building at 625 Sixth Avenue, between 18th and 19th Streets.

headline: Full Selection of Treasury Bills Due
abstract: Treasury financing this week includes new bill issues due in 3, 6 and 12 months, as well as two-year notes. Also, dealers in Government securities expect the Treasury to announce plans this week for a five-year note auction Nov. 26 of about $8.25 billion.   In advance of today's regular weekly bill auction, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 5.38 percent, while the six-month issue was 5.45 percent. Prior to Thursday's sale of new one-year bills, the outstanding one-year issue was bid at 5.52 percent.

headline: F.C.C. DROPS A RESTRICTION AGAINST BELL CONCERNS
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today dropped its rule requiring the Bell telephone companies to use separate companies to sell telephone equipment.   The regulatory panel said that the costs to the companies of the rule ''are high'' and that the public interest would be ''served better'' by granting the companies flexibiity in this line of business.   The practical effect of the decision, made in a 5-to-0 vote, is that telephone customers will again be able to order telephone equipment when they order new service.

headline: Sri Lanka and India To Talk on Rebellion
abstract: President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India will hold talks in the southern Indian city of Bangalore on Saturday to see if they can persuade Tamil separatists fighting for an independent state in Sri Lanka to negotiate an end to the conflict.   Mr. Jayewardene and Mr. Gandhi will meet before the start of a two-day meeting of leaders of seven southern Asian countries.

headline: Getting Even With Ivan
abstract: If you sold stock to Ivan F. Boesky when he knew something that you did not, you could collect restitution from a $50 million damage fund that the Securities and Exchange Commission is creating from Mr. Boesky's ill-gotten gains. But just how that will work is anyone's guess, analysts say.

headline: NEW WEAPONS IN DIAPER WAR
abstract: The great diaper war will never make the history books. But in the continuing battle for the $3 billion disposable diaper market the momentum has always gone to the marketing giant that has come up with the latest innovation.   Sometimes Procter & Gamble has tightened the grip it has had on the market since introducing Pampers 25 years ago, and sometimes Kimberly-Clark's innovations have eaten into P.&G.'s share.   The contest is one in which the rules have changed rapidly: from the shape of the diapers to the sophistication of the machines that make them. And each innovation has made life much happier for moms and dads who change more diapers than they can count.

headline: Interpublic Group Posts 18.3% Rise in Earnings
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported yesterday that net income for the third quarter rose more than 18.3 percent, to $3.95 million, from $3.34 million in the comparable period last year. Its earnings per share rose to 18 cents, from 15 cents, and were restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split earlier this year.   Revenues for the quarter increased to $190.7 million from $156.2 million in 1985.

headline: 2 Cable Cars Fall From Pylon At French Resort, Injuring 36
abstract: A pylon snapped at this Alpine ski resort today, sending two cable cars crashing 40 feet down onto a parking lot and injuring 36 people, 12 seriously, officials said.   ''People were screaming with fear and pain,'' a witness said.

headline: TEXT OF AQUINO'S SPEECH
abstract: Following is the text of President Corazon C. Aquino's announcement today on national television that she was dismissing Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and asking the rest of her Cabinet to resign:   Of late, my circumspection has been viewed as weakness, and my sincere attempts at reconciliation as indecision. This cannot continue. It is clear that the extreme left has no interest in the peace I have continually offered. I have, therefore, given the Government negotiating panel until the end of the month to produce a cease-fire or terminate all further negotiation.

headline: U.S. Aide Urges Seoul To Compromise on Crisis
abstract: A senior United States official said today that he had urged the South Korean Government and the opposition to negotiate a compromise to resolve the political crisis and that he remained optimistic about a peaceful solution.   The official, Assistant Secretary of State Gaston J. Sigur Jr., said at a news conference, ''I have said here that the way to achieve the successful movement toward democracy in this country is through negotiation and compromise.''

headline: MANAGUA HOLDS A PARADE TO SHOW ITS RESOLVE
abstract: For the first time in recent years, the Sandinista Government staged a full-scale military parade today to show off its troops and weapons.   As a large crowd watched, Soviet-built tanks, armored vehicles and artillery pieces passed by a reviewing stand occupied by all nine members of the Sandinista National Directorate.   Diplomats and Government officials said the parade was intended to demonstrate that Nicaragua is equipped to confront an expected widening of warfare here. Congress recently appropriated $100 million to support anti-Sandinista rebel groups.

headline: Chairman to Retire At Lord & Taylor
abstract: Just days after the acquisition of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation by the May Department Stores Company, Joseph E. Brooks announced yesterday that he would retire on Jan. 3 as chairman and chief executive of Associated's Lord & Taylor division.   ''For many years I expected to be the C.E.O. of A.D.G.,'' said Mr. Brooks, who is 58 years old. ''There is no A.D.G. That was a very important thing to me. Keep in mind, as a member of the board of directors of A.D.G. I voted for the merger. I felt it was right to do.

headline: SEOUL FIGHTS BLOW TO ITS CREDIBILITY
abstract: The South Korean Government began a campaign today to repair a serious blow to its credibility at home and abroad over its erroneous reports of the death of Kim Il Sung.   The reports this week that the North Korean leader had been assassinated formed one of the stranger episodes in many years on a divided, heavily armed and potentially explosive peninsula that is a veteran of strange incidents.   It was South Korea that had spread most of the false reports, pouring out ample details of announcements from North Korean border loudspeakers that Mr. Kim, the North's leader since 1948, had been assassinated and his son, Kim Jong Il, elevated in his place.   The argument pursued by the authorities was that they had fallen prey to some sort of North Korean hoax. Its purpose, Prime Minister Lho Shin Yong told the National Assembly today, was to tarnish ''our international image one way or another, and estrange the people from the Government.''

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''If you affirm the N.Y.S.E. request, it will be a blot upon the escutcheon of corporate democracy and the S.E.C.''  Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum warning against a Big Board plan to list companies with different classes of stock.

headline: ISRAELI ASSURED THE U.S. ON CAPTIVES, AIDES SAY
abstract: A high-ranking Israeli official won President Reagan's approval to ship 500 antitank missiles to Iran in 1985 by telling him that Israel believed the action would lead to the freeing of all the Americans then held hostage in Lebanon, American and Israeli sources said today.   The sources - current and former officials from the two Governments -made this point in describing conversations in July and August 1985 between David Kimche, the director of Israel's Foreign Ministry, and Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser. Both Mr. Kimche and Mr. McFarlane are no longer in office.   The sources said the possibility of all the hostages being freed - seven were then being held - was particularly appealing to Mr. Reagan. Concern About Buckley    In particular, the American and Israeli sources said, Washington was very concerned about William Buckley, the station chief for the Central Intelligence Agency in Beirut, who had been kidnapped on March 16, 1984.

headline: New Jardine Holding Unit
abstract: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd. said its Hongkong Land Company unit would spin off its Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group and contribute its remaining interest in Jardine to a new investment company.   The new company, Hongkong Investors Ltd., would be merged with Jardine Securities Ltd. to form Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd., Jardine Matheson said.

headline: NICARAGUA FORMALLY ACCUSES U.S. OF ROLE IN SUPPLY FLIGHT TO REBELS
abstract: The Nicaraguan Government formally accused the Reagan Administration today of sponsoring a rebel supply plane downed here and demanded an end to all American support for attacks in Nicaragua.   The accusations were made in a formal diplomatic protest that Nicaraguan officials said was sent to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today. An American Embassy spokesman said the embassy had not seen or received the Nicaraguan protest.   Noting that one American had been captured and two others killed when Nicaraguan troops shot down the rebel supply plane last Sunday, the protest note asked the United States ''to obey the sentence of the International Court of Justice and end military and paramilitary activities in Nicaragua and against Nicaragua.''

headline: A MULLAH'S RELATIVE CONFESSES TO MURDER AND HOARDING ARMS
abstract: A relative of the designated successor to the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini confessed to murder, hoarding weapons and collaborating with the Shah's secret police, the Teheran radio said today.   The relative, Mehdi Hashemi, said the base for his activities was the office of Hussein Ali Montazeri, an ayatollah and the 86-year-old Ayatollah Khomeini's hand-picked successor.

headline: MOSCOW SEES A GOOD EXAMPLE IN A BIG MAC
abstract: Television today showed a flattering portrait of a McDonald's restaurant, and the commentator said, ''Maybe there is something we can learn from this.''   Soviet viewers were shown hamburgers sizzling on the grill of a McDonald's on Fifth Avenue near the Empire State Building in New York, as the staff hustled behind the counter to fill orders for Big Macs.

headline: AMERICAN IS JAILED IN YUGOSLAV TRIAL
abstract: An American citizen of Yugoslav origin was sentenced to seven years in prison today by a district court in the republic of Montenegro for activities against the state.   The man, Peter Ivezaj, 30 years old, emigrated to the United States in 1972. He had been teaching high school in Sterling Heights, Mich.

headline: Ouster of Yamani May Placate OPEC
abstract: Saudi Arabia replaced its very visible oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, in a surprise move that created turmoil in world oil markets. As OPEC squabbled over ways to get prices back up, Sheik Yamani was often the moderating voice. But now many OPEC members want to return to fixed prices, rather than production quotas, and Sheik Yamani had been perceived by some as an impediment. Saudi Arabia gave no reason for the Sheik's dismissal after 24 years, but many analysts believe the kingdom was under pressure from other OPEC members - particularly Iran, which needs higher oil revenues to finance its war with Iraq.   The Saudis called for an emergency meeting of OPEC's price committee, where the acting Saudi minister, Hisham Nazer, is expected to push for prices of at least $18 a barrel. But despite a surge in oil prices immediately after the dismissal, analysts say it will be awhile before any concrete action can take effect.

headline: CHIRAC REMARKS ON EL AL PLOT IRK ISRAEL
abstract: A controversy has arisen over an American press report in which Prime Minister Jacques Chirac is quoted as saying senior West German officials believe Israel masterminded a terrorist plot in London in April.   In the report, which appears in today's issue of The Washington Times, Mr. Chirac says in an interview that both the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher did not believe in Syrian involvement in the incident, which led Britain to break diplomatic relations with Syria last month.   Mr. Chirac, the newspaper said, told an interviewer of the West German belief that the plot to blow up an El Al Israel Airlines passenger plane was a fake, carried out by the Israelis in conjunction with ''renegades'' in the Syrian secret services who wanted to embarrass the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad.   Israeli officials said they were ''staggered'' by the remarks attributed to Mr. Chirac.

headline: Farmers Take Protest To Palace in Manila
abstract: More than 23,000 farmers marched on the presidential palace today in the largest leftist protest against President Corazon C. Aquino's Government.

headline: Orange Julius Plan By Reuters
abstract: Orange Julius International Inc. said its board had approved a plan to restructure the company by disposing of all operations except its Orange Julius drink and fast-food franchise businesses.

headline: SPEECHES AT U.N. DEAL WITH APARTHEID AND THE AFRICAN DEBT
abstract: Representatives of six African nations addressed the United Nations General Assembly today on apartheid and the continent's external debt crisis. The Foreign Ministers of Honduras and the Solomon Islands also spoke.   The Foreign Minister of Mauritius, Sir Satcam Boolell, hailed the General Assembly for having held a special session on Africa's economic crisis. He said that in the special session, both developed and developing countries, for the first time, ''committed themselves to cooperate in a spirit of genuine and equal partnership.''

headline: 13 Reported Dead In Pakistan Air Crash
abstract: A Pakistan International Airways plane on a domestic flight crashed today near Peshawar in northwest Pakistan, killing at least 13 people and injuring 26, an airline spokesman said.

headline: Newmont Official Plans for Spinoff
abstract: David C. Ridinger, a mining executive, will soon be leaving his New York office for good for the copper-mining regions of Arizona, if a spinoff plan goes through as scheduled.   Mr. Ridinger works for the Newmont Mining Corporation, which has decided to leave the bulk of its copper operations behind for new opportunities. Its Magma Copper Company, of which Mr. Ridinger is president and chief executive, will be spun off to shareholders and Mr. Ridinger will continue to run it as an independent company.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''Let us remember that growth is the key to repaying debt while fulfilling the dreams of the people.''   President Reagan, addressing joint meeting of World Bank and I.M.F.

headline: RENAULT CHIEF: A FIX-IT SPECIALIST
abstract: Georges Besse, president of the state-run automobile maker Renault, was known throughout French industry as a plain-spoken man with a knack for turning around failing companies.   Indeed, Mr. Besse commented in a recent interview that his greatest challenge, restoring the luster to Renault, France's largest manufacturing company, was finally within reach.   Mr. Besse, 58 years old, who was shot and killed near his home in Paris yesterday, slashed Renault's losses in half - they are projected at $850 million this year - by selling off nonessential assets and pushing through a plan to lay off some 21,000 workers, breaking a strike by the powerful Communist-led labor union in the process.

headline: Reebok Agency Race
abstract: Reebok International, Canton, Mass., one of the world's leading manufactuers of athletic footwear, is going to stage an agency race with a $10 million media budget at the finish line.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.458 percent, up from 6.13 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.096 percent, up from 5.96 percent.    * Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering 6.1 percent interest on $701 million of bonds due on April 1, 1987, and $1.15 billion of bonds due July 1, 1987, through various securities dealers.

headline: CHINA TAXING THE RICH
abstract: China announced a new tax on its richest citizens today in an attempt to prevent wide disparity in earnings. The official New China News Agency said more people were earning extra income because economic reforms allowed a bit of free enterprise, straining the supply of goods.

headline: 2 Chinese Counseling On China
abstract: SAMUEL WHITE and Donald G. Heller, veteran packaged goods marketers who served, respectively, at the Liggett Group and Chesebrough-Pond's, are playing modern Marco Polos these days with the help of a very special couple, the P'ans of Old Greenwich, Conn.   Albert Y. P'an and his wife, Virginia, a Chinese couple with a firm foundation in American business and an education to match, run the Transcapital Group, which they characterize as ''business development professionals for China and Asia.'' He is chairman, she president.   They have their offices in the Pan Am Building, which is unrelated.

headline: SIKHS FIRE AT TOP POLICEMAN IN PUNJAB By STEVEN R. WEISMAN
abstract: In the second major Indian security breach in two days, Sikh extremists slipped into a heavily guarded police compound in Punjab today and fired shots at the top police official in the state.   In a related development, the police here raised the strong possibility today that, contrary to earlier reports, the gunman who shot at Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on Thursday was a Sikh.   In the attack this morning, the Punjab police director, Julius F. Rebeiro, escaped unharmed, but his wife was wounded and a police guard was killed.   Officials were shaken that the extremists were able to get into the compound disguised as policemen and may have had police assistance in planning the attack. All six attackers escaped.

headline: GOODYEAR OFFER BEGINS
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company began a tender offer today for up to 40 million of its common shares at $50 each in a previously announced plan to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the financier Sir James Goldsmith.

headline: G.M. WORKERS IN SOUTH AFRICA GO OUT ON STRIKE
abstract: Employees of the General Motors Corporation in South Africa went on strike today, seeking a greater say in company affairs once the unit is sold to South African interests.   The strike was called by the National Automobile and Allied Workers Union, which represents 1,600 of G.M.'s 3,000 workers in South Africa. The strike was joined by members of the Motor Assembly and Component Workers of South Africa, effectively shutting down G.M.'s production in the coastal city of Port Elizabeth.

headline: World Paper to Appear In China, Its 23d Nation
abstract: World Paper, a monthly founded in 1978 in Boston to give an international perspective to global news, will soon be published in its 23d country, China.   Beginning in January, the 16-page publication will begin to appear as an insert in China and the World, a magazine published by the New China News Agency.

headline: Detained Western Reporter Being Expelled, Zambia Says
abstract: The Zambian Government said today that it was deporting a correspondent for The Associated Press, John Edlin, on immigration charges, but that the proceedings had bogged down in paperwork, the reporter's lawyer said.   The lawyer, Solly Patel, said in a telephone conversation from Lusaka, Zambia, that immigration officials told him this morning that they had begun procedures to expel Mr. Edlin, but that the paperwork was not finished and ''may take a while.''

headline: Seoul Lets Currency Inch Up
abstract: The changes so far have been small, but after years of steady devaluation South Korea is allowing its currency, the won, to rise against the dollar.   South Korea says that it bases exchange rates on a trade-weighted ''basket of currencies.'' In practice, the dollar's worth is what counts.   No one here expects that any resulting increase in Korean export prices will put more than a minor dent in the country's surging trade surplus with the United States. Still, Government officials hope that even mild currency adjustments can deflect American irritation about the exchange rate before it turns to full-blown anger.

headline: P.&G. NET CLIMBS 9.2%
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that its net income in its first fiscal quarter of 1987, which ended Sept. 30, rose 9.2 percent, aided by the addition of the results of Richardson-Vicks Inc., which was acquired in November 1985.   Procter & Gamble, a leading manufacturer of household and personal-care products, said that net income in the latest three months rose to $273 million, or $1.61 a share, from $250 million, or $1.49 a share, a year earlier.

headline: Purolator Courier
abstract: The Purolator Courier Corporation announced that it had directed its adviser, Dillon, Read & Company, to study offers from potential purchasers for its United States and Canadian filter manufacturing operations.

headline: American Express
abstract: The American Express Company said that a subsidiary had signed an agreement to sell the stock of the Fireman's Fund Employers Insurance Company of Green Bay, Wis., to the Lincoln National Corporation for $215 million.

headline: Wide Range Of Strategies Emerging
abstract: WITH the Tax Reform Act of 1986 now officially law, the race has begun by investors to adjust their financial affairs to the new rules of the game and take advantage of some year-end opportunities created by the transition from the old to the new system.   In some eyes, the next several weeks present the best of both worlds: A chance to take one last shot at some tax benefits of the old law that will pass into extinction on Jan. 1 and a chance to defer income into next year or the year after, when tax rates are lower.   Tax lawyers and accountants have been advising their clients to consider a whole range of ideas, such as unloading stocks, investment real estate and other assets that have appreciated sharply in value before favorable capital-gains treatment comes to an end on Jan. 1. Tax practioners are also recommending that people take maximum advantage this year of retirement plan deductions, such as for contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts and 401(k) employee plans, before they come under tighter restrictions next year.

headline: REAGAN TO STICK TO ARMS POLICY, OFFICIAL REPORTS
abstract: President Reagan plans to hold firm to his positions in the Geneva arms talks and does not plan to introduce new proposals at his meeting this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to an Administration official.   The official said the Administration planned to exceed the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty on Nov. 11, before an expected regular summit meeting in the United States.   These plans are likely to change only if there is a ''dramatic change'' in Soviet positions, the official said. Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan will meet Saturday and Sunday in Reykjavik, Iceland, and will spend six to seven hours together over the two days.   The American stand on arms control, affirmed a day after Mr. Reagan met with his advisers and decided to hold firm, suggests that considerable differences with the Soviet Union remain.

headline: Israeli Technician Gets Hearing in Treason Case
abstract: A former nuclear technician charged with treason for revealing Israel's atomic secrets was seen in public today for the first time since his disappearance from London two months ago and his arrest.   The defendant, Mordechai Vanunu, 32 years old, was brought to a Jerusalem district court under heavy guard for a closed, 50-minute pretrial hearing.

headline: IRAQ GETS REPORTS FROM U.S. FOR USE IN WAR WITH IRAN
abstract: Over the last two years, the United States has periodically supplied Iraq with military intelligence about Iran, White House and State Department officials said today.   The American officials said the information had been shared to help Iraq avoid being defeated by Iran in their six-year war. The officials said that would be disastrous to American interests.   But after the revelations of the last six weeks about secret arms sales to Iran, the latest disclosure was widely viewed as having further damaged the credibility of the Administration's claim to be neutral in the war.

headline: EGYPT'S SONS BACK HOME, BUT NOT TO FATTED CALVES
abstract: When Mohammed Ibrahim Mustapha came back to this Nile Delta village after a year in Iraq driving a truck on construction jobs he had saved enough money to build a little house.   The house stands ready but empty down a footpath and past a herd of grazing goats. Its two rooms are built of bricks made with rich, dark mud and straw, a building practice frowned upon by the Government since it is depleting the little arable land left in this crowded country.   ''I built a home to get married, but I can't afford mahr,'' the handsome 25-year-old Mr. Mustapha said, referring to the traditional bride price still levied in peasant villages.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1986
abstract: Companies      G.M. plans to cut production and furlough 26,400 workers in January, most of them for two weeks. Nine of G.M.'s 30 car and truck assembly plants are to be closed temporarily. Previously the giant auto maker often resorted to sales incentives to trim excessive inventories. Analysts had predicted production cuts by G.M. because its new-car inventories have grown sharply since its last round of low-rate car loans ended in October.  [ Page D1. ]  In a session with managers of major pension funds, H. Ross Perot and top G.M. executives disagreed about the circumstances surrounding his departure from the company's board.  [ D5. ]    John Z. DeLorean was found not guilty of embezzling $8.5 million from his failed sports car enterprise. It was the second time in two and a half years that he has been acquitted of major criminal charges. ''Praise God!'' Mr. DeLorean said after hearing the verdicts on 15 counts of fraud and racketeering.  [ A1. ]

headline: South Africans Relent On Ouster of Red Cross
abstract: South Africa today reversed an expulsion order against Red Cross officials and said they could remain.   A statement by Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said the decision was made after word had been received from the president of the International Committee of the Red Cross that he disagreed with the suspension of South Africa from a Red Cross conference last month.

headline: Home Loan Banks Price 3 Offerings
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday announced interest rates of 6.55 percent for $1.045 billion of three-year bonds, 7 percent for $970 million of seven-year notes and 7 3/8 percent for $670 million of seven-year notes. All three issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities firms.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Classified Financial Corporation, Waukesha, Wis., has named F.K. Neal Stanley as president and chief executive, and Thomas A. Cockrell as executive vice president and chief operating officer.    * Marriott Corporation, Washington, has elected Frederic V. Malek president of Marriott hotels and resorts.

headline: Allied-Lyons Unit Chairman
abstract: Allied-Lyons P.L.C. said yesterday that it had named Charles E. Arnett chairman of Allied-Lyons North America, the parent company of Baskin-Robbins Ice Cream, Tetley Inc. and DCA Food Industries.   Mr. Arnett, who is 59 years old, had been chief executive of Tetley, the tea and coffee company, since 1973.

headline: SOVIET TEST MONITORS TO GET VISAS
abstract: Soviet scientific experts are scheduled to visit the United States early next month to discuss potential sites for monitoring American tests of nuclear weapons.   The Soviet scientists will not be permitted to visit the sites under the terms of their visa.

headline: PEOPLE EXPRESS BID CLEARED
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation won final approval today from the Transportation Department to acquire the financially troubled People Express Inc. and most of the assets of its bankrupt subsidiary, Frontier Airlines.   The agency attached no conditions to its approval, noting that the merger ''would not substantially reduce competition'' in any market, despite the fact that after the combination Texas Air units would account for about 20 percent of scheduled airline service, Texas Air's offer to buy People Express for $125 million still hinges upon agreement by six groups of holders of People Express debt. They must agree to lower the interest rate on their loans by $12.6 million annually and, in the case of two groups, extend the payout period.

headline: SAN SALVADOR QUAKE WRECKED 3 OUT OF 4 BIG HOSPITALS IN CITY
abstract: One of the worst problems created by the quake that hit El Salvador on Friday was the damage done to the city's major hospitals, officials here said.   Three of the hospitals have been totally evacuated, leaving Rosales Hospital as the city's only large functioning hospital in the center of town. Two others, San Bertola, in the east of the city, and San Rafael, in nearby Santa Tecla, are being used as referral hospitals because they lack operating room capacity and equipment, according to officials.

headline: Cooper Lasersonics
abstract: The Cooper Development Company said it had raised its offer for Cooper Lasersonics Inc. from a straight stock-for-stock merger to a transaction in which each ouststanding Cooper Lasersonics share would be exchanged for 1.25 shares of Cooper Development common and one-tenth of a share of Series A convertible preferred stock. The combined value of the securities is about $5, the company said. Based in Palo Alto, Calif., Cooper Development and Cooper Lasersonics were both spun off from Cooper Laboratories along with Coopervision Inc.

headline: REACTION IN EUROPE IS MIXED
abstract: Reaction in Europe to reports that the United States provided military spare parts to Iran and secretly negotiated with Teheran in an attempt to free American hostages in Lebanon ranged from support in Italy to caution and restraint on the part of British officials to chiding comments by the French Foreign Minister.   While Government officials in many countries preferred to adopt a wait-and-see attitude, many news organizations were quick to label the American action ''hypocritical,'' saying Washington was pursuing a ''risky'' course.

headline: Careers; Getting Aid Following Dismissal
abstract: THIS year may long be remembered as the Year of the Big Dismissals.   Many of those who find themselves suddenly out of work will have the benefit of outplacement services to help them find jobs. Others, however, especially those who take early retirement, often are not offered outplacement help.   Buying such assistance on an individual basis can be not only expensive but also disappointing. Some firms presenting themselves as career counselors have been investigated by various state attorneys general for misrepresentation. Those seeking counseling should inquire about such help at Better Business Bureaus, attorney general's offices and consumer fraud units.

headline: Warsaw Cuts Terms of 3 Jailed in Death of Priest
abstract: Prosecutors today reduced the sentences of three security police officers convicted in the death of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a Solidarity supporter.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt      * DP Acquisition Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $180 million of senior subordinated debentures due 2001 through Shearson Lehman Brothers.    * Newfoundland is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent notes due 1996 at 99.50, to yield 8.575 percent, or about 1.15 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ANGLICAN ENVOY RENEWS EFFORT ON BEIRUT HOSTAGES
abstract: A special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Terry Waite, arrived here unexpectedly today in a fresh effort to secure the release of American hostages held by Moslem extremists.   Mr. Waite's arrival came amid a flurry of rumors that the release of at least some of the Western hostages in Beirut might be imminent. Tonight, two Lebanese Christian radio stations here broadcast an unconfirmed report that two French hostages had been turned over to Syrian officials in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon in preparation for their release along with the American hostages.   Mr. Waite told reporters that he had come to Beirut in the hope that there would be new developments in the case of the hostages. He did not elaborate.

headline: Mississippi Tax-Exempts
abstract: The Mississippi Housing Finance Agency is offering $285 million of bonds, which include ''pure'' tax-exempt bonds and ''tainted'' tax-exempt bonds on which the interest may be subject to the alternative minimum income tax for individuals.   Underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company said strong investor demand enabled the underwriters to reduce yields slightly from the levels announced earlier this week.

headline: Eppler, Guerin Considers Merger
abstract: Eppler, Guerin & Turner Inc., the largest independent investment banking and brokerage firm based in the Southwest, said it was considering merging into the Principal Financial Group of Des Moines.

headline: A Bonn View On Rate Cut
abstract: Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg today dampened hopes of a cut in the country's key interest rates, citing excessive growth in the West German money supply.   Mr. Stoltenberg, reporting to Parliament on the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meeting in Washington earlier this month, said that money growth was exceeding goals set by the Bundesbank, the West German central bank.   He said this was ''an important reason why the Bundesbank sees no possibility of a further reduction of leading interest rates at the present time.''

headline: Chairman Of Collins Leads Sale
abstract: In the early part of the century, Willis G. McCullough recognized that the interior of a new invention, the automobile, could be enclosed with a roof and upholstered much like the contents of a living room. Nearly 80 years later, the company that was built on that idea is being sold for $1.16 billion.   Mr. McCullough's son, Donald, has led the Collins & Aikman Corporation into the agreement with the Wickes Companies in which Wickes is making a friendly $53-a-share tender offer for the manufacturer of auto interiors, fabrics and wall coverings.

headline: Gas Prices Remain Stable
abstract: Gasoline prices remained virtually unchanged from two weeks ago, as retailers battled it out to win over motorists with lower prices, an industry analyst said today.   ''Street competition is so hot, in many cases a wholesale increase cannot get passed through to the consumer,'' said Trilby Lundberg, publisher of a twice-monthly nationwide survey of prices at 15,000 gas stations.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Arkla Inc. filed $300 million of debt securities.    * Commercial Credit Corp. filed up to $750 million of unsecured debt.

headline: Eastern Bid
abstract: Unions trying to buy Eastern Airlines raised their offer to $700 million, in hopes of preventing a takeover by the Texas Air Corporation, union officials said.

headline: Paris to Repay Part of Loan Made by Iran Under the Shah
abstract: France announced today that it had agreed to repay Iran $330 million of a $1 billion loan made years ago by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

headline: DOLE URGES REAGAN TO MEET U.S. ALLIES TO CLARIFY IRAN CASE
abstract: Calling the diversion of profits from Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebels ''just plain stupid,'' Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, urged President Reagan today to call a summit meeting with allies on the foreign policy crisis.   ''There's a lot of frustration on the part of the American people,'' Senator Dole said. ''The bottom line is we have a serious problem.''

headline: IRANIAN IS REPORTED TO FLEE
abstract: The eldest son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament has apparently fled to Canada ''after receiving at least $6 million'' for his role in the sale of American arms to Iran, a London newspaper reported today.   The newspaper, The Observer, cited ''Iranian sources'' in London in reporting that Mehdi Bahremani, son of Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Parliament, ''left his home in Brussels on Nov. 15, closely pursued by an official Iranian investigator.''

headline: Shearson Joins Beijing Project
abstract: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. agreed yesterday with two Chinese partners to develop a one-million-square-foot office and residential complex in Beijing. The $150 million project, to be known as the Beijing American Express Center, will serve the diplomatic and foreign corporate communities.

headline: SIX WHO ADDED THE SPICE TO 1986
abstract: As in any theatrical event, many of the key players in American business during 1986 operated from behind the scenes. They received little notice although their work this year produced stunning revelations on Wall Street and generated millions of dollars worth of new products.   For the most part, 1986 was a year in which Americans were swept up by national pride, a spirit generated by the celebration of the Statue of Liberty's centennial. People were eager to buy just about anything that smacked of Americana - from a $40 photo essay of the nation, which becamse the hottest Christmas seller in the bookstores, to a $400 gold coin newly issued by the United States Mint. The health binge this year put the spotlight on calcium, which turned up in the most unlikely places: orange juice, for example. And despite the drop in the dollar and the burst of patroitism, Americans purchased imports in greater volume than ever beofre in '86. That generated a big payoff for one South Korean automaker who dared to bring a new car into the oversupplied American market. The following is a glimpse of some of the year's unsung heroes: The Packagers Who Finally Scored A Publishing Coup RICHARD S. SMOLAND and David E. Cohen do not dress for success. The 37-year-old Mr. Smolan, known as Rick, sports granny glasses, a mustache, and a shoulder-length mane of brown hair. The 31-year-old Mr. Cohen has put his buttoned-down Yale days behind him and let his dark blond hair grow long.

headline: Kuwaitis Fire Two Missiles At an Unidentified Aircraft
abstract: Kuwait said today that it had fired two antiaircraft missiles at an unidentified target on Saturday night, apparently downing it as it approached Kuwaiti airspace.   Maj. Gen. Abdulla Farraj al-Ghanim, the Chief of Staff, said it had not been possible to identify the target.

headline: ITT Official Picked For Military Unit
abstract: The ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it would consolidate its military and government services businesses into a new company, and named V. William Souveroff to head it.   Mr. Souveroff, 52 years old, was named president and chief executive of the new entity, to be known as the ITT Defense Technology Corporation.

headline: Son of Founder Is Wang President
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc. announced yesterday that Frederick A. Wang, the 36-year-old son of its founder, had been named president of the maker of computers and office automation equipment.   An Wang, 66, the company's chairman and chief executive, had been serving as president since last year after John F. Cunningham resigned. Mr. Cunningham was said to have left because he felt he had no chance to become chief executive since the younger Mr. Wang was widely viewed as his father's successor, An Wang said yesterday that he had no plans to retire and would continue active participation in the company as chairman and chief executive. His son has been with the company for 14 years, most recently serving as treasurer, a post he will retain, and executive vice president.

headline: Advertising; Esquire, Sail Join On Insert
abstract: ESQUIRE magazine's February issue will carry a special insert on the America's Cup race.   There's nothing new about running special inserts in magazines that are made up of supportive editorial material wrapped around advertising. They are called advertorials and the so-called editorial is generally either done in a special department at the publisher or by an independent group.

headline: USX Stock Up; Rumors Cited
abstract: Shares of the USX Corporation rose yesterday in heavy trading as rumors circulated that Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, had resumed buying shares in the steel and oil company and may soon disclose his holdings.   Mr. Icahn, who took control of Trans World Airlines Inc. last year and returned the airline to profitability, has held just under 5 percent of USX's 257 million shares outstanding for several weeks, according to Wall Street sources.

headline: G.M. Saturn Plant Financing Begun
abstract: A $65 million issue of 7 1/4 percent pollution control bonds due in 2005 to finance facilities at the General Motors Corporation's new Saturn Corporation plant in Tennessee was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The bonds, which are issued by the Industrial Development Board of Maury County, Tenn., on behalf of Saturn and G.M., will be used to refund variable-rate notes which were privately placed with Chemical Bank at the end of last year.

headline: A DISCOUNTER WHO COUNTS ON CONSUMER RESEARCH
abstract: JOSEPH E. ANTONINI could have stepped out of one of those classic American rags-to-riches tales, where the young hero starts out as a humble stock boy, works just a little harder than everyone else, climbs over all the obstacles and - lo and behold - ends up at the top of the heap.   For Mr. Antonini, 45, the happy ending seems to be in sight: Four months ago, he was named corporate president and chief operating officer of the K Mart Corporation; he is expected to be named chief executive at the retail company's annual meeting in March, and there is little doubt that he will become chairman in September, when Bernard M. Fauber retires.   But in real life, nothing is quite that simple. The irrepressible Mr. Antonini has plenty of challenges ahead, for K Mart, the nation's leading discounter and No. 2 retailer, is in a crucial period of transition.   K Mart is caught in a continuing race both to catch up with Sears, Roebuck & Company, the No. 1 retailer, and to stay ahead of the fast-growing Wal-Mart, the second-largest discounter. In the last two years, it has had to run faster and faster just to keep its place.

headline: FIFTH AMENDMENT: BACK IN THE NEWS WITH 'INTRIGUING TWIST'
abstract: One of the oldest principles of Anglo-Saxon law is that no one is bound to betray himself, and in 1789 it was incorporated into the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution.   The Fifth Amendment has been invoked in recent days by Government officials who decline to provide testimony to Congressional committees looking into the secret Iran arms deals and the diversion of proceeds to Nicaraguan rebels.   The amendment says that ''no person . . . shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.''   Until now, the most dramatic uses of this right occurred in the 1950's during the anti-Communist campaign of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, who was chairman of a Senate panel that summoned people to testify about Communist ties. The Fifth Amendment has also been invoked by figures in organized crime.

headline: AFG MAY REVIEW ITS OFFER FOR LEAR
abstract: Lear Siegler Inc., faced with the unraveling of its $1.7 billion acquisition by the Wickes Companies, may again be the target of a takeover by AFG Partners if Wickes fails to obtain bank financing for its deal.   AFG Partners, formed by AFG Industries and Wagner & Brown, said in a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might renew its efforts to acquire control of Lear Siegler. The partnership, which made an earlier offer of $85 a share, or $1.51 billion, for the company, said it intends to purchase Lear Siegler's stock on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions.   Jack E. Cressman, a spokesman for Lear Siegler, said the company had no immediate comment on the statement from AFG Partners. The automotive and aerospace company, which was notified late Tuesday of Wickes's failure so far to line up financing for the tender offer that began Nov. 13, said in an earlier statement that it was disappointed by Wickes's announcement. Lear also said that it planned a restructuring if the Wickes deal fell through, but did not elaborate.

headline: HUMBLED G.M.
abstract: To the Editor:   Smith is in the consumer products business and to be successful in that business he must produce products people want to buy.   As a recruiter with recent assignments in the automotive world, I interviewed at least 15 General Motors automobile designers over the past two years.

headline: Basque Business Bombed A Day Before Vote
abstract: A bomb believed set by Basque separatists exploded today at a car showroom, a day before voters elect a regional parliament.   The blast caused considerable damage at a showroom of Talbot and Peugeot automobiles but no injuries, the police said.

headline: Market Place; More Retail Linkups Seen
abstract: AS the dust settles on the $3.6 billion merger between the Campeau Corporation and the Allied Stores Corporation, one of the largest retailers in the United States, investment bankers, analysts and merchants are asking, ''Who's next?''   The consensus is that no company is now immune - not even the K Mart Corporation with its $23 billion in sales - as long as there are those investment groups who perceive any company as either undervalued or underperforming.   ''The big retailers whose origins were in the 1920's are now being scrambled because of mergers and what it opens up are new opportunities for many other companies, either to acquire or be acquired,'' said Peter Solomon, vice chairman of Shearson Lehman Brothers. ''In the retail business, this could lead to a new wave of entrepreneurism.''

headline: SOLIDARITY ADDS WATCHDOG GROUP
abstract: The outlawed Solidarity movement has set up a group to monitor legal abuses, opposition sources said today.   The group, which calls itself the Intervention and Legality Commission, has representatives in 11 cities, will review the existing legal system and help victims of injustice, a statement said.

headline: GILLETTE DEAL ENDS REVLON BID
abstract: The Gillette Company said yester-day that it would pay $558 million to the Revlon Group to end the cosmetics company's vigorous pursuit of the world's largest manufacturer of shaving products.   The transaction, viewed by analysts as ''greenmail,'' reflects the chilled takeover atmosphere on Wall Street in the second week of a growing insider trading scandal.   Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's chairman, will profit from the takeover fight, receiving $59.50 a share for Revlon's 9.2 million shares of Gillette stock, a profit of about $43 million. He also will get an additional $9 million, or 98 cents a share, in expenses.   Gillette stockholders, meanwhile, took a sizable loss yesterday as the company's stock fell by $10.75, to $45.875. It was the most heavily traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Since the $4.12 billion takeover bid was disclosed in newspaper advertisements on Nov. 14, Gillette's stock has traded as high as $67.

headline: GOLDMAN NAMES 37 PARTNERS
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company named 37 new partners yesterday, the most ever in the firm's history. The group included the first black and the first female partner at Goldman and its size reflected, the firm said, Goldman's fast growth in recent years.   ''We're growing,'' said John L. Weinberg, Goldman's chairman. ''And frankly, we needed these people. We've been expanding our activities geographically and in our product lines. We needed to broaden our leadership and we had a number of highly qualified candidates.''

headline: Washington Watch; Judge Is Focus Of Phone Fight
abstract: THE Big Seven regional Bell Telephone holding companies, anxious for an all-out war of competition in the telephone business, have abandoned nearly all hopes of getting help on this effort from Congress.   The principal reason for the change of heart is the shift in control of the Senate to the Democrats from the Republicans. It was the Republican leadership that began an effort in the last session of Congress to get legislation considered that would transfer to the Federal Communications Commission, from a Federal court, jurisdiction over the consent decree governing the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. There was, and still appears to be, little enthusiasm among Democratic senators for such intervention.

headline: HONEYWELL TO TAKE $575 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Honeywell Inc. said today that it would report a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $575 million, primarily from the sale of most of its computer business at a discounted price.   The loss, which includes other restructuring charges, is substantially higher than expected and would result in a net loss of $380 million for the year. Honeywell has been moving away from computers toward aerospace and military electronics and commercial and industrial controls.

headline: Article 103886 -- No Title
abstract: The Indian Government said today that it would seek a minimum of $3 billion from the Union Carbide Corporation as compensation for the gas-leak accident at Bhopal in 1984 that killed more than 2,300 people.   The Government announced the amount in a statement before a court in Bhopal, the central Indian city that was enveloped on Dec. 3, 1984, by a toxic gas cloud that escaped from a Union Carbide subsidiary there. It was the first time the Government had specified a compensation amount in nearly a year and a half of litigation here and in the United States.

headline: NWA Income Rises by 53.1%
abstract: NWA Inc., corporate parent of Northwest Airlines, said today that its net income surged 53.1 percent, to a record $59.7 million, or $2.32 a share, compared with $39 million, or $1.55 a share, in the 1985 period.   The latest results include the acquisition of Republic Airlines, effective Aug. 12, but do not fully reflect the combined financial potential of Northwest, since flight schedules were not integrated until Oct. 1, said Steven G. Rothmeier, NWA's chairman.

headline: A WALL ST. LAWYER ADMITS INSIDER GUILT
abstract: Michael N. David, the last of the young Wall Street professionals charged with insider trading earlier this year, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy, mail fraud, wire fraud and obstruction of justice for his part in the trading ring.   Mr. David, 28 years old, a former associate at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, admitted to taking confidential information about upcoming takeover deals from his firm and passing it on to his four co-defendants.   Mr. David faces up to 20 years in prison and up to $1 million in fines for his part in the ring. He remains free on $25,000 bond.

headline: Meese Is Said to Tell of a Key Memo
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reportedly told Congress today that the diversion of millions of dollars from the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels was uncovered when a senior Justice Department official found an undated memorandum in the files of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proposing the idea. According to a Congressional source, Mr. Meese told the House Intelligence Committee that Colonel North was ''ashen'' when he confronted him with the memorandum during an interview in his office on Nov. 23.   The document was found by Assistant Attorney General Bradford Reynolds, one of several senior Justice Department officials who were helping Mr. Meese in efforts to draw up a chronology of the Iran arms deal, the source quoted Mr. Meese as having said.   Who wrote the memorandum, or whether it was ever circulated to other National Security Council staff members, is not clear. But shortly after it was uncovered, Mr. Meese reportedly told the committee, Colonel North acknowledged arranging the diversion and offered an example of how much money could be realized from the sale of 500 TOW missiles.

headline: Berlin Escape Disclosed
abstract: Two young East Berlin men escaped to the West by climbing over the Berlin wall with a ladder, the West Berlin authorities said today. The escape by Jan Peter Mueller, 24 years old, a bricklayer, and Bernd Hansen, 26, a locksmith, took place in September and was reported for the first time today in the newspaper Bild.

headline: PARLEY ON EUROPEAN SECURITY PACT STARTS IN VIENNA
abstract: Foreign ministers from most of the 35 nations that signed the Helsinki accords in 1975 today inaugurated the third full-dress conference to review and strengthen the document.   The Helsinki accords effectively ratified the postwar boundaries of Europe and mandated respect for human rights.   The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which embraces all the European nations except Albania as well as the United States and Canada, opened today amid expectations that American and Soviet delegates will use it as a backdrop to clarify and possibly advance the discussions at the summit meeting last month in Iceland.
