Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who is scheduled to arrive here early Wednesday with a high-ranking delegation, will hold a first meeting with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in the afternoon at the American Embassy.

headline: Yields Still Bolster Junk Bonds
abstract: The promise of double-digit interest rates continues to sustain the market for junk bonds, even while investors and securities dealers have not yet shaken off their nervousness over investigations into insider trading in the stock market.   This week, for example, investment bankers have scheduled offerings of low-quality bonds and preferred stock exceeding $2.8 billion. Although interest rates for some kinds of debt have increased as much as a percentage point since mid-November, analysts expect the new issues to be sold and the supply to continue heavy through January.   It was Nov. 14 when Ivan F. Boesky, the trader, agreed to pay a penalty to the Government for profiting from the illegal use of inside information. When Federal investigators then issued subpoenas to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and some of its executives, prices of junk bonds began to weaken and their yields rose. Because Drexel is by far the leading underwriter and trader of such bonds, investors worried that problems at the firm might make it harder to trade them in the secondary market.

headline: Sears to Sell Back Hagemeyer Stake
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it had agreed in principle to sell back to Hagemeyer N.V. the 20 percent of the general trading company that it had bought 13 months ago. Sears said it would receive $31.1 million for the 770,000 shares.

headline: Auditors Settle Suit
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services said it had reached a settlement with certain former auditors of its Alexander Howden Group subsidiary in England, under which it would receive $24.8 million. The agreement settles a suit brought against the auditors over reported irregularities in Howden's books, which Alexander & Alexander discovered after acquiring Howden in 1982. Alexander & Alexander said it would receive $14.2 million from Josolyne Layton-Bennett & Company, $5 million from De Paula Turner Lake & Company and $4.8 million from Peat Marwick International.

headline: 12 Die in Sri Lanka Clashes
abstract: Two policemen were killed today and seven others wounded when Tamil separatist guerrillas ambushed a police patrol in northern Sri Lanka, the Government said. On Friday, at least seven rebels and three civilians were killed in clashes with troops in the north and east, the Government said.

headline: Allied-Signal's Henley Stake
abstract: Allied-Signal Inc. confirmed yesterday that it was continuing to negotiate its plan, announced earlier this year, to sell its 15 percent interest in the Henley Group. Allied-Signal holds 19.6 million shares of Henley preferred stock, which is convertible to an equal number of common shares.

headline: PERU ECONOMY BOUNCES BACK
abstract: This month, in order to meet an unexpected surge in domestic demand for textiles, the Peruvian Government struck a blow against its new export drive by suspending all cotton sales abroad. Yet, it announced the decision quite cheerfully.   In a country that in recent years has seen its gross domestic product contract - with a sharp 12 percent decline in 1983 that resulted from damage caused by heavy rains from the tropical current El Nino - it is still very much of a novelty to be struggling with problems of growth rather than recession.   Over the past 15 months, the Peruvian economy has gradually begun to come alive. Although many economists question whether the recovery can last, economic growth this year should be about 6.5 percent, a larger increase than at any time since 1974. Manufacturing production alone should expand by as much as 20 percent in 1986.

headline: PATENTS; Princeton Inventions Tied to Fusion Power
abstract: Two inventions related to fusion power that can be produced with hydrogen isotopes in a nuclear reactor were patented this week for the Department of Energy under a contract with Princeton University.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The investor windfall on U.S. savings bonds seems to be over. The Government is expected to announce today a substantial cut in the guaranteed 7 1/2 percent interest rate on savings bonds that have been held at least five years. The decision to cut the minimum yield comes as sales have boomed to more than $1 billion a month. The new rate, which would be effective Nov. 1, has not been disclosed, but analysts suggested the drop would be at least a full percentage point and perhaps as much as two points.  [ Page A1. ]    The Administration has urged the Japanese to redress a $5 billion deficit with the United States in auto parts trade. But in two rounds of talks, the Japanese have remained noncommittal.  [ D5. ]

headline: Chrysler Prices Increasing 1.6%
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation's 1987 domestic cars will cost an average 1.6 percent more than the 1986 models, but its subcompact Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon America versions will cost 11.6 percent less, the company says. The base price for 1987 Omni and Horizon cars will be $5,799, Chrysler announced Friday.

headline: Advertising; TV Show Spawns Magazine
abstract: SOME people in the supermarket tabloid business will tell you that Robin Leach, host of the television show ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,'' was inspired by the tabloids to create the show. He had been a writer for two of them.   Now the publisher of one of those two, Globe Communications, has decided to complete the circle and bring out a monthly magazine inspired by the show. It is called Celebrity Focus and is scheduled to show up at checkout counters late next month carrying a January cover date.

headline: U.S. JURY IN MIAMI LOOKS INTO CHARGES CONTRAS BROKE LAWS
abstract: A Federal grand jury in Miami is examining evidence of gunrunning and Neutrality Act violations by Nicaraguan rebels and some American backers, a Federal official said today.   The official said the grand jury investigation started last month and was not connected to the inquiries into the diversion of $10 million to $30 million in profits from arms sales to Iran to the rebels, known as contras.

headline: Market Place; Hanson Profile Rising in U.S.
abstract: NEXT Monday, the stock of Hanson Trust P.L.C., the conglomerate based in Britain, will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In itself, the event is rather routine. Hanson will simply be joining a number of other large British companies that decided in recent years to expand their shareholder base by tapping the American market.   But, for Hanson, there seems to be another reason for allowing the stock to trade, in the form of American Depositary Receipts, in the United States. The company wants a higher profile in the country, which could come in handy the next time Hanson attempts a takeover.

headline: Japanese Securities Markets
abstract: E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, seems pleased enough with how much Japan has opened its securities markets to Americans to let Japanese firms here become primary dealers in Government securities. In a letter to Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn, Mr. Corrigan said that the Fed has been ''encouraged that the Japanese authorities have been making steady progress toward opening their market to foreign firms.''

headline: LISTEN, AND YOU CAN HEAR A HOLY WAR NEXT DOOR
abstract: The evenings are chilly now in this dusty old city on Pakistan's northwest frontier, and people say that soon the cold weather will again curtail the fighting in the rugged hills of neighboring Afghanistan.   In the makeshift office of a guerrilla group fighting the six-year-old war, a commander has just returned from the front. He says that throughout the country, people have fled their villages and farms to escape Russian bombardments.   ''Every child you meet has someone in the family killed by enemy forces,'' said the commander, Mulla Malang, folding his legs on the floor.

headline: JAPAN TO CUT EXPORTS OF TEXTILES
abstract: After a flurry of negotiations aimed at undercutting protectionist moves in the new Congress, Japan has agreed to sharp reductions of exports of textiles and machine tools to the United States, officials of both countries said today.   The new arrangements follow the announcement by the Japanese Finance Ministry earlier this week that the United States had a record $5 billion deficit in trade with Japan in October, suggesting that this politically sensitive measure will exceed forecasts for 1986.   Just last Aug. 6, President Reagan's veto of a textile quota bill was sustained by a margin of only eight votes in the House. And Democratic leaders have promised that trade legislation will come up early in the new Congress, now fully controlled by their party.

headline: Union Carbide Countersuit
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, while continuing to deny its own liability, filed a countersuit today against the governments of India and the State of Madhya Pradesh, accusing them of ''contributory'' responsibility for the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.   India has already demanded compensation of at least $3 billion for the gas victims and charged that flawed designs supplied by the American parent company had caused the leak of poisonous gases from a subsidiary's pesticide plant at Bhopal.

headline: U.S. Team Inspects A Site in Vietnam
abstract: United States officials investigating American servicemen listed as missing in action in the Vietnam War have inspected a site in northern Vietnam where an American warplane might have crashed, officials said today.   Lieut. Col. Joe Harvey, head of the Hawaii-based Joint Casualty Resolution Center and leader of a delegation that met with Vietnamese officials last week, said the possible crash site is a few miles outside of Haiphong.

headline: ANGLICANS KINDLE HOPE IN VAST ARCTIC DIOCESE
abstract: Not long ago, an imprisoned Eskimo who had killed a friend in a drunken rage resolved in his remorse to become an Anglican priest.   Such credentials would not open the doors to most seminaries, but the killer, who underwent a conversion in jail, took religious instruction on Baffin Island after his release, was ordained and was given a small parish in the Canadian North.   ''And now he is one of the most beautiful priests we've got,'' said the Right Rev. John P. Sperry. ''When you get people like that, it gives a lot of hope to people who are at the bottom and despairing.''

headline: SHIFT OF POWER ON BANK BOARD SEEN
abstract: The defeat suffered by the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on his proposal to extend a limit on real estate investments by thrift institutions signaled a major shift in the balance of power at the agency, industry experts said this week.   The inability of Edwin J. Gray to muster support from the agency's two other members, both Reagan appointees, may have even neutralized his tough regulatory stance on the industry's widespread problems, some experts said.   In the agency's packed boardroom last Thursday, Mr. Gray had argued for a two-year extension of a measure limiting direct investment in real estate ventures to 10 percent of a thrift institution's assets. But after two hours of debate, he lamented: ''Ladies and gentlemen, there has been some consultation as to where the various board members are coming out. I have indications that the other two members do not want to extend it. So it seems somewhat ridiculous for me to make that motion.''

headline: Japan Ship Line In Debt Crisis
abstract: Japan Line Ltd., one of the world's leading tanker operators, has asked a group of its creditor banks for urgent financial help to stave off bankruptcy, a company spokesman said today.   The company thus becomes the latest big Japanese shipping concern to fall victim to the sharp rise of the yen and a prolonged slump in world shipping.

headline: A Nobel Mix
abstract: The winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, James M. Buchanan, has combined economics and politics in unorthodox ways. In developing his public choice theory, an attempt to explain the economic reasons behind political decisions, Mr. Buchanan risked the wrath of both disciplines. Described by colleagues and former students at George Mason University as a serious, dedicated but intimidating scholar, Mr. Buchanan will, with the prize, likely gain loyalty and legitimacy in skeptics' eyes.

headline: NVHOMES LEADER SEES RYAN AS A STRATEGIC FIT
abstract: Dwight C. Schar, chairman and chief executive of NVHomes L.P., is a residential builder by trade. Now, he is trying to make a large addition to his home construction company.   On Monday, NVHomes began a $45-a-share cash tender offer - a total of $292 million - for the shares of Ryan Homes Inc. it does not already own. NVHomes, a partnership with headquarters in McLean, Va., acquired a 6.9 percent stake in Ryan in late August. Based in Pittsburgh, Ryan is one of the nation's largest builders of moderately priced homes.

headline: Fireman's Fund Debentures
abstract: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, a property and casualty insurance underwriter, is offering $150 million of 9 5/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99.07, to yield 9.72 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The debentures, rated A-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P., are nonrefundable for 10 years. A sinking fund beginning in 1997 will retire at least 4 percent of the issue annually, giving the debentures a minimum life of 14.7 years and a maximum life of 22.4 years.

headline: Arab League Asks U.N. Unit To Seek End to Iran-Iraq War
abstract: The Arab League called on the Secutiry Council today to seek an end to the Iran-Iraq war.   Chedli Klibi, the Tunisian who is Secretary General of the 21-member Arab League, told the Council, ''The mounting Iranian threats to launch a new extensive attack against Iraq endanger the security of the region.''

headline: SPOKESMAN QUITS STATE DEPT. POST ON DECEPTION ISSUE
abstract: Citing the importance of personal and governmental credibility, Bernard Kalb resigned today as the State Department spokesman to protest what he called ''the reported disinformation program'' conducted by the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.   ''Faith in the word of America is the pulsebeat of our democracy,'' Mr. Kalb told reporters at the State Department. ''Anything that hurts America's credibility hurts America.''   President Reagan, asked about the resignation of Mr. Kalb as he boarded Air Force One tonight in Atlanta, en route to Washington, said, ''No one on our side has been lying to anyone.''

headline: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers digested a large auction of new 10-year Treasury notes and prepared for today's finale to the Treasury's three-part financing - a $9.25 billion auction of 30-year bonds.   The $9.75 billion of new 7 1/4 percent Treasury notes due in 1996 sold with an average yield of 7.25 percent, up from about 7.21 percent a day earlier, but still the lowest auction yield ever for such a maturity.   By late in the day, the new notes were little changed from the auction level. But the 6 3/8 percent three-year notes auctioned Tuesday weakened slightly, and were offered late in the day at 99 27/32, to yield 6.44 percent, down from an auction average of about 99 7/8.

headline: DELOREAN FOUND NOT GUILTY ON CHARGES OF EMBEZZLEMENT
abstract: John Z. DeLorean was found not guilty today of defrauding his failed sports car company of $8.5 million.   But prosecutors immediately challenged the not-guilty verdicts on the 15 counts, including fraud and racketeering, saying the jurors may have misinterpreted the legal instructions given by Federal District Judge Julian A. Cook Jr. The jury decided to acquit Mr. DeLorean, 61 years old, despite the fact that 3 of the 12 jurors thought he was guilty, several jurors said in interviews tonight. They said they thought they had to acquit Mr. DeLorean if they could not unanimously agree on a verdict. They apparently ignored the possibility of declaring a hung jury, according to the interviews.

headline: Bid for Utility In Indiana Seen
abstract: The First City Financial Corporation, controlled by the Belzberg family of Vancouver, made an offer to acquire the Public Service Company of Indiana, according to a report in the Indianapolis Star.

headline: NICARAGUA SAYS IT DOWNED PLANE WITH 4 U.S. CREWMEN, KILLING 3
abstract: The Defense Ministry said tonight that a rebel supply plane had been shot down in southern Nicaragua and that the sole survivor had identified himself as an American military adviser in El Salvador.   Nicaragua said the three other crew members were killed in the crash on Sunday afternoon and were also identified as Americans by the survivor.   The Defense Ministry said the survivor of the incident had identified himself as Eugene Hafenfuf, 35 years old.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * ADT Inc., a maker of electronic life and property protection systems, named as a director Philip E. Beekman, chairman and chief operating officer of Hook-SuperX, a new drug chain that recently bought most of Kroger Co.'s drugstore operations.    * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, elected Thomas J. Albani, executive vice president, to the additional post of chief operating officer.

headline: Iran Says U.S. Engineer Has Admitted Spying
abstract: Newspapers here reported today that an American engineer, arrested four months ago, has admitted he spied for the Central Intelligence Agency.   The papers printed a television interview with the American, John Pattis, 50 years old, of Aiken, S.C.   Mr. Pattis was quoted as saying he had worked in Iran on various projects since 1969 and supplied the agency with information on telecommunications sites and projects, black market money rates, rumors about the health of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and other internal subjects.

headline: PATENTS; Nucleic Acids Utilized In Diagnosing Diseases
abstract: A method of identifying nucleic acids was patented this week for the Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif.

headline: LEAR SIEGLER STOCK TOPS $88
abstract: The stock of Lear Siegler Inc., the aerospace, automotive and industrial company that is the subject of a $1.51 billion acquisition offer by AFG Partners, climbed steadily to $88.375 today, up $2.625 in busy trading.   Its closing price is well above the $85 a share offered by the partnership.

headline: OFFICIAL BUILDINGS ARE FIRED ON IN TOKYO
abstract: Attackers believed by the police to be left-wing radicals fired six home-made rockets this evening in the direction of the Prime Minister's official residence and other Government installations.   No one was hurt, and the projectiles, fired almost simultaneously from the trunks of two parked cars, landed short of their apparent targets. They fell harmlessly onto the street and a rooftop, with no reported damage more severe than a broken street lamp.   Nevertheless, the well-timed attacks jolted Tokyo residents, who are normally unaccustomed to street violence but who have experienced half a dozen such episodes over the last seven months.

headline: SOVIET DEFENSE CHIEF MISSES KEY PARADE
abstract: The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, who has been out of public view for the last two months, failed to review the Revolution Day parade in Red Square today, increasing the speculation that he is seriously ill.   In his stead, the troops of the Moscow garrison were reviewed by Gen. Pyotr G. Lushev, one of three First Deputy Defense Ministers, who has been filling in for Marshal Sokolov at major functions and who is viewed by Western military experts as the most likely candidate to become the next Defense Minister.   Although Marshal Sokolov's name has continued to appear under documents requiring the Defense Minister's signature, he last made a public appearance on Sept. 9.

headline: ITALY LOOKS INTO CASE OF ISRAELI PRISONER
abstract: The Government has begun an investigation into whether an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted by Israeli agents on Italian soil, and if so, whether any Italian laws were violated.   ''We will insist that this be cleared up,'' Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said today.   Mr. Craxi, speaking at a news conference, said there were reasons to suspect that the Israeli, Mordechai Vannunu, 31 years old, had been kidnapped in Rome by Israeli agents and taken back to Israel to face trial for spying and treason.   Specifically, Mr. Vanunu has been accused in Israel of selling information to The Sunday Times of London about the Dimona nuclear plant in the Negev, where he worked for 10 years. The newspaper reported that the plant is the key part of a nuclear weapons production complex.

headline: Getting Rid of the Ghoulish Image
abstract: TWO years ago, after losing a brother in December, a great-grandmother in January and an uncle in February, Bostonian Diane Latham left a successful career as a broadcast engineer and entered mortuary school.   ''I found that funeral directors were not morbid, but were very sensitive and caring,'' said Ms. Latham, 39 years old. ''I wanted to comfort other people going through what I went through.''

headline: McLean Chief's Gamble Has Failed to Pay Off . . .
abstract: Thirty years ago, Malcolm Purcell McLean revolutionized the shipping industry when he pioneered the use of container ships. But his latest effort to reshape the industry has run aground.   His company, McLean Industries , this week filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy code.

headline: PLEAS FOR SILENCE ON MIDEAST DEALS
abstract: With President Reagan at his side, David P. Jacobsen, the former American hostage, pleaded with journalists today ''in the name of God'' to ''back off'' and refrain from reporting the details of hostage negotiations.   ''A simple speculation on your part could cause the death of my dear friend Tom Sutherland or Terry Anderson or Joe Cicippio or any of the other hostages,'' Mr. Jacobsen said in a choked voice, standing with President and Mrs. Reagan in the White House Rose Garden.   Mr. Jacobsen, a 55-year-old hospital administrator from Huntington Beach, Calif., was released Sunday after more than 17 months in captivity. Reports on Iran   Since Tuesday, when Iran said Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, and four other Americans had made a secret trip to Teheran, there have been published reports that the United States was providing military spare parts to Iran in a secret operation to gain the release of American hostages.

headline: TAIWAN STARTS TO CLEAN UP ITS AIR AND WATER
abstract: Surrounded by the sheer marble cliffs of what is sometimes called Taiwan's Grand Canyon, Hsu Kuo-shih reflected on Taiwan's rush to curb pollution and create national parks.   ''We've had 30 years of high-speed development on Taiwan,'' he said. ''But sometimes we damaged nature in the process. Now people have higher incomes, and they begin to think of nature. This is our environmental age.''

headline: NOT BECOMING SOFT ON SOVIET, PRESIDENT SAYS.
abstract: President Reagan, responding defensively to conservative criticism, said today that he was opening negotiations with Michael S. Gorbachev ''without illusions'' about the Soviet Union.   At the same time, Mr. Reagan sought to dampen expectations for the two days of talks he will hold with the Soviet leader in Iceland this weekend, warning against ''false hopes.'' He said he viewed the talks as largely ''laying the groundwork'' for a later visit by Mr. Gorbachev to the United States.   The President's remarks, made to a group of corporate executives at the White House, were his longest so far on the Iceland meeting, which was sought by Mr. Gorbachev.

headline: Racz & Dessimoz Wins Kawasho TV Account
abstract: Racz & Dessimoz Associates, specializing in boating, camera, hi-fi, video, wine and toy advertising, is going to be promoting television sets for Kawasho International (U.S.A.) with a budget of between $3 million and $4 million, starting Jan. 1. There was no previous agency.

headline: Ratings Revised For Auto Makers
abstract: Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago-based rating service, has lowered debt ratings of the General Motors Corporation and its finance subsidiary, while raising ratings of the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and their finance subsidiaries.   Ratings for G.M. and its subsidaries were reduced to D.&P.-4 from D.&P.-3, the equivalent of a drop to AA- from AA.

headline: Advertising; D'Arcy's Zurich Office
abstract: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles will open a Zurich office Feb. 1 bringing its worldwide presence to 55 offices in 47 cities in 27 countries. The first account there will be Fiat, for all of Switzerland. Urs Gysin will be leaving the GGK agency to be its managing director.

headline: British Seek Bank Curbs
abstract: The British Government urged Parliament Friday to approve legislation to strengthen supervision of banks, a reaction to the collapse two years ago of the London banking firm of Johnson Matthey Bankers.   Johnson Matthey collapsed in September 1984 with $:248 million, or $347 million, in unsecured or badly secured loans.

headline: Imperial C.E.O.'s
abstract: To the Editor:   The piece quotes an observer as saying ''. . . the nominating committees act as the arm and will of the chief executive, who feeds them names.''

headline: Bond Yields Fall Modestly
abstract: Yields on Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly yesterday, while short-term interest rates were unchanged to slightly higher.   Although yesterday's trading and investment activity was not particularly heavy, securities dealers said they had made good progress over the last six trading days in distributing the $29 billion of Treasury notes and bonds auctioned in the week of Nov. 3. Payment for the new issues was due yesterday, and dealers said that activity in the market for repurchase agreements suggested there was no burdensome glut of the new issues.   With yesterday's gains of nearly a half-point, the new 7 1/2 percent Treasury bonds due in 2016 were offered at 100 9/32 to yield 7.48 percent, up from 99 17/32 at the auction, while the 7 1/4 percent notes due in 1996 were at 100 11/32 to yield 7.20 percent, up from 100. The new 6 3/8 percent notes due in three years were offered at 99 7/8 to yield 6.42 percent, up 1/8 point on the day and about equal to the auction average.

headline: U.S. Plane Crashes in Spain
abstract: An American pilot escaped unhurt when his F-16 fighter plane crashed today near a United States air base here in eastern Spain, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. He said the pilot had parachuted out of the plane, which crashed against a mountain side.

headline: WOODWARD CHAIN BUYING WANAMAKER
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its John Wanamaker department store chain, which is based in Philadelphia, to the Woodward & Lothrop stores of Washington, D.C. The selling price was estimated by trade sources at $200 million.   The Woodward department stores are a subsidiary of the Taubman Investment Company, which is owned by A. Alfred Taubman, one of the nation's leading builders of shopping centers and an owner of Sotheby Parke Bernet, the large auction house.

headline: Yields Are Still Weak
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds remain weak for the third consecutive week.   For the period ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed the average yield for six-month C.D.'s unchanged at 5.92 percent, while the average yield of a bank money market account, which competes with money market mutual funds, was off 2 basis points, to 5.55 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Cleveland-Cliffs Chief
abstract: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. said that M. Thomas Moore, its president, would also become chief executive at the end of the year upon the retirement of Samuel K. Scovil, who remains chairman. Mr. Moore, 52 years old, became president and a director in July. He joined Cleveland-Cliffs in 1966. Mr. Scovil, now 63, joined the company in 1950 as an iron ore salesman. The company produces iron ore, contracts for oil and gas drilling and produces hardwood lumber.

headline: NL Says It Spurned Bid For Its Chemicals Unit
abstract: NL Industries, a company with interests in both chemicals and oil services, said late yesterday that a ''large financial institution'' it did not identify was prepared to buy its chemical operations, which it is contemplating spinning off.   NL Industries said the unidentified buyer had suggested paying $13.25 a share, in cash, plus an additional $2 a share in preferred stock for NL Chemicals. But NL Industries said that it rebuffed the proposal ''at this time'' to continue exploring the separation of its two basic businesses.

headline: PANAMA OFFERS A HAVEN FOR SHADOWY CONCERNS
abstract: This is a land of companies that exist only on paper. There are more than 150,000 of them, and scores more are being set up every day, according to Government officials and corporate lawyers.   The companies usually consist of no more than a few typed pages in a manila folder, but they enable their foreign owners to do business anywhere in the world anonymously and tax-free.   In the last week, three Panamanian companies have been linked to the United States' sale of weapons to Iran and the diversion of profits to the supply network of the Nicaraguan rebels or contras. Other Panamanian companies may also be involved.

headline: G.E.-Fanuc Joint Venture
abstract: The General Electric Company, the giant electric and television concern, moved further into factory automation today by announcing a $200 million joint venture with Fanuc Ltd. of Japan. The G.E. Fanuc Automation   Corporation will be based in Charlottesville, with three operating units: G.E. Fanuc Automation Europe S.A. in Luxembourg, Fanuc G.E. Automation Asia Ltd. in Japan and G.E. Fanuc Automation North   America Inc., Charlottesville.

headline: Stake in Seabrook
abstract: Eastern Utilities Associates said its new EUA Power Corporation unit had completed the previously announced purchase of 12.2 percent of the Seabrook nuclear power project in Seabrook, N.H., for a total of $173.7 million. It said it had paid $133.2 million for the plant and $40.5 million for fuel and would raise $225 million in financing.

headline: I.B.M. AND HITACHI IN NEW ACCORD
abstract: Setting aside a bitter four-year dispute, the International Business Machines Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. said today that they had reached an agreement that apparently eases the penalties imposed against Hitachi for its theft of I.B.M. technology.   Neither company would give details of the accord, which replaces an eight-year agreement reached in 1983 after Hitachi officials pleaded guilty to charges that they had stolen I.B.M. computer designs and software. Industry officials, however, said today that under the new agreement Hitachi's payments to I.B.M., currently reported to total $3 million to $6 million a month, would now be vastly reduced.

headline: Teaching the Teachers in Black Schools
abstract: BY any measure, black education in South Africa is in crisis. In 1984, only 11.3 percent of graduating secondary school students scored well enough on matriculation exams to qualify for admission to universities, down from 14.9 percent four years before, according to the Department of Education and Training. Violent pressure from radical youths who tie education to an oppressive government have kept many students from schools in Soweto and other black townships. And most black teachers are sorely underqualified: One recent survey determined that 80 percent of black secondary school teachers had themselves never received the equivalent of a high school diploma.

headline: SOVIET EMIGRE FAMILY ARRIVES IN ISRAEL IN THE LEUKEMIA CASE
abstract: Inessa Flerov arrived here today after an eight-month struggle with the Soviet Government for the right to emigrate. She wants to give her bone marrow to a leukemia-stricken brother, Michael Shirman, who lives in Israel.

headline: Norman Lear Acquires A Second Magazine
abstract: Norman Lear's Act III Communications has acquired a majority interest in Marketing and Media Decisions magazine.   The cash deal brings to two the publications owned by the prominent TV producer.

headline: Cavities? Just Wash Them Away
abstract: EVERY dental patient has a dream: that cavities could simply be washed away and that the torture of the drill and even the annoyance of the anesthesia could be forever done away with.   Now a chemical process for removing tooth decay is bringing this dream closer to reality. The process, which has already ended the need for anesthesia and drilling for many, is known as the Caridex Caries Removal System, and was introduced in the United States last February. Last month it became available in Europe.

headline: A Rise in Working Rigs
abstract: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose to 910 this week from 874 last week, Hughes Tools Company officials said. It marked the fourth consecutive weekly increase. A year ago, the count stood at 1,942, the officials said.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT PLANS NEW PRESS RESTRICTIONS
abstract: South Africa's information chief said today that the Government was planning sweeping new steps to restrict news reports about unrest in this country.   The new regulations will be promulgated in a Government gazette on Thursday, said the information chief, Stoffel van der Merwe.   The new measures, critics said, seemed designed to insure blanket censorship. ''An intolerable and dangerous situation must arise,'' the South African Catholic Bishop's Conference said in a statement.

headline: An Argentine Court Upholds Convictions of 5 Ex-Leaders
abstract: The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the convictions of five former military junta members accused of complicity in the torture and killing of thousands of political prisoners.   But the court, on a vote of 4 to 1, slightly reduced the prison sentences of two of the defendants, former President Roberto Viola and Orlando Agosti, former commander of the air force.

headline: U.S. SAYS IT BRIEFLY DELAYED CONTRA CASE OVER HOSTAGES
abstract: Justice Department officials said today that the department had briefly delayed an investigation into private schemes to aid Nicaraguan rebels because of concern that the inquiry would jeopardize negotiations to free American hostages in Lebanon.   Two law enforcement officials said the Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed to halt its inquiry for about 10 days at the request of Stephen S. Trott, the No. 3 official at the Justice Department. The request was made several weeks ago, the officials said.   Lawmakers said the disclosures raised serious questions about whether senior Justice Department officials had advance knowledge of ties between support for the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras, and efforts to release the hostages.

headline: LEADERSHIP TRADE DELAYED IN ISRAEL
abstract: The job switch between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, which was scheduled for today, was postponed at least until Wednesday because of quarreling between the Labor Party and Likud bloc over Cabinet appointments.   The Parliament vote of confidence in Mr. Shamir has been tentatively rescheduled Wednesday afternoon. Until then, Mr. Peres remains the caretaker Prime Minister.

headline: Real Estate; Mineola's Mini-Boom In Building
abstract: MINEOLA, the Nassau County seat, is experiencing a small building boom.   The village was named the county seat at the turn of the century, when Nassau and Queens Counties were divided. As the location of the county executive's offices, government agencies and the court system, Mineola long ago emerged as an important office area for Long Island, attracting not only law firms and companies that serve the legal profession but also banks and branch offices of major national companies. The village, however, saw its last speculative office building open more than three years ago.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1986
abstract: The World    A crippled Soviet submarine sank in the Atlantic in 18,000 feet of water 1,200 miles east of New York. Moscow said the crew had been evacuated to Soviet vessels. The Pentagon said the nuclear craft was carrying 16 ballistic missiles.  [ A1:6. ]    A split over arms controls between House Democrats and President Reagan will not occur this year, the House majority leader, Jim Wright, said. He said the Democrats were ready to delay a resolution of five arms-control issues to avoid hindering Mr. Reagan at meetings with Mikhail S. Gorvachev.  [ A1:1. ]

headline: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
abstract: To the Editor:   The official data David M. Kotz used to describe the existing inequality of household incomes are virtually worthless (''How Many Billionaires Are Enough?'' Forum, Oct. 19). Because the data are obtained by self-reporting, they contain large errors.

headline: Control Data Registers Offering
abstract: The Control Data Corporation has registered for the previously announced initial public offering of 38 million common shares of its financial services unit, the Commercial Credit Company. In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Control Data said it plans to sell 32.3 million shares of the Baltimore-based concern in the United States and 5.7 milllion shares overseas for estimated prices ranging from $21 to $24 a share.

headline: State Dept. Aides Criticize Ransom
abstract: A Texas billionaire's revelation that he was asked by a White House aide to put up $2 million as ransom for the release of four Americans in Lebanon was described by senior State Department officials today as further evidence that White House officials were ready to violate the Administration's anti-terrorism policy to free the hostages.   The officials said that the ransom plan was only the most obvious sign that the Iran operation in the White House, run largely by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, was principally geared to freeing hostages and that the other reasons given by President Reagan, such as seeking an opening to moderates in Iran, were secondary.   ''From the moment that the President agreed to supply arms to Iran it was always apparent to us that the driving motivation was to free the hostages,'' one senior official said. ''The ransom plan was just a logical extension of the supply of arms.''

headline: BRITISH SAY THEY HEARD SYRIAN ENVOY DISCUSS PLOT
abstract: British intelligence agents were able to eavesdrop directly on conversations verifying the complicity of the Syrian Ambassador in the plot to bomb an Israeli airliner, Government officials asserted today.   The intelligence gathered from this source and others was an underlying factor in the Thatcher Government's decision to break relations with Syria on Friday and cite ''conclusive evidence'' that Syrian diplomats and intelligence agents were involved in the attempted bombing of the El Al jet.   In taking the action, the Government implicitly disclosed how intensively the agents of its MI-5 security service have been focusing and eavesdropping on the Syrian Embassy.   In another development, the Foreign Office today ordered the Syrian Embassy to close within seven days, not the 14 it originally granted. The move came after Syria's decision on closing the British Embassy in Damascus.

headline: WITH IRAQIS AT THE FRONT: ESPRIT LOOKS STRONG
abstract: Presumably they complain, or else they would be among the few soldiers in history not to exercise that right. But even after six years of war, the morale of Iraq's soldiers appears to be reasonably good.   Most foreign military attaches here hold this view to some extent. Any such assessment, however, needs the qualification that Iraqi society is close to impenetrable to foreigners, and in-depth surveys are hardly possible.

headline: Raisa Gorbachev Appointed To a Cultural Fund in Soviet
abstract: Raisa M. Gorbachev, the wife of the Soviet leader, has been elected to the governing body of a new cultural organization, the newspaper Sovetskaya Kultura said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1986
abstract: International OPEC agreed to cut production and raise prices to $18 a barrel. The accord, signed early this morning by all of the group's members except Iraq, calls for across-the-board reductions in output of more than 7 percent for the first half of 1986. A key question about the agreement is whether the group will maintain enough discipline to defend a fixed price.  [ Page 1. ]  Prices of crude oil and petroleum products fluctuated in frenetic trading on world markets.  [ 41. ]  Brazilians were cheered by the agreement of 17 government creditors to negotiate their nation's outstanding debts without insisting on a prior agreement with the I.M.F.  [ 39. ]  China's Government plans to reduce the $8.1 billion it spends on subsidizing food for its 200 million city dwellers. China buys 50 million to 60 million tons of grain a year from its farmers under contract, about 15 percent of its total harvest.  [ 38 ]  Markets The ''triple witching hour'' produced frantic trading in the final half hour on the New York Stock Exchange. The number of orders that piled up for execution at the closing bell produced the busiest minute ever for the stock exchange, one in which more than 85 million shares traded. In all, almost 244.7 million shares traded on the Big Board, topping the previous record of 240.5 million set on Sept. 12. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 1,928.85, a 16.03-point gain for the day and a 16.59-point advance for the week.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association elected Eldon C. Hanes chairman and Raymond A. Lein president and a director.    * Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, a bottler, appointed H. Richard Hiller Jr. senior vice president and Thomas D. Sherman general counsel, secretary and vice president.

headline: Transworld 2-Part Sale
abstract: The Transworld Corporation is selling $250 million of notes and debentures, in two parts. Underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: VIEW IN CONGRESS ON TALKS IS MIXED
abstract: Initial Congressional reaction tonight to the failure of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reach agreement on nuclear arms control was mixed.   Some Democrats blamed the President for refusal to compromise on his missile defense program and some Republicans praised him for avoiding what they called a Soviet trap.   Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations committee, spoke out in Mr. Reagan's defense, saying the meeting was a ''Soviet trap to put the United States in perpetual jeopardy of the remaining intercontinental ballistic missiles.'' 'Did Not Blink'    ''The President did not blink,'' Mr. Lugar said, adding that he acted in an imaginative and proper way to ''preserve the defense of our country.''

headline: PATENTS; Correcting the Position Of a Satellite
abstract: A satellite communications system patented this week for the RCA Corporation provides for examination of radio transmissions to ground stations, so that any error in the pointing of a satellite antenna can be corrected.

headline: S.E.C. Defends Figures
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied published reports that Ivan F. Boesky's insider trading profits totaled more than $200 million.   ''Those reports are inaccurate,'' said Gary G. Lynch, the S.E.C.'s director of enforcement, in an interview. ''Fifty million dollars represents our best ballpark estimate of the profits realized by Boesky based on Levine tips.'' Dennis B. Levine, a former Wall Street investment banker, was charged last May in a $12.6 million insider trading scheme.

headline: ORDER TO BYPASS CONGRESS ON IRAN CALLED C.I.A. IDEA
abstract: Government officials said today that the Central Intelligence Agency originally proposed the idea of keeping the Iran arms sale secret from Congress. They said the agency took the unusual step in the first draft of what became a Presidential order guiding the program.   The decision not to tell Congress was a crucial step in the Iran affair, according to Administration officials, because it meant that the entire operation had to be run outside normal channels.   The issue of what one official termed an ''off the books'' covert action has become significant because the Defense Department and the State Department were largely kept in the dark about the program, and even C.I.A. officials have testified to Congress that they knew little about the details. C.I.A. Contingency Fund    One result of keeping the matter from Congress was that the agency's multimillion-dollar contingency fund could not be used to underwrite the arms. The C.I.A. is barred by law from spending any money not appropriated by Congress.

headline: People
abstract: * Garry Gassel has been named a partner in Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

headline: Times Mirror Lifts Net 15.4%
abstract: The Times Mirror Company today reported a third-quarter profit rise of 15.4 percent, partly due to the sale of The Dallas Times Herald.

headline: Action Urged On People Deal
abstract: The Justice Department has urged quick approval of Texas Air Corporation's acquisition of People Express Inc., suggesting that Government delay might ''force People into bankruptcy and even scuttle'' the deal.   The Transportation Department has final say over whether to approve the acquisition, and a department spokesman said Friday the request from the two airlines for expeditious consideration remains under review.   Earlier last week, People Express told the department that it needs to have its deal with Texas Air approved by Tuesday or it would not be able to pay $13.4 million in interest on debt, which is due Wednesday.

headline: U.S. SPY ARRESTED, NICARAGUANS SAY
abstract: A United States citizen has been arrested at an airbase in northern Nicaragua and is being held on suspicion that he was spying, the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann said today.   Mr. d'Escoto told a news conference that the American, identified by his United States passport as Sam Nesley Hall, 49 years old, of Dayton, Ohio, was captured yesterday inside an air base at Punta Huete, north of Managua.   Mr. d'Escoto said Mr. Hall first identified himself as a writer interested in Nicaragua, but then told the Nicaraguan authorities that he was a member of the ''Phoenix Battalion.''

headline: Westinghouse, NBC in Talks
abstract: Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc. and the National Broadcasting Company, two of the oldest names in radio, are discussing merging 20 of their 21 radio stations and the NBC Radio Networks, executives at the two companies said Thursday.

headline: U.S. Offers Conrail Plan
abstract: The Department of Transportation today outlined its process for selection of brokerage houses to handle the sale of the Government's 85 precent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.   Sale of the Conrail stock, expected to begin in the spring, would produce an estimated $80 million in commissions for stockbrokers.

headline: Big Pistachio Crop Seen
abstract: The California pistachio crop is forecast at a record 70 million pounds, more than two and a half times last year's harvest, the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service said.

headline: FAIRNESS STRESSED BY NATION'S PRESS
abstract: On the day after President Reagan's Nov. 25 revelation that money from arms sales to Iran had been diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, the editor of The Chicago Tribune interrupted a news meeting with his staff to make what he called ''a speech.''   James D. Squires, the editor, said that ''when history looks back at this event,'' he wanted The Tribune's coverage to be ''cautious, fair, and honest from the beginning.''   Such special sensitivity to fairness, and to being perceived as fair, is a topic of almost daily discussion in the newsrooms of many of the country's largest news organizations, according to a spot check.   While many editors say their concern for fairness was already established and has not changed, many also report a heightened attentiveness to established standards.

headline: IRAN DENIES RESPONSIBILITY IN HIJACKING OF IRAQI JET
abstract: Amid a flurry of conflicting claims of responsibility by anonymous callers, Iran yesterday dismissed accusations by Iraq and Jordan that it was behind the hijacking of an Iraqi airliner in which Saudi Arabia has said 62 people were killed.   The Iranian statement, reported in a state radio broadcast that was monitored in Cyprus, was issued as callers claiming to speak for four different groups said they were responsible.   The Iraqi Airways Boeing 737 crashed in a remote desert region in northern Saudi Arabia Thursday after being commandeered by armed men who, according to witnesses, subsequently battled with security men as the crew struggled to control the plane.   Government sources in Amman said the gunmen confessed to Saudi interrogators that they had planned to take the plane to Damascus and on to Teheran. But the Saudi Government, which provided the first official announcement of the crash, remained silent about the hijacking, and questions remained about many aspects of the disaster, including the number of people on board the flight, the number who died or were injured, the number of hijackers involved, and to what group, if any, they were linked.

headline: MISSILES FOR IRAN LINKED TO THE ARMY IN EUROPE
abstract: The military commander of NATO indicated today that there was circumstantial evidence that some of the American arms sold secretly to Iran might have been taken from Army stocks in Europe.   The commander, Gen. Bernard D. Rogers, who heads North Atlantic Treaty forces in Europe, made the point in an appearance before the House Armed Services Committee.   When asked whether the weapons had been taken from Army stocks in Europe, he paused for a long time and said, ''Maybe.''   ''I said 'maybe' because I have been advised that a member of the European Command staff said that the U.S. Army had been directed to return just over 2,000 TOW missiles to the United States,'' he said.

headline: DEALING WITH IRAN: HOW EXPERTS SEE IT
abstract: President Reagan's decision to authorize unpublicized talks with Iranian officials and send them some weapons and spare parts has touched off a major dispute involving United States foreign policy and has prompted a heated debate that has transcended the usual partisan divisions in Washington. Mr. Reagan has angrily denied reports that he traded arms for American hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militants. Many of his critics challenge this assertion. Some experts who have followed the United States-Iran relationship, ranging from former Directors of Central Intelligence to scholars, were asked these questions: Is it good or bad to trade military supplies for hostages? What are the pros and cons of making such overtures to the Iranians? And what are the prospects for the United States to restore and improve its ruptured relations with Iran? Here are excerpts from their replies:  SHAUL BAKHASH  Professor of Government George Mason University    For the U.S. Government that has made the foundation of its policy not to bargain with hostage-takers, trading arms for hostages is not a very wise policy. It encourages further hostage-taking; it sends the wrong signals to America's allies, and it suggests that the U.S. Government has not been straightforward with its own people.

headline: NASDAQ SHORT INTEREST DOWN BY 2.8%
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks was down 6.5 million shares, or 2.8 percent, in the month ended Dec. 15, to 206.4 million shares.   The short interest figures for Nasdaq stocks reflect the total number of shares sold short by N.A.S.D. members and their customers.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and a lower price.   The following companies show large changes:

headline: Owens-Corning Sets Debentures
abstract: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation is offering $300 million of 11 3/4 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 2001 at a price of par, through Goldman, Sachs & Company as agent.   The issue, rated B-3 by Moody's and B by S.&P., may be redeemed by the company in 1991. A $60 million annual sinking-fund payment beginning in 1997 will retire 80 percent of the issue before maturity.

headline: The U.N. Today: Nov. 13, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.   Pledging Conference for Development Activities - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Turning the PC Into Speed Reader
abstract: CONVERTING traditional, typed data into something a computer can digest is shaping up as a major problem in the age of personal computers. The quandary will probably lead to the greatest cleanout of files American business has ever seen. Information not crucial may sit around gathering dust for a few more years before ending up unread in the dumpster. However, there are a lot of corporate records to which this easy solution simply cannot be applied.   I have one document, an unpublished novel, it might well be worth my while to convert. I have never gotten around to entering its 300 pages via the keyboard, daunted by the sheer time-consuming nature of the task. But not long ago I received for possible review a PCS Model 245 text scanner ($3,995 from CompuScan, Fairfield, N.J., 07006, (201) 575-0500). Designed to handle the paper-to-electronic transformation almost single-handedly, this device is intended to supplant weary fingers.

headline: POL POT MYSTERY: ILLNESS AND CONFLICT
abstract: Thai military officials and some Cambodian exiles are saying that Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, is terminally ill in China, but that a power struggle within his organization may be holding up statements about his condition.   According to the Thai reports, Mr. Pol Pot, who is 58 years old, was evacuated to Beijing from the Thai-Cambodian border area in September.   The Khmer Rouge, the Communist movement that ruled Cambodia from April 1975 to January 1979, denies that Mr. Pol Pot is gravely ill. No one has reported seeing the former Cambodian leader in China.

headline: Anti-Apartheid Boycotts Close School for Blacks
abstract: A high school financed by American companies to help South African blacks enter the business world has closed because of anti-apartheid boycotts, an American spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Kenneth Mason, said he hoped to negotiate with parents, students and community leaders on a future for the school that would allow it to reorganize and reopen at the start of the new school year in January.   The school, Planned Advancement for Commercial Education, was built in 1982 in Soweto, Johannesburg's huge black satellite. Mr. Mason said the school fell victim to boycotts of black schools enforced by ''comrades,'' a term used to describe young anti-apartheid militants.

headline: UNDER CLAUSEN'S REIGN, BANK'S ASSETS SURGED
abstract: A. W. Clausen will be on familiar ground if, as expected, he is named this weekend to succeed Samuel H. Armacost as president and chief executive officer of the troubled BankAmerica.   The 63-year-old Minnesota native spent his entire career at the bank, including 11 years at its helm, before turning over the reins to Mr. Armacost and moving to Washington to become head of the World Bank in 1981. He saw the bank's assets soar during the time he was in command.

headline: A Premium on Prompt Action
abstract: AS if successful investing were ever as easy as it may seem to the uninitiated, the most sweeping tax-overhaul legislation in American history has just made the job even harder. The new tax code calls for a comprehensive rethinking of one's entire strategy - and puts a premium on prompt action. And, compounding the difficulty, it will bring profound, largely unpredictable changes in the $4 trillion United States economy.   This is a tough combination of challenges for investors, and no amount of computer-power can meaningfully forecast how an almost infinite number of forces will play out as the new law unleashes a shower of unintended consequences, as well as many others that are largely unquantifiable.   Alan Greenspan, the respected New York economist who served as chief economic adviser to President Gerald R. Ford, maintains that the new law probably contains ''10 or 20 major mistakes'' that, for the sake of the economy or of fairness will have to be rectified with additional legislation.

headline: PATENTS; Mixer Alters Air in Bid To Keep Insects Away
abstract: An air mixer patented this week by John A. Paoluccio, a consulting mechanical engineer in Salida, Calif., is said to prevent insects from finding humans.

headline: REAGAN FRIENDS SAID TO ASK CHANGES
abstract: Some longtime political supporters of President Reagan have discussed how to engineer high-level staff changes at the White House and in the Cabinet in the hope of repairing political damage that he has sustained because of Washington's dealing with Iran, a close confidant of the President said today.   The confidant said the discussions stopped short of an ''organized effort'' and involved a small group of associates who have been involved for many years in Mr. Reagan's political career.   ''It's a tough time and a difficult time for the President,'' the confidant said. ''Anxiety is high, particularly among the old friends.''

headline: U.S. TO END ITS SOVIET NICKEL BAN
abstract: The United States plans to end its three-year-old ban on imports of Soviet nickel, and both Washington and Moscow will intensify efforts to help American companies obtain more Soviet business, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.   The announcement of improving commercial relations between the two countries came after a meeting here this week of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Joint Commercial Commission, a body set up by the two Governments during a thaw in relations in 1972.   The Soviet Foreign Trade Minister, Boris I. Aristov, who headed the Soviet delegation, said at a news conference that ''we would like to increase trade three and four times with you.'' He described trade as ''one of the oldest professions'' and the sector ''where confidence between our two nations can be achieved easier than in other fields.''

headline: DANILOFF HAS AN EMOTIONAL HOMECOMING
abstract: Nicholas S. Daniloff was reunited with his children and colleagues from U.S. News & World Report today in an emotional homecoming at Dulles Airport outside Washington.   Mr. Daniloff and his wife, Ruth, cheered as their Pan American World Airways flight from West Germany touched down in Washington and they jumped to their feet, embracing each other and Henry Trewhitt, a deputy managing editor of U.S. News who spent the last two weeks in Moscow with them.   Mrs. Daniloff shouted, ''We made it, we made it!''   Mr. Daniloff waved his arms over his head as he descended a ramp from the plane.

headline: Iraq Reports 14 Dead In Iranian Raid on Basra
abstract: Iraq said 14 people were killed and 66 wounded today when Iran bombed the port of Basra in retaliation for two days of Iraqi attacks on an Iranian refinery city that left 32 people dead.   A military communique said 26 houses, five shops and a school in Basra were destroyed.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1986
abstract: The World The State Dept. spokesman resigned in protest over what he called ''the reported disinformation program'' of the Reagan Administration against the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The spokesman, Bernard Kalb, told reporters, ''Anything that hurts America's credibility hurts America.''  [ Page A1, Column 6. ]    Reporters praised Bernard Kalb for resigning as the State Department's chief spokesman. Many journalists said they regarded the action as a demonstration of his integrity and further evidence of the existence of a disinformation program in the Administration.  [ A17:1. ]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Cutco Industries, Jericho, L.I., said its investment banker, Montgomery Scott Inc., had found the proposed $5-a-share leveraged buyout offer by its chairman, Marvin W. Marcus, and its president, Don Von Liebermann, to be too low.    * Deere & Company, Moline, Ill., which this week reported its first annual loss in 53 years, has halved the cash dividend on its common stock to 6.25 cents a share, from 12.5 cents.    * Diamond Shamrock Corp., Dallas, completed the previously announced sale of its South African unit to Tiger Oats Ltd., a South African company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ashton-Tate, a software company based in Torrance, Calif., said Ronald S. Posner, executive vice president and general manager of the systems, service and information division, had resigned. Richard DeGiovanni was named acting general manager of the division.

headline: Nomura Fills U.S. Jobs
abstract: The Nomura Securities Company, the world's largest securities firm, announced in Tokyo yesterday that its board had nominated Masaaki Kurokawa to serve as chairman, and Katsuya Takanashi as president, of Nomura Securities International, the firm's American subsidiary. The announcement, which had been expected, is subject to shareholder confirmation on Dec. 19. Mr. Kurokawa will succeed Yoshio Terasawa as chairman. Mr. Takanashi will replace Akira Shimuzu as president. The subsidiary is based in New York City.

headline: AMERICA AND THE CATHOLIC CHURCH: CONFLICTS WITH ROME AND WITHIN
abstract: Long before it was popular to do so, a Roman Catholic clergyman from the United States favored celebrating mass in English instead of Latin, the election of the leadership of the American church by its own priests instead of its appointment by Rome, and a strong role for the laity.   The man in question was not a latter-day Catholic dissident, but John Carroll, the first Catholic Bishop of the United States, elected by his fellow clergymen in 1789. Pope Pius VI agreed to leave the choice to them, which was not unusual at the time.   The story of Bishop Carroll underlines the unusual role that America has played in the Roman Catholic Church and the fact that conflicts today between Rome and elements of the American church are not new. Genuine Conflicts    The recent struggles have been bitter, however, dividing the American church itself. And despite the insistence of some American bishops that differences between Rome and American Catholics are exaggerated, Vatican officials say the conflicts are genuine and have an importance that transcends the United States.

headline: Advertising; Ogilvy and Grey Widen Net Income Slightly
abstract: The Ogilvy Group and Grey Advertising reported their third-quarter earnings Friday.

headline: Options Seem Fewer For Beneficial's Head
abstract: Finn M. W. Caspersen is a busy chief executive these days. The head of the Beneficial Corporation has been trying to sell the company before the year ends to take advantage of better treatment under the tax laws.   But apparently no bidders interested in committing themselves before year-end have been found. And the company has canceled a special stockholders meeting at which liquidation was to have been considered.

headline: GUILTY PLEA IN MORGAN CASE SEEN
abstract: A former top officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company will plead guilty in Federal court today, according to his lawyer, on charges of having made $4.3 million in unauthorized withdrawals from Brazilian depositors' accounts.   The former officer, Antonio Gebauer, will also plead guilty to having made $2.9 million in unauthorized loans to the Brazilian accounts to help cover up the withdrawals, said Stanley S. Arkin, the attorney representing Mr. Gebauer. The pleas would settle criminal charges; no civil cases against Mr. Gebauer are pending.   Mr. Gebauer headed Morgan's Latin American lending operations from 1981 to 1983. When he resigned from the bank in August 1985, he was responsible for maintaining relationships with chief executives of industrial companies in Latin America.

headline: SOVIET SEEKS TO JOIN WITH WEST AGAINST TERRORISM
abstract: The Soviet Union has begun telling some Western European governments that it is prepared to join forces in combating terrorism, according to highly placed West German officials.   Some experts detect Soviet concern that it and its allies are becoming overly identified with terrorist movements - and that terrorist organizations could pose long-term problems for Soviet interests.   One senior West German official said that two recent trials in London and West Berlin, suggesting strongly that Syrian intelligence agents were embroiled in terrorist outrages, had prompted the latest overture, which he said had taken place in Moscow several weeks ago.

headline: Canada to Aid Brand Drugs
abstract: Canadian pharmaceutical manufacturers pledged millions of dollars in new investment last Friday as a result of a Federal Government promise to act to protect brand-name drug makers from generic competition.   Legislation, which would prevent generic drug makers from making no-name copies of brand-name drugs for 10 years, was introduced last June and reintroduced last Thursday during the new session of Parliament.

headline: Careers; The Lure Of Investor Relations
abstract: IN a bustling period of mergers, leveraged buyouts and other competition for capital, there is a growing need for people skilled at investor relations.   This job typically calls for encouraging stockholders to keep the company's shares and persuading Wall Street financial analysts, banks and mutual funds to take an interest. Companies often require infusions of capital through loans or stock sales. If their shares are fairly priced in relation to current or future expectations, they have a better chance to raise money.

headline: Chase Lowers All Card Rates
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the country's third-largest issuer of credit cards, said yesterday that it would reduce the annual percentage rate on all of its cards by as much as 3.3 points.   Several smaller financial institutions have reduced credit card rates and fees in the last six months, but Chase is the largest issuer to announce across-the-board reductions.

headline: Company Sold For 49 Cents
abstract: West German labor unions today sold a union-owned, debt-burdened real estate concern for one mark, or the equivalent of 49 cents, to a Berlin bakery owner.   The concern, Neue Heimat, or new homeland, owns about 190,000 homes across Germany.

headline: Stocks Up as Volume Falls
abstract: With trading volume plunging to its lowest level in nearly two years, Wall Street yesterday sleepwalked its way through a session of slightly higher stock prices.   Monday was the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur as well as Columbus Day, and that was enough to keep attendance way down in the financial district of Manhattan.   ''I went out for lunch today for the first time this year,'' said Jack Baker, the head trader at Shearson Lehman Brothers, who added that even the restaurants were empty.

headline: Treasury Issues Up Modestly
abstract: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, with most of the gains coming in the last few hours of trading, after a day of generally light activity.   While many investors and traders in the Treasury market were content to wait for fresh banking and economic statistics to be released later this week, securities dealers said they continued to make progress in distributing recently auctioned Treasury notes and bonds.   Investor activity has been strongest, securities firms said, in the corporate and mortgage securities market, where yields are much greater than on Treasury issues. Underwriters said sales were strong for several new corporate issues yesterday.

headline: Airbus Engine Deal For 3-Nation Group
abstract: Airbus Industrie, the European plane manufacturing consortium, said today that it had chosen a jet engine designed by a group of American, British and Japanese engine makers to power its planned A340 long-haul airliner.   Airbus said the proposed aircraft would be powered by four V2500 superfan engines made by International Aero Engines, a group formed by Rolls-Royce of Britain, Pratt & Whitney of the United States and Aero Engines of Japan. CFM International, which was formed by the General Electric Company and Snecma, the French state-owned jet engine maker, had also bid for the contract.

headline: Meese Finds No News in His Inquiry
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he had not ''seen anything'' to contradict his original finding that only Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North knew of the diversion of Iranian arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels.   Mr. Meese, speaking at a news conference after testifying under oath for five hours before the Senate Intelligence Committee, said he had no evidence that any official other than Colonel North took part in the diversion.   ''So far, I have not seen anything that would provide evidence different from what we originally found,'' he said.

headline: SOME AT FIRST INTERSTATE PREFER TO AVOID A FIGHT
abstract: Several directors of the First Interstate Bancorp appear to be against a hostile tender offer to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation and a proxy fight to try to unseat BankAmerica's board.   Four of the company's 14 outside directors, all of whom asked to remain anonymous, said today in interviews that they would strongly prefer to avoid a hostile takeover.   ''This isn't going to be a street fight,'' one director said.   ''My view is that would be a very last resort,'' said another, referring to a hostile effort. ''I can't really conceive of that happening, just knowing management'' of First Interstate, he added.

headline: India Seeks Carbide Order
abstract: The Indian Government today asked an Indian court to bar the Union Carbide Corporation from destroying evidence relating to the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PRETORIA ORDERS A 'SWOOP' ON FOES IN SECURITY MOVE
abstract: A day after South Africa drastically tightened controls on political expression and news reporting, the police announced today that they had carried out a series of actions against their adversaries.   President P. W. Botha said the steps were designed to head off an impending increase in what it called revolutionary violence.   What the police termed a ''swoop'' was reported to have included a cross-border raid into Swaziland that led to the abduction and detention of two foreigners sympathetic to the Government's black foes. Labor Federation Affected    South Africa's state-run television reported tonight that the police responsible for black townships east of Johannesburg imposed sweeping restrictions on various anti-apartheid movements.

headline: Japanese Investment Expands
abstract: Every month lately, the Japanese embassy has been sending around lists of ''Milestones of Progress in U.S.-Japan Economic Relations.'' The lists summarize investments, joint ventures and licensing and distribution agreements by the two countries' industries.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1986
abstract: International    Canada imposed a duty on American corn, the first penalty of its kind imposed on the U.S. by any nation. The duty would amount to about 70 percent of the current corn price. It was imposed in response to complaints by growers in Ontario that U.S. farm policies provided an unfair subsidy. The Reagan Administration, which recently put a 15 percent duty on Canadian lumber imports, said it was ''dismayed'' by the corn decision.  [ Page 37. ]    Talks between the Philippines and its bank creditors collapsed. The Philippines negotiators said a single bank's ''intransigence'' led to the breakdown. Sources said that bank was Citibank and that it had refused to consider allowing the Philippines the same loan repayment terms recently given Mexico.  [ 37. ]

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: ''I waited two years for this performance. I have sung Tosca maybe 140 times all over the world.

headline: GETTING FIRED ISN'T WHAT IT USED TO BE
abstract: ''Sacked: Why Good People Get Fired and How to Avoid It,'' by Richard Gould. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., N.Y. 202 pages, $18.95. LEE Iacocca's success at Chrysler after he was fired as president of the Ford Motor Company - not to mention his boasting about it in his best-selling autobiography - has helped remove some of the stigma of dismissal. But it has not eliminated the myths surrounding firings.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of electrical appliances and personal care products, has named Edward B. Harmon senior staff vice president and associate general counsel.    * Converse Inc., North Reading, Mass., a maker of athletic footwear, has named Gilbert Ford president. Mr. Ford succeeds John P. O'Neil, who is retiring in December.

headline: BIDDING RISE SEEN FOR TEXAS BANKS
abstract: Chemical New York's agreement to acquire Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. for $1.1 billion is likely to touch off fresh bidding for other Texas banks, according to several banking analysts who predicted that more takeover announcements were possible within weeks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp in New York, and First Interstate and Security Pacific in Los Angeles, are known to be exploring takeovers in Texas, the nation's third most populous state. So are NCNB and First Union, both of Charlotte, N.C.   Allied Bancshares of Houston, with nearly $10 billion in assets and a comparatively strong retail network and solid loan portfolio, is considered the most likely candidate, said Frank W. Anderson, a bank analyst at Ferguson & Company in Dallas. ''We will see future transactions,'' he said.   The bidding for Texas banks comes at a time when their loan portfolios are burdened with problems in the energy, agriculture and real estate industries.

headline: Advertising; A Camera Victory For Bloom
abstract: THE Bloom Agency, New York, won the Pentax camera business by beating Ally Gargano/ MCA of New York, Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis and Foote, Cone & Belding of San Francisco. Sort of a coast-to-coast victory.

headline: Cashing In On Changes In Currencies
abstract: LAST March, Bret J. Davis, 31 years old, decided to change his investment strategy. Mr. Davis, a director of a medical laboratory in Brooklyn, who had previously dabbled in I.B.M. and some other blue-chip stocks, as well as a domestic mutual fund, moved everything to the Fidelity Overseas Fund, a mutual fund that currently is heavily invested in Japanese securities.   Since the move, he has seen a 30 percent rise in the value of his original investment. ''It's like having the best of both worlds,'' he said. ''I live and work in America. But if the outlook is better for yen-denominated investments, I come out ahead.''

headline: ISRAELI JETS RAID SOUTHERN LEBANON
abstract: Israeli warplanes attacked suspected Palestinian guerrilla bases near the southern Lebanese port of Sidon today, and a Palestinian statement said there had been many casualties and extensive damage to property.   The police said two fighter-bombers had dropped bombs and rockets on hilltops at Darb al Sim, which overlooks the sprawling Palestinian district of Ain Kilweh at Sidon's southern edge.   Ain Kilweh has been a target of repeated Israeli strikes from the air and sea because it is believed to hold the largest concentration of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas.

headline: DREXEL 'JUNK BOND' WIZARD...
abstract: When a relatively unknown corporate official needed money recently to acquire a company, he did what many others have done before him. He traveled to the mecca of ''junk bonds'' - also known as the Beverly Hills office of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   There, after a half-hour screening process performed by several Drexel functionaries, he was granted an ''audience,'' in his words, with Michael R. Milken, the 40-year-old Drexel senior vice president and wizard of the junk bond market.   It was Mr. Milken who, a decade ago, helped pioneer the market for junk bonds, the below-investment-grade securities corporate raiders find essential in cornering their prey. A Personal Fortune    And it was Mr. Milken, who, over those years, has parlayed his knowledge of junk bonds, of corporate takeover strategies and of investment banking into a personal fortune that some estimate to be as high as $500 million, while also arguably making Drexel Burnham the most important force in the very visible, highly lucrative corporate takeover game.

headline: BRITISH SEE TRADE THREAT
abstract: Huge Japanese trade surpluses and record American defictis seriously threaten the world's free trade system, Britain's top trade official said today.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $374.6 million, to $234.98 billion, for the week ending Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. All three fund categories showed slight gains. Assets of the 92 institutional funds rose $184.6 million, to $66.47 billion; assets of the 191 general-purpose funds gained $128.5 million, to $64.05 billion, and the 92 broker-dealer funds increased by $61.5 million, to $104.45 billion.

headline: RIGHTS GROUP DEPICTS ARMY ABUSES IN LIBERIA
abstract: Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian President, ''has sanctioned an undercurrent of lawlessness and random brutality'' by the military since he took power in 1980, a New York-based human rights group said last week.   On the anniversary of an unsuccessful coup attempt last Nov. 12, the group, the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, issued a 175-page report that described hundreds of instances of summary executions by soldiers as well as abuses involving arson, looting, rape and dismemberment of bodies of slain rebels.   The report also quoted several people who said they witnessed acts of cannibalism. The accounts said Government soldiers ate the bodies of the leaders of the unsuccessful coup attempt.

headline: Kodak Price Rise
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would raise prices on most of its consumer and professional photo products, including all Kodacolor film formats, effective Jan. 24. A Kodak spokesman, Henry K. Kaska, said the increases would range from 3 percent to 6 percent. Prices on photographic paper will increase, Kodak said, but photofinishing charges and videotape prices will remain the same.

headline: The Rise of the 'No Frills' Convention
