abstract: COMPARED to the annual extravaganzas it used to throw, the Philip Morris Companies' corporate affairs conference last month was positively austere. The refrigerators in attendees' rooms were devoid of beverages. There was no open bar at lunch, and the pre-dinner cocktail hour was only 45 minutes.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET TO STUDY WAYS TO SAVE THE OZONE
abstract: United States and Soviet officials agreed today to widen cooperation on environmental issues, including a joint effort to halt depletion of atmospheric ozone.   At a news conference after four days of meetings, Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said scientists from the two countries would meet in Moscow next month to consider what measures may be needed to halt the destruction of ozone by man-made chemicals.   Yuri A. Izrael, chairman of the Soviet State Committee for Hydrometeorology and Control of the Natural Environment, said his country did not think there was sufficient evidence yet demonstrating the need to limit production of chlorofluorocarbons and other chemicals that destroy ozone in the upper atmosphere. But in response to a question he said such evidence might be presented at next month's meeting.

headline: 43.31 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,817.21
abstract: The stock market, already stunned by the Boesky insider trading scandal, suffered a big setback yesterday, with takeover stocks pounded for the second straight day.   The Dow Jones industrial average, after challenging its highest levels ever just last week, fell 43.31 points, to 1,817.21. The plunge, which represented a 2.3 percent decline, was the fourth worst ever in points for the average.   The credit markets also were turbulent. Treasury bond prices fell sharply but some participants said the Government securities market would benefit eventually from the unfolding scandal.  [ Page D22. ]  Wall Street experts who have spent years buying and selling stocks said yesterday's market session was one of the most emotional they had ever experienced.

headline: Counting Money
abstract: To the Editor:   The wild response (Letters, Nov. 9) to David Kotz's mild suggestion to chop off some of those magnificent monetary personal accumulations was something to behold. The obscenity of inheriting millions or billions for nothing while so many inequities exist in all societies should be adjusted.

headline: NEW REVIVAL: OLD-TIME GUM
abstract: Gum chewers might remember Beemans gum, once promoted as a cure for indigestion and sea sickness. Or Clove gum, said to help drinkers disguise the rum on their breath. Or Black Jack, flavored with shredded licorice.   These are just a few of the old-time products now making a comeback as gum companies, like movie producers and all manner of other businesses, are finding it profitable to go back to the future. Other golden oldies undergoing a revival include player pianos, Barbasol shaving cream and Life magazine, products that had either experienced declining sales or been pulled from the shelf altogether.

headline: Advertising; Needham Quits Crayola Maker
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide announced Friday that it had resigned the Binney & Smith account that it worked on for two and a half years.

headline: AMERICAN IS FREED AFTER 18 MONTHS AS BEIRUT CAPTIVE
abstract: David P. Jacobsen, an American held hostage in Lebanon for nearly 18 months, was released Sunday and stopped here briefly today on his way to West Germany.   Islamic Holy War, the pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalist group that had held Mr. Jacobsen, did not say specifically why it released him. It said the United States had made moves that could lead to the release of other captives, but it gave no details.  [ In California, President Reagan hailed the release but warned that the captors would be held responsible for the safety of the six other Americans missing in Lebanon. Officials said the Administration had made no concessions to gain the hostages' freedom. Page A14. ]  Two United States Navy helicopters arrived in Larnaca this morning from Beirut, about 100 miles east of here, carrying Mr. Jacobsen and Terry Waite, the Archbishop of Canterbury's special envoy.

headline: Advertising; AIDS Center TV Spots Are Set for This Week
abstract: Public service announcements for the AIDS center at St. Clare's Hospital in New York will begin showing this week as 30- and 10-second TV spots in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with Helen Hayes as the spokesman.   Sieber & McIntyre, a New Jersey-based medical advertising agency, produced the spots with the help of LCL productions in Manhattan. A print campaign got under way yesterday.

headline: Viacom Stake
abstract: A unit of the New York-based financial services firm, Oppenheimer Group Inc., said it had increased its stake in Viacom International Inc. to the equivalent of 6.3 percent, from its previous stake of 5.3 percent, paying prices ranging from $43.75 to $44.25 a share.

headline: Top Posts Assigned For Baker Hughes
abstract: The giant oilfield services company that would be created by the proposed merger of the Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation will be run primarily by the current top management of Baker.   The new chairman of what will be known as Baker Hughes Inc. will be Earnest Hubert Clark Jr., the current Baker chairman and chief executive. W.A. Kistler Jr., chairman, president and chief executive of Hughes, will become vice chairman of Baker Hughes. J.D. Woods, who is president and chief operating officer of Baker, will become president and chief executive of the combined company.   However, sources close to the deal said Mr. Kistler would report to Mr. Woods.

headline: Cannon Extension
abstract: The Cannon Group Inc. said that the previously extended deadline for a $75 million debt payment to Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. had been extended again, through today. Those close to Cannon, an independent film producer and distributor, said the company was likely to secure the financing through bank credit with the assistance of Warner Communications Inc., which would, in return, obtain rights to some of Cannon's releases.

headline: Insurer's Japanese Plans
abstract: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the third-largest United States life insurer, will process 12,000 applications for life insurance policies with total premiums of $12 million in its first year of operation in Japan, Donald Mooney, president and chief executive officer of the Equitable Life Insurance Company Ltd., said today.

headline: AQUINO ADVISERS DISCUSS STRATEGY
abstract: With President Corazon C. Aquino and Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile on a seeming collision course, some of Mrs. Aquino's advisers said today that they were meeting to seek ways to counter the vigorous political attacks of Mr. Enrile.   They said they were eager to counter an appearance of weakness and indecisiveness in the Government.   Today, Mrs. Aquino reaffirmed her commitment to seek a peaceful end to the Communist insurgency, telling a group of nurses that her own Christian convictions led her to seek talks with her opponents rather than bloodshed.   Mrs. Aquino compared the insurgency to a lingering illness, and added, ''Should it prove to be as incurable as a cancer, then it must be removed by the more drastic surgery of warfare.''

headline: Grey's New Position
abstract: Grey Direct/West in San Francisco, which is part of Grey Advertising, is billing about $15 million and is getting its first president, David Jedele, 44 years old, who reports for duty today. He is coming in from Ogilvy & Mather Direct, where he ran its data base development. Previously he managed the London office, and before that worked 10 years for the firm in New York.

headline: A.T.&T. FIGHTS PLAN FOR RIVAL OPERATOR SERVICE
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been immersed in court battles with its former local telephone service subsidiaries over who should be the ''operator'' for long-distance calls that require assistance.   A skirmish before Judge Harold H. Greene of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia was the latest in a series of disputes to arise from a three-year-old court decree aimed at ending A.T.&T.'s monopoly over telephone service in the United States.   Under the decree, A.T.&T. was allowed to stay in the long-distance business, but it had to sell its local telephone companies. Those local companies are now owned by seven independent regional holding companies that are barred from offering long-distance service.

headline: Kenya Seizes Elephant Tusks
abstract: Custom agents seized nearly 1,000 elephant tusks valued at $250,000 Friday after finding the ivory hidden among bags of wheat at the port of Mombasa, an official said today.

headline: Grace & Rothschild Has Hospital Account
abstract: Grace & Rothschild's fourth account is Mount Sinai Hospital of New York City, which will soon be getting the first multi-media advertising campaign in its 134-year history.

headline: FOES REBUKE THATCHER FOR STAND ON IRAN AFFAIR
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was charged today with having ''severely discredited'' her Government's policy on state-sponsored terrorism by accepting President Reagan's explanation for United States arms shipments to Iran.   The accusation came from Neil Kinnock, the leader of the Labor Party, in a highly partisan debate in the House of Commons after Mrs. Thatcher made a statement on the talks she had with the President on Saturday at Camp David.   ''We share the aim of bringing Iran back into better relations with the West,'' the Prime Minister said, adding the provisos that this should be done without taking sides in the Iran-Iraq war or paying ransom for hostages.   Although her statement came closer to an endorsement of the Reagan Administration's secret diplomacy with Iran than anything she had previously said, it stopped short of approving the arms shipments.

headline: U.S. MOVES TO STAFF EMBASSY
abstract: The Government has awarded a $10 million contract to a Los Angeles-based company to furnish support staff for the United States Embassy in Moscow and the American Consulate General in Leningrad, the State Department announced today.   The Government awarded the contract to Pacific Architects and Engineers, a company with 4,500 employees that provides maintenance, operations and support staff to businesses and governments.

headline: U.S. Acts to Enhance Image After Talks
abstract: White House officials, expressing unhappiness over news accounts of President Reagan's stance in his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have begun one of the most extensive public relations efforts of the Reagan Presidency.   The officials say their goal is to reverse the emphasis of newspaper and television reports that, in their view, portrayed President Reagan's adherence to the Strategic Defense Initiative as the major reason for the leaders' failure to agree on a major arms control accord in the meeting last weekend in Iceland.   President Reagan and his key advisers today began a series of interviews and speeches that, according to White House aides, are aimed at placing the blame for the outcome on the Soviet leader.   As part of the effort to get domestic support and counter potential criticism abroad, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today that all officials would speak on the record.

headline: J. P. Morgan Sells 7.1% Notes at Par
abstract: J. P. Morgan & Company is offering $300 million of 7.1 percent notes due in 1991 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   The notes, rated triple-A, are non-callable and yield four-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

headline: Pakistani Is Gloomy On an Afghan Settlement
abstract: United Nations negotiations show ''no sign'' of achieving the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister declared today.

headline: ALEXANDER'S PLANS SHIFT TO PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Alexander's Inc. announced yesterday it would transform itself from a corporation into a limited partnership.   The conversion is part of a plan to ultimately lessen the tax consequences to its shareholders when the company carries out its previously announced decision to close its flagship store at Lexington Avenue and East 58th Street and sell the site for real estate development. But the actual conversion could have negative tax consequences for some shareholders.

headline: VOLUME DROPS
abstract: Stock prices dropped sharply and trading volume contracted yesterday as fainthearted investors held back with only two days to go before the ''triple witching hour.''   Program trading, which ordinarily occurs just before the expiration of stock index options, index futures and regular stock options, helped push equities higher both Monday and Tuesday. Yesterday, however, with the three simultaneous expirations coming tomorrow, institutional investors were more inclined to sell stocks.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 13 points on Tuesday, retreated 17.85 points yesterday, to 1,918.31. Stock prices started off the day lower, held steady during most of the middle of the session before encountering selling pressure just before the last hour of trading.

headline: RED CROSS PANEL SAYS IT FEARS THE EFFECTS OF PRETORIA ACTION
abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross said in a statement today that it ''fears strongly'' the ''serious consequences'' of South Africa's decision to expel the organization from its territory.   The move, announced late Saturday by the South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, was in retaliation for the expulsion of the Pretoria delegation from a conference here of the International Red Cross. The ouster by a majority of African, third world and Communist nations came in a hotly debated vote that overrode Western objections.

headline: COMPANY NEWS; A.T.& T. RATE CUT INCREASED BY F.C.C. ADVERTISING; City Sports In New York
abstract: The Government ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to reduce rates an additional $650 million to $700 million beyond what it had been planning, bringing a scheduled New Year's Day long-distance cut to almost $1.9 billion, or 11 percent.  The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Mark S. Fowler, said a large portion of the new reductions would come at night and on weekends and thus would benefit people who make long-distance calls from home.  A.T.&T.;'s competitors said earlier that they would reduce their long-distance rates to remain competitive. Mr. Fowler estimated that their reductions, coupled with A.T.&T.;'s cuts, would bring the total reduction in 1987 phone bills to more than $2 billion.

headline: REMARKS BY REAGAN AND GORBACHEV AFTER REYKJAVIK TALKS: MR. GORBACHEV
abstract: Following are excerpts from the statement by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, at his news conference today, as translated by Mr. Gorbachev's interpreter:   About one hour has passed since our meeting with the President of the United States of America, ended. It lasted a little more than we had expected, had planned.   Now the meeting has ended. And sometimes they say when you stand face to face with somebody you cannot see his face. So I have just left the place where we had that meeting and particularly at the last stages of that meeting, the debates were very pointed and I'm still very much under the influence of those debates. The atmosphere at the meeting was friendly. We could discuss things freely and without limitation, outlining our views as to various problems and this has made it possible for us to have a more in-depth understanding of many major issues of international politics, bilateral relations and above all, the questions of war and peace, of ending the nuclear arms race and the entire range of problems within that broad topic.   But before I characterize the substance of the discussions and proposals of the two sides and the outcome of this meeting, I would like to explain to you why is it that we put forward this initiatitve, to have this meeting.

headline: Riot at Italian Atom Plant
abstract: The police fired scores of tear-gas grenades and made repeated charges with riot sticks today to disperse hundreds of firebomb-throwing demonstrators who blocked the entrance to a nuclear energy plant 72 miles northwest of Rome.

headline: Vancouver Bank's Takeover Talks
abstract: The Bank of British Columbia, Canada's eighth-largest domestic bank, said it was holding talks about its possible takeover by a local credit union.   The bank, which has struggled to regain depositor confidence after the collapse last autumn of two small unrelated banks in western Canada, said no agreement in principle had been reached and that any agreement would need government and other regulatory approvals.   The bank said talks were proceeding regarding the possible acquisition of a significant portion of its business by a trust company to be formed as a subsidiary of Vancouver City Savings Credit Union.

headline: Allied Said to Study Merger of 2 Chains
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation is considering merging its two Florida store divisions - Maas Brothers in Tampa and Jordan Marsh in Miami - as a move to cut overhead and create a unified retail organization in that state, trade sources said yesterday. Allied recently agreed to a merger with the Campeau Corporation, a Toronto-based developer.   An Allied spokesman in New York denied trade reports that the company had already decided to consolidate the 35 stores in Florida. ''We are considering a consolidation in Florida along with many other things,'' the spokesman said.

headline: Chinese Students Protest In a Provincial Capital
abstract: Several thousand students staged an anti-Government demonstration in a Chinese provincial capital today, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported.   In a dispatch from Beijing, Kyodo said about 3,000 students from five universities in the eastern province of Anhui gathered today in Hefei, the provincial capital, where they protested at the offices of the provincial government and the local newspaper.   The report, based on information from unidentified students at Anhui University, said about 5,000 students had staged a similar protest in the city last Friday, chanting slogans such as ''No modernization without democracy!'' and halting traffic for several hours.

headline: Airline Vote Is Extended
abstract: People Express Inc., the financially troubled airline, said yesterday that it had extended until today the deadline for obtaining creditor approval of a change in the airline's debt structure, the second such extension in a week. Under the terms of the airline's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation, 85 percent of the company's debenture holders must approve of the changes.

headline: ICELAND ARMS OFFER NOT YET ON THE GENEVA TABLE
abstract: The Reagan Administration has not yet presented the arms control proposals it made at the Iceland summit meeting in the arms talks in Geneva because senior military leaders say they first need to review them, officials said today.   After the meeting in Reykjavik, Administration officals said the United States and the Soviet Union would pick up in Geneva where the two sides left off in Iceland.   Administration officials said this meant that the United States would present the proposals it made in Iceland on on long-range arms, medium-range arms and adherence to the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty.   Administration officials also said they would seek to build on the areas of agreement reached in Iceland.

headline: G.M. and Ford To Cut Output
abstract: The nation's two largest auto makers said today that they would cut fourth-quarter production from earlier estimates.   The General Motors Corporation attributed its cutbacks to slack demand following the end of bargain-basement financing deals on new cars.

headline: A Dissenter On Pop-Ups
abstract: At least one advertising agency is not overjoyed about those spectacular pop-up ads that have run recently - and at great expense - in Time and Sports Illustrated. And MacNamara, Clapp & Klein is not too crazy about those ''advertorial inserts'' either.

headline: AMERICAN JEWISH GROUPS SAY CARDINAL SHOULD CANCEL ISRAEL VISIT
abstract: Several American Jewish spokesmen said yesterday that even at this late date, John Cardinal O'Connor should cancel a trip to Israel rather than risk snubbing Israeli leaders by refusing to meet with them officially in Jerusalem.   It was the third day in a row that American Jewish groups criticized the agenda for the trip, which was changed at the insistence of the Vatican so it would not appear to be formally recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital.   The Cardinal, who is Archbishop of New York, is in Jordan and plans to go to Israel on Thursday.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Will Durables Endure?    With the economy sputtering along, economists and politicians alike are looking for encouraging signs. They may have found one in the recent report that September durable goods orders rose by 4.9 percent, the largest jump in two years.   Some economists are responding cautiously, saying the numbers were heavily influenced by auto-sale incentives and by the new tax law. Businesses and individuals were rushing to buy durable goods, they say, because depreciation schedules are more liberal now than they will be next year. ''It's unlikely that the strength will be sustained into the first half of 1987,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.

headline: The U.N. Today: Dec. 19, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Egyptian Police Arrest 111 During Clashes Over Religion
abstract: The police arrested 111 people during street clashes today with Moslem militants demanding the application of Islamic law in Egypt, security officials said.

headline: NERVOUS MARKETS PLUNGE ON FEARS OF WIDER SCANDAL
abstract: The repercussions of the insider trading scandal rocked Wall Street yesterday. The stock market and parts of the bond market suffered heavy losses in response to the fear that has gripped the securities business over how high and how far the scandal will reach.   The closely watched Dow Jones industrial average fell a steep 43.31 points. Trading was extremely active as concern grew that further evidence of illegal insider trading would undermine market integrity.  [ Page D1. ]  There was an even sharper selloff of stocks involved in, or previously rumored to be involved in, corporate takeover battles.

headline: FRANCE DENIES DEAL SYRIANS
abstract: Government officials repeated denials today that Syria had helped France to obtain a ''truce'' with the extremist group believed responsible for a series of terrorist bombings in Paris last month.   The report was published Wednesday in Le Monde, and was one of a series of press disclosures indicating that the Government has multiplied its contacts with Syria in an effort to prevent a renewal of the wave of attacks.   But French officials, including Foreign Minister Jean-Bernard Raimond and Interior Minister Charles Pasqua, confirmed that France had actively sought Syrian cooperation to put an end to the terrorist attacks, with Mr. Pasqua saying that the secret services of the two countries have entered into a ''real collaboration.''

headline: Celeron Vice President Will Become Chairman
abstract: In 1977, when the Mid Louisiana Gas Company was sold to the Celeron Corporation, Carl S. Quinn told Celeron's chairman he did not want to run a company that had been acquired.   ''If I stayed and worked for him, I'd be telling him we didn't use to run the company that way and I didn't want to stay under those circumstances,'' he said in an interview from his office in Santa Barbara, Calif.   Two years later, Gale L. Galloway, Celeron's chairman and chief executive, persuaded Mr. Quinn to return as vice president and chief financial officer of Celeron.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN 'WELLNESS' PROGRAMS
abstract: CORPORATIONS increasingly are focusing on keeping employees healthy, rather than helping them get well. They are investing in wellness programs at record rates.   Their offerings range from the cheap and simple, like free raisins for morning snacks and scales in the bathrooms, to the expensive and technological, like corporate gymnasiums and computerized health-risk analyses. There are classes for quitting smoking, losing weight, eating better, exercising and managing stress. There are seatbelt and drug-awareness campaigns, and tests for high blood pressure or diabetes.

headline: SIKH 'SUICIDE SQUAD' IN TRUCK KILLS 3 NEW DELHI POLICEMEN
abstract: Seven people were reported killed here today when a truck driven by Sikhs roared suddenly out of a Sikh temple and ran over a group of policemen, killing three of them before it crashed into a wall.   In response, policemen stormed the truck and pulled two passengers from the truck, beating them to death, according to Indian news agency reports.   Two other Sikhs were killed by police gunfire as the authorities tried to stop a stone-throwing mob that had gathered outside the temple at the time of the incident. The group was trying to march in a procession in honor of a Sikh saint.

headline: PATENTS; Floatable Platform Can Hold 20 Survivors
abstract: A floatable platform patented this week can be used to help rescue as many as 20 people from open water.  The platform has a flotation ring that supports it in water, and a collapsible surrounding netting.

headline: AMERICANS DO IT MAZDA'S WAY
abstract: The work day begins with shouting. Wearing their tan company uniforms and hard hats, the trainees from the United States stand facing each other outside the Mazda Motor Corporation factory in this small city in western Japan. First, the Americans bow to each other. Then they touch their hats and point at their partners' hats. ''Hat O.K.!'' one shouts, and the other replies. One by one, they check their partners' safety glasses, uniforms, name tags and shoes, shouting approval.   Like so much else the Americans have adopted at Mazda, they have embraced this exercise wholeheartedly. The 48 employees, mostly supervisors, are taking a month of training before beginning work at Mazda's first American assembly plant.

headline: PATENTS; Aspartame Sweetening Frozen Diet Desserts
abstract: A New Jersey chemical engineer received a patent this week for a variety of dietetic frozen desserts with a low-calorie content.

headline: Americans Still Missing in Beirut
abstract: Edward Austin Tracy A self-described world traveler, poet and author of children's books . . . 56 years old from South Burlington, Vt. . . . Reported kidnapped in West Beirut on Oct. 21 . . . Accused by his abductors, the Revolutionary Justice Organization, of being a spy for Israel and the United States . . . A resident of Lebanon for several years . . . Speaks Arabic and has a certificate from Al Azhar University in Cairo documenting his conversion to Islam . . . Has lived abroad for the last 21 years and is said to have traveled to Iran, Iraq, Australia, Italy, Ethiopia, the Canary Islands and Trinidad as well as Lebanon. Joseph James Cicippio    Controller at the American University of Beirut and its hospital . . . 56 years old from Norristown, Pa. . . . Kidnapped Sept. 12 on his way to work from his apartment in the faculty building . . . His wife, Elaham Ghandour, a Lebanese Moslem, works for the United States Embassy . . . His wife appealed to President Reagan in October to intervene on behalf of the hostages held in Lebanon, as the President did for Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American reporter who was charged with spying but later freed by Moscow. Frank Herbert Reed    Director of the private Lebanese International School . . . 53 years old from Malden, Mass. . . . Kidnapped in West Beirut on Sept. 9 . . . His wife, Sahmiyeh, is Syrian, and they have a 5-year-old son . . . Mrs. Reed joined Mrs. Cicippio in the plea to Mr. Reagan, broadcast over Lebanese state television.

headline: Repeal Sought On Jet Trainer
abstract: The Air Force will ask Congress to repeal a provision of the military spending law calling for a competition to select a new jet training aircraft. Among the contenders in the competition is the Fairchild Republic Company's T-46A, which is built on Long Island.

headline: Mother Teresa Unhurt In Tanzania Air Crash
abstract: Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner in 1979, escaped unhurt today from an air crash in which her small plane killed six people at a dusty airstrip in rural Tanzania.   The aircraft crashed on takeoff, plowing into a crowd at Hombolo airport, 200 miles west of Dar es Salaam.

headline: SmithKline's Dutch Auction
abstract: STOCKHOLDERS who may wish to sell their shares of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation are being given an unusual opportunity known as a Dutch auction by the giant producer of ethical and proprietary drugs.   In contrast to a typical stock buyback at a set price, the Philadelphia-based company is making a tender offer for a minimum of 5 million and a maximum of 15 million of its common shares at a price between $86 and $96 a share. Depending upon the ultimate price and the number of shares tendered, the offer conceivably could cost SmithKline more than $1 billion.   When the offer was announced on Nov. 26, the stock jumped $4.50, to $91.25. Since then it generally has traded around the midpoint of the offering range and closed yesterday at $90.125, up 37.5 cents. The offer expires at midnight on Friday, Dec. 26.

headline: Head of Ansa Software Likes Building Business
abstract: In joining Ansa Software last week as president and chief executive, Ronald S. Posner says he is actually indulging in his favorite hobby: building a new business.   Ansa, based in Belmont, Calif., was begun two years ago by two software engineers with venture capital from the Sevin Rosen Management Company and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, and is known for its Paradox data base management software that competes directly with dBase.   Mr. Posner, 44, has most recently been executive vice president of the Ashton-Tate Company of Torrance, Calif., best known for the dBase program. Previously, he had founded two computer training companies, including National Training Services, which he sold to Safeguard Business Systems in 1984. At Ashton-Tate, Mr. Posner directed the international division, which now accounts for 25 percent of sales.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: According to A. C. Nielsen, the monitor of the monitorable, the highest per capita sales of grocery products this year have been in Norway, with Sweden being in second place.

headline: INDIA AND CARBIDE IN PACT ON ASSETS
abstract: India and the Union Carbide Corporation arrived at an agreement today that will clear the way for court action on a suit against the company arising from the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.   Under the agreement, Union Carbide will maintain assets in the United States worth $3 billion to satisfy potential judgments in favor of Bhopal victims. The company did not admit any liability under the agreement, however.

headline: Sluggish Activity Continues
abstract: In lackluster trading the last few weeks, credit market participants have appeared content to accept the standard forecast: a weakening of the economy in the first quarter, accompanied by an easier monetary policy and lower interest rates.   The complacent attitude has left Treasury bond yields little changed in the last several weeks, and still in the middle portion of the range that has prevailed since April. The newest 30-year issue, the 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2016, were offered Friday at 102 2/ 32, to yield 7.33 percent.   ''Clearly this is a market with a bullish bias,'' analysts at Griggs & Santow noted in their latest newsletter. They noted that the bond market seems to have overlooked certain devolpments, such as stronger-than-expected economic data and higher short-term interest rates.

headline: Rumors Spur Hess's Stock
abstract: Pushed by widespread rumors that the company is the target of a takeover attempt, stock of the Amerada Hess Corporation rose strongly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The stock gained $1.125 to close at $26.875, and with four million shares changing hands, Hess was the Big Board's most active issue.

headline: Pontiac Fiero Cuts Cause 600 Layoffs
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will cut production on its Pontiac Fiero models and lay off 600 workers next year to avert the need for financing sales incentives on the sporty cars, G.M. officials said.

headline: NEW OFFER ACCEPTED BY ALLIED
abstract: In an effort to stave off a $66-a-share bid by the Campeau Corporation, the board of the Allied Stores Corporation yesterday approved a $67-a-share merger offer from Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. and Paul A. Bilzerian.   Mr. DeBartolo, the largest developer and manager of shopping malls in the United States, and Mr. Bilzerian, a California investor, are offering to buy all outstanding Allied stock for $67 a share, if 27 million shares -a majority of the company's stock -are tendered by midnight, Nov. 6.   Fully diluted, there are more than 53 million Allied shares outstanding, and the deal would be valued at more than $3.5 billion. 'Outstanding Partnership'    Thomas M. Macioce, chairman and chief executive of Allied and a longtime friend of Mr. DeBartolo, said it would be ''an outstanding partnership.''

headline: DEFENSE CHIEF SAYS HE MAY QUIT MANILA CABINET
abstract: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, who has been in increasingly open conflict with his Cabinet colleagues, said today that he was considering the possibility of resigning in response to their criticism.   His statement came during a tour of three southern islands that seemed to mimic some elements of a simultaneous swing by President Corazon C. Aquino through two neighboring islands.   In his speeches to military and civilian audiences in Cebu, Jolo and this city in southern Mindanao, Mr. Enrile questioned the President's policy of negotiating with Communist insurgents, calling it ''simplistic and naive.''   ''Because of what I'm doing today, many of my colleagues in the Cabinet have been asking for my resignation,'' he told a gathering of top officers of the southern military command.

headline: PROTESTS REVEAL AN UNSUSPECTED DISCONTENT AMONG ELITE YOUTH AND FEARS ABOUT FUTURE
abstract: The pro-democracy demonstrations by university students over the last several weeks have revealed a depth of discontent among the elite of China's youth that was unsuspected until now.   That university students, the chosen young, should demonstrate in such numbers in favor of political principles closely associated in the minds of Chinese with the non-Communist West, particularly the United States, has raised disturbing questions among many here about the direction of economic and political change in China.   The largest rallies were in Shanghai last weekend, where close to 50,000 people were estimated to have gathered on Sunday alone. But they also occurred in Beijing and about half a dozen other cities. Today there were reports that 3,000 students demonstrated in the port city of Tianjin to show their solidarity with the Shanghai protests.

headline: STICKING POINTS IN ICELAND
abstract: President Reagan and his aides came here with the expectation that Moscow was prepared to reach tentative agreements on medium-range missiles and other arms issues without first solving the problem of space-based defenses.   And they had reason to believe this, based on the two leaders' pledge last November in Geneva to seek an ''interim'' accord on medium-range weapons, and based on more recent public statements by Soviet leaders.   But today in the dramatic finale to their two-day get-together, Mikhail S. Gorbachev told them they were wrong.   To the Soviet leader, every agreement to reduce arms depended on American willingness essentially to scrap Mr. Reagan's dream for space-based defenses against missile attacks.   And he had a basis for this belief as well. That same joint statement in Geneva pledged the two sides to ''accelerate'' efforts to ''prevent an arms race in space.''

headline: Gain at New Woman
abstract: New Woman magazine has reported that its January issue closed with 56 ad pages, a 17.4 percent gain over the previous year, while its February issue closed with 75.1 ad pages, a 25.5 percent gain over a year ago.

headline: OTHERS WHO QUIT IN PROTEST
abstract: In resigning from the State Department today, Bernard Kalb joined what Dean Acheson once called ''the most exclusive club in the America - men in public life who have resigned in the cause of conscience.'' Here are some of the other officials who have taken similar steps in recent years:   Les Janka, deputy White House press secretary for foreign affairs.

headline: SPANISH RIGHTIST QUITS, ENDING AN ERA
abstract: The longtime leader of Spain's rightist opposition resigned today, two days after the conservatives were routed in Basque regional elections.   The departure of Manuel Fraga Iribarne, a political giant for the last two decades of Spanish history, brought to a head a crisis in the Spanish right.   Mr. Fraga, who is 64 years old, submitted his ''irrevocable'' resignation to the 30-man executive committee of his Popular Coalition Party and informed King Juan Carlos. The committee voted unanimously not to accept the resignation, but party leaders said the vote was taken to honor Mr. Fraga and that his decision to quit was firm.

headline: GUINNESS'S PLANS GO DRY
abstract: LAST Monday, the same day the British Government began an investigation of Guinness P.L.C, the company's chairman, Ernest Saunders, went ahead anyway to host a stylish fete at London's National Gallery. Confronted by reporters and photographers on the museum steps, Mr. Saunders said, ''I see no reason why I should let it spoil my party.''   Yet, that will probably be the last Guinness party for a while. The Government inquiry could have scarcely come at a worse time. The dust had just settled - or so it seemed to Mr. Saunders, who is avoiding the press for the moment - from the bitter but successful takeover fight for the Distillers Company earlier this year. For the past few months Mr. Saunders, a marketing whiz and ruthless cost-cutter dubbed ''Deadly Ernest'' for his hard-nosed style, has been scrutinizing the Distillers empire with an eye toward major changes.   Guinness, according to analysts and insiders, was about to unveil a bold plan for streamlining the bloated Distillers organization and reviving worldwide sales of its stable of blue-chip Scotch whisky brands led by Johnnie Walker, Dewar's and White Horse. The cost-cutting promises to be far easier than the global marketing push, in light of the steady decline in worldwide Scotch sales in recent years as drinkers shun heavier spirits in favor of lighter-tasting, lower-alcohol beverages.

headline: Market Place; G.M.'S E STOCK: ANALYSTS WARY
abstract: THE class E stock of the General Motors Corporation has often shown wide price swings - it rose 93 percent in 1985 - but its sharp decline yesterday reflected an executive suite conflict at the world's largest automotive company.   The E shares, actually comprising a class of G.M. common stock, were issued to pay for part of G.M.'s $2.5 billion acquisition of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in October 1984. Yesterday, the E stock plunged 4 1/2 points to close at 26 7/8, on the news that H. Ross Perot, the billionaire founder and chairman of E.D.S., had resigned after an escalating feud with Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive.   ''Ross Perot is the champion of E.D.S. and shareholders of the class E stock,'' said Stephen T. McClellan of Merrill Lynch. ''His departure put a cloud over the stock. I have been cautious on the E stock since August. I maintain a high degree of caution, since too many unknowns still exist.''

headline: Stocks Up Broadly; Dow Adds 34.03
abstract: The stock market staged a broad advance yesterday, as investors focused on blue-chip equities and showed renewed confidence in the prospects for recently shunned takeover targets.   The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 34.03 points to close at 1,860.66, as advances outnumbered declines by 1,308 to 373. On Wednesday, the Dow had notched a confidence-building 9.42 advance.   Volume on the Big Board slid to 158.1 million shares, from 183.3 million Wednesday.

headline: Dana May Take Write-Downs
abstract: The Dana Corporation said it might write down assets of its businesses other than financial services, a move that could result in pretax fourth-quarter charges of $38 million to $40 million. Dana today reported third-quarter earnings of $12.2 million, after $12.3 million in charges, compared with net income of $41.1 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.

headline: U.S. MIGHT HASTEN BREACH OF TREATY
abstract: The Reagan Administration has been considering whether to move up the date when the United States will exceed a limit in the 1979 strategic arms treaty, according to Administration officials and Congressional experts.   Administration officials declined in interviews to discuss the deliberations in detail or to say how they could be influenced by President Reagan's meetings next weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.   The United States will exceed a treaty limit when it equips a 131st bomber with cruise missiles, unless other systems are dismantled.   Administration officials said consideration had been given in recent weeks to carrying out that action as soon as Nov. 11, rather than in late December. They said the decision would turn on policy considerations rather than technical reasons.

headline: OMAN HOLDS WAR GAMES AGAINST 'FANTASIA'
abstract: Precisely 28 minutes after they landed here to complete a 4,560-mile flight from England, six Tornado aircraft, four fitted for ground attack and two as fighters, roared off this island's air base and into Operation Swift Sword.   The exercise pits British and Omani naval, air and ground forces against other Omanis acting as ''invaders'' from neighboring ''Fantasia.''   Tonight, the Tornados and other aircraft, including jump jets from the British carrier Illustrious, attacked Fantasia forces in preparation for major operations the next day.

headline: TRIAL IN NICARAGUA IS SET TO PROCEED
abstract: After four days of pretrial maneuvering, a Sandinista political tribunal is now expected to spend the next 8 to 12 days judging the case against the American captured from a downed rebel plane.   Political analysts inside and outside the Nicaraguan Government say they believe that if punishment is ultimately meted out, it will depend less on legal arguments in the courtroom than on a calculated political decision by the Sandinista leadership, which controls the political tribunal.   The American prisoner, Eugene Hasenfus, was captured after a supply plane was shot down three weeks ago over Nicaragua while trying to drop guns and ammunition to anti-Government units. The Nicaraguan Government has treated the incident as a major political issue and as conclusive evidence of American aggression against Nicaragua.

headline: DUTCH ARE QUIETLY TAKING THE LEAD IN EUTHANASIA
abstract: Quietly, with barely a public debate, this nation has become the leader in voluntary euthanasia.   Each year, despite an explicit condemnation of the practice in the Dutch criminal code, doctors help more than 5,000 suffering patients to die. In effect, the medical profession, bolstered by court rulings and a sympathetic public, has stepped ahead of politicians in making euthanasia a reality.   One of the leading practitioners of voluntary euthanasia is Dr. Pieter V. Admiraal, an anesthesiologist. He began cooperating more than a decade ago, despite the law, with terminally ill patients who asked for final relief from unbearable pain.

headline: Ryan Opposes Bid by NVHomes
abstract: Ryan Homes Inc., a Pittsburgh-based home builder, said that a $45-a-share tender offer from NVHomes L. P. was financially inadequate, and it recommended that shareholders not tender their shares. Ryan also filed suit in Federal District Court in Pennsylvania, seeking to enjoin NVHomes, a home builder based in McLean, Va., from proceeding with the tender offer.

headline: EUROPEANS WILL MEET TODAY ON SYRIA
abstract: Two weeks after it failed to get agreement from its European partners on a set of measures against Syria, Britain will try again Monday at a meeting here of the 12 Foreign Ministers of the European Community.   The British demand for action against Damascus came in the aftermath of the conviction here of Nezar Hindawi, a Palestinian of Jordanian citizenship, on charges of trying to place a bomb on an El Al Israel Airlines jumbo jet in April. The prosecution contended that Mr. Hindawi, who traveled to London under an alias on a Syrian passport and later sought refuge in the Syrian Embassy, was an agent in a plot engineered by high military intelligence officers in Syria. Within hours of his conviction on Oct. 24, Britain broke diplomatic relations with Damascus.

headline: A NEW GENERATION OF NON-SAVERS
abstract: ''The habit of saving is in itself an education that fosters every virtue, teaches self denial, cultivates the sense of order, trains to forethought and so broadens the mind.''    THE words are chisled along the rim of the rotunda in the Crossland Savings Bank, once the midtown headquarters of New York's Greenwich Savings Bank. Like the ornate building itself, the homily is florid tribute to a thriftiness Americans have long preached but rarely practiced.   The fact is, Americans as individuals save less than their counterparts in the rest of the industrialized world. And the national savings rate - a broader gauge that measures personal, business and Government saving - is lower than in any European country or Japan. Neither economists or governments can quite agree on how savings should be measured, but one accepted way of adjusting the figures puts the rate here at about 3.1 percent of gross national product, compared with about 15 percent for Japan and 7 percent to 10 percent in Europe - a gap that has prevailed during much of the post-world War II era.

headline: 3d World Trade Deficits
abstract: Poor countries in Asia, Europe and the Western Hemisphere are plunging deeper into debt, posting a $4.9 billion trade deficit for the first quarter of this year, according to the International Monetary Fund. The monthly I.M.F. memorandum said the trade deficit for those countries, along with developing nations in the Middle East and Africa, totaled $3.1 billion in 1985, compared with a surplus of $10.5 billion in 1984.

headline: Chad Says It Downed A Libyan Fighter Jet
abstract: Chad said today that its armed forces had shot down a Libyan fighter plane and killed 200 Libyan soldiers in fighting in the northeast of the country.

headline: CHASE OFF
abstract: Four major bank holding companies reported third-quarter gains yesterday, while a fifth reported a slight decline. But even some of the banks whose profits rose said continuing problems with loans and a strong dollar, which has raised costs overseas, tended to crimp performance.   J.P. Morgan & Company, the First Chicago Corporation, the Security Pacific Corporation and the Irving Bank Corporation reported profit increases ranging from 1 percent to 24.7 percent compared with results a year ago.But the Chase Manhattan Corporation said its third-quarter net fell 8 percent, citing one-time charges and an $80 million increase in its provision for loan losses. A Chase spokesman also said about 1,000 jobs at the bank would be eliminated in a cost-cutting effort.

headline: EPITAPH FOR A COMIC: HE CAPTURED THE GALLIC SOUL
abstract: ''Why Not the Pantheon?'' was the rather unusual headline in the serious, sober Le Monde last week.   It referred to what a columnist for the paper called ''an unfurling of superfluous messages and excessive sorrows'' that followed the death Thursday of Thierry Le Luron, a popular 34-year-old nightclub comedian whose specialty consisted of uncannily accurate caricatures of France's political figures.   Le Monde's columnist, Daniele Heymann, was about the only commentator here on the day after Mr. Le Luron's death to note the exaggerated and deeply emotional effect that the event had on French society, which treated it with degrees of bereavement and attention worthy of the passing of a head of state or a giant of literature.   Mr. Le Luron, a slight, boyish man popular here for the last decade or so, was known, among other things, for his creation of a character called Adolphe-Benito Glandu. The character was a rightist bigot full of rancor whom he lampooned with savage effect - in so doing lampooning as well a certain prototype of the ordinary Frenchman from the provinces largely untouched by the values of the Enlightenment.

headline: Israeli Soldier on Foot Patrol Is Wounded by Arab With Ax
abstract: An Arab man with an ax attacked an Israeli soldier patrolling the West Bank town of Ramallah today, wounding him lightly, a military spokesman said.

headline: Consumer Credit
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Calling in the Credit Counselors'' (Personal Finance, Aug. 31) performed a valuable public service. But we would like to make one alteration to your advice on timing.

headline: Salant Proposal
abstract: The Salant Corporation, an apparel producer based in New York, said it had agreed on a reorganization plan with committees of unsecured creditors and stockholders. Salant and its major subsidiaries, the Thomson Company and Obion Company, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1985. The plan, subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, provides that for each $1,000 of unsecured claims, creditors would get $450 in cash, $500 principal amount of senior subordinated debentures and four common shares.

headline: Zale Studies Bid
abstract: The Zale Corporation said in a terse statement that it was reviewing an unsolicited $50-a-share cash offer from Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto and Swarovski International Holding of Zurich.

headline: INDEX ON DIRECTION OF ECONOMY CLIMBS
abstract: The Government index intended to predict the economy surged 1.2 percent in November, the biggest advance in seven months, the Commerce Department reported today.   The latest reading, which was somewhat stronger than expected, was widely regarded as pointing to continued economic growth in 1987.   But analysts differed markedly about how vigorous the fifth straight year of expansion was likely to be. Many contended that the sharp November jump in the index of leading indicators overstated the economy's strength, partly because the new tax law that takes effect this week has been spurring demand recently.

headline: VIETNAM PARLEY ON NEW CHIEFS
abstract: An important session of Vietnam's National Assembly opened today in Hanoi, according to the official radio, the Voice of Vietnam.   The assembly is expected to name the country's President and Prime Minister.

headline: BOB EVANS RESIGNING
abstract: Bob Evans, a sausage producer who founded a restaurant chain bearing his name, is resigning as president and director.

headline: TOYOTA ADJUSTS ITS STRATEGY
abstract: On paper, the outlook at the Toyota Motor Corporation is anything but rosy these days. The company is forecasting a 2.3 percent decline in car shipments in the current, 1987, fiscal year and a 4.8 percent drop in revenues. Profits could fall to one-third of their level in the 1986 fiscal year that ended June 30, top executives warn.   The culprit, of course, is the strong yen, which has forced up car and truck prices in the United States, the company's most lucrative foreign market, and squeezed profit margins so much that export earnings declined 66 percent last year, according to company officials. But there is no sense of panic in this tightly knit industrial community that was the boyhood home of Ieyasu Tokogawa, the great shogun, or military leader, of 16th century Japan. The Social Contract    Instead, top Toyota executives say they will deal with an increasingly crowded world car market by relying on advanced technology, higher-priced luxury and performance car models and the painstakingly forged social contract between the company and its employees.

headline: 14 KILLED, 41 HURT IN TAIWAN QUAKES
abstract: Two earthquakes shook Taiwan today, killing 14 people, most of them under a collapsed building, the police said. At least 41 people were injured.   Twenty people were believed buried alive after a three-story building collapsed in the Taipei suburb of Chungho, the radio quoted residents as having said. More than 200 rescuers, using bulldozers and dogs, searched for survivors.

headline: SAUDIS DENY REPORT ON DEALER
abstract: Reports that the Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi arranged financing for Iran's purchase of United States arms are ''planted lies,'' the Government said today.   The official Saudi Press Agency quoted an official it did not identify as having said the denial referred to reports this week in The New York Times and The Washington Post.

headline: Continental Illinois Declares Dividend
abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation, which was kept afloat two years ago by a $4.5 billion Federal rescue plan, declared its first dividend on common stock since February 1984, another important symbolic move to show it is on the road to recovery.

headline: PRELUDE TO CBS: TISCH AT CNA
abstract: A few days after Laurence A. Tisch won a bitterly contested takeover battle for the CNA Financial Corporation in 1974, he toured the company's new headquarters and came upon the chairman's stately suite with its marble staircase spiraling up to a private dining room.   ''When Larry Tisch saw that, I knew that was one office that would never be used again,'' said J. Ira Harris, a Salomon Brothers director who was with Mr. Tisch at the time.   Mr. Harris was right. The office is still vacant, a symbol of the no-frills, no-nonsense management style that Mr. Tisch, the chairman of the Loews Corporation, brought to the troubled insurance company after it was acquired by Loews. Mr. Tisch, together with his brother, Preston Robert Tisch, and a few top assistants, brought in new management, sorted through the insurer's problems and narrowed its lines of business. The conservative course they set for the company has paid off handsomely in recent years, even while the property-casualty insurance industry went through the wringer.

headline: Patents; New Way To Hunt Arctic Oil
abstract: AN improved method of exploring Arctic regions for oil and gas was patented this week for the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco. William J. Ostrander, a senior staff geophysicist, was granted patent No. 4,621,347.

headline: KHOMEINI RULES OUT LINK WITH U.S. AND ASSAILS IRANIANS WHO SEEK TIES
abstract: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ruled out reconciliation with Washington today, saying any Iranian officials who seek to improve relations are ''Satan-oriented.''   ''I never expected such things from these people,'' Ayatollah Khomeini, the Iranian religious leader, said of officials who would seek improved ties.

headline: Senate Passes Dealer Rules
abstract: The Senate tonight passed by unanimous consent a bill that will require dealers in government debt securities to register with the Federal Government.   The bill gives the Treasury Department the authority to set regulatory guidelines, including minimum capital and public reporting requirements and auditing standards, for more than 200 current sellers and dealers in government securities.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A caption on Oct. 5 with the photo of Dean Witter's chairman misidentified him. He is Philip J. Purcell.

headline: TEXACO NAMES TWO TO ITS TOP POSTS
abstract: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, said yesterday that James W. Kinnear would succeed John K. McKinley as chief executive at the end of the year.   But Mr. Kinnear, who is 58 years old and has been vice chairman for the last three years, will apparently share considerable power with Texaco's president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., his rival in the race for the top spot. Texaco said that Mr. DeCrane, 55, would take the title of chairman when Mr. McKinley retired on Dec. 31.

headline: El Paso Utility Offering Bonds
abstract: The El Paso Electric Company is offering $311 million of 10 3/4 percent lease obligation bonds due in 2013 at par through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.   The financing stems from the utility's sale and leaseback of its interest in the Palo Verde nuclear power plant. Lease payments on the plant are high enough to cover the interest and principal on the bond issue.   The obligations, which yield almost three percentage points more than Treasury securities of similar maturity, are not refundable for five years and are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB- by S.&P. El Paso's regular first mortgage bonds carry slightly higher ratings of A-3 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

headline: Silver Coins Sell Out Fast
abstract: The new American Eagle silver dollars were snatched up quickly by bulk dealers today, and the initial supply of 1.4 million coins was gone within hours, officials of the United States Mint said.   They said the demand for the silver coins matched the frenzy generated a month ago when the companion gold coins were first offered.   The Mint was forced to allocate the available silver coins, allowing 28 bulk purchasers to buy 50,000 coins each, far fewer than most had requested.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Montreal Trustco Inc., Montreal, said it would buy the $250 million residential mortgage loan portfolio of Bank of America Canada. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Ivar Kreuger: Sweden's Match King
abstract: IVAR Kreuger, the Swedish match king, may have been the biggest thief of all time. Mr. Kreuger, a mechanical engineer from Kalmar, Sweden, was among the world's most powerful industrialists back in the 1920's, when he supplied 75 percent of the world's matches from factories in 34 countries.   His dream was to be the producer of every match on the face of the earth. So in exchange for monopolies on match production, he loaned enormous amounts of money to more than a dozen nations. At the same time, his empire grew as he bought everything from banks, film companies and railways to gold mines and forests. He also built a 125-room office in Stockholm, which became known as the Match Palace.

headline: Revlon Is Confident On Drexel's Funds
abstract: The Revlon Group said yesterday that Drexel Burnham Lambert had provided assurance that it would be able to provide the bulk of the financing for Revlon's proposed $4.12 billion takeover of the Gillette Company.   Revlon's announcement was an attempt to counter Wall Street speculation that a Federal investigation of Drexel would prevent it from raising the capital for the takeover.   In addition, Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of the cosmetics company, disputed accusations by Gillette that Revlon had forewarned arbitragers and stock traders of its takeover plans, calling the charges ''without merit and self-serving.''

headline: IN 'PACIFIC CENTURY,' SARIS AMID THE PALM TREES?
abstract: Late at night, as passengers stumble into the nearly deserted arrival hall of a Fijian airport, Indian music is drifting from a radio in the corner, and the tellers who scramble to cash travelers' checks seem to be speaking Hindi.   On Suva's streets, in the heart of the South Pacific, the coffee shops serve vegetable curry. Saris rustle in a library.   Indians, not Melanesians or Polynesians, are Fiji's largest ethnic group, and their dominance of trade and the professions is immediately evident. What is not obvious, Indians say, is the precariousness of their position as both the numbers and aspirations of ethnic islanders rise. Is there a place for them, they ask, in the ''Pacific century''?

headline: Spicy Salami From Hungary
abstract: PERSUADING Americans that there is more to Hungarian cuisine than goulash has not been easy, but Terimpex, the Hungarian agency responsible for food exports, will not give up. It has chosen Hungarian salami to lead its American marketing efforts.

headline: MOBSTER TELLS ON NEIGHBORS IN TOKYO COURT
abstract: This is a country where the organized criminals have been known to call news conferences and to hold their gangland funerals on national television.   So it came as small surprise today when the local yakuza, or organized crime, leader in Hamamatsu, a small city 125 miles southwest of Tokyo, went before the local district court to complain that his neighbors were picking on him.   In several cities across Japan, residents have banded together in protest whenever a yakuza clan has moved into a new neighborhood. Hamamatsu became a typical case last August when Tetsuya Aono took over a six-story building as a headquarters for his enterprise, a yakuza group known as the Ichiriki.

headline: Japan Output Index Off
abstract: Japan's industrial production index for October fell 1.9 percent (a preliminary figure) from the month before, to a seasonally adjusted 120.8, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said Wednesday.

headline: SPINOFF CHARGE IS CITED
abstract: Dart & Kraft Inc. said today that its third-quarter net income fell 81.7 percent, mainly as a result of an $81 million special charge related to an impending spinoff.   The diversified food company reported earnings of $21.2 million, or 17 cents a share, for the 13 weeks ended Sept 27, down from $116.1 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier.   Sales grew 9.2 percent, to $2.73 billion, from $2.5 billion.

headline: Record Fine For Trader
abstract: Conticommodity Services Inc., a former futures trading unit of the Continental Grain Company, agreed yesterday to settle two lawsuits against it by paying $1.5 million, the largest civil penalty ever assessed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.   The suits settled yesterday involved activities that occurred before Conticommodity's assets were sold to Refco Inc. of Chicago in 1984.

headline: Britoil Plans Sale
abstract: Britoil, the privatized British oil and gas conglomerate, said it was putting up for sale its American assets, bought three years ago for $157 million.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.9 billion of debentures with maturities of 3 years, 7 years and 10 years through various securities dealers.

headline: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEAL AT EASTMAN KODAK
abstract: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company, said today that it had entered into an agreement with the Eastman Kodak Company to gain increased production capability for Snomax, a bacteria that induces the formation of snow and ice.   Snomax has been used at ski resorts around the country for three years to produce drier, higher-quality snow, and more snow for the same amount of water, increasing productivity and lengthening the skiing season, the company said. Kodak has agreed to produce 5,500 kilograms of Snomax for the 1986-87 season and 15,000 kilograms for the 1987-88 season.

headline: Carter Hawley Silent on Offer
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the owner of Bergdorf Goodman Inc. and Neiman Marcus, said yesterday that it would not comment on whether it had responded to a $1.8 billion cash offer for the retailer made a week ago today.   Yesterday was the deadline for a response set by The Limited, a major retailer, and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, a builder of shopping centers, which made the offer.

headline: Washington Watch; View on F.T.C.'s Role
abstract: Daniel Oliver, the former journalist who since April has been chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, complains that the nation's trade deficit has received so much media attention that many people mistakenly think his agency is mainly responsible for dealing with import and export policy.   He thus considers, at least half-seriously, proposing that the F.T.C. be renamed the Bureau of Consumer Protection.

headline: U.S.-INDIA ACCORD ON COMPUTER SALE
abstract: High-level negotiators from India and the United States reached a tentative agreement today on a set of safeguards that would permit India to buy an American supercomputer for weather forecasting, according to officials involved in the talks.   The tentative accord, which must be approved by top officials on both sides, was seen as a significant step in the two countries' growing cooperation on high-technology matters.   An American spokesman declined to confirm a tentative pact, saying only that the negotiators had held three days of ''fruitful discussions.''  [ In Washington, meanwhile, the United States announced a formal inquiry into Japanese barriers to the import of supercomputers. Page D11. ]  The United States has never made a high-speed supercomputer available to a country outside the West. But American officials redoubled their efforts to reach an agreement on this computer deal, to show that the United States' relationship with India remained strong despite Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's recent welcome of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to New Delhi.

headline: Ex-Captive Is Opposed To Arms for Hostages
abstract: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, an American priest who was released by kidnappers in Lebanon, said today that it would be better for other American hostages to stay in captivity than be freed in return for United States arms shipments to Iran.   But Father Jenco said he did not believe his release and that of two other Americans over the last 14 months were part of a trade for arms.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * MEI Diversified Inc. is offering $75 million of 12 1/2 percent senior subordinated notes due 1996 at 100 and $50 million of 8 percent convertible debentures due 2006 at 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The notes are noncallable for five years, while the debentures, which are convertible into the company's common stock at $11 a share, are noncallable for three years.    * May Department Stores Co. is offering $150 million of Aa-3/AA- rated 9 1/8 percent debentures due 2016 at 100 through Morgan Stanley.

headline: RECORDS OF CANADA'S TAXPAYERS STOLEN
abstract: Personal records on 16 million Canadians, virtually every taxpayer in the nation, were stolen last month from a Government tax office, Parliament has been told.   Although officials said the records were returned about three hours after the disclosure, the Oct. 30 theft raised concern that terrorists or criminals may have copied the data to use for obtaining false birth certificates or passports or to file fraudulent claims for welfare or pensions.   Today, the police said they were questioning an employee of the Government tax office.

headline: MOSCOW, IN A THAW, AWAITS A LITERARY BOMBSHELL
abstract: As literature and the arts become less confined under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet writer Anatoly Rybakov has promised a literary bombshell for next spring.   It is an explosion he has prepared for 20 years, a major novel set at a critical juncture of the Stalin era in which the dictator himself is a major character, stripped of official myth, falsified history and a 30-year veil of silence.   Even at a time when Moscow's cultural fraternity is abuzz with talk of long-suppressed writings or bold new works appearing in print, the news that Mr. Rybakov's ''The Children of the Arbat'' will appear next year in the literary monthly Druzhba Narodov has come as a sensation.   Of all the forbidden themes of Soviet letters, the terror under Stalin looms foremost, a memory both the Government and many people have preferred to suppress because of the questions it raises about the system.   Though Stalin lurks in literature, plays and films, usually as the nation's leader in World War II, no one has dared offer an unadorned portrait of him.

headline: Gold Warrants From Standard Oil
abstract: The Standard Oil Company said it would issue 120 million Swiss francs, or almost $75 million, of 3 1/8 percent bonds in the Euromarket at par, with detachable gold warrants, through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Ltd. of Switzerland.   The bonds, due in 1993 and not redeemable before maturity, will be sold in denominations of 5,000 Swiss francs.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  None  Tuesday  None  Wednesday  None  Thursday  Retail Sales November  Friday  Producer Prices November  Inventory-Sales Ratio October

headline: UNOCAL'S COSTLY INDEPENDENCE
abstract: Having escaped from T. Boone Pickens only to come up against plummeting oil prices, the Unocal Corporation is paying a price for its independence.   ''They have managed reasonably well in a difficult environment,'' said Sanford L. Margoshes, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''They're muddling along.'' Unocal's problems started when Mr. Pickens, the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, made a run at the company last year. Unocal successfully fought off his takeover attempt in May 1985, but at the cost of taking on a huge debt load - an additional $4.4 billion, bringing total debt to a peak of $5.9 billion - to buy back 40 percent of its shares at a premium.   Several other concerns, including the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and CPC International Inc., have recently initiated expensive stock buyback programs in moves to fend off corporate raiders. Unocal's performance has been closely watched since the Pickens episode by those who wonder how much such companies can afford to pay for their freedom.

headline: FUNDS MAY HAVE AIDED REBEL AIR DROPS
abstract: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that it was possible that some of the money secretly diverted from Iran arms sales may have been spent on supplies dropped to their forces by air. But they said they did not know who would have arranged for such flights.   The leaders, members of the umbrella group known as the United Nicaraguan Opposition, continued to insist that they had not directly received any of the funds that the White House said had been secretly diverted.   But at a news conference here this afternoon, the three top leaders of the umbrella rebel group suggested that some of the money could have been spent to help their men ''in the field.''

headline: If You Think 1986 Is the Year for a Mink
abstract: IF you have been dreaming of a fur coat, there is an incentive to buy this year: The sales tax -which can easily amount to $500 or more in New York - will cease to be deductible in 1987.   But the tax break is a relatively minor consideration these days, when a fur can cost as much as a car. If the price tag for your dream coat is heftier than your bank balance, many stores will gladly extend credit. At the Fur Vault, a chain with a reputation for lower-priced coats, a casual shopper may receive an application for a revolving credit account (with an annual percentage rate of 19.8 percent) without even requesting it. Saks Fifth Avenue offers four deferred payment plans, depending on the amount borrowed: For a loan of $1,500 or less, for example, fur coat buyers pay an annual percentage rate of 9.37 percent and have six months to repay; loans of $10,000 and up carry a 10 percent rate and customers, who must put 10 percent down, have 24 months to pay.

headline: Rax, D'Arcy Parting Ways
abstract: After less than two years together, Rax Restaurants of Columbus, Ohio, and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/New York are going their separate ways. Split day is Feb. 20.

headline: Accuray Gets Bid From Combustion
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc. said that it planned to begin a $35-a-share, or $147 million, tender offer for the Accuray Corporation. Accuray produces measurement and control systems for the pulp and paper industry.

headline: PRETORIA POLICE DISPERSE G.M. STRIKERS
abstract: South African policemen used dogs and whips today to break up a gathering of striking workers at the General Motors plant in Port Elizabeth, witnesses said.   General Motors said it called in the police after workers, striking in protest at details of the American company's plan to sell out to local buyers, intimidated fellow workers into staying away from the plant. The strike started on Oct. 29 to back demands for union representation on the board of the local company to be formed as General Motors' successor and for severance pay when the company changes hands.

headline: KASPAROV MAKES A KEY MOVE, AND HE FANS SENSE A VICTORY
abstract: As 800 people watched in tense silence in the Leningrad hall, the referee in the world chess championship today opened a move sealed by Gary Kasparov in a game adjourned the night before.   Then, when the move - a knight's attack on the king - was announced, the crowd exploded in a standing ovation, aware that Kasparov was guaranteed a victory in the game and, barring a near-miracle, retention of his championship.  [ Page 42. ]  No Escape Remaining The challenger, Anatoly Karpov, struggled for 11 more moves in the slender hope Kasparov would commit a gross blunder, but both the champion and the audience knew that there was no escape.

headline: Belzberg Urges GTE Spinoff
abstract: Samuel Belzberg, the corporate raider, yesterday suggested that the GTE Corporation spin off its Sprint long-distance telephone service to its shareholders.   He also said shareholders would benefit from the sale or spinoff of GTE's mobile phone operations.   Mr. Belzberg, a Canadian with a reputation for profiting from unsuccessful takeover attempts, made his comments in a delicately worded letter sent yesterday to GTE's chairman, Theodore Brophy. The letter said a partnership headed by the First City Financial Corporation, which Mr. Belzberg owns, possesses a ''large'' number of GTE shares.

headline: CREDIT CHANGES LOOM IN NEW INTEREST CURBS
abstract: The way many Americans borrow money to finance everything from college educations to refrigerators is likely to change under the new tax law as interest deductions become subject to new restrictions.   With deductions for credit cards and other consumer loans being phased out, attention is being drawn to alternative financing sources, such as home loans, where interest deductions will be preserved.   ''I think there's going to be a massive restructuring of credit by consumers in this country,'' said Charles A. Humm, vice president of the credit management group at Merrill Lynch, which has been promoting home-equity loans. ''The idea is to reduce or possibly eliminate the use of consumer debt and use other forms of credit that are still deductible.'' A New Form of Financing    In recent weeks financial institutions have been hawking second mortgages and home-equity loans as the vogue in consumer financing. Even colleges that make direct loans to students are advised by tax consultants to get into the mortgage business so the loans will remain deductible.

headline: IRANIAN DEAL LED TO 2,200 MISSILES, A LAWMAKER SAYS
abstract: The House majority leader said today that Israel, acting with the approval of the United States, had shipped Iran 2,008 TOW anti-tank missiles and at least 235 Hawk antiaircraft missiles, a quantity of weapons much greater than previously acknowledged.   The Congressional leader, Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, said he had learned of the shipments from Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, President Reagan's national security adviser. He said there had been a series of shipments by Israel, which was ''given to understand it was carrying out the wishes of the United States.''   The statement by Mr. Wright came amid a wave of protest that swept Capitol Hill today over the Reagan policy on Iran.

headline: G.E. Will Close TV Tube Plant
abstract: The General Electric Company said today that it would close its manufacturing plant for color television tubes in July 1987, eliminating 655 hourly and 135 salaried jobs in Syracuse.   G.E. officials said the Cathode Ray Tube division, which produced in relatively small volume, could no longer compete in the highly price-sensitive market - especially in the face of strong competition from Japan and South Korea.

headline: SAKHAROV, CITING ILLS AND WORK, SAYS HE CAN'T BE FOCUS OF SOVIET DISSENT
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov said today that because of physical infirmity and a desire to renew his work in physics, he could not serve as the rallying point for dissent in the Soviet Union.   But he said in an interview that he would continue to seek ''the liberation of prisoners of conscience.''   ''This is an area where I cannot spare my efforts,'' he said.   The interview was one of a series he has been giving to Western reporterssince he returned Tuesday from exile in the city of Gorky. He was banished in early 1980 for public criticism of policies under Leonid I. Brezhnev.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Sports Illustrated will increase its circulation rate base 2.68 percent, to 2,875,000, and its advertising rates 6.7 percent with the Jan. 5 issue.

headline: HOPE DIMS ON HOSTAGES' RELEASE
abstract: Two Arab-Americans seeking the release of hostages in Lebanon said their hopes had dimmed of returning home with at least one freed captive.   On Wednesday they said that two men claiming to represent the captors had been in touch with them.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Preferred Stock   * ASB Funding Corp. plans to offer $75 million of Dutch auction rate transferrable preferred stock, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue will consist of 750 shares at a price of $100,000 a share. Common Stock    * Bank of Boston Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 2.6 million common shares, 2 million to be offered domestically through Salomon Brothers and the remainder overseas.

headline: Imported Car for Japan
abstract: The Mitsubishi Corporation is importing for sale in Japan passenger cars made by an Australian subsidiary, an official of the corporation said today. The recent rise of the yen against the Australian dollar makes it possible to sell the imported cars at prices below those of many comparable domestically produced models, he said. Twenty of the medium-size cars made by Australia Mitsubishi Motors Ltd. on a sample basis have been sold and 50 to 100 cars may be imported annually, the spokesman said.

headline: First Chicago Unit Gets A Coordinating Partner
abstract: When George L. Davis resigned his position last Friday as one of the top four people at the First Chicago Corporation, Stephen C. Diamond, an executive vice president, was called on to fill his shoes - at least in part.   Mr. Diamond, 52, was named coordinating partner of First Chicago's Global Corporate Bank, a partnership-like structure that was modeled after an investment bank to provide a lift for First Chicago's lackluster commercial operations by giving its officers greater incentives. When the Global Corporate Bank was set up, its chairman, Barry F. Sullivan, 55, announced that Mr. Davis and he would be its two senior partners - which increased speculation that Mr. Davis, an executive vice president, would some day succeed Mr. Sullivan.

headline: Credit Cards
