abstract: To the Editor:   Most surprising in ''Pick a Card, Any Card, Every Card'' (Nov. 30) was your view that American Express was ''imperiling its traditional snob-appeal'' because of its warranty extension program. While tarnishing the Amex image is always a possibility if the card becomes positioned more for refrigerators than resorts, I believe the warranty extension program will have the opposite effect.

headline: Queen Will Retire Her Horse And Ride Carriage at Parade
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II will drop her traditional horseback ride at her annual birthday parade, the Trooping the Color, in favor of a carriage instead because her horse is too old, Buckingham Palace said today.   The announcement said the 61-year-old Queen feels that Burmese, the Canadian-bred black mare she has ridden side-saddle at the mid-June ceremony for the last 18 years, should be retired and she does not want to use a new horse.   Burmese, who was given to the Queen by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, is now nearly 24.

headline: QUAKER STARS IN A WALL STREET SOAP
abstract: IF the bizarre takeover battle for the Anderson Clayton Corporation had been a Broadway melodrama, the curtain for the final scene would have gone up on the comfortable, book-lined study at Charles Nathan's Brooklyn town house.   It is just before dawn in late September. Mr. Nathan, a balding investment banker for Salomon Brothers, is seated at his desk. He will spend most of the scene talking intently on the telephone, putting together a deal. At one point, women's voices are heard offstage. Mr. Nathan's mother-in-law has just arrived from Chicago, weary from a rain-delayed flight. Torn, he puts a caller on hold and rushes from the study to greet her and help show her to the guest room. For the moment that he is gone, the phone's red button light blinks urgently.   Mr. Nathan, in his mid-40's, has been up all night quarterbacking the final bidding by the Quaker Oats Company for Anderson Clayton, another food products concern that Quaker is trying to buy. In the climactic moment, just before the curtain falls, Quaker's $66-a-share bid for Anderson Clayton is accepted, virtually assuring purchase of the company for about $800 million.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * American Standard Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million of debt securities.    * A.T.&T. Credit Corp. has filed for the sale of up to $1 billion of medium-term notes through Salomon Brothers Inc. and First Boston Corp.    * Citizens and Southern Corp. is offering $100 million of A-1/A+ rated 8 percent, seven-year notes at 99.25, to yield 8.14 percent, through First Boston.

headline: Microsoft Regains Licensing Rights
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation, based in Redmond, Wash., said it had agreed to buy back seven licensing agreements from Seattle Computer Products Inc. for $925,000.

headline: Asset-Backed G.M.A.C. Notes
abstract: G.M.A.C. Series 1986-F Grantor Trust, formed by General Motors Acceptance Corporation, is offering $326.96 million of asset-backed certificates through underwriters led by First Boston Corporation.   The certificates, backed by automobile and light-truck loans, bear a 6.85 percent coupon and are priced at 99.65 to yield about 7 percent, or 71-hundredths of a percentage point more than two-year Treasury note on a when-issued basis.   Rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., the issue has an estimated average life of 1.9 years with the underlying loans having a weighted average coupon of 11.7 percent and a weighted average life remaining to maturity of about 4.5 years.

headline: ARMS NOT 'RANSOM'
abstract: President Reagan, under intense domestic and international criticism, tonight defended what he called his ''secret diplomatic initiative to Iran'' and vigorously denied that the United States had sought to exchange weapons for American hostages in Lebanon.   In a nationally broadcast speech from the Oval Office, Mr. Reagan said he had authorized the transfer of ''small amounts of defensive weapons and spare parts'' to Iran. The President said his intent was to ''send a signal that the United States was prepared to replace the animosity between us with a new relationship.''   It is ''utterly false,'' the President said, to assert that the United States sent weapons to Iran as ''ransom'' for Americans held in Lebanon. He said at another point that one of the reasons for the diplomatic initiative was ''to effect the safe return of all hostages.''

headline: Calm Trading for Second Day
abstract: In the second consecutive day of desultory trading, interest rates were little changed for short or long maturities.   Prices of Treasury notes and bonds had recovered from the modest declines early in the day, and ended the day at close to their highest levels. Rates for Treasury bills fell slightly.  ''The decline in the Federal funds rate helped the tone of the market, especially in the short end,'' said Doug McAllister, a sales manager in the government securities department at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Among longer maturities, Mr. McAllister said, fears of a quick rise in inflation have subsided, but that has not been enough to entice many institutional investors.

headline: Gerber Debentures
abstract: The Gerber Products Company is offering $100 million of noncallable 9 percent debentures due in 2006 at 99.625, to yield 9.041 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Company. Rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., the debentures yield 1.12 percentage points more than Treasury bonds with a similar maturity.

headline: Morgan Stanley Partners
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm, announced Friday that it had elected 32 new managing partners, three of whom are the first women to receive that title. They are Karen H. Bechtel, Catherine B. James and Marie-Elaine A. La Roche. Ms. Bechtel, 37 years old, is a merger and acquisitions specialist in the investment banking division. Ms. La Roche, 37, is director of marketing for the fixed-income division, and Ms. James, 34, is corporate finance officer for the insurance and financial service group.

headline: 2 Former Reagan Aides Invoke 5th Amendment in House Hearing on Iran
abstract: Two former White House officials linked to the diversion of Iran arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels declined again today to answer questions before Congress, invoking their Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.   But the two officials, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee in separate appearances that they wanted to cooperate fully and would reveal what they knew at an appropriate time.   ''I don't think there is another person in America that wants to tell this story as much as I do,'' Colonel North said. An 'Appropriate' Forum    Lawyers for both Colonel North and Admiral Poindexter told the committee that neither was actively seeking immunity for his client. Under a grant of immunity, the two officers could testify without fear that what they said could be used in evidence against them.

headline: THE SINGAPORE CONNECTION
abstract: The Singapore International Monetary Exchange finally appears to be living up to its advance billing. Though still not bursting with energy on most days, the Simex recently showed why it was hailed as a prototype of the time when financial exchanges would be linked across international boundaries 24 hours a day.   Simex's chance to serve as a financial trading link among exchanges that girded the globe occurred when rumors of an imminent discount rate cut in Japan awakened American financial managers in the early morning hours of Oct. 30. Scrambling to protect their exposed financial positions in fixed-income securities and to take advantage of the possibility of an imminent rally in the bond market, money managers turned to Simex, where contracts in financial futures change hands after futures exchanges close in Chicago and before trading opens in London.   For those managers who had already bet that bond prices would drop, the idea was to buy financial futures on the Simex that would gain in value and offset the loss back home if Japan cut its discount rate. Foreign orders helped send trading volume on the two-year-old financial futures market here soaring to a record 17,821 contracts as overseas money managers hedged.

headline: Pole Bars Solidarity Talks
abstract: Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner has declared that he will not talk with leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union because they oppose Communism, the official press agency PAP said today. ''There will not be any talks with the opponents of this system,'' Mr. Messner said in a speech to a Communist Party conference on Saturday.

headline: SCORES DIE AS BUILDINGS COLLAPSE
abstract: A strong earthquake and a series of aftershocks hit the Salvadoran capital this morning, causing extensive damage in the center of the city and killing at least 100 people.   Casualty figures were not precise because rescue workers had not yet dug through a number of damaged buildings. At least one large office building in the center of the city was destroyed.   Strong tremors continued throughout the afternoon, sending inhabitants of the capital into the streets, where they remained tonight, sleeping in makeshift shelters.  [ Radio Cuscatlan, a station monitored in neighboring Honduras, said about 45 people were known dead, including at least 30 youths whose bodies were found in two schools, and another radio station, YSU, said more than 150 people were killed in the collapse of the 10-story Ruben Dario theater building, The Associated Press reported. Neither report could be confirmed immediately. ] [ Doctors said about 50 children died at the Bloom Children's Hospital and an undetermined number of people were trapped beneath the rubble, according to United Press International. The news agency said President Jose Napoleon Duarte had declared a state of national emergency and pleaded for ''tranquillity'' among Salvadorans. ]  Emergency clinics were set up on street corners, but communication was cut in most of the capital and electricity was available in only a few neighborhoods.

headline: BRAZIL ELECTIONS PROMISE CHANGES
abstract: Brazil is in the midst of its first national election campaign since civilian rule returned last year. But a long-anticipated debate on Brazil's political future is overshadowed by regional issues and personality clashes.   The elections are widely regarded as a crucial part of Brazil's transition from dictatorship to democracy, since the Congress to be chosen Nov. 15 will write a new constitution - the country's eighth - to replace one imposed by the ruling military in 1969.   In the process, it will decide when the next presidential elections - the first by direct popular vote since 1960 - will be held, whether a presidential or parliamentary system will be adopted, what role the state should assume in the economy and what - if any - circumstances authorize the armed forces to seize power without violating the constitution.

headline: Exxon Leaving South Africa
abstract: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it is selling its interests in South Africa because of the deteriorating economic and business conditions there brought on by the country's racial crisis. Exxon's involvement in   South Africa is relatively minor.

headline: Accuray-Hercules
abstract: The Accuray Corporation and Hercules Inc. said their boards had approved a merger agreement under which Hercules would acquire Accuray for $40 a share - $5 more than a recent offer by Combustion Engineering.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE SAYS 200,000 FLED
abstract: The national news agency said today that about 200,000 people had fled into neighboring Malawi in the last six weeks to escape attacks by rebels fighting Mozambique's Marxist Government.   The news agency said rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance had hacked 44 peasants to death in two incidents and were seen crossing into Malawi with sheet metal, furniture and other goods taken in the attacks.   The agency quoted officials as saying that this proved Malawian complicity in the attacks. The Government has long claimed the rebels are based in Malawi, but that country denies it.

headline: ALL NIPPON WILL BUY 11 BOEING 747'S
abstract: The All Nippon Airways Company will buy eleven 747 jumbo jets from the Boeing Company for $1.56 billion as part of the Japanese carrier's plan to expand its new international routes, the two companies said today.   Delivery of the aircraft, including spare parts, is scheduled to begin next July and continue through 1992.   Akio Kondo, the airline's deputy president and chief operating officer, said at a news conference that the specific model of the 747 aircraft would depend on talks with the airline's pilots on whether their union would accept cockpit crews with two members instead of three. 747-400 Uses Two-Member Crew The Boeing 747-200 requires three crew members, while the advanced 747-400, which will begin to roll off assembly lines in late 1988, relies more heavily on computers and is certified for a two-member crew. Each of the aircraft, including spare parts, will be worth about $110 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1986
abstract: The Economy      An immigrant surge in New York's Chinatown has lifted rents to the level of midtown Manhattan, making the commercial real estate in one dingy corner of the city among the most expensive in the nation. The demand for space is so strong, local real estate brokers say, that the operators of vegetable stalls near one bustling intersection pay more rent per square foot than the owners of Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue.  [ Page 1. ]    The Fed plans to decide in April whether to expand banks' role in underwriting securities. The question is whether banks should be permitted to underwrite commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities and municipal revenue bonds.  [ 45. ]

headline: SHOCKER ON SOVIET TV: BROOKLYN EMIGRE CANDOR
abstract: Soviet television viewers have been given an unusual offering: an uncensored, uncut American television documentary on Soviet emigres in Brooklyn, openly discussing their problems not only with the society they joined but also with the one they left.   Uttering thoughts usually considered provocative or worse in the Soviet Union, Jewish immigrants interviewed on the documentary spoke of the ''totalitarian'' system they left, the corruption and black market they had to deal with and the regimentation that marked their social life.   They also spoke of the problems they have encountered in the United States in finding jobs, making friends, wrestling with unfamiliar freedoms, choices, rights, of trading the cradle-to-grave security of the Soviet system for a brutal commercialism, of profound nostalgia for their homeland.   The documentary, called ''The Russians Are Here,'' was made by an Israeli film maker for American public television and first shown in the United States in 1983. It was broadcast on Soviet television Sept. 21, accompanied by a long commentary led by Genrikh Borovik, a journalist and critic who has taken the lead in portraying the ills of American life to Soviet audiences.

headline: DESIGNER PACKAGES THAT SELL
abstract: Decades of advertising taught America to spell cheese K-R-A-F-T. But consumers walking into supermarkets in recent years have had difficulty spotting the famous brand name amid a wall of lookalike competitors.   ''Everything looked the same,'' said James G. Shennan Jr., president of S&O Consultants, a San Francisco packaging design firm that recently helped Kraft Inc. give its cheeses a face lift.   When the bandages came off last month, the 130 Kraft cheese packages had a new color scheme, a bigger logotype and a more uniform look that the company hopes will make the brand stand out more on crowded retail shelves.   Whether the new look will help sell more cheese remains to be seen, and some skeptics wonder whether consumers will even notice the design changes. But executives at Kraft, like most other makers of consumer goods, are investing ever-increasing amounts of time and money into remaking their faces to grab the attention of harried shoppers.

headline: MANY LAWS BEAR ON DEALS
abstract: Several laws bear on American arms shipments to Iran, and the question of whether any have been violated has still to be resolved by legal experts.   In 1979, when Iran seized Americans as hostages, President Carter directed that all arms exports to that country be banned under authority of the Arms Export Control Act.   At the same time, a Carter order froze Iranian assets in the United States, and that order has been renewed each year by President Reagan, the last time just this week. Iran and the United States, however, are nearing an agreement on the return of $500 million - the balance left in a $3.667 billion account - in Iranian funds held by the Federal Reserve Bank since 1981.

headline: OPEC PACT ON OUTPUT LIKELY TO EXEMPT IRAQ
abstract: OPEC ministers inched closer today to an agreement to curb oil production, but it appeared that any accord would exempt Iraq.   The plan under discussion by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries calls for a 7 percent reduction in total output, aimed at pushing the price of crude oil toward $18 a barrel. ''We will not be part of that agreement,'' Qassim Ahmed Taki, Iraq's oil minister, said today.   OPEC officials would not discuss whether the 7 percent reduction would be made from the temporary, reduced levels agreed to in August and October or from the previous quotas.

headline: Anchor Hocking Rejects Newell Bid
abstract: The Anchor Hocking Corporation, a maker of household packaging and hardware products, said its board had rejected a $330 million takeover proposal from the Newell Company on the ground that it was not a firm offer. The company said that, after consulting with its financial and legal advisers, its board reached that conclusion because the proposal was open-ended, lacking in commitment and potentially detrimental to shareholders.

headline: PICKENS MEETS DIRECTORS
abstract: After a two-day meeting that included a discussion with its unsolicited suitors, led by T. Boone Pickens, the board of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today that it was still evaluating the $2.03 billion takeover offer from Mesa Limited Partnership.   The directors met in Rye Brook, N.Y., Thursday night and this morning, and sources said that they would meet again on Wednesday in Dallas to continue their review of the proposal. The sources said that the directors were expected to announce their recommendation to shareholders after next week's meeting.

headline: 2 QUESTIONED IN PALME CASE, BUT MYSTERY GOES ON
abstract: Two men identified as Kurdish political activists were arrested after a barroom shootout and questioned by the police tonight in their investigation into the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme.   There was no official word on whether the men were formal suspects in the killing or merely more of the hundreds of people who have been interrogated and released in the nine-month-old manhunt.   Unofficially, the police said the men were members of a Kurdish organization listed as a suspected terrorist group. Police officials said two members of the group, the Kurdish Workers' Party, had been convicted of homicides in recent years in Stockholm and in Uppsala, 40 miles to the north.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: A 'Perfect' Timepiece Sought in West Germany
abstract: Here's a timely gift idea. Junghans Uhren G.m.b.H. of Schramberg, West Germany, says it is working to develop the ultimate wristwatch, a timepiece so accurate it will lose only one second in 150,000 years.

headline: AMERICANS HOPEFUL AS GENEVA TALKS RESUME
abstract: The Geneva arms talks resumed today, and the Americans characterized the Iceland meeting last weekend as an unexpectedly successful ''serious and positive step.   Max M. Kampelman, the chief American negotiator, said the United States believed the Iceland talks could help the resolution of the issues under discussion here.   In candid and optimistic comments before today's meetings of the subgroups on space defenses and on strategic arms, Mr. Kampelman said the United States was ready to ''formalize'' an agreement eliminating medium-range missiles in Europe and reducing them in Asia.   He also said the United States would pursue a proposal to eliminate all ballistic missiles within 10 years. But he cautioned that differences remained over the United States' space-based missile defense program, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative and popularly as ''Star Wars.''

headline: 2 MORE LOSE POSTS IN MANILA CABINET
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino removed two more Cabinet ministers today and announced a package of new benefits for soldiers.   Her actions indicated that she was moving to reciprocate for the support of the armed forces, which had united behind her at the eleventh hour to block armed action by a group of dissident officers last month.   Meanwhile, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the armed forces Chief of Staff, announced that that he was stripping the dissident officers of their armor by redeploying 10 armored vehicles in a move to ''demilitarize the ministry.'' The dissidents, all backers of the former Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, hold commands in the Defense Ministry's security group. Mrs. Aquino ousted Mr. Enrile on Nov. 23.

headline: AdvertisingPhilip H. Dougherty; New Ads Step Up to The Plate
abstract: THE makeup and size of a World Series television audience makes the telecasts of the games an ideal place to introduce new advertising campaigns for masses of males.   So, according to ad agency sources, the NBC-TV network is getting about $240,000 per 30-second spot for the games and will be offering audiences of 18 million to 24 million households - and a few gin mills as well.   It is obviously the kind of audience that appeals to companies involved in the information revolution. Companies such as Apple Computer Inc., whose new advertising was reported here on Oct. 7, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose top advertising executive previewed some rough renditions of his TV commercials and finished print work yesterday.

headline: Freighter Sinks Near Iceland; 6 Reported Lost and 5 Saved
abstract: An Icelandic freighter carrying 19,000 barrels of herring sank in rough seas in the north Atlantic early today.

headline: BACK TO BASICS AT QUAKER OATS
abstract: During the last 15 years, the Quaker Oats Company has struggled to diversify, trying everything from clothes and hardware to fast-food restaurants and video games. But with one notable exception - its Fisher-Price toy line - Quaker has kept coming back to the same conclusion: Its traditional name-brand packaged foods base is the company's only sure-fire source of growth.  That lesson has been the driving force behind the company's recent flurry of acquisitions and planned restructurings.  In August, Quaker agreed to pay $278 million for the Golden Grain Company, adding Rice-a-Roni to such formidable brand names as Gatorade, Ken'l Ration, Aunt Jemima and the Quaker labels. The next month, Quaker beat out the Ralston Purina Company to acquire Anderson, Clayton & Company for $812 million. This time the prize was the Gaines pet food line.

headline: Guilty Plea in Theft of $13.5 Million
abstract: An investment banker based in Greenwich, Conn., has pleaded guilty to stealing $13.5 million from two banks and attempting to steal $23 million from three other banks in a complex scheme that involved faked documents and impostors who posed as bank officers and brokers.   The defendant, John A. Grambling Jr., who is 36 years old, faces up to 20 years in prison after pleading guilty to a 32-count indictment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. A co-defendant, Robert H. Libman of North Miami, Fla., pleaded guilty last month to fifth-degree conspiracy for his role in the scheme, impersonating financial officers. He was sentenced last week to six months in jail.

headline: STATEMENT BY REAGAN AND KEY SECTIONS OF REMARKS BY MEESE
abstract: Following are a transcript of President Reagan's statement and exchange with reporters in Washington yesterday, as provided by the White House and transmitted by The Associated Press, and key sections of a news conference by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, as recorded by The New York Times:   Comments by Reagan Last Friday, after becoming concerned whether my national security apparatus had provided me with a security, or a complete factual record with respect to the implementation of my policy toward Iran, I directed the Attorney General to undertake a review of this matter over the weekend and report to me on Monday.   And yesterday, Secretary Meese provided me and the White House chief of staff with a report on his preliminary findings. And this report led me to conclude that I was not fully informed on the nature of one of the activities undertaken in connection with this initiative. This action raises serious questions of propriety.   I've just met with my national security advisers and Congressional leaders to inform them of the actions that I'm taking today. Determination of the full details of this action will require further review and investigation by the Department of Justice.

headline: Radio Address by Reagan From Camp David
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's radio address today from the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., as recorded by The Associated Press:  I'm speaking to you today from Camp David. And because the atmosphere here is a bit more informal than every day in Washington, I thought it would be a good opportunity to think and reflect with you about those crucial foreign policy matters in the news lately.   It's also a chance to do something I have wanted to do throughout the course of these events, and that's share some personal thoughts with you, to speak to you the American people from the heart.   I realize you must be disappointed and probably confused with all the furor of the last couple of weeks. You must be asking, what were we doing in the Middle East, what was our policy, where was it wrong, were we engaged in some kind of shenanigans that blew up in our face?

headline: DeLOREAN FRAUD TRIAL READY
abstract: John Z. DeLorean, the flamboyant auto maker who was acquitted in Los Angeles two years ago on charges of cocaine trafficking, is scheduled to go on trial here Monday on charges that he schemed to bilk investors in his failed car company.   Mr. DeLorean was indicted in September 1985 on 15 Federal counts of criminal fraud and racketeering stemming from his handling of money raised to finance the engineering and development of the sports car that bore his name. According to the Government, Mr. DeLorean arranged for $8.5 million to be transferred through a series of Swiss and Dutch accounts to his personal bank account in the United States.   Preliminary maneuverings by both sides indicate that the tone of the trial will be testy, with Mr. DeLorean portrayed by his lawyers as a man hounded by government officials on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: 9-Nation Bond Index by Salomon
abstract: A new bond index measuring the government securities markets in nine countries, including the United States, Japan and Britain, was announced yesterday by officials at Salomon Brothers.   Called the world government bond index, the new entrant is the first of several indexes measuring foreign markets that Salomon Brothers officials expect to introduce in the future.

headline: NIGERIA SEEKS THE SLAYERS OF AN EDITOR
abstract: ''Hello,'' starts one note penned by a 15-year-old schoolgirl. ''Elephant fails and cannot stand up. Dele Giwa, good-bye.''   Another, typed by a college student, contains an ode to ''Giwa, the Honest and Patriotic Son of the African soil.''   Mourning a man they never met, these letter writers are two of thousands of Nigerians who recently have flooded the offices of Newswatch, Nigeria's largest news magazine.

headline: FORCING BANKS TO MARK DOWN LOANS
abstract: MANY Latin American countries became debt junkies during the decade of the 1970's. Now these countries claim that they cannot maintain their habits. In an attempt to keep the debtors addicted and to give the illusion that creditors are in perfect health, our financial alchemists have devised a virtual international Ponzi scheme. Here's how it works: If, after 90 days, interest due is not paid, loans must be placed in ''non-accrual status.'' At the same time, these loans are often declared ''non-performing'' and written down. But, to avoid these unpleasantries, banks have taken to rescheduling loans. In addition to reducing the servicing costs and extending the life of old loans, this procedure typically requires creditors to lend new money, which gives debtors the money to pay interest owed on old loans. As a result of these maneuvers, debts grow; loans continue to ''perform'' and are carried on the books at face value; and bank profits are realized.

headline: Lucky Stores To Study Offer
abstract: Lucky Stores said Friday that its board would consider a sweetened offer from Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, at a special meeting to be scheduled this week.   Lucky executives and directors met with Mr. Edelman late last week after he raised his offer for the Dublin, Calif., retailer to $37 a share, or $1.88 billion, from $35 a share.   Earlier this month, Lucky announced that it would close its 80 unprofitable Gemco stores, sell most of the Gemco leases to the Dayton Hudson Corporation and buy back up to 11.3 million shares of its approximately 52 million shares outstanding.

headline: Varian Associates Loss
abstract: Stung by the continuing slump in the semiconductor industry and charges resulting from plant shutdowns, Varian Associates Inc. today reported a loss of $11.4 million for its fourth quarter ended Oct. 3, in contrast to earnings of $11.1 million, or 55 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales rose 1.9 percent, to $236.3 million, from $231.9 million in the 1985 period. ''Conditions in our major markets were worse than we had anticipated,'' Thomas D. Sege, Varian's chairman, said in a statement.

headline: HARD-HIT MEXICO TRIES TO COPE
abstract: For several recent weeks, the people of Mexico City coped with a scarcity of eggs.   Producers, eager to raise prices because of Mexico's potent inflation, held their eggs off the market. They did so to bring pressure on the Government, which controls the price.   ''You can swear on it that they are going to raise the price soon, and that the egg men are hiding the eggs so that people get desperate,'' Dolores Villamil Reyes, a 57-year-old beautician, said during the contretemps.   The administration of President Miguel de la Madrid will not fall over the price of eggs, but the shortage was yet another symbol of the deterioration of Mexico's economy.

headline: Interest Rates Hold Steady
abstract: Interest rates were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday, and were little affected by the Federal Reserve's late afternoon announcement of slightly faster money supply growth than was expected for October.   Fresh data for money supply growth last month attracted more attention than usual, because a recently published summary of a Sept. 23 meeting of monetary policy officials showed they were concerned enough about rapid money supply growth to consider a slight tightening of monetary policy.   ''Growth in the broader money aggregates was stronger than expected, but I don't think it is going to lead to any material change in Fed policy,'' said William Sullivan, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He said sluggish economic growth and diminished fears of inflation, as shown by declines in precious metal prices and bond yields since Sept. 23, argued against any central bank move to tighten monetary policy and raise short-term interest rates. 'To Rule Out Any Move'   Mr. Sullivan added that growth in the M-2 and M-3 money supply measures is rapid enough ''to rule out any move towards an easing in policy'' and a decline in short-term rates.

headline: JEFFREY ARCHER QUITS HIS TORY PARTY POST AMID VICE SCANDAL
abstract: Caught in the coils of a plot he might well have devised for one of his best-selling novels, Jeffrey Archer resigned today as deputy chairman of the Conservative Party after a Sunday tabloid disclosed he had made a payoff to a prostitute.   Mr. Archer, a politician who turned to fiction after an embarrassing bankruptcy forced him to give up a seat in the House of Commons, had held his unpaid post in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's party for a little more than a year.   His political comeback was abruptly terminated by the appearance in The News of the World, a newspaper that specializes in scandal, of a phone conversation he had Thursday evening with the prostitute.   In the recorded conversation, arrangements were made for the prostitute, Monica Coghlan, to receive money from an intermediary the next morning so she could leave the country.

headline: Choose a Casket, Get a Tree For Free
abstract: FOR every coffin purchased, Batesville Casket, the country's largest coffin maker, donates money to a fund that plants a tree in a national forest in memory of the deceased.   Keith & Keith Funeral Home in Yakima, Wash., videotapes funerals for the benefit of family members too far away to attend.   Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx offers walking tours that highlight the graves of notables buried there, outdoor musical tributes to George Gershwin every Mother's Day and to George M. Cohan (who is buried there) on July 4 and, for the first time this year, a Christmas tree lighting celebration. ''These events are important from a marketing and competitive standpoint,'' explained Jeanne Capodilupo, Woodlawn's director of public relations. ''About a third of the people that attend are here for the first time, and many ask for more information'' about the cemetery.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1986
abstract: The World   A Moslem group freed an American in Lebanon. The hostage, David Jacobsen, was the director of American University Hospital when he was seized nearly 18 months ago. The possibility of releasing others was also hinted at.     Page A1    President Reagan hailed the release of Mr. Jacobsen and warned that his Islamic Holy War captors would be held ''responsible'' for the safety of the remaining American hostages.

headline: Nike Profit Off; Revenues Fall
abstract: Nike Inc., a leading athletic shoe and apparel maker based in Beaverton, Ore., today reported a profit of $14.9 million, or 39 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter, ended Aug. 31.   This was down 38 percent from $24.2 million, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday misattributed a description of autumn as a season of ''mists and mellow fruitfulness.'' The quotation, from the poem ''To Autumn,'' was by Keats, not Coleridge.

headline: G.E. WILL CLOSE TRANSFORMER UNIT
abstract: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would stop building large transformers - the huge machines that regulate voltage for electricity generating stations -in the United States. It also said it would combine its transformer operations in Canada with those of Westinghouse.   G.E. gave no financial details about either the closing of its United States large-transformer division in Pittsfield, Mass., or the proposed venture of its Canadian subsidiary, Canadian General Electric, with Westinghouse Canada Inc.

headline: Advertising; Hotels Pick New Agencies
abstract: A COUPLE of hotel chains checked out of their ad agencies over the weekend.   Helmsley Hotels dismissed Beber Silverstein & Partners of Miami and has assigned the business to Noel Frankel & Associates, formed recently by the B.S. New York creative director.   The Intercontinental Hotels Corporation left Grey Advertising, which it retained in January 1983, and moved its $4 million business to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon GGK. The assignment is for a worldwide corporate campaign. Intercontinental has 100 hotels.  For the assignment, the agency will be, among other things, preparing both print and electronic advertising for international markets.

headline: COURT RULES FOR BANK ON COMMERCIAL PAPER
abstract: In what commercial bankers called an important victory in their attempts to take on Wall Street, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Bankers Trust New York Corporation may act as a commercial-paper agent.   The ruling, by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, means that Bankers Trust may continue placing commercial paper - short-term i.o.u.'s issued by large corporations that are traded in the open market. The New York banking company's commercial paper group had been hamstrung by the possibility that the court would rule against it.   ''A legal cloud has been removed from the bank's commercial paper operation,'' said Thomas Parisi, the Bankers Trust spokesman.

headline: Margeotes, Fertitta Gets Nature's Bounty
abstract: Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss has added Nature's Bounty Vitamins of Bohemia, L.I., to its client list.

headline: Macy's Malls Sold
abstract: Westfield Holdings Ltd. of Australia agreed to acquire the three shopping centers wholly owned by R.H. Macy & Company for $363.5 million. The three malls are the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J.; the South Shore Mall in Bay Shore, L.I., and the Bay Fair Mall in San Leandro, Calif. The deal also includes a 44-acre parcel adjacent to the Garden State Plaza.

headline: Shift in SCI-Storer Setup
abstract: SCI Holdings Inc., the closely held successor to Storer Communications Inc., said Friday that it would liquidate and transfer its operations to a limited partnership called Storer Communications L.P. The company said the move was intended to take advantage of provisions in present tax laws that favor the partnership form over the corporate form for holding companies disposing of subsidiaries. It said it would repay, in full, about $660 million of existing bank debt.

headline: Article 755886 -- No Title
abstract: The British and Commonwealth Shipping Company, a diversified concern headed by John Gunn, a financier, has agreed to buy Exco International P.L.C. in a deal valued at $948.2 million. Exco is a London-based money-brokering company that Mr. Gunn founded and ran until last year.

headline: Oil-Tax Fears in Venezuela
abstract: President Jaime Lusinchi has criticized a proposed United States tax on imported oil, saying that it represents a protectionist act that could seriously damage the economy of Venezuala and other oil-exporting nations.   Mr. Lusinchi made the comment on Sunday before leaving on a nine-day official visit to Spain and Portugal.

headline: Walesa and Others Ask U.S. to End Sanctions
abstract: Lech Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union movement, joined nine well-known critics of the Government today in calling on President Reagan to lift remaining American economic restrictions and help Poland toward economic recovery.   The 300-word statement was to have been printed today in Tygodnik Powszechny, a Cracow-based independent weekly Catholic newspaper, but the censor's office did not issue it in time for the paper's deadline.

headline: ...AND A JEFFERIES EARLY BIRD
abstract: When Harold C. Simmons concluded last August that he could take command of NL Industries by buying enough shares on the open market to gain a controlling stake, it was Jefferies & Company that sold the Dallas investor the stock in a matter of minutes.   ''It was simply smart marketing on their part,'' Mr. Simmons said.   Under its hard-driving founder and chairman, Boyd L. Jefferies, the Los Angeles-based firm has forged a highly profitable business of trading large blocks of stocks at all hours of the day and week. Indeed, Wall Street traders say Jefferies & Company may have the nation's most detailed, computerized data banks of trading patterns among these professional investors who often are decisive in takeover battles.

headline: Penn Central To Sell Units
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation yesterday announced a series of transactions involving the sale and public offering of most of its energy-related businesses.   The dealings will increase the company's cash holdings to more than $1 billion by yearend.

headline: MONTREAL TO VOTE FOR MAYOR TODAY
abstract: In an election that will end an era of Montreal politics, citizens will vote Sunday to pick a successor to Jean Drapeau, the city's Mayor for the last 26 years.   The candiates are Jean Dore, 41 years old, a labor lawyer who appears to be the favorite, and Claude Dupras, 54, a consulting engineer who is Mr. Drapeau's handpicked choice to succeed him.   A poll this week in the daily Le Journal de Montreal indicated that Mr. Dore has the support of 71 percent of the voters, compared with 29 percent for Mr. Dupras.   Mayor Drapeau's Civic Party is in reality a private club, closed to popular membership. The party consists only of Mr. Drapeau's handpicked group of city councilors and potential candidates for municipal seats.

headline: KAHANE MAY BE FADING, BUT THE IDEAS GAIN GROUND
abstract: After reaching a pinnacle last summer, Rabbi Meir Kahane's popularity has fallen drastically in recent Israeli public opinion polls.   But although his personal appeal has diminished, he is still influencing Israeli politics. Among his ideas is one calling for the expulsion of all Arabs from Israel and the occupied territories.   ''Kahane as an individual has lost popularity,'' the poll-taker Hanoch Smith said. ''But Kahanism as an ideology is gaining.''

headline: SOVIET DISSIDENT TO ARRIVE TODAY
abstract: The authorities have told the wife of Yuri F. Orlov, the dissident, that he has been brought back from Siberian exile and will be put on an Aeroflot flight for New York on Sunday.   Mr. Orlov's wife, Irina L. Valitova, who has been using her maiden name since his arrest in 1977, was told of his deportation by an official of the visa agency on Friday. She was also handed her own ticket for the flight; she paid 900 rubles for the ticket last week.

headline: MAking the Most of Margin Accounts
abstract: A BY-PRODUCT of two recent financial developments - falling interest rates and a rising stock market - has been an increase in the use of margin account buying, or borrowing against one's stock portfolio.   With margin loan rates averaging 8 percent, significantly less than rates on bank or credit card debt, some people are attracted to margin borrowing as a source of ready cash. More traditional borrowers use margin loans to leverage their investment portfolios and make quick profits in a highly volatile market.   Whatever the reason, investors held a record $34.6 billion in margin debt at the end of September, compared with $28.4 billion at the end of 1985, according to statistics compiled by the New York Stock Exchange. ''It reflects the fact that the Dow has increased in recent years, and that, given the interest rate environment, margin borrowing can be an efficient way to increase the level of their investments,'' said Charles A. Humm, vice president of the Credit Management Group at Merrill Lynch.

headline: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP BY 3.3%
abstract: Prices farmers get for raw products averaged 3.3 percent higher in November, the first increase in the monthly index since July, the Agriculture Department said today.   But the increase, based on preliminary figures, still left the overall farm commodity price index 1.6 percent below the level of a year ago.   The department's Agricultural Statistics Board said higher prices for oranges, lettuce, cotton, grains, eggs and milk led the advance in the November index. However, lower prices for broilers, grapefruit, strawberries and apples offset part of the increase for the other commodities.

headline: OIL GROUP WARNED ON IMPORT FEE
abstract: The head of Mexico's national oil company told an oil industry conference today that a United States oil import fee - or equivalent measures - would provoke retaliation by many of America's trading partners, not just oil producers, and would harm American export industries.   The comments of Mario Ramon Beteta, director general of Petroleos Mexicanos, to those attending the American Petroleum Institute's annual meeting here, appeared to be a direct response to the increasing pleas by American oil executives for direct help from Washington.   Such a call was reiterated shortly before Mr. Beteta addressed a concluding session of the petroleum institute's meeting, and from the same podium.

headline: NET FALLS AT AMOCO, ASHLAND
abstract: The Amoco Corporation, one of the nation's largest energy companies, said yesterday that its earnings dropped 97.3 percent in the third quarter because of a $162 million special charge for various offshore properties that have been drilled without success.   Separately, Phillips Petroleum posted a 21.5 percent gain in earnings, and the Amerada Hess Corporation said that its profits rose 15.1 percent. Meanwhile, Ashland Oil Inc. said its earnings had slipped 26.1 percent. Amoco    Amoco said its third-quarter net income fell to $13 million, or 5 cents a share, from $490 million, or $1.87 a share, in the 1985 period. Revenues dropped 37.5 percent, to $4.5 billion, from $7.2 billion a year earlier.

headline: Fomon Replies
abstract: To the Editor:   ''America's Imperial C.E.O.'' (Oct. 12) prominently featured a quotation attributed to me: ''No chief executive can be held accountable for any single thing that happens in a corporation.'' What I recall saying was that a chief executive cannot be held personally responsible for everything that happens in a major corporation.

headline: Buying a Car
abstract: To the Editor:   Many articles talk about the interest rate savings and/or its comparison with cash rebates. None that I have read, however, mention whether there is a true savings if depreciation is factored in, when comparing all of the interest and/or rebate deals, in purchasing a 1986 model versus a 1987 model. I would think that the impact would be considerable.  JAY S. GINGOLD  New York, Oct. 15

headline: Net Up 11.1% at McDonald's
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation today reported record net income of $142.3 million in the third quarter, up 11.1 percent from $128.1 in the corresponding quarter last year.

headline: Reagan Sees Haitian; Aid Package Discussed
abstract: President Reagan met today with Haiti's interim leader, Gen. Henri Namphy, and discussed a $100 million American aid package.   General Namphy, who took office after President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled Haiti in February, also met with Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.   As part of General Namphy's visit, the two Governments agreed to a major training initiative for Haiti that would make available aid over the next five years for training technicians, administrators, medical personnel and business professionals.

headline: AQUINO CHALLENGER DENIES ACCUSATIONS OF STEALING U.S. AID
abstract: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile today denied accusations that he had diverted American military aid to the Philippines for his personal use, and he accused his critics of trying to blackmail him into stopping his agitation against the Government.   ''Needless to say, I shall not be silenced or intimidated,'' he said. ''I never expected that ill-meaning quarters would stoop so low in their partisan efforts to besmirch not only my name but that of my family.''   The opening last week of a Justice Department investigation of the accusations against Mr. Enrile, coming at this sensitive moment in Philippine politics, was taken by some Filipinos as a new involvement of the United States Government in their affairs. As Mr. Enrile's challenge has grown, the United States has emphatically restated its support for President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: CONSTITUTION POSES AQUINO CHALLENGE
abstract: A new Philippine constitution approved by a presidential panel this week may produce the first electoral challenge to the eight-month-old Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.   The constitution, which was formally presented to the President today, will be put to a nationwide plebiscite in January that is developing into something of a vote of confidence in the Aquino administration.   Once in place, the constitution would end the legal limbo in which Mrs. Aquino placed her administration last March when she scrapped the 1973 charter under which she was elected and declared herself the head of a ''revolutionary government.''   Mrs. Aquino has called the charter the ''framework of the house of democracy that we hope to build.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1986
abstract: Companies    BankAmerica's chief executive, Samuel Armacost, will resign this weekend, the troubled bank holding company said. Industry sources said Mr. Armacost's departure was forced. During his 5 1/2 years at the helm, BankAmerica was surpassed in size by Citicorp and posted huge losses. Mr. Armacost's successor is expected to be A. W. Clausen, who had preceded him at the company before leaving for the World Bank.  [ Page 1. ]  Mr. Armacost's tenure began to unravel in the middle of last month, sources said.  [ 39. ]  Mr. Armacost was once seen as a bright young banker who would lead the industry into the new era of deregulation.  [ 39. ]  Mr. Clausen, 63, spent his entire career at the bank, including 11 years at the top.  [ 41. ]    Intel reported its largest quarterly loss ever and said it was withdrawing from the bubble memory business. Another big chip maker, Advanced Micro Devices, also had a loss that was considerably larger than last year's. Both companies took charges against earnings in the quarter as they tried to position themselves for the long-delayed revival in the semiconductor industry.  [ 39. ]

headline: PROSPECTS FOR MORE U.S. AID TO REBELS ARE SEEN AS BLEAK NOW IN CONGRESS
abstract: Members of Congress said today that the prospects for continued financing of the Nicaraguan rebels, already in doubt after the Democratic victory in the Senate, have dimmed further in the aftermath of disclosures about the diversion of secret Iranian arms money to the insurgents.   ''I cannot see further aid,'' said Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, the leader of a group of Democrats whose support was crucial in June when the House of Representatives reversed itself and voted for $100 million to the rebels known as contras.   ''The contras are on their own,'' Mr. McCurdy said in an interview. ''The power of the President, the personality of the President, is not going to carry the day for them again.''

headline: COLGATE REVAMPING ITS STODGY IMAGE
abstract: Reuben Mark, the chairman and chief executive of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, jumps around his Park Avenue office, hands waving, talking excitedly about his company.   Excitement has always been in short supply at the headquarters of Colgate-Palmolive, the maker of Colgate toothpaste, Palmolive soaps, Ajax cleansers and a host of other familiar brands. Stodgy and slow-moving, Colgate has perenially been a distant second to the Procter & Gamble Company in the American household products business, although it is bigger abroad.   Earnings were weak, its new products were uninspiring, the company lacked a coherent strategy, Wall Street considered the stock a dog, and staff morale was low.

headline: PRETORIA GOVERNMENT OUSTED AT GENEVA RED CROSS PARLEY
abstract: A conference of the international movement of the Red Cross voted today to oust the South African Government delegation to protest what one African delegate called Pretoria's ''evil and inhuman'' policy of apartheid.   The move, which marks the first time a government delegation has been excluded from a Red Cross conference in the organization's 123-year history, was described by Western countries and Red Cross officials as endangering the 137-nation organization's policies of impartiality and neutrality.  [ The Pretoria Government retaliated by ordering Read Cross representatives to leave South Africa as soon as possible, The Associated Press reported from Johannesburg. ]  Conference observers and Western delegates said the vote to exclude South Africa would create a ''very bad'' atmosphere at the weeklong meeting, which is also considering changing Red Cross statutes and examining compliance with its conventions.

headline: Careers; Scanners Changing Marketing
abstract: SCANNERS, those computerized devices that record product details in supermarkets and retail stores, are causing an upheaval in merchandising and a rapid change in marketing careers.   Most brand managers used to allot two-thirds of their budgets to advertising agencies and one-third to sales promotion activities, like coupons. ''Now all this has flip-flopped,'' said John M. McCann, an associate professor of marketing at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business.   ''The general level of brand loyalty has gone down because consumers have become more price sensitive,'' Dr. McCann said. ''Now companies have the data to start measuring it.'' Once companies analyze the information, he said, they can focus sales promotion for a particular area and a particular product with greater effectiveness.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Texaco Canada Chief
abstract: Peter I. Bijur, an executive of Texaco Inc., has been named president and chief executive of Texaco Canada Inc. Mr. Bijur, 44 years old, succeeds James L. Dunlap, who was named earlier in the week as president of Texaco U.S.A. in Houston, Texaco's largest division.

headline: A SENATE PANEL TO CALL REAGAN ON IRAN AFFAIR
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee plans to question Donald T. Regan, the President's chief of staff, and the White House has decided to let him testify, according to White House and Congressional sources.   By not invoking executive privilege, the White House would avoid a potential confrontation with Congress.   The Intelligence Committee has put all Cabinet-level members of the National Security Council on notice that they may expect to be called to testify this week about the Iran arms affair, according to two people familiar with the decisions. 'No Chance' of Privilege Claim    A senior White House official said that despite concern about setting a precedent, ''there's no chance whatsoever'' that President Reagan will invoke executive privilege and prevent Mr. Regan from testifying.

headline: Reagan Envoy Describes Trip
abstract: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, last night branded as fiction many of the bizarre details in Iranian accounts of his secret four-day mission to Iran last spring.   During an interview on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' he also defended the decision to go to Iran rather than seeking to arrange a meeting in Geneva or another location as being essential to his effort to reach influential Iranians believed to be relatively moderate.

headline: JOURNALISTS LAUD KALB FOR QUITTING
abstract: Many journalists said today that they regarded the resignation of the top State Department press spokesman as a demonstration of his integrity and further evidence of the existence of a disinformation program within the Reagan Administration.   In explaining his resignation, Bernard Kalb, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, repeatedly declined to confirm that there was a policy to disemminate false information to accomplish political objectives. But he also said his resignation was a ''modest dissent'' prompted by press reports of a disinformation policy.

headline: Joint Viacom Bid Studied
abstract: National Amusements, the company that owns 18.3 percent of Viacom International, said yesterday that it might make a bid for the company jointly with another bidder.   Several industry sources believe that Sumner Redstone, the president of National Amusements, one of the nation's largest theater circuits, will make a bid for the company alone or with a partner and that any proposals that do not involve Mr. Redstone will face difficulty.

headline: G.E. to Sell Gates Its Battery Unit
abstract: The General Electric Company said that it had agreed to sell its battery business to the Gates Corporation, and that after the sale it would sell rechargeable batteries made by Gates in the consumer market. G.E. said that although its industrial battery business has a world leadership position, it does not fit strategically with other G.E. businesses.   Terms of the sale were not disclosed. In 1985, G.E. reported sales of $140 million from its battery business, and Gates reported sales of $42.8 million from its battery operations. G.E. said that in the industrial and original-equipment markets, Gates would have use of the G.E. name for one year after completion of the sale.

headline: AT O.A.S., MANY REJECT THE CONTRAS
abstract: A meeting of the Organization of American States here has convinced many United States officials that for others it can be logical both to disapprove of the Nicaraguan Government and still oppose the rebels who are fighting to overthrow it.   Many of the United States officials say they believe such a policy is fundamentally inconsistent. Yet, to their frustration, it is the policy of many Latin American Governments.   As the O.A.S. held its discussions here, diplomats from several member nations, speaking to reporters, expressed distaste for the Sandinistas on ideological grounds. At the same time, however, they condemned United States support of Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: U.S. Group In Thai Talks
abstract: An American Congressional delegation put pressure on Thailand today to join efforts to force Japan, South Korea and Taiwan to open their domestic markets to foreign products.   But Thailand responded with a warning that threats of protectionist trade laws could damage friendly ties between Washington and its allies.

headline: Asset-Backed Offering
abstract: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it plans to offer about $3.2 billion of asset-backed obligations next week, the largest corporate offering of its kind in the American capital markets.   Anthony V. Dub, managing director in charge of First Boston's Asset Finance Group, said the offering of asset-backed securities ''may be as significant for that market as First Boston's 1983 introduction of collateralized mortgage obligations was for the mortgage market.''

headline: Exxon Capital
abstract: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering $300 million of 6 1/2 percent notes due 1989 at a price of 99.917, to yield 6.56 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., the notes are noncallable for life and yield 15-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 7, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 60 Are Killed in Snowstorm In Mountains of North India
abstract: At least 60 people have died in a sudden snowstorm that swept mountains above Srinagar in northern India, news agencies said today.

headline: Airbus Denies Bonn Pressure
abstract: The European Airbus Industrie consortium denied today, despite reports to the contrary, that it had come under pressure from the West German Government to resume talks with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation on building a long-range passenger jet for the 1990's.   ''There has been no pressure,'' a spokesman said here.

headline: We Weren't Looking For a Quick Fix
abstract: CRITICS of the Agency for International Development and the American foreign economic assistance program are adept at shrill rhetoric. The reality of the United States aid effort, however, is far different from what we hear.   Policy negotiations demand privacy if we are to achieve meaningful reforms. Therefore, the substantive achievements of A.I.D. are not often trumpeted. It takes political courage to make difficult economic policy changes. Where such leadership is in place, we cannot make it look as though donor nations cajoled or bullied the recipient into reforms in exchange for foreign aid.

headline: Citicorp Notes To Yield 8.03%
abstract: Citicorp yesterday began offering $250 million of 8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.875, to yield 8.03 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.   Noncallable for three years, the notes are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA by S.&P. and yield 1.05 percentage points more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.   In separate transactions, the bank holding company's weekly sales of commercial paper resulted in an average rate of 5.775 percent for $50 million of 91-day paper, up from 5.639 percent last week, and 5.770 percent for $50 million of 182-day paper, up from 5.586 percent.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 10, 1986: MONDAY

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * British Printing and Communication Corp. appointed James T. Sullivan to the new post of executive vice chairman, responsible for worldwide print operations.

headline: THE MOUNTIES ARE TOLD TO INVESTIGATE IRAN DEAL
abstract: The Government ordered the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today to investigate reported statements by William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, that Canadian business executives were involved in financing Iranian purchases of American weapons.   According to a Congressional official who heard Mr. Casey's testimony before a House panel Wednesday, the C.I.A. chief said a former business associate, Roy M. Furmark, told him that a group of Canadians had been involved in financing arms sales to the Iranians.   Mr. Casey said he was further informed that the Canadians had not been reimbursed and feared that their money had been diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels.   On Thursday, the Government declined requests for an inquiry into the Canadian role in the matter, saying that the American Government has yet to provide it with Mr. Casey's testimony or other information.

headline: MEXICO AIDE'S BROTHER IN DRUG ARREST
abstract: The Mexican federal police have arrested the brother of a former Governor of the northern state of Sonora and charged him with drug trafficking in connection with marijuana fields discovered on ranches he owned, Mexican officials said today.   Gilberto Ocana Garcia was arrested this week and charged with drug trafficking after several acres of marijuana were discovered by the Mexican Army at farms in southern Sonora. The state borders Arizona and California.

headline: WASHINGTON TIMES PUBLISHES TRANSCRIPT OF CHIRAC REMARKS
abstract: The Washington Times today published what it said was a full transcript of an interview conducted by its editor in chief with the French Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, which has become the subject of controversy.   On Friday, in an article based on the interview, the newspaper said Mr. Chirac had remarked that the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher believed that a purported plot to blow up an Israeli jetliner in April was a fake.   According to the newspaper, Mr. Chirac said the two West German officials had told him that the operation probably was planned by the Israeli secret service and Syrian political factions, not the Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad.   Britain broke diplomatic relations with Syria last month after Nezar Hindawi, a Jordanian citizen, was convicted of trying to smuggle explosives aboard the El Al jetliner in London by hiding them inside the bag of his pregnant lover. The British Government said it had direct and incontrovertible evidence of Syrian Government involvement in the incident, including contacts between Mr. Hindawi and the Syrian Ambassador to London. Britain is to seek further sanctions against Damascus at a meeting of European foreign ministers today.

headline: Embattled Chief Of Fermenta Quits
abstract: Refaat el-Sayed resigned yesterday as president of Fermenta A.B., the Swedish pharmaceutical and biotechnology company that he founded, Until recently, Mr. el-Sayed had been viewed as one of Sweden's top businessmen and his company had been hailed as one of the fastest-growing concerns in Western Europe. But their fortunes quickly soured.

headline: POWER OF KENYA'S LEADER IS GROWING
abstract: The Kenyan authorities appear to be moving to place increasingly greater power in the hands of President Daniel arap Moi and the nation's sole political party, as some church leaders and other critics warn that such steps border on totalitarianism in a country that professes to be a democracy.   The Parliament of Kenya, a pro-Western nation that has long stood as a symbol of relative stability in Africa, this week unanimously approved a Constitutional amendment that stripped the security of tenure from the powerful posts of Attorney General and Auditor General. The Attorney General is the country's chief legal officer, and the Auditor General oversees its accounts.   Tenure had been provided to protect the officeholders from political pressure. Mr. Moi, whose power has grown steadily in the last four years, now has the legal power to dismiss them.

headline: Delays Seen for Apple Model
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. appears to be experiencing delays in shipping its new II GS personal computer. Dealers say they got demonstration units for the model's Sept. 27 introduction but do not expect to receive any inventory before next month.

headline: IRANIAN TELLS OF LEBANON TRIP TO OBTAIN HOSTAGES' RELEASE
abstract: The Iranian middleman who negotiated the Administration's secret arms dealings with Iran asserted today that he had personally gone to Lebanon to arrange the release of American hostages.   In his first public interview, Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian businessman living in Europe, declined to specify how he had obtained the release of the three hostages from terrorist groups with links to Iran.   Mr. Ghorbanifar spoke in an interview with Barbara Walters broadcast tonight on the ABC News program 20/ 20. The interview was filmed in the apartment in Monte Carlo of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi billionaire arms merchant who helped to arrange the deal between Washington and Teheran.

headline: PATENTS; Aircraft Laser Advance
abstract: A wide-angle laser window for aircraft, patented this week by the Boeing Company of Seattle, is described as directing a laser beam at a distant point or controlling an incoming beam. The inventors named in Patent No. 4,614,405 are Werner M. Brandenberg, a retired engineering supervisor, and Denis J. Pistoresi, an engineer. Mr. Pistoresi said the beams can be used for tracking targets or for optical communications. The wide-angle windows have been tested in the laboratory but not yet installed in aircraft.

headline: A.T.&T. Computer Price
abstract: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company said it is cutting the price of its PC 6300 Plus personal computer by 24 to 30 percent to better position it in the market. That will bring the price closer to personal computers sold by such competitors as I.B.M. and Compaq. The new prices will range from $3,025 to $3,775, depending on the model. A.T.&T. has also lowered its price of the color monitor for the PC 6300 and the PC 6300 Plus by 16 percent, bringing that price down to $795 from $945, effective through December.

headline: Soviet Research Site Intact
abstract: A Soviet Antarctic research station has drifted into the Wendell Sea on an iceberg but remains intact, the official press agency Tass said today. The agency said the Druzhnaya-1 station had failed to show up on satellite photographs after the breaking up of the Filchner ice shelf, where it was situated. But a helicopter crew later spotted the station and found it undamaged on a large section of the ice shelf.

headline: THRIFT UNIT IS ACQUIRED
abstract: First Nationwide Bank, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said today that it had acquired the Lincoln Federal Savings and Loan Association of Louisville, Ky. With the acquisition, First Nationwide, which is based in San Francisco, received the rights to expand into Virginia and Maryland through a bidding process conducted by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

headline: Advertising; Layoffs Afflicting Agencies
abstract: THE New York office of Ogilvy & Mather dismissed 60 people last week. Graham Phillips, chairman of the domestic company, said these employees were the last of 200 to be dismissed nationwide this year because of the sluggish economy.   The agency is the largest unit in the Ogilvy Group, a holding company that is publicly held and therefore particularly sensitive to its own bottom line. Mr. Graham said he waited in New York until the last possible minute but in the end just had to make the job cuts.   If you wonder why advertising agencies are constantly scrambling after new business, this is the reason. In a down year like this one, unless there are new income sources to take care of the increasing costs of doing business, something has to go. Since people costs are the major costs, it is the people who suffer.

headline: Long-Distance Rate Drop Seen
abstract: Mark. S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, predicted today that most long-distance telephone rates would fall by about 5 percent, or $900 million, in January, reflecting reduced costs for the use of local exchange-carrier equipment for call completion.   Rate reductions are expected to be proposed in November by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company based on recent filings by local telephone companies proposing to lower their charges to A.T.&T., the nation's principal provider of long-distance service A.T.&T. is the only long-distance company regulated by the F.C.C. and its rate changes must be approved by the regulatory agency.

headline: SATURN'S MAKERS PLANS SLOW BUILDUP OF SALES
abstract: Saturn Corporation cars will probably be sold only in California and other areas with high import penetration when they are first introduced in the early 1990's, officials of the General Motors Corporation subsidiary said today.   Saturn officials also said they still expected the first Saturn model to roll off the assembly line here by mid-1990, but they said cars would not be available in volume until the following year because of a planned slow increase in the production rate. With the cars in short supply at first, they will probably be concentrated in a few areas rather than spread thinly across the country.

headline: Envoy Says Austrians Botched Computer Case
abstract: The United States Ambassador to Austria said yesterday that Austrian customs authorities ''blew it'' two months ago when they allowed the last part of a shipment of computer equipment to disappear mysteriously from a Vienna warehouse.   The shipment, in boxes bearing the markings of the Control Data Corporation, was discovered by American customs officials in August. The American authorities believe it was part of $11 million worth of sophisticated electronic equipment apparently smuggled out of Western Europe over the last year in what they said was one of the largest and most damaging technology diversions to the Eastern bloc in recent memory.   Immediately after agents made the August discovery, they reported it to Ronald S. Lauder, the United States Ambassador. Mr. Lauder immediately went to Ferdinand Lacina, Austria's Minister of Finance, to ask that Austrian officials prevent the shipment from leaving the country.

headline: G.M. Closings Surprise Perot
abstract: Ross Perot, the head of the General Motors Corporation's Electronic Data Systems subsidiary and the auto maker's largest individual stockholder, said yesterday that he was ''surprised'' at the number of plant closings announced yesterday.   Mr. Perot, in a telephone interview from his Dallas headquarters, said he learned of the move at last Monday's directors' meeting.

headline: Pretoria Denies Role In Machel Plane Crash
abstract: South Africa today denied accusations by black African countries that it was involved in the plane crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique 11 days ago.   At the same time, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha denied press reports that Mr. Machel lived for four hours after his Soviet-built plane crashed in South Africa, saying the Mozambican leader died instantly.

headline: FRANCE TO DROP PART OF UNIVERSITY PLAN
abstract: The Government, trying to quell the largest student protests in France in nearly two decades, said tonight that some provisions of a university bill fiercely opposed by students would be deferred.   In a nationally televised broadcast, Rene Monory, the Minister of Education, announced that the Government would pursue its plan. But, in what seemed a concession, he said earlier provisions to increase fees and make universities somewhat more selective would not be pursued immediately.   It was unclear, however, if the apparent concession would put an end to a vast, well-organized student movement that over the last two weeks has confronted the conservative Government with its gravest crisis since it came to power nine months ago.

headline: Realty Adventurous For Merrill Officer
abstract: When David H. Komansky switched from the securities side to the real estate side of Merrill Lynch & Company some 15 months ago ''it was the beginning of an adventure,'' he said.   The adventure is continuing, with plans announced by Merrill Lynch last week to convert its real estate operation into a master limited partnership, retaining control but selling units to the public.   Mr. Komansky, who is president of Merrill Lynch Realty, will be head of a Merrill Lynch subsidiary to be created to act as general partner under the plan.

headline: St Germain Asks Inquiry
abstract: The chairman of the House Banking Committee asked the General Accounting Office today to open an investigation into the travel and other personal and administrative expenses of five Federal agencies that regulate financial institutions.   The move comes in the wake of disclosures that top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board were reimbursed for large amounts of travel and personal expenses by thrift industry trade groups and the 12 Federal Home Loan Banks.

headline: Ford Set to Invest In Michigan Plants
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said it plans to invest $171 million in two southeast Michigan plants for the manufacture of newly designed alternators and starters.   The No. 2 American auto maker said alternators would be produced at the Rawsonville plant and starters at the Ypsilanti plant, facilities of Ford's electrical and electronics division. Ford said the new parts would be phased into production starting in the 1989 model year.

headline: British Air Net Is Down 29.9%
abstract: British Airways reported today that earnings declined by 29.9 percent in the first half from the period a year ago, in part because of fears of terrorism.   Net income for the six months ended Sept. 30 totaled $:141 million, or about $202 million, down from $:201 million, or about $287 million, a year ago.

headline: Ryan Seeks To Thwart Bid
abstract: Ryan Homes Inc. said its board was considering several options, including a leveraged buyout, to ward off a hostile bid by NVHomes Inc. Yesterday, the Ryan board rejected a $45-a-share, or $292 million, offer from NVHomes as inadequate and recommended that shareholders not tender their shares.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ryan Homes, a Pittsburgh-based builder, said the other options under consideration include the acquisition of another company, a complete or partial liquidation of Ryan or the spin off of certain assets.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: Tables of election results last Thursday misstated the winner in the 46th Assembly District in Brooklyn; incorrectly listed participants in the race in 23d Congressional District in upstate New York, and misstated the outcome of the contest for Supreme Court justice in the Nassau-Suffolk County district.

headline: A.M.C. BETS ON BIGGER CARS
abstract: The American Motors Corporation, the perennial also-ran of the auto industry, could be headed either for a turnaround or for its last hurrah when it introduces a new line of midsize cars next fall.   At a time when even the industry giant, General Motors, is retrenching, troubled A.M.C. is planning to increase production in a big way. The company sees this as its last chance: ''We're betting the bank on our new cars,'' said Joseph E. Cappy, A.M.C.'s chief executive, who came over four years ago from the Ford Motor Company. ''We can't afford to make a mistake.''   American Motors is expanding with a $675 million state-of-the-art assembly plant in Canada and a new line of midsize cars - to be named the Renault Premier and the Renault Medallion. Yet, for the company, which had only marginal success with such offbeat cars as the Gremlin and the Pacer, this is hardly a sure bet.

headline: Guidance for Workers In Filling Out New W-4
abstract: In filling out the new W-4 form, taxpayers will be given a four-page package that includes line-by-line instructions for figuring exactly how many withholding allowances they can claim. Here are some general guidelines:    * Working married couples should sit down together and figure the total number of exemptions they should claim. Once that decision is made, says Lawrence B. Gibbs, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, all the withholding exemptions should be claimed by the spouse with the higher income. No exemptions should be claimed by the lower-earning spouse.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Digital Equipment Corp., Maynard, Mass., and Valid Logic Systems Inc. said they had entered into a marketing agreement to promote Valid's computer-aided engineering products.    * Hong Kong International Terminals Ltd., Hong Kong, said it had awarded a civil works contract worth more than $75 million to a Japanese joint venture headed by Kumagai Gumi Co.    * Hoyts Corp., Sydney, Australia, said it had formed a subsidiary in the United States that acquired Cinema Centers Corporation, a Boston-based company which operates 111 screens at 25 theaters.

headline: Data Seized at Northrop Unit
abstract: Federal agents seized time cards, employee logs, computer disks and other items in a search of the Northrop Corporation's Warner Robins unit in Georgia as evidence in a criminal investigation of charges that the company may have overbilled the Government on military contracts, Federal officials said today.   The nine-hour raid, which began Tuesday morning, was conducted by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Postal Service and the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

headline: GOODYEAR PREDICTS JOB CUTS
