abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company told its employees yesterday that the restructuring it is considering will result in the loss of jobs.   The energy and tire concern, based in Akron, Ohio, did not give specific numbers of jobs to be cut, but its chairman, Robert E. Mercer, said in a letter to 135,000 employees worldwide that ''there is no question but that we must generate personnel reductions as part of that program.''   This week, Goodyear announced that it was looking into reformulating its mixture of businesses, in what Wall Street analysts viewed as an attempt to hold off Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French investor who holds 11.5 percent of its stock. Units That May Be Sold   The company has said that it might sell its Celeron oil and natural gas subsidiary, its aerospace business and its Motor Wheel Corporation.

headline: KINNOCK PREPARES FOR A U.S. MISSION
abstract: Neil Kinnock, who hopes to lead the Labor Party back to power in the coming year, is about to do a little campaigning in the United States. He will try to persuade Americans that his party's promise to remove all nuclear weapons from Britain could serve the interests of the Western alliance.   In an interview in his paneled study at the House of Commons, the leader of the opposition rehearsed the case he will be making by arguing that Labor's stand on nuclear weapons would enable Britain to strengthen its commitment to the conventional defense of Europe.   Even after insisting on the removal of all American nuclear weapons from bases in Britain, he went on to say, a Kinnock government would never seek to close British ports to American submarines that might be carrying nuclear weapons. He thus drew an implicit distinction between his party's stance and that of the governing Labor Party in New Zealand.

headline: Harnischfeger
abstract: A group of investors, led by the Miami-based Columbia Ventures Inc., said it had purchased a 7.7 percent stake in the Harnischfeger Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it ''may seek to influence management or may even seek control'' of the Milwaukee-based concern.

headline: ADMINISTRATION IS ACCUSED OF DECEIVING PRESS ON LIBYA
abstract: The Reagan Administration faced a growing controversy today over reports that it had made selective disclosures of news and ''disinformation'' about Libya and its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.   The issue arose after a report by Bob Woodward in The Washington Post today that the Administration had devised a policy that included leaking false information intended to convince Colonel Qaddafi that Libya was about to be attacked by the United States or that he was about to be overthrown.   The Post traced the ''disinformation'' plan to a memo written by Adm. John M. Poindexter, President Reagan's national security adviser.   But today, Administration officials said the program did not originate with that memo, but grew out of a mid-August State Department document to the White House laying out a ''deception'' campaign. That document represented a consensus at interdepartmental meetings, the officials said.

headline: ITALIAN ENTERS PARIS FASHION
abstract: Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian industrialist who runs the Olivetti office equipment group, announced today that he had purchased a 25 percent stake in Yves St. Laurent, one of the world's leading fashion designers.   The move continues the rapid and often controversial expansion of Mr. de Benedetti's business interests in France. But it also illustrates a general expansionary drive by Italian industrialists and financiers, whose appetite for northern European acquisitions in recent months has become a major feature of the European business scene.   Mr. de Benedetti, who is chairman of Ing. C. Olivetti & Company as well as a major shareholder, told a news conference that he was paying $35 million for the St. Laurent stake and would ''develop a long-term strategy for the group and an ambitious program of expansion, especially in the U.S.'' 'Strategic Partnerships'    He described the investment, which he made for his own account, as part of an overall plan for building up what he termed ''strategic partnerships'' with promising French companies that need financing to expand.

headline: DEREGULATION COMES SLOWLY AS TOKYO TRADING PICKS UP
abstract: Not so long ago, Tokyo was a fairly sedate posting for foreign bankers and brokers, a place where opportunities were limited by strict regulation of financial markets. Those days are just memories now. Tokyo has become a vital international financial center, drawing on Japan's huge pools of capital and aided by easing of regulations.   Prodded both by growth in Japanese Government debt and by pressure from Washington, financial authorities here have allowed the creation of a number of new markets. Trading volume has soared.  Six foreign companies, breaking through a longstanding barrier, have been allowed to become members of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and nine foreign banks have been allowed to enter the area of trust banking.

headline: CONTRAS SAID TO HAVE USED AID GRANT FOR AMMUNITION
abstract: A Nicaraguan rebel group diverted $15,000 in United States funds intended for nonlethal aid to buy ammunition earlier this year, Congressional and Administration officials say.   A State Department official said today that the department learned of the diversion in June and forced the rebels to return the money.   The discovery, included in a draft report by the General Accounting Office, is the first conclusive evidence that some of the $27 million in nonlethal aid for the Contras went for lethal assistance, according to three American officials who spoke Thursday on condition that they not be identified.   The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, reported last spring that it could not track more than half the $27 million in nonlethal aid, with much of it disappearing into offshore bank accounts, into the Honduran military or staying in the United States.

headline: Key Iranian Calls for Hostage-Arms Deal
abstract: A key Iranian leader involved in the secret arms negotiations with the United States said today that Iran was still willing to intercede for the release of American hostages in return for weapons.   ''We have nothing against talking to them through the same arms dealers with whom we talked, through the same weapons purchase channels,'' the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said in an interview with the official press agency.   Hojatolislam Rafsanjani's remarks appeared to indicate that the Iranian moderates who dealt with the Americans over the arms deal had not been politically damaged by their contact with what Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, customarily refers to as ''the Great Satan.''   If so, the situation would be in marked contrast to that of the early days of the revolution in the fall of 1979, when Islamic fundamentalists seized the American Embassy, causing the fall of the provisional Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan, who was seen as too friendly to the West.

headline: CORPORATE AMERICA IN TURMOIL: COURTS WEAKEN DEFENSES
abstract: John E. Olson: Chairman American Telephone and Telegraph Company    ''We will make the tough decisions necessary to insure that we are in the best position to thrive in the years ahead.''  Laurence A. Tisch: Acting Chief Executive Officer, CBS Inc.    ''This is no takeover,'' Mr. Tisch told reporters on the evening of Sept. 10, when the board of directors named him acting chief executive officer of CBS, succeeding Thomas H. Wyman.

headline: Energy Prices Decline On News of OPEC Deal
abstract: Prices of crude oil and refined petroleum products slumped in heavy volume on the futures markets yesterday as traders who had bid up prices in advance of the breakup of yesterday's OPEC meeting reacted to news of the agreement by liquidating positions.   On the face of it, yesterday's selloff would tend to suggest that traders were expecting big things from the meeting, which produced an extension of the current production agreement. But traders uniformly agreed that the decline would be short-lived, and that prices were likely to remain in a relatively narrow range for some time.

headline: A Citicorp Deal Is Overturned
abstract: A Federal Court of Appeals has set aside an order by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation that would have let Citicorp acquire the National Permanent Bank in Washington.   The three-judge panel's unanimous ruling, issued Friday, was a victory for Gordon Getty, who had made a competing bid for the bank.

headline: GAF Sale Of Stake Seen
abstract: The GAF Corporation has sold more than half of the stock it held in the Union Carbide Corporation, according to Wall Street sources.   The sale came in the form of a five-million-share block that traded yesterday through Salomon Brothers.

headline: Fed Plan on Banks' Real Estate Role
abstract: In a move that would override state banking laws and cause some banks to reduce large real estate operations, the Federal Reserve Board today proposed to let banks enter real estate development on a very limited basis.   The Fed's board of governors, in a public meeting held here today, voted to seek public comment on a proposal that would permit bank holding companies only modest real estate investments through subsidiaries that are separate from their individual banks.   Some exemptions would be given to banks that have existing real estate subsidiaries. Under current Federal law, while banks can make loans to developers, they are prohibited from taking direct equity positions in developments. An exception allows a bank holding company to invest directly in its own offices.

headline: Bulgarian Athlete Defects
abstract: A Bulgarian weight lifter, Neum Shalamanov, is seeking political asylum in Australia, the Foreign Ministry said today. Mr. Shalamanov, 19, disappeared Sunday after winning a third world cup title in Melbourne.

headline: G.M.'S CUTS REFLECT A LONG-TERM TREND
abstract: When the General Motors Corporation said last week that it would close 11 plants, affecting 29,000 workers, industry analysts noted that the world's largest auto company had plenty of worries, such as high per-car production costs and declining consumer enthusiasm for its products.   However, none denied G.M.'s contention that its move also reflected forces affecting all American manufacturers. Global competition; pressure to remodel industry into smaller, more flexible units, and modern manufacturing technology have all eaten away at industry's need for workers.   According to business executives, labor experts and consultants, these forces are likely to eliminate hundreds of thousands of jobs in the domestic auto industry in the next few years and millions more in other industrial enterprises.

headline: Grand Metropolitan
abstract: Grand Metropolitan, the British brewing, hotels and leisure group, has named Alan Sheppard chief executive.

headline: STRAUS FAMILY TO SELL WMCA
abstract: WMCA, which claims to be the first New York radio station to play rock-and-roll music and is now one of the city's top three talk stations, will be sold for $10 million in cash to Federal Enterprises Inc. of Detroit, its owners said yesterday.   The station, which has a history of innovative programming decisions, has been owned since 1943 by Straus Communications Inc. It is the last privately held family-owned station in a leading urban market.   R. Peter Straus, who has run the station since 1961, said that the sale, like some others recently, was spurred by impending changes in the tax law. ''We decided to sell because of the increase in the capital gains tax,'' he said, adding that, under the new tax law, the top capital gains rate will ultimately rise to 28 percent from 20 percent.

headline: Market Place; Petro-Lewis Deal Is Clouded
abstract: BARRING any last-minute developments, the fate of the Petro-Lewis Corporation, the Denver oil and gas company that is one of the nation's largest oil and gas drillers, will be decided at midnight tonight. That is when a cash tender offer for Petro-Lewis debt securites expires. The offer is being made by Freeport-McMoran Inc., a natural resources company.   Oil analysts who have followed the proposed deal believe that it is too close to call. Petro-Lewis, which lost $405.6 million in its latest fiscal year, has said that, if its debtholders reject the proposed transaction, it will file for bankruptcy.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: ''What makes the question of dissent all the more complicated in our local church is the passion we have in this country to let all persons have the freedom to give their point of view.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Centerre Bank, St. Louis, elected to its board Andrew E. Newman, chairman of Edison Brothers Shoe Stores Inc.    * Daiwa Securities elected Jiro Yamana deputy president, replacing Yukio Hosoi, who is retiring to become president of Daiwa Investment Trust and Management Company. It also named as director Katsuhiko Fujimoto, replacing Yasukazu Akamatsu, who will become senior managing director at Daiwa Investment Trust and Management.

headline: The High Cost Of Dishonesty
abstract: THE case of Ivan F. Boesky, the most famous of the arbitragers, has hit the stock market hard. And the Boesky affair raises serious questions about the integrity of the markets.   Some economists, lawyers, investment bankers, Government officials and free-market ideologists insist that Mr. Boesky was obviously a scoundrel and a thief. He has agreed to pay a penalty of $100 million for illegal insider trading and has reportedly cooperated with the Government by allowing the taping of his conversations with major investment figures.

headline: RED CROSS MOVEMENT CHANGES ITS NAME
abstract: The International Red Cross movement agreed by consensus today to change its name to the International Movement of the Red Cross and Red Crescent. The move was protested by the World Jewish Congress and Israel, which said the move added religious significance to the organization's symbols.

headline: 8 LATIN COUNTRIES PUSH PEACE TALKS
abstract: Eight Latin American Governments have announced that the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to join them in a new initiative aimed at reviving peace negotiations in Central America.   A special delegation is expected to visit the capitals of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in January in the hope of persuading the five Central American Governments to return to the bargaining table. The delegation will include the heads of the two international organizations and the foreign ministers of the eight countries organizing the effort.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''We're lean and mean, but it would be wrong to say we haven't been wounded.''  Robert E. Mercer,  Goodyear chairman, on the successful  fight against Sir James Goldsmith.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE COST-CUTTING
abstract: AMERICAN companies are casting as sharp an eye on their costs as on their markets these days. Not only are they trying to squeeze the last ounce of concessions out of their suppliers on prices and payment terms, but they are even attacking such once-sacrosanct items as executive expense accounts.   ''Controlling costs is not just a way to create more profit and reduce taxes,'' said William T. Parsons, president of Senn Delaney, a consulting firm in Long Beach, Calif. ''It's becoming a survival issue.'' When asked why, consultants and business experts trot out the usual suspects: competition from imports, pressure from shareholders for dividends, fear of corporate raiders who might pounce on any company that showed the slightest sign of unnecessary flab in its cost structure.

headline: Market Place; Doubts Linger On E.D.S. Role
abstract: EVER since Dec. 1, when the General Motors Corporation paid H. Ross Perot $700 million to buy out his holdings in the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, relations between the automotive giant and its E.D.S. subsidiary have posed a mystery to the investment community. The buyout followed Mr. Perot's mounting criticism of Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive.   Yesterday, at the Hotel Parker Meridien in Manhattan, officials of E.D.S. and G.M. sought, in their own words, ''to clear the air.'' Their audience consisted of nearly 100 securities analysts and a handful of money managers - some of whom have watched with dismay the falling price of E.D.S. stock. The presentation, by Les Alberthal, recently named chief executive of E.D.S., was followed by a spirited question-and-answer period.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA RIGHTS GROUP ACCUSES THE SECURITY FORCES OF BRUTALITY
abstract: South Africa's Black Sash civil-rights movement has accused the country's security forces of ''indiscriminate brutality and insensitivity'' in their handling of the nation's black youth.   In a 33-page memorandum issued Tuesday, the organization, run by white women critical of Government policy, said a ''long-term conditioning of whites to regard blacks as something less than human'' had contributed to a ''bullying abuse of power.''   The report cited a series of signed and unsigned statements by black youths who said they had been beaten and tortured in the custody of the police and army. Moreoever, the report accused the security forces of indiscriminately opening fire and said some blacks had disappeared after being detained by the authorities.

headline: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
abstract: ''It is my great hope that things will soon return to normal in the United States.'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher

headline: Shifts Seen in Supply Of Taxable Municipals
abstract: The supply of new taxable municipal bonds, which has been dominated recently by special financings that take advantage of investment profits, is likely to change with more emphasis on financings needed for government spending projects, according to a research report published yesterday by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The recent financings, which the Morgan analysts called ''market driven,'' rely heavily on the initial investment of bond proceeds in guaranteed investment contracts. With yields that are nearly 1.5 percentage points greater than yields on 10-year Treasury notes, the bond yield is about four-tenths of a percentage point more than A-rated industrial company bonds.

headline: Argentina, at U.N., Reproaches the British
abstract: Argentina's Foreign Minister accused Britain today of trying to ''expand its domination over waters under Argentine sovereignty'' by declaring a 200-mile controlled fishing zone around the Falkland Islands.

headline: ADMINISTRATION PREDICTS 3.2% GROWTH NEXT YEAR
abstract: The Reagan Administration today predicted a fifth straight year without a recession, with the economy growing by a relatively healthy 3.2 percent next year.   The growth would be stronger than the 2.4 percent expected this year but significantly less than the Administration last predicted for next year. Unemployment would be higher than the Administration previously predicted.   Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said interest rates should also be lower next year than the Administration had expected. He added that inflation would rise sharply from this year's rock-bottom level, but not enough to arouse fears of serious inflation.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bell Petroleum Services Inc., Midland, Tex., said it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law after its principal lenders had begun foreclosure proceedings.    * BSN Corp., Dallas, said it had bought the assets of Medalist Industries' All-American division for $13.4 million.

headline: A Painful Round of Cuts for G.M.
abstract: G.M. is shutting 11 plants in the United States and laying off many of the 29,000 workers at those plants. The move was not unexpected, though the magnitude surprised some analysts, and the company hopes the shutdowns will help it to regain a competitive edge in the auto market. The 11 plants account for 10 percent of G.M. production vehicles in North America, but the chairman of G.M., Roger B. Smith, said the remaining plants will become more efficient as its $10 billion modernization plan proceeds. Analysts said the moves should result in a stronger G.M., but warn that G.M. still must make cars that are attractive to consumers, rather than rely on incentive plans to attract buyers.   The auto industry in the United States has been battered in recent years by the wave of imports. At first, American auto makers began producing cars overseas, where costs are lower, but their attentions are now turning back home. But while G.M.'s cutbacks may help the industry, they are a setback for the United Automobile Workers, which has been fighting for job security, and for parts of the country that are still heavily dependent on autos.

headline: Partners Get 4.8% of Lear
abstract: AFG Partners, anticipating the failure of the Wickes Companies' $1.7 billion bid to acquire Lear Siegler Inc., said today that it had bought a 4.8 percent stake in the aerospace, automotive and manufacturing company.   The partnership, formed by AFG Industries, a glass concern, and Wagner & Brown, a closely held oil and gas concern, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it bought 850,000 Lear Siegler common shares today for $80.09 each, or about $68.1 million, in a private transaction with the investment firm of Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: I.B.M. Package
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer company, will announce an expert-systems software package next week, a company official said. The official, Victor Goldberg, assistant group executive for market development in I.B.M.'s Information Systems Group, said the product would combine into one package all the artificial intelligence tools and software that I.B.M. now sells separately.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 27, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Council for Namibia - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Suriname Declares State of Emergency
abstract: The Government declared a state of emergency in remote areas of the country today after 21 people were killed in four days of fighting between the military and guerrillas.

headline: MOZAMBICAN CHIEF DIES IN AIR CRASH IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: President Samora M. Machel, leader of Mozambique since it won independence from Portugal in 1975, was killed Sunday night in a plane crash in South Africa, the Pretoria Government announced today.   The cause of the crash, on a flight from Lusaka, Zambia, to Maputo, Mozambique, was not known.   The Mozambican authorities, who withheld a formal announcement while they debated the succession and other issues, confirmed Mr. Machel's death about 24 hours after the crash. An Anti-Apartheid Figure    The 53-year-old President was an important figure among African leaders opposed to apartheid. His death coincided with increasing strains in Mozambique's relationship with South Africa after the virtual collapse of a 1984 nonaggression pact.  [ Mr. Machel led a Marxist Government but was far from being an ideologue who followed a strict Marxist-Leninist line, and in recent years he seemed above all a pragmatic nationalist. Obituary, page A7. ]  The South African authorities said at least 26 people, including President Machel, had been killed in the crash. Ten people survived, one of them thought to be a Soviet pilot.

headline: J. Walter Thompson Gets Jake's Diet Cola
abstract: The J. Walter Thompson Company, already a Pepsi-Cola agency, will be doing the advertising for a new soft drink called Jake's Diet Cola, which the company expects to put into a number of test markets in January.

headline: Reuters Holdings Makes Instinet Bid
abstract: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the large British financial news and information service company, said yesterday that it had offered $92 million, or $7.25 a share, to acquire the Instinet Corporation, a small New York-based company that provides professional investors with a computer-based market access network.   The merger proposal was sent by letter to William Lupien, Instinet's president and chief executive. Mr. Lupien was attending a conference sponsored by The Financial Times in London yesterday and could not be reached for comment.   Charles Hood, an Instinet spokesman in New York, said the company's board would consider the offer at a meeting early next week.

headline: Peking Asks Seoul to Return An Air Force Pilot and Plane
abstract: China asked South Korea today to return a Chinese Air Force pilot and the MIG-19 jet fighter he flew to a South Korean air base.   The jet was intercepted Friday afternoon over the Yellow Sea and escorted to an air base near Chongju, 70 miles southeast of Seoul, a South Korean Defense Ministry spokesman said.

headline: ANTI-EMERGENCY DRIVE BANNED IN CAPE TOWN
abstract: The police in Cape Town outlawed a Christmas campaign against South Africa's emergency today, ignoring a strong protest against the nation's crisis issued by the European Community.   The nation's violence continued, meanwhile, with The Sowetan newspaper reporting at least five blacks slain in Soweto on Tuesday in fighting between campaigners against the emergency and conservative vigilantes.   Britain's Ambassador, Sir Patrick Moberly, representing the 12 European Community members, delivered the protest note to the Foreign Ministry today, a community statement said.

headline: SOVIET OFFERS EAST-WEST RIGHTS TALKS IN MOSCOW
abstract: The Soviet Union, in a bold effort to defuse criticism of its rights policies, proposed today that an international conference on human rights be convened in Moscow.   Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in making the proposal in a speech at an East-West conference here, said the parley should consider human contacts, cultural and educational issues, and information policies.   In the speech, Mr. Shevardnadze was critical of American accounts of the Iceland summit meeting last month, saying that the United States was deliberately ignoring Soviet concessions on arms control. But Mr. Shevardnadze, who later met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, added that the understandings reached in Iceland were a solid basis for further progress.

headline: Holmes a Court Bid On Australia Papers
abstract: The financier Robert Holmes a Court today opened a battle with the publisher Rupert Murdoch for ownership of the nation's largest newspaper group.   After intensive talks with The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., Mr. Holmes a Court announced a $1.4 billion offer for the company that exceeds the $1.2 billion bid made on Dec. 3 by the News Corporation, which is controlled by Mr. Murdoch.

headline: RIVAL PALESTINIAN FACTIONS ARE SAID TO BE DISCUSSING RECONCILIATION
abstract: A reconciliation effort between Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Syrian-based Palestinian factions is under way, Palestinian sources said here today. If successful, it would change the political lineup in the Middle East.   The effort was begun in Prague last week at a meeting between Mr. Arafat's military chief, Khalil al-Wazir, better known as Abu Jihad, and Dr. George Habash, the leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the sources said. The front is the most prominent anti-Arafat Palestinian group.

headline: G.M.'S BRIEF FLING WITH PEROT
abstract: When Roger B. Smith announced that the General Motors Corporation would buy the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 1984, he made it clear that he wanted to acquire H. Ross Perot's entrepreneurial spirit as well as the assets of the company.   Mr. Smith, easily the most maverick chairman in G.M.'s long history, seemed to sense a kindred soul who could understand the vision he harbored for transforming the staid industrial giant.   Mr. Smith said he wanted G.M. to become more like E.D.S., rather than overshadowing the lean, results-oriented computer systems company with its vast size. In fact, Mr. Smith said in a light moment, Mr. Perot had his personal permission to shoot anyone from G.M. who showed up at E.D.S. headquarters with a G.M. procedures manual.

headline: USG Plans A Buyback
abstract: The USG Corporation, the diversified building products concern that has been the target of several takeover rumors, said today that it planned to repurchase up to 20 percent of its common stock outstanding.

headline: 2 Protestant Ministers Are Being Held in Seoul
abstract: Two Protestant ministers are being held for questioning in connection with anti-government remarks, the police said today.   The two ministers were identified as the Rev. Kim Tong Wan, 45 years old, the secretary general of the National Council of Churches of Korea, and the Rev. Koh Yong Keun, 53, head of a Christian organization in Seoul.

headline: Chip Makers Said to Meet
abstract: Executives of several United States semiconductor manufacturers held a special meeting Friday night to discuss the planned merger of Schlumberger Ltd.'s Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation unit with the American semiconductor unit of Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, according to industry sources.   While the executives have not commented publicly on the deal, the sources say they are concerned that the merger of Fairchild and San Diego-based Fujitsu Microelectronics Inc. would give the Japanese access to United States chip distributors that they have previously been denied.   The meeting followed reports that the Reagan Administration might seek to block the merger for security reasons, because Fairchild makes a special type of gate-array chip used in military-related computers.

headline: Advertising; '85 Income Growth Off To 4.4% at 14 Agencies
abstract: Among the 14 publicly held ad agencies operating in 1985, income growth dropped to 4.4 percent, from 15.5 percent in 1984, according to figures that are included in newly released portions of the Communications Industry Report, a bit of self-promotion issued annually by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, investment bankers.   It also noted that, by the barest margins, last year missed out on having the worst operating and cash flow margins.

headline: Sri Lanka Ends 3-Day Drive Against the Tamil Guerrillas
abstract: Sri Lankan troops ended a three-day drive against Tamil guerrillas in northwestern Mannar district today in which 40 rebels and 14 soldiers were killed, a Government spokesman said.

headline: Software For Investors
abstract: FIND the right stock, and an investment in a personal computer and stock market software can pay off handsomely. But that is not to say the process is effortless. Personal computers do not have the artificial intelligence capacities to replace human analysts.

headline: EXPERTS DISAGREE ON SPACE TEST BAN
abstract: Scientists inside and outside the Government sharply disagreed yesterday over what effect a 10-year ban on space testing would have on President Reagan's missile defense program, known popularly as ''Star Wars.''   A chief scientist in the program said such a ban, one condition the Soviet Union seeks in exchange for sharp reductions in nuclear weapons, would have no significant effect, but Pentagon officials and other scientists said it would be devastating.   Officials have stressed recently that many parts of the program, formally known as the Strategic Defense Initiative, are ready for tests that would be some of the most spectacular of the space age. Effect on Test Bans    Surprisingly, some scientists outside the Government said yesterday that a ban on space testing might speed technical progress if showy demonstrations in orbit were foregone for more exacting ones on earth.   Soviet officials proposed last weekend that all but laboratory research, testing and development of antimissile systems be halted for 10 years.

headline: OBSTACLES FORCE NARROWER FOCUS ON 'STAR WARS'
abstract: President Reagan's missile-defense program has made advances in the last two years but has run up against technical and financial barriers that are forcing changes in emphasis and direction.   The program, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative and popularly as ''Star Wars,'' has already demonstrated that a missile can be attacked with a defensive weapon and that a target can be tracked in space. It has also helped spur scientific and technological advances needed to produce a defensive system.   At the same time, the program has uncovered problems that make the job even more daunting than originally thought. The problems of discriminating real missiles from decoys, of coordinating the whole complex system, of launching its components into space, and of protecting them against an adversary are all proving more difficult than expected.

headline: PACIFIC NATIONS, AT U.S., CRITICIZE FRENCH POLICIES
abstract: Pacific island nations, speaking in the General Assembly, continued to criticize France today for its failure to grant independence to New Caledonia and for its nuclear testing in the region.   After the Assembly speeches critical of France delivered last week by the Foreign Ministers of Australia and New Zealand, the head of the Vanuatu delegation, Robert F. Van Lierop, said today that his country would ''not be intimidated'' by threats ''that economic aid will be terminated if we persist in bringing the question of New Caledonia to the United Nations.''   Referring to France as the ''administering power,'' Mr. Van Lierop said that ''it can blame no one but itself'' for the attention the United Nations has given to the question of independence for New Caledonia. He added that France had chosen ''not to proceed with what it had promised the colonized people of New Caledonia.''

headline: Option Is Held On Magazine
abstract: Sports Illustrated has taken a one-year option to buy the 12-year-old Women's Sports and Fitness magazine. During that year, it will put money and people into it to see if it is a viable property.

headline: GILLETTE SOARS $10 AS WALL STREET EXPECTS FIGHT WITH REVLON
abstract: Shares of the Gillette Company soared $10, to $67.75, in exceptionally heavy volume yesterday as Wall Street traders geared for a battle of wits between Ronald O. Perelman, the head of the Revlon Group, and one of the world's major consumer product companies.   Mr. Perelman, who wrested Revlon from an apparently entrenched management in a takeover battle in late 1985, offered yesterday to pay $65 a share - or $3.8 billion - for the 86.1 percent of Gillette that he does not already own.   The offer values the entire company at $4.1 billion.   Traders gambled heavily that Gillette would muster its considerable resources to oppose Mr. Perelman, taking some sort of action, possibly a restructuring, that would drive up the price of Gillette stock.

headline: The U.N. Today: Nov. 14, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Legal Committee - 3 P.M.  Pledging Conference for Development Activities 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee for Contributions to Program of High Commissioner for Refugees - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Webster Industries, a Boston plastic bag manufacturer, to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.    * Marcal Paper Mills to Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman for Whenever, a new line of feminine hygiene products.

headline: Without Pact, Oil Sags; Sugar Contracts Drop
abstract: Prices of crude oil and oil products sagged in world trading yesterday because of disappointment that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had not yet reached an agreement to cut its oil output.   The near-month futures contract for West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark grade, slipped 26 cents, to $16.10 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It fell 25 cents, to the same price, in the London-based spot market. The British Brent North Sea crude oil, a key international marker, was trading in London at $15.50 a barrel, down 50 cents.

headline: AFRICA WRITERS NOTE HAZARDS OF THE TRADE
abstract: Seated in a Harlem restaurant, East Africa's most prominent writer recently raised his glass in a quiet salute to West Africa's most prominent writer.   The West African, Wole Soyinka, had just won the Nobel Prize for Literature, the first for an African. At that moment, he was being honored throughout his homeland, Nigeria.   The East African, Ngugi wa Thiong'o of Kenya, was marking his fourth year in self-imposed exile.

headline: THE PASSAGE ACROSS INDIA OF GORBACHEV
abstract: For nearly an hour, a group of unsmiling Soviet security men guarded the gates of a shopping emporium here while Raisa M. Gorbachev, wife of the Soviet leader, was inside buying a green and pink silk sari for her daughter.   Before long, the agents succumbed to the scene, as most tourists eventually do. They pulled out their instant cameras and snapped pictures of each other posing in front of two caparisoned elephants waiting nearby.   Few such spontaneous moments arose in the four-day passage to India by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, which ended Friday. But there were many distinctive Indian touches offering the Soviet couple some challenges they may not have faced before.

headline: FILIPINOS DISAPPOINTED BY SENATE VOTE AGAINST AID
abstract: The Government reacted with disappointment and some bitterness today over the defeat in the United States Senate on Monday of a proposal for $200 million in increased economic aid for the Philippines.   President Corazon C. Aquino was quoted by her press secretary, Teodoro Benigno, as having said she was disappointed at the defeat but understood that the majority of the Senate had its own priorities ''and the Philippines is unfortunately not one of them.''   The presidential spokesman, Rene Saguisag, warned that ''we will remember those who were with us'' when the agreement allowing two American bases comes up for renewal in 1991.

headline: Allied Stores-Campeau
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn a motion for a preliminary injunction against the Campeau Corporation's tender offer in view of the Canadian company's extension of its offer until next Friday. A hearing had been scheduled for Monday in a New York Federal court.

headline: THE PRESS IS THRIVING IN LEBANON
abstract: When the Beirut magazine Al Shiraa reported in early November that a former United States national security adviser had been to Iran to sell weapons, it touched off a controversy that continues to reverberate.   That a scoop of such dimensions could be scored by a Beirut magazine has shown that, despite 11 years of civil war in Lebanon, Beirut continues to be a major listening post for the Middle East.   Al Shiraa said it was not serving any political motive when it reported that the former security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, had been to Teheran to offer arms and improvement in American-Iranian relations to the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: Peru Ends Price Freeze To Help Spur Economy
abstract: Prime Minister Luis Alva Castro, detailing measures to prolong an economic boom next year, announced an end to a price freeze imposed in August 1985 and said it would be replaced by a series of controls.   Mr. Alva, who is also Economy Minister, told a meeting of private business executives last night that there would be four varieties of control that would go into effect Dec. 15.   The measures followed an announcement this week by President Alan Garcia that the Government planned to increase wages by at least 6 percent over the level of inflation next year and was seeking economic growth of around 6 percent in 1987.

headline: Campeau Extends Its Offer for Allied
abstract: The Campeau Corporation has extended its tender offer for shares of the Allied Stores Corporation until Oct. 24, including withdrawal rights and proration.

headline: Allied's Move Is Opposed
abstract: The Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it would take all steps necessary to remove the ''poison pill'' adopted by the Allied Stores Corporation to thwart a $66-a-share tender offer for its stock by Campeau.   On Friday, Allied obtained a temporary restraining order halting the offer for 10 days.

headline: QUERY SEEN ON TRADING IN CBS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission turned to the First Boston Corporation yesterday for help in uncovering possible illegal trading in CBS stock or stock options, Wall Street sources said.   First Boston, one of the most successful Wall Street advisers in takeover situations, assisted Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman and one-time motion picture executive, on two takeover offers for the communications giant earlier this year. CBS rebuffed both bids.

headline: U.S. WILL PRESS FOR A SEPARATE MEDIUM-RANGE PACT
abstract: The White House said today that the United States would ask the Soviet Union to agree to drastic cuts in medium-range arms despite the Russians' opposition to the ''Star Wars'' program.   The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said Secretary of State George P. Shultz would take up the issue when he meets next week in Vienna with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union.   The talks will be their first since the Iceland summit meeting two weeks ago ended without a final agreement.   Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, indicated in a speech last week that all arms-control issues had now become linked in a single package, and that agreement in one area should be tied to agreement in other areas.

headline: TEXT OF MAIN ADDRESSES AT BANK-I.M.F. MEETING
abstract: Following are excerpts from the prepared texts of the addresses by President Reagan, Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, and Jacques de Larosiere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to the joint meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund yesterday:  PRESIDENT REAGAN All in all, we have made great progress towards a stronger world economy since I last addressed you, and yet problems remain.   As President of the United States, I am particularly aware of the tasks we in America have before us. Highest among these is curbing the growth of our Government's spending. No nation can survive if government becomes like the man who in winter began to burn the wallboards of his house to keep warm until he had no house left and froze.   We have made progress against those who would condemn future generations of Americans to lives of pauperdom; the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation is evidence of this. But we can and must do more. I pledge to you that I will do all in my power to stop this fiscal death march.

headline: Washington Water Bonds
abstract: The Washington Water Power Company is offering $80 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at a price of par through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.   Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds yield about 1.54 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016. Underwriters said the issue was rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poors.

headline: Sir James Cashes In His Goodyear Chips
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith ended his bid for Goodyear after the company agreed to buy back his shares at a $93 million profit for the British financier, a sum that had some analysts intimating greenmail. Sir James, in fact, said he was getting a good price - $49.50 a share. Goodyear also said it would buy back 40 million shares at $50 each; Sir James had offered $49 a share. The buyout surprised analysts, since days earlier Sir James had told a Congressional committee that Goodyear was squandering funds and that he could rescue it. Goodyear's chairman, Robert E. Mercer, who had been fiercely resisting Sir James, countered that people like Sir James are plunderers.   Goodyear had announced a major restructuring when Sir James first made advances, and now it says it will cut costs even further to pay the $2.6 billion its stock buyback will cost.Analysts are worried that Goodyear is loading itself with debt.

headline: ALTERING UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: A month before he is scheduled to succeed Harry J. Gray as chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, Robert F. Daniell has already moved quickly to trim management jobs, reduce costs and dismantle the company's strategy of growth through acquisition.   Mr. Daniell, a 53-year-old engineer, became chief executive officer last January and will become chairman on Jan. 1, 1987.   Under Mr. Gray, whose domineering personal style and frequent hostile takeover offers made him both feared and admired, United's sales have grown to more than $16 billion from $2 billion in 1972. On Wall Street, Mr. Gray came to be known as the ''Grand Acquisitor'' of corporate America. Among his acquisitions were Otis, the world's largest elevator manufacturer; Carrier International, the largest producer of air-conditioners, and Essex International, a maker of wires and cables.

headline: Account
abstract: * St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center to William Douglas McAdam.

headline: People
abstract: * Anthony R. Brescia, David Cantor, Alex Carlin and George Miller elected senior vice presidents at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

headline: 2 MORE COMPANIES SEEN QUITTING SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Following the lead that the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation took earlier this week, two more companies - Honeywell Inc. and Warner Communications Group -have apparently decided to sell their South African operations.   Officially, Honeywell said yesterday only that it was considering a pullout. ''The board of Honeywell is considering certain options for the sale of its South African affiliate,'' a company statement said. ''No final action has been taken.''

headline: SAUDI ARABIA: FAMILY BUSINESS
abstract: When Saudi Arabia's oil minister of 24 years, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was abruptly dismissed last week, worldwide attention was drawn to one of the world's more secretive royal families, the House of Saud.   The family, estimated to contain 8,000 members, is led by King Fahd, 64 years old, a man known in the Arab world for being extremely clever, cunning and alert. Hence the sobriquet, ''the desert hawk,'' which his subjects sometimes apply to him.   King Fahd became the ruler in 1982, with the agreement of senior family members, after his half-brother, the amiable, sports-loving King Khaled, died after a history of heart trouble.

headline: Technology; Plastic Blends Growing Fast
abstract: GREAT leaps forward are rare events in the world of plastics.   Occasionally, someone creates or discovers in the natural world a new grouping of molecules that can be repeated over and over in a linked string. Such strings, known as polymers, are the main chemical building blocks of the industry. The announcement of a new polymer with useful properties such as high strength, flexibility or heat resistance sends ripples of excitement - and competitive worry - through research and development groups around the world.

headline: I.B.M. Buybacks
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's biggest computer company, has announced that it would buy back about five million shares of common stock and a series of debentures, in transactions valued at $1.1 billion. I.B.M.'s shares closed Wednesday at $126 on the New York Stock Exchange. I.B.M. said it would redeem all $500 million of its 10 1/2 percent debentures due July 15, 2015, at $1,093.60 per $1,000. The redemption is set for Dec. 29.

headline: First Nationwide In Missouri Merger
abstract: First Nationwide Bank said it had acquired the St. Louis Federal Savings and Loan Association of Clayton, Mo. The association, which has assets of approximately $959 million and 25 branches, will be merged into First Nationwide, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company.   In making the acquisition, First Nationwide said that it had received financial assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to offset the Missouri association's negative net worth and that the San Francisco savings bank would provide sufficient additional capital to build and maintain net worth at positive regulatory requirements.

headline: Prime's Net Slips 20.4%
abstract: Prime Computer Inc. said today that weak demand in United States markets and a softening in some international markets contributed to lower earnings in the third quarter. Prime announced a 20.4 percent decrease in net income to $12.1 million, from $15.2 million last year, despite a 12.8 percent increase in revenue, to $221.9 million, from $196.7 million.

headline: PATENTS; A Reactor Is Termed Less Costly
abstract: ANUCLEAR reactor that reportedly can be manufactured at reduced cost was patented this week for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh.

headline: AIRBUS GETS BIG ORDER BY NWA
abstract: NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that it might buy as many as 100 planes from Airbus Industrie, for up to $3.2 billion.   Northwest obligated itself to buy only 10 of the European planes, but some analysts said the carrier would probably order all 100. If it did, the move would be one of most extensive ever taken by a domestic carrier to improve its fleet.   The order could give Airbus an important foothold in the American market, and thus it is a blow to the Boeing Company. In Seattle, Boeing said it was disappointed it did not get the order.

headline: A WINTER OF CABBAGES AND TRAFFIC JAMS AND RATS
abstract: A cold front, the television weatherman said, is moving in from Mongolia. Also moving in from the north - and the south, the east and the west - are cabbages, piles of cabbages, stacks of cabbages, molehills and mountains of cabbages, even carpets of cabbages.   In courtyards of the Great Hall of the People, where people like Deng Xiaoping meet foreign leaders, mounds of cabbages are tucked in corners, under driveway ramps, around the glass boxes manned by the green-uniformed soldiers of the People's Liberation Army.   More than the Mongolian cold front, it is the appearance of the cabbage Adirondacks on the streets of Peking that signals the impending onslaught of winter and the end of vegetable variety on home and restaurant tables everywhere.

headline: GORBACHEV ANGRILY ACCUSES REAGAN OF SCUTTLING AN ACCORD AT REYKJAVIK
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that by insisting on development of ''Star Wars'' weapons, President Reagan ''scuttled'' a series of broad arms control agreements reached by the two men at their meetings here.   The Soviet leader said that ''only a madman would accept'' the American insistence that research and development of a space-based missile defense system be allowed to proceed beyond laboratory work under a broad agreement to reduce nuclear weapons.   Mr. Gorbachev said at a news conference after the collapse of his talks with Mr. Reagan that he had come to Iceland thinking that the best way to end the arms race was to present President Reagan with a radical package of new proposals. 'Major Concessions' by Moscow    Mr. Gorbachev said Moscow had presented a package of ''major concessions and compromises'' at the meeting, while the United States side ''came empty-handed, with a whole set of mothballed proposals.''

headline: Kaiser Accepts Plan For New Company
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that it had agreed in principle with the British investor Alan Clore, its largest shareholder, to form a new holding company, with Mr. Clore as chairman. The agreement caps a 15-month takeover effort led by Joseph A. Frates, an investor from Tulsa, Okla., and an associate of Mr. Clore.   Under the agreement, subject to shareholder approval in early 1987, shares in the holding company would be exchanged for an equal number of shares in Kaiser Aluminum. Cornell C. Maier, Kaiser's chairman and chief executive, would become vice chairman of the holding company and retain his title at Kaiser Aluminum. The company would continue to be operated by current management, and would retain its headquarters in Oakland, Calif.

headline: BANKAMERICA DEAL PRODUCES DOUBTS
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation is likely to reject First Interstate Bancorp's takeover proposal as inadequate, analysts and banking industry sources said today.   ''My first guess is that First Interstate is not going to buy Bank of America, and no one is,'' said Ronald Mandle, banking analyst with Paine Webber Inc.   The offer, according to the analysts and banking sources, is worth far less than the $18-a-share value put on it by First Interstate. These sources estimated its value at only $13.50 to $14 a share.

headline: MANILA, ALLEGING TRUCE VIOLATION, REPORTS 3 DEAD IN A REBEL ATTACK
abstract: The military said today that three people had been killed and two others wounded when Communist rebels attacked a bus. It was the most serious accusation so far that the rebels had violated a eight-day-old cease-fire.   Bishop Antonio Y. Fortich, head of a bipartisan monitoring panel, said the incident, in which the military said two rebels were among the dead, ''could be a serious violation'' if confirmed.

headline: U.S. Honda Unit In Taiwan Deal
abstract: Taiwan's San Yang Industry Company has signed a one-year agreement to import up to 2,000 Honda Accord cars next year from the Honda Motor Company's American subsidiary, San Yang's chairman, Huang Shi-Hui, said. Honda's American unit had said in Detroit Thursday that it was negotiating a deal to export cars made in its Ohio plant to Taiwan.

headline: China and Portugal In Accord on Macao
abstract: China and Portugal have reached an agreement on returning the Portuguese settlement of Macao to China, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said today.   A working group will be set up to iron out the details, the ministry said in a statement issued after two days of talks between Chinese and Portuguese officials.

headline: 4 Wounded by Police Gunfire At a Political Clash in Malta
abstract: The police shot and wounded four people today during a clash between supporters of the opposition Nationalist Party and followers of Prime Minister Carmelo Mifsud Bonnici, the Nationalists' leader said.   The incident occurred as 30,000 Nationalist supporters marched on the village of Zejtun, nine miles south of here, for an electoral rally.

headline: Sikh Militants Reported To Kill 4 in Punjab
abstract: Four people were shot dead in Punjab state over the weekend, apparently by Sikh militants, as India's main Hindu opposition group charged Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had failed to restore peace to the northern state.   The Press Trust of India said the latest victims were a supporter of the mainstream Sikh party, the Akali Dal; the son of Pawan Kumar, a Hindu leader of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party; a teacher, and a Hindu businessman.

headline: NASDAQ SHORT INTEREST IS UP BY 3.5%
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that its short interest on Nasdaq stocks was up 6.7 million shares, or 3.5 percent, in the month ended Nov. 14, to 197.1 million shares.   Beginning today, The New York Times business report includes the short interest figures for Nasdaq stocks.

headline: SOVIET LAW WIDENS PRIVATE BUSINESS
abstract: The Soviet Union approved an array of private production activities today, cautiously restoring a touch of free enterprise to the Government-run economy for the first time since the 1920's.   A law voted by the Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament, at the conclusion of a three-day meeting gives individuals and families the right to act as private entrepreneurs.   Under the law, which will become effective May 1, Soviet citizens may go into business on their own to manufacture consumer goods like clothing and furniture and perform services like repairing cars and painting apartments.   The hiring of others remains prohibited, and this traditional restriction in this Marxist society is expected to limit the size of private enterprises.

headline: Washington Watch; Outlook for Economic Panel
abstract: Representative David R. Obey's two-year tenure as chairman of the Joint Economic Committee is just about up, with the current session of Congress ended and a new one beginning in January. That means the strong Democratic tone the Wisconsin Congressman has set for the committee would shift markedly to the right if Republicans keep control of the Senate.

headline: SHULTZ REAFFIRMS HIS OPPOSITION TO NEGOTIATIONS WITH TERRORISTS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he remained opposed to any negotiations with terrorists for the release of American hostages.   Mr. Shultz made his comments on his Air Force jet returning to the United States from Paris.   He said he had been ordered by the White House not to comment on reports that Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, had secretly negotiated with Iranian officials and helped arrange for arms to be supplied to Iran to secure the release, over a period of time, of three American hostages held in Lebanon.   After saying many times that he would not comment, Mr. Shultz, expressing some exasperation, said: ''The White House is in charge of the executive branch, and they have issued a statement that all questions shall be answered by the White House. And that's why I say, 'Ask the White House,' and I have no comment to make myself.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CAREER NETWORKING
abstract: IN the old days, before personal computers and the Women's Movement, networking was primarily a male activity, undertaken in all-male social and dining clubs. But now computers can electronically link hundreds of strangers via bulletin boards, and women are breaking down the barriers of the once-male domains. The result is a profusion of professional networks through which men and increasingly women of all occupations trade business cards, information, advice and referrals.

headline: THE U.N. TODAY: OCT. 29, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: NEW N.S.C. CHIEF IS SAID TO PLAN A NEAR-TOTAL OVERHAUL OF COUNCIL
abstract: The new director of the National Security Council, Frank C. Carlucci, plans a virtually complete overhaul of the council, and has already selected key aides on the Soviet Union and Latin America, Administration officials said today.   One Administration official said that Mr. Carlucci, who was named less than two weeks ago to replace Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, plans a ''clean deck of people'' at the council, and that he was ''disturbed'' about the way the council had been operating.   Mr. Carlucci's plans to revamp the National Security Council come amid revelations that council officials apparently played a central role in what the White House has described as the diversion of millions of dollars to Nicaraguan rebels from the profit of clandestine Iran arms deals. Admiral Poindexter resigned as assistant to the President for national security affairs as the arrangements were revealed, and a key aide, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, was dismissed.

headline: EASING THE BITE OF THE ALTERNATIVE TAX
abstract: THOUSANDS of individuals who think they are taking prudent steps to minimize their taxes may discover next year that they have outsmarted themselves. The reason is the alternative minimum tax, whose reach has been expanded to catch more taxpayers, and whose rate has been raised to extract more taxes from them.   The A.M.T. - as the alternative tax is nicknamed by professionals - is designed to insure that wealthy individuals pay their fair share of taxes and do not escape by artificially lowering their income through the use of ''tax preference'' items such as long-term capital gains, accelerated depreciation and paper losses on tax shelters. The A.M.T. has been part of the tax code since 1978, but the new tax law has radically enlarged its scope and bite.

headline: AFTER ISRAELI'S VISIT, DEBATE IN ASIA CONTINUES
abstract: Nearly three weeks after President Chaim Herzog of Israel ended a visit to Southeast Asia and the Pacific, a heated political and diplomatic debate is still going on over charges of ''Zionist influence'' in the region.   Among non-Communist Southeast Asian countries, especially the Philippines, where a scheduled stop by Mr. Herzog was canceled at the last minute because of what were called political considerations, the debate has brought into focus emergent policy makers who want to redirect traditional pro-Western alliances and move more into line with other third-world nations.   In a recent speech to diplomats in Manila, a Philippine Deputy Foreign Minister, Mamintal Tamano, called for a greater ''Islamic factor'' in Manila's diplomacy.   Another Deputy Foreign Minister, Leticia Ramos Shahani, a former United Nations official close to President Corazon C. Aquino and someone widely regarded as a future foreign minister, is reported to have played the pivotal role in having the Herzog visit called off. Mrs. Shahani declined to discuss the issue in an interview.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said the recent public offering of 51 percent of its bottling unit had resulted in a pretax accounting gain of about $376 million in the value of the 49 percent it retained.

headline: USX STOCK UP ON TAKEOVER
abstract: Indications that Carl C. Icahn, the New York takeover specialist, might soon make a move against the USX Corporation sent that company's shares sharply higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.   USX stock rose $1.75, to $26.375 on the day's heaviest volume of 8.1 million shares.   Wall Street sources said Mr. Icahn, who has not returned telephone calls all week, has been talking to investment bankers in the past few days about whether financing would be available to attempt a takeover of the nation's largest steel manufacturer.

headline: Datapoint Stake
abstract: James Grosfeld, chairman of the Pulte Home Corporation, said today that he had sold his entire 7.3 percent stake in the Datapoint Corporation. Mr. Grosfeld gave no reason for the sale in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Datapoint, a computer products company based in San Antonia, was acquired last year by the New York financier Asher B. Edelman. Between Nov. 23 and Nov. 26, Mr. Grosfeld sold his 1.42 million Datapoint shares on the open market for $10.03 million, or an average price of $7.03 a share.

headline: EGYPTIAN WARNS OF RISK GULF WAR WILL WIDEN
abstract: Egypt's Defense Minister said today that the use of more advanced weapons by both sides in the Iran-Iraq war carried an increased risk that hostilities would spread to neighboring countries.   Moreover, he said, hopes for a cease-fire ''are diminishing.''   The Defense Minister, Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, who is also Deputy Prime Minister, said possibilities that the conflict would worsen had increased in a way that would menace Egypt's interests, those of the region and those of the West.   ''There is no way to predict the course of the Iran-Iraq war,'' he said. ''Most of the fixed elements of the old formula become variables,'' he said, apparently referring to the changes imposed on standard military assumptions in the region by the introduction of new weapons technology. ''The old variables become more variable.''

headline: Advertising; Jacques Jaunet Drops Agency
abstract: Jacques Jaunet, the French apparel company, has split with its United States agency, Altschiller Reitzfeld, which it retained in February 1983.

headline: PHILIPPINE MILITARY ISSUED DEMANDS TO AQUINO
abstract: The armed forces Chief of Staff said today that he gave President Corazon C. Aquino a set of military demands last week as part of a move to block a planned coup.   After a 90-minute meeting with the President today, the Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, said the demands included ''immediate replacement of Cabinet officials who have not performed adequately.''   Mrs. Aquino's spokesman, Teodoro Benigno, who read the general's statement to reporters, said the removal of one or two Cabinet members was a possibility, although he insisted this would not be in response to military demands.   He said the powers of Executive Secretary Joker Arroyo, who has been criticized by the military and others, might be cut back with the appointment of a palace chief of staff to ''streamline'' the affairs of Government.

headline: Advanced Micro To Take Write-Off
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a leading semiconductor maker, said that it would take an extraordinary charge of $15 million to $20 million in the just-ended second fiscal quarter for costs associated with the consolidation of manufacturing operations.   The Sunnyvale, Calif., company said it expected that, excluding the write-off, both sales and operating results for the quarter that ended Sept. 26 will be roughly the same as in the June quarter, when it lost $28 million on revenues of $154 million. It is also expected that later this month the company will announce layoffs of hundreds of employees, ending a no-layoff policy that has existed for several years.

headline: ELECTION OF U.N. LEADER TO 2D TERM IS EXPECTED
abstract: The re-election of Javier Perez de Cuellar as Secretary General is virtually assured, diplomats said today.   The 159 members of the United Nations are expected to elect Mr. Perez de Cuellar, a 66-year-old Peruvian diplomat, to a second five-year term unanimously next Friday, they said.   On Thursday, representatives of the five permanent members of the 15-nation Security Council - the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union - met secretly with Mr. Perez de Cuellar to tell him officially that they would like him to stay on, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.   ''It's in the bag,'' a diplomats who attended the meeting said. ''It's a fait accompli.''

headline: Boesky Terms: Too Lenient?
abstract: FROM all appearances, when Ivan F. Boesky agreed to pay Uncle Sam a stunning $100 million to settle insider charges against him, both parties thought they had gotten a good deal.   The Government had bagged risk arbitrage's most prominent practitioner on illegal trading and extracted a money penalty that dwarfed any similar sanction on record. It had also secured Mr. Boesky's cooperation, with the prospect of his leading investigators to other, equally prominent wrong-doers on Wall Street.   And for their part, Mr. Boesky and his legal team seemed to feel the financier was getting off relatively well. Whatever the price tag, the settlement left Mr. Boesky, whose net worth is estimated at $200 million, with vast wealth. His agreement to plead to a single felony count seemed to minimize the prospects of prison, and, though barred for life from the brokerage business, he was given him a decent interval to wrap up his affairs. There was a feeling that he was taking his medicine and putting the episode behind him.

headline: Radio Marti Reporter To Fight Reassignment
abstract: A reporter for Radio Marti who was reassigned for questioning President Reagan at a news conference said today that she had changed her mind and would not resign. Instead, she said, she will ''fight this case.''

headline: People
abstract: * Carole Cohan, Charles Abrams and David Herzbrun all named executive vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.    * Janet Riccio promoted to senior vice president at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

headline: Iraqi Planes Reportedly Hit 2 Tankers in the Persian Gulf
abstract: Iraqi warplanes attacked two supertankers in the Persian Gulf today, shipping sources said.

headline: Altman Chief Sentenced
abstract: Anthony R. Conti, chairman and chief executive of the B. Altman stores, was sentenced yesterday to serve 22 days of community service in a drug treatment center and received two years' probation for failing to file his 1982 Federal income tax on time. Appearing before United States Magistrate Serena Peretti in Newark, he was also ordered to pay a $2,000 fine.

headline: BCI to Sell Webcraft Unit
abstract: The BCI Holdings Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Webcraft Technologies Inc. unit to a group led by management and Riordan Freeman & Spogli, a Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm, for about $275 million.   Webcraft is a specialty printing company that makes promotional mail products for the direct-mail industry. The company, based in North Brunswick, N.J., is expected to report fiscal 1987 sales of $200 million.

headline: Black & Decker Change
abstract: Laurence J. Farley has retired as a director and chairman of the Black & Decker Corporation to form a consulting and investment firm, the company announced Friday. Mr. Farley had relinquished the title of chief executive in March to Nolan D. Archibald, who continued as company president. Black & Decker, which is based in Towson, Md., makes power tools and small appliances.

headline: Markets Ignore Iranian Crisis
abstract: THE crisis over the Reagan Administration's secret arms shipments to Iran and the dismissal of two key White House aides over the transfer of funds received from Iran to Nicaraguan ''contras'' has thus far had no perceptible effect on the stock market. This week investors pushed the Dow-Jones industrial average up to 1,916.76, just a bit below its record high of 1,919.71.   The way the markets have shrugged off not only the Ivan F. Boesky affair and Wall Street's spreading insider scandal but also the most serious crisis President Reagan has faced appears to reflect investors' judgment - or their wishful thinking -that nothing has happened that will seriously hurt the stock market.   They seem convinced that the Iranian affair will not bring down the President or force a drastic change in the economic, financial and deregulatory policies that produced the long stock market boom.

headline: REAGAN CALLS PLANE'S CREW A NEW LINCOLN BRIGADE
abstract: President Reagan strongly suggested today that he approved of efforts by private American citizens to help Nicaraguan insurgents fighting the Sandinista Government, including those Americans who sent in a cargo plane that was shot down on Sunday.   But Administration officials disclosed that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had opened what was decribed as a ''preliminary investigaton'' of those private activities as possible violation of American neutrality laws.   Even so, President Reagan compared the efforts of private citizens at this time to those of Americans who joined the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the 1930's to fight alongside Spanish Republican soldiers against Franco and his rightist insurgents. 'We've Been Aware'    Referring to the Nicaraguan insurgents by their popular name, contras, the President said that ''we've been aware that there are private groups and private citizens that have been trying to help the contras to that extent.''

headline: Goodyear Net Climbs by 18%
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today its third-quarter profit rose 18 percent to $182.3 million, or $1.68 a share, from $154.5 million, or $1.44 a share, a year earlier.   Sales rose 10 percent, to $2.60 billion, from $2.36 billion.   The company attributed the increases to improved unit sales of automobile tires worldwide, higher shipments of industrial rubber products in the United States, and stronger foreign results that were aided by the dollar's decline against European currencies.

headline: HASENFUS LAWYER IN A CHALLENGE
abstract: The lawyer defending the American captured from a rebel plane challenged the legality of court documents today and showed a statement signed by the American prisoner that contends his human rights have been violated.   The lawyer, Enrique Sotelo Borgen, denied to reporters that his client, Eugene Hasenfus, was an American intelligence agent.

headline: IRAN'S PRESIDENT REBUTS REAGAN, DENYING THERE WERE CONTRACTS
abstract: The President of Iran took issue with President Reagan today, denying that his Government had held talks at a diplomatic level with the United States.   The Iranian President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, speaking a day after President Reagan said the United States had sent a small amount of weapons to Iran in a bid to improve relations with Teheran, dismissed Mr. Reagan's assertions of negotiations as ''mere lies.''   Hojatolislam Khameini vowed that there would be no ''leniency and comprise'' with the United States until it changed what he called its aggressive policy in the Middle East.

headline: Papal Economics
abstract: To the Editor:   Those who are dismayed by the Pope's refusal to propose specific solutions to economic problems are forgetting that such solutions fall outside of the Church's mission and competence. It is the role of the Church to preach the basic moral principles that govern society.

headline: New Interco Bid Accepted by Lane
abstract: The Lane Company has accepted a sweetened takeover proposal from Interco Inc., the companies said today.

headline: Strong Quake Hits Bulgaria
abstract: A strong earthquake shook most of Bulgaria this afternoon and caused some damage, the state-run Bulgarian press agency reported.

headline: Credit Suisse Unit Picks Key Officerr
abstract: After seven years as a senior executive in the capital markets area for First Boston Inc., David C. Batten is moving over to Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., the leading underwriter in the Eurobond market. Mr. Batten, 42 years old, will work in the same field for Credit Suisse First Boston and head the London-based firm's efforts to attract and generate new business, starting Jan. 1, with the title executive director.   The decision to move Mr. Batten over to London, reported earlier this week by Corporate Financing Week, a New York newsletter, comes less than a month after the announcement that Hans-Joerg Rudloff, deputy chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston, was named a director of Credit Suisse, Switzerland's third-largest bank and the controlling shareholder in Credit Suisse First Boston.   Mr. Rudloff, one of the best-known figures in the Euromarkets, retained his position at Credit Suisse First Boston, where he has been in charge of the firm's capital-markets and new-business areas.

headline: AQUINO SAYS AIDE VOWED TO AVERT COUP
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile had promised to ''do his best'' to avert a coup during her four-day visit to Japan next week.   He was said to have made the pledge at a meeting on Friday evening arranged by the armed forces chief, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos. Military sources said the general had succeeded in defusing a plot by officers close to Mr. Enrile.   ''I just said that just assure me that nothing happens while I'm in Japan,'' Mrs. Aquino said today, referring to Mr. Enrile. ''I told him that, and he said he's going to do his best.''

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's 375 money market mutual funds decreased $1.03 billion, to $233.9 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: SLIM PROFITS SEEN FOR MCDONNELL JET
abstract: By leaping into the production of a new jumbo jet, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is entering a growth market, but one that may not yield big profits, analysts said yesterday.   ''My gut feeling is that they will sell enough airplanes to break even and not much more,'' said Howard Mager, an aerospace analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.   Analysts said the MD-11 aircraft, which got McDonnell's go-ahead on Monday, would be ideal for many airlines - particularly those that fly to international destinations from ''secondary hubs,'' such as Chicago or Dallas, rather than from primary gateways like New York. Improved Efficiency    That is because the MD-11, although based on McDonnell Douglas's three-engine DC-10, will be much more fuel-efficient and have a flying range of up to 8,870 miles - an increase of more than 30 percent. It will also carry as many as 405 passengers, compared with a maximum of 380 for the DC-10, and will have an advanced cockpit that will require only a two-man crew, compared with three for the DC-10.

headline: PRETORIA ADMITS DETAINING CHILDREN
abstract: The South African authorities acknowledged for the first time today that children between the ages of 11 and 15 are being held under the nation's emergency decree, which permits detention without trial.   Figures made public by the police indicated that South Africa's youngest political prisoner is 11 years old, and that 6 12-year-olds, 21 13-year-olds, 88 14-year-olds and 140 15-year-olds are being held.   The police chief, Gen. Johann Coetzee, disputed assessments by anti-Government activists that up to 1,800 black teenagers are in detention. General Coetzee said the figure for detainees between the ages of 11 and 15 was 256, but gave no figure for 16- to 18-year-olds.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Boston Gas Co. is offering $30 million of 8 3/4 percent debentures due in 2001 at a price of 100, or 1.6 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by First Boston. Nonrefundable for 10 years, the debentures are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.13 percent, up from 5.93 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 5.96 percent, up from 5.80 percent.

headline: Inquiry at Intelsat Continues
abstract: The directors of Intelsat, scheduled to meet here Thursday and Friday, may consider dismissing their top two operating executives because of a disputed payment to a mortgage broker, sources close to the international communications satellite consortium said.   The two executives - Richard R. Colino, director general of Intelsat for nearly three years and the first American to serve as its chief executive, and Jose L. Alegrett, deputy director general for business planning and external development - were placed on ''administrative leave'' on Nov. 24.   A statement then from Intelsat said they were put on leave after the chairman received a letter from external auditors ''raising questions about certain transactions.'' The contents of the letter were not disclosed.

headline: Judge Backs Knudsen Deal
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved the sale of about half of the operations of Knudsen Foods Inc. to Kraft Inc. and Hughes Markets, a Southern California grocery operator.
