headline: Utility Takes Loss
abstract: The Public Service Company of Indiana said it would take a $140 million charge in the current quarter to cover losses related to its Marble Hill nuclear project near New Washington, Ind.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: GALBRAITH ON THE BOESKY SCANDAL; A Classic Case of 'Euphoric Insanity'
abstract: In his 1954 book ''The Great Crash 1929,'' John Kenneth Galbraith provided a memorable portrait of one of the most notorious figures in Wall Street history. That was the patrician Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1930 to 1935, who was convicted of grand larceny in 1938 (for using other people's stock as collateral for his own loans).  This week, Professor Galbraith -who is preparing a lengthy article on the precarious state of today's capital markets for the Atlantic Monthly magazine - was asked to compare the Whitney scandal of old with Ivan Boesky's unfolding misdeeds and to explore the causes and likely repercussions of the current insider trading case. In a discussion with Kyle Crichton, Business Forum editor, Mr. Galbraith, emeritus professor of economics at Harvard University, finds Mr. Boesky's fall less dramatically pleasing than Mr. Whitney's, but is otherwise optimistic that, by dampening the merger wave, the scandal may prove salutary.  Q. In Wall Street's gallery of rogues, where does Ivan F. Boesky rank?  A. If you are making a gallery of rogues, $100 million puts you pretty high up.

headline: Kaiser Steel Seeks To End Dispute
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation is continuing discussions with Bruce Hendry in a bid to resolve a dispute about control of the company's board, a Kaiser spokesman said. An election inspector last week granted control of the board to a slate of directors backed by Mr. Hendry.

headline: Advertising; A Political Void Filled By Cleaner
abstract: AGAINST the backdrop of a dazzling array of advertising creativity awards, the stars of Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey revealed, yesterday morning, the name of the replacement for Andrew O'Rourke, defeated Republican candidate for governor - and their first lost account.   It is the Regina Company, the maker of floor-cleaning gear, and master of the clean sweep, unlike the candidate.   The new account will bill about $12 million.

headline: Bokassa Trial Put Off After Turbulent Session
abstract: The trial of Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the former Emperor Bokassa I, was postponed until next month after the prosecutor said during a stormy four-hour opening session today that he needed more time to prepare the case.

headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Printouts; Using Super Glue In Medicine
abstract: Anyone whose fingers have accidentally become stuck together while working with Krazy Glue knows how quickly and tenaciously it bonds skin. However, there is little practical benefit in gluing one's finger to one's ear when trying to fix an earring.

headline: 11 Die in Indian Bus Crash
abstract: A bus swerved off the road into a ditch in the northern Punjab today, killing 11 people and injuring more than 20, the United News of India reported. The accident occurred in the village of Dhar Kalan, near the border with Pakistan, the agency said.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW GIVEN BY THE SAKHAROVS IN MOSCOW
abstract: Following is a transcript of remarks made by Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, to Western reporters today, as translated by The Associated Press:   Q. Do you have any Christmas wishes?   SAKHAROV. As usual on this day, I wish people and their families happiness, love, peace and health. On this day, a family day, a day when people must think about or, at least, hope that everything will be all right in the world, for all nations of the world.

headline: TOP MOZAMBICAN ACCUSES PRETORIA
abstract: Mozambique's new leader, Joaquim Chissano, accused South Africa today of breaking a security pact with his beleaguered land by dropping supplies and providing other logistical support for a new offensive by rebels here.   President Chissano was speaking at his first news conference since taking over after his predecessor, Samora M. Machel, died in a plane crash in South African territory on Oct. 19 that has not yet been explained. President Machel had ruled the increasingly impoverished country since its independence from Portugal in 1975.

headline: No Retreat Is Seen on Bank's Bid
abstract: The management of the First Interstate Bancorp is expected to recommend to its board of directors on Monday that the company proceed with its bid to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, numerous industry sources said this weekend.   The First Interstate board will be meeting in Los Angeles to discuss how to respond to BankAmerica's request that the takeover bid be withdrawn to allow BankAmerica more time to study its options.   First Interstate's management, however, will not recommend withdrawing the bid, said one knowledgeable source, who asked not to be named.

headline: 5 RUSSIANS GIVEN NEW DAY TO LEAVE
abstract: The State Department announced today that the remaining Soviet diplomats ordered expelled by the Reagan Administration must leave the United States by Sunday.   According to an official at the United States Mission to the United Nations, 5 of the 25 diplomats originally named are still here, but they are expected to leave by tomorrow.   A leading Soviet official, asked if his country would carry out an earlier threat to retaliate against the United States for the expulsions, said, ''The retaliation will be made.'' He did not elaborate.

headline: FURTHER ACCOUNTS BLOCKED BY SWISS
abstract: The United States today gave the Swiss authorities an additional list of three companies and nine people whose bank accounts it wants temporarily blocked because of their reported use to funnel Iranian arms payments to rebels in Nicaragua.   Swiss officials described the American request as a supplement to an earlier request Monday that led to the blocking of accounts in the Geneva branch of Credit Suisse, held in the name of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a former member of the National Security Council staff in the White House.   Swiss officials said that the supplementary American request listed the three companies as Hyde Park Holdings, Stanford Technology Corporation and Lake Resources Inc., and the individuals as Colonel North, Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a former Pentagon official, and Albert Hakim, a business associate of General Secord. Khashoggi Account Is Blocked The Swiss officials said others on the list were Adnan Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian, and Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian. The names of Canadians were also said to be included. Donald Fraser and Ernest Miller, Toronto investors, have been linked to the affair.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: GEBAUER OFFERS GUILTY PLEA
abstract: A former top officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company pleaded guilty, as expected, in Federal court yesterday to charges of defrauding the bank by making $4.3 million in unauthorized withdrawals from the accounts of Brazilian depositors.   Antonio Gebauer also pleaded guilty to tax evasion and to using his position as a senior vice president to make $2.9 million in unauthorized loans to six Brazilian accounts to cover up the withdrawals.   Howard Wilson, chief of the criminal division for the United States District Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said in an interview that no more charges would be brought against Mr. Gebauer. But Mr. Wilson said there was a continuing investigation ''to determine whether there are other people who should be charged with crimes.''

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A brief report last week about sugar as a political lever incorrectly described the fate of amendments proposed by Senator Jesse Helms to the anti-drug act. The act does, as Senator Helms proposed, eliminate the sugar quota from any country suspected of aiding the trafficking of drugs to the United States.

headline: GUINNESS INVESTIGATION LOOKS AT STOCK ACTION
abstract: The British Government's investigation of Guinness P.L.C. is focusing on suspicious movements in the stock prices of companies involved in the bitter battle to take over the Distillers Company earlier this year, according to sources close to the inquiry.   For the last two days, investigators have been seeking records from the merchant banks and brokerage houses that dealt with the companies involved in the struggle for the Scotch whisky giant. Guinness won the protracted fight last April with a $3.8 billion offer, beating a rival bid from the Argyll Group P.L.C.   The Government apparently is examining the sharp run-up in Guinness shares last April. That price surge helped the brewing company win Distillers because both of the competing bids were partly in cash, partly in stock. The Guinness shares jumped from 281 pence on March 13 to 353 pence on April 11, one week before Guinness won control of Distillers.

headline: Iberian Leaders Meet
abstract: The Prime Ministers of Portugal and Spain today discussed ways of improving commercial and political ties to put relations between their countries on a new footing within the European Community. The talks in Guimarais, in northern Portugal, were the first formal meeting between Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal and Felipe Gonzalez of Spain since their nations joined the Community in January.

headline: Israeli Gunboats Off Lebanon Shell 2 Palestinian Positions
abstract: Three Israeli gunboats today shelled two Palestinian positions outside Sidon.   The Lebanese police said the warships had fired missiles against strongholds around two refugee districts, Ain Khilwe and Mieh Mieh.

headline: NEW LIFE FOR A 'LAME DUCK'
abstract: UNTIL about six weeks ago, those who profess to know who's who in this town said that Paul A. Volcker had become a lame duck - a man whose chances of being reappointed head of the Federal Reserve had fallen well below 50-50 and who had begun to weigh seriously some of the juicy seven-figure-a-year offers dangling before him.   Some observers even said they detected a certain detachment in Mr. Volcker's performance in the world's mightiest financial job. He had, they said, not engaged in the subtle lobbying that would have signaled his eagerness to remain in power.   Mr. Volcker's departure, in many eyes, would be a sharp blow to confidence in American economic policy making and could lead, among other things, to a run on the dollar. Like two of his modern predecessors, William McChesney Martin Jr. and Arthur F. Burns, Mr. Volcker has come to be seen as an almost impossibly tough act to follow.

headline: Thousand Pay Homage To Mozambican Leader
abstract: Thousands of Mozambicans today filed past the coffin of President Samora M. Machel.

headline: HARD TIMES IN MEXICO CAUSE CONCERN IN U.S.
abstract: Economic troubles and other problems in Mexico appear to be severe enough that the United States must worry about the possibility of social unrest and political instability there, according to American experts in and out of Government and Mexican officials and scholars.   Interviews with more than two dozen American experts and reporting from Mexico found agreement that the foundation of the Mexican Government was being eroded by its failure to curtail pervasive corruption, drug trafficking and electoral fraud.   A wide range of Mexican intellectuals, scholars, writers and Government officials concur that their country is in serious trouble and say its turmoil is likely to have a growing effect on relations with the United States.  [ Page 20. ]  A Strategic Role Mexico's difficulties have created concern in Washington, not least because of the country's strategic location. Since World War II, the United States' ability to play an active role in world affairs has been premised on the knowledge that its 1,952-mile border with Mexico was secure. Serious problems in Mexico could force the United States to reassess its strategy and refocus its foreign policy.

headline: BANK SUITOR BOLD, SUCCESSFUL
abstract: After spending 25 years working his way up the ladder at the Bank of America, Joseph J. Pinola resigned 10 years ago partly because he felt the top spot would never be his. Now the 61-year-old son of a machinist from Pennsylvania's coal country is engineering an audacious bid for his First Interstate Bancorp to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, a move that would place him atop a powerful, world-class banking institution.   It also would represent an ultimate victory for Mr. Pinola, who, colleagues say, has tried to outdo his former employer at every turn. Shortly after joining First Interstate, for example, Mr. Pinola is said to have ordered a plane for the bank and required that it be bigger than BankAmerica's.

headline: AUDIT SAYS IT CAN'T VERIFY THE USE OF 'HUMANITARIAN' AID TO CONTRAS
abstract: A special State Department office set up last year by President Reagan to distribute $27 million in ''humanitarian assistance'' to Nicaraguan rebels has been unable to verify how most of the money was spent, according to a report published today by the General Accounting Office.   The State Department, however, asserted that many of the conclusions in the report were wrong. The director of the special aid office, Richard W. Duemling, said he was able to account for virtually all of the money, which was spent on food, clothing, and medical supplies for the rebels, also known as contras. Ammunition and Grenades Cited   In its report, the General Accounting Office, which is the investigative arm of Congress, also said that in at least one instance funds were spent on ammunition and grenades, a violation of the Congressional act that financed the special aid office. In another incident thousands of dollars was embezzled by a Central American supplier, the G.A.O. said.

headline: Chicago Board Sets New Expirations
abstract: In a major move designed to end the havoc created by ''triple witching hours,'' the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it planned to change the expiration dates of its stock index futures and stock index option contracts.   The Merc said it was applying to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to make the changes so that the settlement price of its stock index futures and options contracts would be based on Friday's opening stock prices.   Until now, the Merc's Standard & Poors 500-stock index future contract, the most popular stock index future, expired on Friday afternoon and the settlement was based on the closing stock prices that afternoon on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Shamrock Further Cuts Its Stake in Foote, Cone
abstract: Shamrock Holdings, which at one point had Foote, Cone & Belding Communications worried about a takeover attempt, has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has once again sold off 100,000 shares of the agency's stock, bringing its holdings down to 4.4 percent.   Shamrock, owned by Roy E. Disney, had permission from the S.E.C. to buy up to 25 percent. As soon as it got permission, it sold 100,000 shares at $57.75 each, dropping its ownership stake to 7.2 percent from 9.9 percent The latest sale was for $44 a share.

headline: Nepal Prince Warns Of Threat to Wildlife
abstract: The brother of King Birenda warned today that a paper mill that China helped build threatens rare crocodiles, dolphins and the fabled Bengal tiger.

headline: DANILOFF'S UNWITTING ROLE IN INTRIGUE
abstract: Nicholas S. Daniloff said today that he had been unwittingly caught up in a complex intelligence confrontation in Moscow between the Central Intelligence Agency and the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and secret police agency.   Mr. Daniloff said he fell into a situation he still does not fully understand when he delivered to the American Embassy in 1985 an unsolicited letter from a bogus priest who he thinks was probably a K.G.B. agent.   The embassy's efforts to follow up the letter, he said in an interview, included two communications with the priest that mentioned Mr. Daniloff indirectly, apparently giving the Soviet authorities the impression that he was involved in American espionage.   He said the K.G.B. was planning to present the incident as key evidence against him if he had gone to trial.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: A MARSHALL PLAN FOR THE 80'S; 'Recycling' Surpluses to the Third World
abstract: THE world economy is in serious trouble, wracked by major tensions that threaten to derail what the World Bank already calls ''hesitant recovery.'' Tuesday's election demonstrates that the precarious health of this recovery is also uppermost in the minds of millions of Americans, whether they earn their livings in older, smokestack industries, new high-tech companies or family farms.  At the heart of this concern is the tremendous increase in the United States trade deficit. The soaring American trade deficit has provided almost all of the growth in world import demand in the last few years, but now stands at a level that simply cannot be sustained. At the same time, the rising surpluses of West Germany and Japan call forth ever stronger demands for protective action.

headline: Great Moments in French Fries
abstract: Before McDonald's existed, 5 percent of America's potato crop was consumed as french fries; now it is 25 percent. McDonald's plumbed the potato's secrets, perfecting the type (No. 1 Idaho Russet), the curing (three weeks), the storage (cool) and the cooking oil (vegetable oil and refined beef fat).

headline: WIESEL, ACCEPTING THE NOBEL, ASKS THE LIVING TO REMEMBER
abstract: Elie Wiesel dared not speak for the dead today as he accepted the Nobel Peace Prize.   ''No one may interpret their mutilated dreams and visions,'' he said, his voice, as ever, a tenacious wisp of memory and grief for the Jews killed en masse in World War II.   Instead, the weary-faced author and teacher, 58 years old, fought back tears and eventually smiled and spoke for the living in accepting the prize ''as one who has emerged from that kingdom of night.''   ''This honor belongs to all the survivors, to their children and, through us, to the Jewish people with whose destiny I have always identified,'' he declared after an opening scene of great emotion.

headline: Prudential Picks Leader For Global Investment
abstract: William M. Bethke, a vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has been named president of Prudential Affiliated Investors, a new unit that will coordinate global money management for the nation's largest life insurer.   ''There are great opportunities worldwide, and there should be some efficiencies and synergism in having one unit with responsibility for our expansion globally,'' Mr. Bethke said yesterday.

headline: Dialogue in Vienna: The Issues
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, are in Vienna for a 35-nation meeting reviewing the Helsinki accords. In private talks outside the meeting, they are expected to take up these Soviet-American issues:  Arms Control 1. ''Star Wars'': The Soviet Union and the United States are talking about a commitment to adhere for 10 more years to the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. They differ about how to interpret the treaty and how much research would be allowed on the ''Star Wars'' space-based missile defense program. At the Iceland meeting, the Soviet Union said it wanted to limit research on space-based systems to the laboratory. Since then, the Soviet Union has hinted that it may take a more flexible position, and American officials want to follow up these hints. It remains to be seen whether the United States will agree to strict limits. The United States is insisting on the right to interpret the ABM Treaty in a loose way that would allow testing and development of space-based systems. Amerian negotiators of the 1972 treaty do not believe that this loose interpretation is valid. 2. Medium-Range Missiles: In Iceland, the two sides agreed to eliminate all American and Soviet medium-range missiles from Europe. The Soviet Union would be allowed to keep 100 warheads on medium-range missiles in Asia and the United States 100 warheads on medium-range missiles within its own territory. The Soviet Union now inists that such an accord be linked to a resolution of the dispute over ''Star Wars.''

headline: Photo of Donald E. Nickelson; BUSINESS PEOPLE Paine Webber Inc. Appoints President
abstract: After successfully rethinking and rebuilding Paine Webber Inc.'s retail brokerage division over the last four years, Donald E. Nickelson is being asked to try his hand on the entire firm.   Donald B. Marron, Paine Webber's chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday that the 54-year-old Mr. Nickelson had been named president of the company, the securities brokerage subsidiary of Paine Webber Group Inc. Mr. Nickelson had been president of the firm's profitable Consumer Markets division.   The promotion of Mr. Nickelson, an avid sportsman who grew up in Kansas and spent years working as a stockbroker in the Southwest, has two aims. It is an effort to lighten Mr. Marron's day-to-day operating responsibilities at Paine Webber so that he can focus on the firm's broad strategy. The operations, administration, systems, finance, research and consumer markets departments will all report to Mr. Nickelson, who is known as ''Nick.''

headline: Dividend Canceled
abstract: Mcorp, the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, suspended payment of the quarterly dividend on common stock because of poor earnness in the Southwest.

headline: GILLETTE'S STOCK PRICE FALLS $7.25
abstract: The stock price of the Gillette Company fell more than $7 yesterday, reflecting the market's uncertainty that the Revlon Group and Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's chairman, could raise the capital for its $4.25 billion attempted takeover of Gillette.   The doubts stem from the investigations of Drexel Burnham Lambert that are part of the scandal surrounding Ivan F. Boesky. When Revlon announced its bid last week, it said Drexel would provide more than $3 billion of high-yield, high-risk bonds for the $65-a-share bid. 'Up in the Air'    Analysts said the Drexel investigation raised serious questions about the future of the Revlon plan. ''The stock price obviously questions whether Drexel can raise the money,'' said Diana K. Temple, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. ''The new question is: Is there someone else out there who can raise the money? It is a lot of money.''

headline: Kay Jewelers
abstract: Kay Jewelers Inc. said it was negotiating to acquire the J.B. Robinson retail jewelry store subsidiary of W.R. Grace & Company.

headline: G.N.P. GROWTH REVISED DOWN SLIGHTLY, TO 2.8%
abstract: The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the third quarter, the Government announced today, but inflation picked up as well.   The Commerce Department's report on the rise in the gross national product represented only a slight revision from the Government's estimate a month ago of a 2.9 percent growth rate in the quarter, but was sharply higher than the six-tenths of 1 percent rate in the spring.   Inflation, however, almost nonexistent in the spring, revived as well in the July-September period. A price measure tied to the G.N.P., which is the broadest indicator of the nation's economic health, rose at an annual rate of 3.8 percent during the summer, double the spring pace.

headline: MORTGAGE RATES FALL SHARPLY
abstract: Mortgage rates fell sharply in September, to the levels of last spring, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive decline and the first time since May that both fixed- and adjustable-rate mortgages declined.   The average rate on fixed-rate loans dropped to 10.5 percent, from 10.84 percent, between early September and early August, the bank board said in Washington. In May, the rate had fallen to 10.47 percent. It was 12.65 percent a year ago.

headline: Fermenta Plant
abstract: A Swedish biotechnology company, Fermenta A.B., said it had signed a letter of intent for the Monsanto Company to buy its Ohio-based agrochemical subsidiary, the Fermenta Plant Protection Company. In a statement, Fermenta said both companies had agreed in principle to the deal, but terms were not disclosed. Dealers said the sale was not likely to have a significant effect on talks between Fermenta's chief executive and major shareholder, Refaat el-Sayed, to obtain his controlling interest in Fermenta, and for Montedison S.p.a., the Italian company, to buy his controlling interest in Fermenta.

headline: State Mortgage Agency Altering Disbursement
abstract: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sony Mae, is offering $333 million of tax-exempt bonds to refund outstanding bonds and to finance low-cost home mortages.   Using a new disbursement program, Sony Mae plans to make the low-cost mortgage money available gradually rather than all at once. By doing so, the state agency hopes to avoid a problem of past years when its mortgage money sometimes went unclaimed because its interest rate became unattractive as the general level of interest rates declined.

headline: WESTFIELD SAID TO BUY MACY MALLS
abstract: The management group that took R. H. Macy & Company private has agreed to sell the bulk of the retailer's holdings in eight shopping centers to Westfield Holdings Ltd., an Australian real estate company, according to an industry source familiar with the deal.   Westfield will pay between $325 million and $350 million for the three shopping centers that Macy's owns: the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J.; South Shore Mall in Bay Shore, L.I., and Bay Fair in San Leandro, Calif. Macy's had been asking $327.5 million for the three malls.

headline: Bid for Ponderosa
abstract: Ponderosa Inc., which thwarted a takeover attempt earlier this year, said it was evaluating the New York investor Asher B. Edelman's disclosure that he had amassed an 18.5 percent stake in the restaurant chain and was considering acquiring the rest. Mr. Edelman has not specified a takeover price, but in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing made public today, he disclosed that he and seven investment groups in which he has an interest own 1.8 million of Ponderosa's 9.75 million shares outstanding. Ponderosa closed today at $24.875, down $1.625 a share.

headline: Market Place; Texas Banks' Grim Realities
abstract: INVESTORS willing to bet that enactment of a sweeping interstate banking bill in Texas would be rapidly followed by a wave of takeovers at rich prices may be in for a costly surprise.   Over the summer, that sort of speculative thinking helped lift the share prices at many of these institutions, even though the state's economic outlook remains bleak, and energy and real estate loan portfolios continue to lose value.   So far, the large out-of-state banks that might seek entry into the nation's third-largest banking market have contained their enthusiasm. The new law has been in place since late September, but major New York and California banks, which seem to be the most likely potential purchasers, have stayed on the sidelines. In the opinion of a growing number of analysts, their caution is well founded.

headline: SHULTZ CALLS USE OF PRESS TO SCARE LIBYAN JUSTIFIED
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Washington was free to take whatever actions might cause trouble for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi because the United States was ''pretty darn close'' to a state of war with Libya.   In a news conference, Mr. Shultz refused to comment on a report that the Reagan Administration had engaged in a campaign of deception against Colonel Qaddafi in August.   But he seemed to confirm the report by his answers, in which he praised the use of deception if it would cause problems for the Libyan leader.   Although Mr. Shultz did not explicitly confirm or deny the existence of a ''disinformation'' campaign, the tone of his remarks conflicted with statements by White House officials, who said the Government had not planted any false reports in American newspapers.

headline: PATENTS; Concrete Boats to Seal Polluted Water Areas
abstract: A method patented this week for the reclamation of lakes, marshes and other areas polluted by dangerous wastes includes the use of boats made of low-density concrete.

headline: GREEK SOCIALISTS LOSE HEAVILY IN MUNICIPAL VOTING
abstract: The ruling Socialist Party of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou suffered serious losses to the Communists in voting Sunday for municipal offices. As a result, the party runs a risk of losing its hold over the three biggest cities - Athens, Piraeus and Salonika - in runoff races next Sunday.

headline: Beverly Hills Hotel to Davis Group
abstract: A partnership led by Marvin Davis, as expected, said today that it would purchase the Beverly Hills Hotel from Ivan F. Boesky, his wife and her family. Sources said the price was about $135 million.

headline: It's Not What's Said, But Who Hears
abstract: FOR months, Senator Paula Hawkins, caught in a very tight race for re-election in Florida, has been filming campaign commercials on issues ranging from Social Security to drug abuse. While Robert Goodman, her media consultant, worried about what her positions should be, a few computer consultants, hunkered down over six I.B.M. personal computers in Virginia, were deciding when and onw hat progams they would be heard.   They are the time buyers at National Media Inc., a company formed in 1980 by several aides close to Ronald Reagan, including Charles Black, former political director for Mr. Reagan's Presidential campaign. A hybrid of politicians and advertising executives, they are the ones who figure out which television programs particular groups of people - say, working mothers - watch most.

headline: 4 More Bank Failures in U.S.
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation closed four banks today as bank failures this year rose to 120, a post-Depression high for the second year in a row, an F.D.I.C. spokesman said.

headline: UP TO 25 ARE KILLED AS IRAQI WARPLANES RAID IRAN
abstract: Iraqi warplanes struck deep into Iran for the second consecutive day today and reports in Teheran said as many as 25 people were killed in early morning raids.   In Baghdad, a military spokesman said Iraqi jets had hit an oil refinery and a power station in the central Iranian city of Isfahan and as well as an oil field. The Baghdad statement said dozens of planes had attacked military camps near the war fronts.

headline: PERES AND SHAMIR REACH AN ACCORD
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir today resolved all of the issues holding up their job-exchange, but members of Mr. Shamir's Likud bloc rejected part of the agreement and further negotiations were expected.   In a meeting today, Mr. Peres and Mr. Shamir worked out a three-point resolution of their differences.   First, Mr. Peres agreed to a Likud demand that the former Likud Minister of Justice and Finance, Yitzhak Modai, be allowed to rejoin the Government under Mr. Shamir as a Minister Without Portfolio. Mr. Modai was thrown out of the Cabinet last July for insulting Mr. Peres.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * American Express Co. has named Jerry Cole senior vice president, strategic planning.

headline: NICARAGUAN COURT CONVICTS AMERICAN OVER AID TO REBELS
abstract: Eugene Hasenfus, the American air-cargo specialist whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua Oct. 5, was convicted today and sentenced to 30 years in jail by a Nicaraguan tribunal.   Mr. Hasenfus, 45 years old, had admitted being part of a clandestine operation delivering weapons to anti-Government forces in Nicaragua. In the verdict today, a People's Tribunal said such weapons ''have been used to kill peasants and other Nicaraguan citizens.''   The tribunal ordered the 30-year term after declaring Mr. Hasenfus guilty of violating a public security law that bans ''actions aimed at subjecting the nation totally or partially to foreign domination, or infringing on its independence or integrity.''

headline: Soviet Health Official Quits
abstract: Health Minister Sergei P. Burenkov, who has held office since 1980, has retired on grounds of ill health, the Tass press agency reported today. No successor has been named.

headline: Marketing Corp. to Sell Couponing Operations
abstract: The Marketing Corporation of America is going to sell its couponing operations to George F. Valassis & Company of Farmington Hills, Mich., which is already in the business of producing free-standing Sunday newspaper inserts.

headline: Asbestos Case Settlements
abstract: The Raytech Corporation said its Raymark Industries unit had agreed to settle between 10,000 and 15,000 asbestos injury cases for about $2,821 a case, or about $42 million.   About 28,000 asbestos injury cases are pending against the company.

headline: C.F.T.C. TRADING RULE
abstract: The commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously today to prohibit employees of commodity exchanges and futures associaions from disclosing non-public information to the benefit of someone tradding futures, options or cash commodities on a C.F.T.C.-regulated exchange.

headline: Borden Buys Gioia For $72 Million
abstract: Borden Inc., which already sells pasta in 44 states and five regional markets, has purchased a 76-year-old Buffalo pasta maker from its British owner for $72 million, company officials said. The Gioia Pasta Company, founded in Fredonia, N.Y., in 1910, was sold to Borden by Ranks Hovis McDougall Ltd., officials said.

headline: AMERICANS TRAIN AFGHAN GUERRILLAS AS MEDICS
abstract: Three years ago, Gay-LeClerc Brenner, a lawyer, and her husband, Robert, a private fire investigator, quit their jobs in Sacramento, Calif., to find something to do, as she put it, ''for the good of other people.''  A solution presented itself, Mrs. Brenner said, when her husband accompanied some friends to a ''Soldier of Fortune'' convention in Las Vegas, Nev., where he heard a speech by an Afghan guerrilla commander, Hassan Gailani of the National Islamic Front. Mr. Brenner came back with an idea: the couple could provide medical assistance to parts of the world in need.  Now the Brenners, through a private medical relief group that they and six other people founded with $30,000 of their own money, operate a medical training program in Pakistan for Afghan guerrillas, as well as two clinics for Afghan refugees.

headline: BCI Will Sell Americold
abstract: The BCI Holdings Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Americold refrigeration business to a buyout group formed by Kelso & Company, a private investment banking firm, for $480 million.   Kelso said the buyout group includes Americold's senior managers and employees.

headline: WASHINGTON WATCH; Succession at the Fed
abstract: With Emmett J. Rice's resignation as a member of the Federal Reserve taking effect at month's end, the Reagan Administration is said to have sharply narrowed its list of possible successors.  It also appears to have decided that the slot need not go to one of the several black candidates initially mentioned for the job when Mr. Rice, the second black governor in the Fed's history, announced in early October that he would leave.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Celcor Inc., Englewood, N.J., a diversified telecommunications company, said its president, Charles Arslan, had resigned for personal reasons. Robert Edwards, chairman and chief executive, will add the title of president.

headline: CAMPEAU TO DIVEST SOME ALLIED ASSETS
abstract: Bonwit Teller, Garfinckel's and other less-profitable divisions of the Allied Stores Corporation may soon go on the block, according to analysts, if the Campeau Corporation, which yesterday won its long takeover battle for Allied, decides to move quickly to strengthen the giant retailer.   ''We will have to sell some of the less productive assets of Allied to reduce the debt load created by the merger,'' Robert Campeau, the chairman and chief executive of Campeau, said in a telephone interview yesterday from Toronto.   While Mr. Campeau declined to be specific, analysts such as Walter F. Loeb of Morgan Stanley & Company suggested that Bonwit, the New York-based retail fashion chain; Garfinckel's, the apparel retailer based in Washington, and some of Allied's weaker Middle Western divisions would be the first to go.

headline: PATENTS; Small Tumors Targets In Cancer Detection
abstract: David M. GOldenberg, founder and chairman of Immunomedics Inc., a biotechnology company in Newark, was granted a patent this week for a method of detecting cancer cells that could be important in cancer diagnosis and therapy.

headline: Argentina Offers End To Falkland Hostilities
abstract: Argentina said today that it would formally end hostilities with Britain if Britain drops a 150-mile ''protection zone'' around the Falkland Islands, where the two nations fought a 74-day war in 1982.   All Argentine planes and ships are barred from that zone in the South Atlantic, which Britain declared at the end of the war.

headline: Soviet Delegation in a Visit to Iran
abstract: The Soviet Union and Iran today held their first high-level economic talks since the 1979 Islamic revolution.   An Iranian leader said improving relations with Moscow is one of Iran's top foreign policy priorities.   Teheran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored here, quoted Mines and Metals Minister Mohammedreza Ayatollahi as saying his country wants to expand ties with its neighbors, including the Soviet Union. Criticism by Rafsanjani    But the agency quoted Iran's powerful Parliament Speaker, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, as criticizing Moscow for supplying weapons to Iraq, Iran's enemy in the Persian Gulf war, and for occupying neighboring Afghanistan.

headline: Chairman Of Blair Named
abstract: Henry R. Silverman, a senior vice president of Reliance Group Holdings Inc. and chief executive of its Reliance Capital Group unit, was named chairman yesterday of John Blair & Company, which Reliance acquired in August after a long takeover battle.   At the same time, Blair's five outside directors resigned as part of the transition to new ownership.

headline: MITSUI UNIT GETS EXXON BUILDING
abstract: The 54-story Exxon Building, part of Rockefeller Center, has been sold to a subsidiary of the giant Japanese conglomerate Mitsui & Company for $610 million, the owners of the 13-year-old skyscraper announced yesterday.   The price was at least $100 million lower than the Exxon Corporation had anticipated when it put the building up for sale in October. According to industry analysts, the deal still sets a record for the total amount paid for a single building in New York. It is also the first time a single building that was part of Rockefeller Center has been sold.

headline: Reynolds Metals' Profit
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company yesterday reported a third-quarter profit of $25.5 million, or $1.02 a share, in contrast to a loss of $303.8 million a year earlier, which included a $322 million after-tax charge for the write-down of certain assets, mainly in the company's raw materials and primary aluminum operations.   Reynolds, the nation's No. 2 aluminum producer after the Aluminum Company of America, said sales in the latest quarter rose 4 percent, to $910.8 million, from $875.8 million.

headline: 48 ARE REPORTED KILLED AND 52 WOUNDED AS IRANIAN MISSILE HITS THE CAPITAL OF IRAQ
abstract: An Iranian missile devastated an entire block of a Baghdad residential district before dawn today, killing 48 people and wounding 52, the official Iraqi radio reported.   Iraqi warplanes bombed seven Iranian targets in retaliation, an Iraqi military communique said.   The reported casualties were the highest toll in six Iranian missile attacks on the Iraqi capital this year. Three of the attacks have occurred in the last two weeks.

headline: Dow Loses 7.45 Points; Volume Falls
abstract: Stock prices dropped yesterday in concert with a weaker bond market, and a wave of profit taking. The market was also hurt by the psychological impact of another decline in the International Business Machines Corporation's price, which fell 1 3/4 points, to 121 3/8.   The Dow Jones industrial average was down nearly 21 points at one time early in the day, but ended the day off only 7.45 points, to 1,891.59. Volume dropped to 165.3 million shares, from 183.2 million shares on Wednesday.

headline: Chips and Antitrust Curbs
abstract: The Justice Department is expected to have a say about the semiconductor industry's plans for cooperative development of advanced chip technology. The industry's initiative, which follows protection won from the Reagan Adminstration against predatory Japanese pricing, still has to be fleshed out.

headline: NEW TAX CODE'S PRINCIPAL ELEMENTS
abstract: Here are the main elements of the tax bill President Reagan signed into law today:  Revenues: The new law is projected to generate the same total revenue over the next five years as the old tax system, although in some years it will raise slightly more and in some years slightly less. Over a five-year period, corporate taxes will be increased by $120 billion, and taxes on individuals will be reduced by that amount.  Tax liability: About 6 million poor people will be removed from the tax rolls altogether. When fully effective, about 15 percent of taxpayers will have a tax increase, and the rest will pay approximately what they would have paid under the old system or less.

headline: RUSSIAN, IN BONN, DENIES ARMS LINK
abstract: A Soviet arms negotiator said here today that medium-range nuclear missiles could be removed from Europe without linkage to the United States' missile defense program.   The negotiator, Viktor P. Karpov, referred at a news conference to the agreement in the Iceland talks that all Soviet and American mdium-range missiles could be withdrawan from Europe and that these missiles elsewhere be limited to 100 warheads on Soviet missiles in Asia and to 100 on American missiles in the United States.   The Soviet position had been that a medium-range accord could be concluded without reference to the dispute over the United States' missile defense program, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative and popularly as ''Star Wars.'' But in Iceland, the Americans got the impression that all arms issues were now interrelated.

headline: Article 814686 -- No Title
abstract: OPEC should aim for a crude oil price of $28 a barrel, Algeria's energy minister said in a newspaper interview here today.   Belkacem Nabi was quoted in the latest edition of the official weekly Revolution Africaine as saying that the $18 target price of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was ''barely acceptable.''

headline: ECONOMIC BILLS CALLED LIKELY IN DEMOCRATIC SENATE
abstract: The new Democratic-controlled Senate is likely to propose major legislation affecting banking, corporate mergers, welfare, research and wages soon after the 100th Congress begins work, the probable chairmen of the Senate's economic policy committees and staff members said today.   Senate leaders said bipartisan legislation governing the nation's foreign trade was their highest priority, but they said they expected to bring up many other issues quickly. Democrats won control of the Senate, 55 to 45, in Tuesday's elections.   Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, a former chairman of the Banking Committee and now the probable successor to Jake Garn of Utah, said he favored legislation preventing giant mergers - among banks and corporations alike - and thwarting the rush of non-banking institutions into the business of banking.

headline: PACESETTER OF OPEC: SHEIK AHMED ZAKI YAMANI
abstract: He was dismissed the way he had ministered: by royal decree.   It was short and gave no reason for the decision. But after King Fahd of Saudi Arabia relieved his oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, of his duties Wednesday, an era of turbulent oil politics led by one of the shrewdest, most colorful and most durable arbiters of Arab power, had ended.   Graceful, eloquent and energetic, Sheik Yamani had, since 1962, been oil minister of a nation with roughly one-third of the non-communist world's oil reserves. Widely known through frequent television appearances and visits to Western countries, he came to embody Arab oil power, emerging since his appointment in 1964 as the chief executor, if not always the principal architect, of Saudi oil policies.

headline: REAGAN SECURITY ADVISER AND AIDE ARE OUT
abstract: President Reagan said today that he had not been in full control of his Administration's Iran policy, and the White House said that as a consequence up to $30 million intended to pay for American arms had been secretly diverted to rebel forces in Nicaragua.   At the same time, the President announced that two men he held responsible - Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the national security adviser, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a member of the admiral's staff - had left their posts.   With the Administration already in turmoil over the earlier disclosure of clandestine arms shipments to Iran, and with speculation rampant about a major overhaul of the White House staff, the President's statement seemed to deepen a sense of disarray. By all accounts, Mr. Reagan now faces the most serious crisis in his six-year Presidency.

headline: Manville Settles
abstract: The Manville Corporation said it had settled its insurance disputes with the Columbia Casualty Company and the Continental Casualty Company, both units of the CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago. The two carriers, the last remaining defendants in insurance litigation pending in San Francisco, had agreed to pay a total of $38.5 million, Manville said. It also said that the confirmation hearing in New York on its plan for reorganization had been delayed until noon Tuesday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

headline: A HECTIC YEAR-END PACE IN REAL ESTATE INDUSTRY
abstract: Thousands of real estate lawyers, sales agents and accountants are working around the clock to close deals before the big apple descends in Times Square, ringing in the new year and tolling goodbye to the advantageous income tax provisions that have helped make real estate a favored investment for many.   James L. Mooney, managing director of Landauer Associates Inc., a real estate consulting company, has been drawing up the last documents on 10 deals of $25 million or more.   ''I knew I was falling behind when the Christmas cards began arriving from our Japanese clients,'' Mr. Mooney said. ''It's not even a holiday for them, but they managed to get the cards out on time. Mine will be dated Jan. 2.''

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 12.7%, TO A RECORD
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was up 49.1 million shares, or 12.7 percent, in the month ended Oct. 15, to a record 436.3 million shares. The previous high of 387.1 million shares was set Sept. 15. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 222 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was up 353,274 shares, to 28.6 million shares.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Carling O'Keefe Ltd., Toronto, makers of alcoholic beverages, said S. Roderick McInnes had resigned as chairman, president and chief executive.    * Magma Copper Co. has elected Vincent R. McLean as chairman.

headline: AQUINO ADDS BIT OF SWAGGER TO HER STYLE
abstract: A week after she dismissed Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, President Corazon C. Aquino has acquired enough new confidence to step out of her old image as reticent housewife and chide her male challengers.   In a light-hearted address with an underlying toughness before a women's group tonight, Mrs. Aquino referred to her victories over both Ferdinand E. Marcos, whom she ousted as President in February, and her more recent opponents.   ''It has often been said that Marcos was the first male chauvinist to underestimate me,'' she said. ''He was not the last to pay for that mistake.''

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: ''If the spread of the virus is not checked, the present epidemic could become a catastrophe.

headline: TEXT OF SOVIET PROPOSAL ON HOW TO PRECEED
abstract: Following is the text of a Soviet proposal on how to proceed in the arms negotiations. The Soviet text was presented at a meeting of senior Soviet and American officials here. The United States proposed an alternative text, and no agreement was reached.

headline: PX'S BATTLE THE DISCOUNTERS
abstract: The cavernous department store off J.E.B. Stuart Road in the middle of Fort Bliss here has regulation-issue Christmas music and decorations. It has Lazer Tag and Snuggle Bears, Bruce Springsteen and Lionel Richie, Liz Claiborne and Gucci Pour Homme.   It also has a preponderance of shoppers in military fatigues, no sales tax, requires identifications for admittance and plows all its profits into things like day-care centers and swimming pools on military bases.   Known simply as the Fort Bliss Exchange, the store is part of the nation's 10th-largest retailer, but it is a store that most shoppers can never enter. It is one of 258 such big stores that are part of the military PX, or post exchange, system (officially known as the Army and Air Force Exchange System). That system does $4.9 billion of busineess annually, serving armed forces personnel around the world.

headline: Nynex-British Tie
abstract: The Nynex Corporation has agreed to buy a British company that offers computer software, professional and other business services for stock valued at $:75 million, or about $107 million. The company, Business International Services Ltd., has been privately owned.

headline: U.S. IS WEIGHING PLAN TO SELL LOANS
abstract: President Reagan is likely to propose that the Government sell loans it makes to private investors within days of granting them, James C. Miller 3d, the President's budget director said today.   Mr. Miller joined a number of Reagan Administration critics of big business. He said that rather than turn to ''Uncle Sugar'' for help in the face of foreign competition, companies should examine their own management.   The Administration has often espoused selling many existing loans -and it has made modest progress. But selling new loans is a novel proposal from the White House.

headline: MAJOR REFINANCING PLANNED FOR CARBIDE
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, culminating a year of restructuring, outlined a sweeping recapitalization plan yesterday to slash debt, strengthen its financial profile and increase its freedom to buy and sell assets.   The Carbide plan centers on three points. First, the company this week will offer to acquire at a premium $2.5 billion principal in high-yield debt securities. The securities were issued to help buy 38.8 million common shares in Carbide's successful takeover defense against the GAF Corporation last January.   Second, to finance most of that purchase, Carbide said it would arrange medium-term bank borrowings at about 10 percent, lower than the average 14.2 percent yield the notes pay.

headline: Grumman Unit
abstract: The Grumman Corporation plans to move a unit that works on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space station and other projects to Houston. The company's initial transfer from its Bethpage, L.I., headquarters will involve about 100 employees, principally engineers and technicians, according to Gerry Griffin, president of the Houston Chamber of Commerce and former director of the Johnson Space Center. If Grumman's plans for new business development succeed, the company estimates its Civil Space Programs Unit 1 in Houston will expand tenfold.

headline: Making The Phone Info Into a P.O. Box
abstract: DEBBIE FIELDS, the Mrs. Fields of cookie fame, talks to the managers of each of her 350 cookie shops at least twice a week. But their phones never ring. And she dictates only one message each time.

headline: 9 Are Executed in Indonesia
abstract: Indonesia executed nine men convicted of helping to lead an attempted coup in 1965, a military spokesman said today.

headline: BRAZIL IS SHOPPING FOR COFFEE
abstract: Brazil, the patriarch of coffee and long a mainstay of the world's drinkers of the brew, startled markets at home and abroad with the announcement last month that it would import up to 1.5 million bags of coffee this year.   Brazil said a severe drought has caused greater damage than expected in the coffee fields, ruining more than half of the country's crop.   Government officials said that Brazil would buy inferior quality coffee from Africa and perhaps Indonesia for domestic use and would send abroad as much as possible of its own premium-grade product. The plan is intended to maintain Brazil's 30 percent share of the world market.

headline: SOMNOLENT, GROUCHY WALL ST. DOES A GOOD MINUTE'S WORK
abstract: The head trader at one Wall Street brokerage firm had a bone to pick with John Phelan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.   ''I called John Phelan to indicate that nothing was going on, and it was foolish to have the market open,'' the trader said. ''And he wasn't in.''   Mr. Phelan was on vacation. But he was not the only one on Wall Street who had the day off. Trading was numbingly slow, the slowest in exactly two years. Stock prices, because they had to do something, drifted higher.

headline: Big-Time Blues At Big Blue
abstract: I.B.M.'s earnings dropped 26.5 percent in the third quarter, to $1.08 billion, on a tiny increase in revenues. The big computer manufacturer, which had been sending signals of gloom for months, blamed the drop on slumping sales abroad and at home. The company's stock price, already depressed in anticipation of the earnings report, hit a low of $119.75 after the earnings report. Although the chairman, John F. Akers, tried to play down the dismal performance, most analysts said they do not expect Big Blue to recover before the end of the year, especially because after-tax margins are dropped.   Retail sales jumped 4.6 percent in September, their best showing since the Government started tracking them 20 years ago. But since the biggest boost came from auto sales, many analysts warned that the figures were misleading. . . . But housing starts plunged 7.6 percent, dropping to an annual rate of 1.68 million units, its lowest rate in a year. . . . Industrial production inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in September, but industry was operating at just 79.2 percent of capacity, unchanged from August. . . . Business sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent, but inventories held steady.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1986
abstract: Markets    Stock prices soared to record levels as the market staged its third-largest rally in history. Investors were relieved that President Reagan had acted to support a full inquiry into the Iranian arms sale controversy. In a session that began with a burst of computerized program buying, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 43.03 points, to 1,955.57, topping the previous record of 1,919.71 set Sept. 4. The New York Stock Exchange had its fourth-heaviest day ever, with 230.4 million shares traded. The market was also buoyed by the report of a larger-than-expected gain in the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators.  [ Page A1. ]    Prices of Treasury issues advanced sharply as bond buyers returned to the market in force in the belief that President Reagan would weather the Iranian arms sale crisis.  [ D17. ]

headline: Joy Manufacturing Rejects Pullman Bid
abstract: The Joy Manufacturing Company, a coal mining and petroleum equipment manufacturer based in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that its board had rejected an unsolicited $31-a-share, $527 million offer made last week by the Pullman-Peabody Company, a maker of train and truck equipment.   The board also instructed management to explore options to enhance shareholder value, including a leveraged buyout with or without the current management, the sale of the company or the acceleration of a previously announced restructuring program.

headline: FOR RUMANIA, A VOTE TODAY ON MILITARY CUTS
abstract: Rumanians from age 14 up will vote Sunday in a national referendum on Nicolae Ceausescu's decision to reduce military spending by 5 percent.   At a carefully staged mass rally here Friday evening, Mr. Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, announced that immediately after the referendum, Rumania would reduce its armed forces by 10,000 men and their weapons by 250 tanks and armored vehicles, 130 cannon and grenade launchers and 26 combat planes and helicopters. Military spending in the 1987 budget will be curtailed by $130 million, Mr. Ceausescu pledged. Such an amount would actually represent far more than 5 percent of the announced military budget for this year of $12 billion. Western analysts were unable to clarify the apparent inconsistency in the figures.

headline: Group Sues Schwab, Fed
abstract: The Securities Industry Association filed a suit today in Washington challenging the participation of Charles Schwab & Company in the offering of a new mutual fund.   The suit filed in Federal District Court names as defendants the Federal Reserve and Schwab, the discount brokerage unit of the BankAmerica Corporation.

headline: MERRILL PLANS REAL ESTATE PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Dissatisfied with the bids it had received since deciding to sell its real estate operations, Merrill Lynch & Company adopted a new tack yesterday. It said it would convert those operations into a master limited partnership, retaining control but selling units to the public.   When it put them up for sale in September, Merrill valued the operations at about $500 million. It said yesterday that it could not speculate about details of the offering, including the percentage that would be marketed. It said the offering would be by prospectus, probably early next spring.

headline: U.S. IS SEEN RETALIATING ON EUROPE FARM TRADE
abstract: The Reagan Administration is expected to announce Tuesday retaliatory measures against some European farm exports, White House officials said tonight.   The action would be part of a trade dispute that the United States contends is costing American farmers $400 million to $500 million a year.   Decisions dealing with this and another trade dispute, involving Brazilian computer imports, will be announced by Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States Trade Representative, the officials said.

headline: WIESEL ENDS HIS SOVIET VISIT WITH PLEA FOR RELEASE OF JEWS
abstract: Elie Wiesel, winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, concluded a five-day visit to the Soviet Union today with an appeal to the Soviet authorities to release Jews seeking to emigrate.   ''I say without any anger, without any animosity, with deep compassion, that it would be to the honor of the new style of leadership to allow these men, women and children to be happy again,'' Mr. Wiesel said at a news conference shortly before his departure.   The Nobel laureate, a survivor of the Auschwitz and Buchenwald death camps who has dedicated most of his life to perpetuating the memory of the Holocaust, spent much of his time in Moscow meeting with Jews, both at private homes and at an emotional celebration of the feast of Simhath Torah on Saturday night at the main Moscow synagogue.

headline: U.S. SAYS ALL MAJOR SOVIET SPIES WILL BE GONE
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the 55 Soviet diplomats ordered to leave by Nov. 1 included all the senior spies in the United States.   The officials said the two Soviet espionage agencies - the K.G.B., the main intelligency agency, and the G.R.U., military intelligence - had suffered a severe blow. The officials said it takes years to train English-speaking agents and the Soviet Union would have to use less experienced agents.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1986
abstract: International    The U.S. set a 15 percent tariff on $3 billion of Canadian lumber to protect domestic producers from import competition that the Administration said is government-subsidized. The tariff, representing a major escalation of protectionism, reverses the Administration's decision of three years ago. A trade group said the preliminary decision by the Commerce Department would mean an immediate rise of $1,000 in the cost of new houses.  [ Page D1. ]    James M. Buchanan won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his pioneering development of new methods for analyzing economic and political decision-making, particularly the forces determining government spending. Mr. Buchanan, 67, is a professor at George Mason University.  [ D1. ]

headline: U.S., IN A REVIEW, FOUND OUTLOOK POOR FOR CONTRAS
abstract: Even before the Iran arms affair jeopardized the Nicaraguan contras' chances of success, Administration officials were apparently re-evaluating the rebels' prospects.   Early last month a group of senior American officials visited Central America and asked United States ambassadors, intelligence analysts and military commanders why the contras were not as effective as the leftist rebels in El Salvador. Although weakened, the rebels fight effectively against the Salvadoran Army.   ''We wondered why the Salvadoran guerrillas don't need $100 million to keep fighting,'' an American official informed of the discussions said. Some Painful Answers    The answers were painful, according to two American officials, raising deep questions about the origins and direction of American policy toward Nicaragua and about the nature of the contra movement itself.

headline: 2 Partners Oppose Genentech Buyout
abstract: Two limited partners have opposed Genentech Inc.'s proposed buyout of two of its research and development partnerships.

headline: Lear Siegler Bid Ended by Wickes
abstract: The Wickes Companies, as anticipated, said tonight that it had terminated its agreement to acquire Lear Siegler Inc. for $1.7 billion. Wickes, which said Nov. 18 that it had encountered difficulty in securing bank financing for the deal, said that both companies had agreed to scrap the acquisition without liability to either company.

headline: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: ANGLICAN MAVERICK TENDS TO OKLAHOMA FLOCK
abstract: The Bishop of London, a maverick prelate wary of the ecclesiastical ''club,'' is unrepentant after roiling the clergy of two churches with a visit far beyond his vineyard to Episcopal America, where he comforted an outcast priest in Broken Arrow, Okla.   ''It has been a most moving experience,'' said the Bishop, Dr. Graham Leonard, a ranking prelate and a theological conservative who feels that the deposed priest, John Pasco, was disciplined by United States churchmen because he, like the Bishop, is opposed to the ordination of women. Episcopal officials deny this is the reason.   The Bishop's action this month in venturing so far afield to officiate at confirmation services with Father Pasco in a small parish outside Tulsa has aroused rancor on an intercontinental scale.

headline: Terror Suspects in Israel
abstract: Israeli security forces uncovered a terrorist cell whose members are suspected in the stabbing deaths of two Israeli civilians in the Gaza Strip in September and October, the Israeli radio said today.

headline: The U.N. Today: Nov. 10, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: HANSON MAY JOIN A BID FOR GOODYEAR
abstract: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate with a war chest of more than $5 billion in cash, is said to be considering joining an effort with Sir James Goldsmith to take over the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Wall Street sources said yesterday.   They said the decision to combine forces had not yet been made, but could come within several days.   It was reported earlier this week that Sir James, who won a long battle for control of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, the paper company, had been accumulating stock in Goodyear and might already be the company's largest stockholder.

headline: Litvack Plans to Resign From Donovan Leisure
abstract: Sanford M. Litvack, the managing partner at the law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, has told his partners that he is planning to resign.   ''I suppose I just reached the point where the burden was too great,'' said Mr. Litvack, 50, a former head of the antitrust division of the United States Justice Department under President Carter. ''And I thought I should tell my partners before I began looking for a new job. I don't know where I'm going yet, but I will be practicing law, antitrust law if I can find it.''

headline: Coast Utility's Yield Is 8.80%
abstract: The Southern California Edison Company is offering $125 million of 8 3/8 percent first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at 95 1/2 to yield 8.80 percent.

headline: DEBATE ON TRADE DEFICIT: HAS IT REALLY IMPROVED?
abstract: After many months of frustration in which the huge United States trade deficit continued to mount in the face of a falling dollar, recent figures seem to indicate to many that the long-awaited reversal has begun.   A sizable number of skeptics, however, remain. Among other things, they cite renewed growth in imports, a worsening of the trade balance with Japan, revisions of previously reported data and the general ''flakiness'' of month-to-month figures that, to mention just one interpretative hazard, are no longer adjusted for seasonal variations as of this past January.   Then there are those who believe that a reversal has begun, but that the improvement may not be very rapid.

headline: Fighting on Green Line Traps Beirut Lawmakers
abstract: Moslem and Christian soldiers battled across Beirut's Green Line for three hours today, trapping several legislators in the Parliament building.

headline: THE LAST INNING FOR CAPITAL GAINS PLAYS
abstract: NOW that the tax overhaul bill has finally cleared Congress, it is time to scrutinize your investment portfolio to make maximum use of the liberal capital gains provisions that will remain in effect only until the end of this year.   But before issuing indiscriminate sell orders, remember that your goal should be to strike a deal that makes investment sense as well as tax sense. ''The idea is not necessarily to pay the lowest tax,'' advises Leon M. Nad, national tax partner with Price Waterhouse. ''What you're trying to get is the most gain after taxes.''   With that in mind, consider the implications of the new law. Starting Jan. 1, the top Federal tax rate on long-term capital gains (that is, assets you have held for at least six months and a day) will rise to 28 percent from the current 20 percent. But the tax increase will be sharper for people in lower brackets, who now can pay an effective capital gains rate of as little as 4.4 percent. And by 1988, when many of the provisions of the new bill will be fully phased in, top-bracket investors will be paying a tax of 33 percent on their capital gains.

headline: Transamerica Unit Will Be Spun Off
abstract: Continuing its divestiture of subsidiaries that are not part of its core business, the Transamerica Corporation said it had approved the spinoff of its manufacturing unit, Transamerica Delaval Inc., to shareholders effective Dec. 18. The manufacturing subsidiary will become a publicly traded company, which will be renamed Imo Delaval Inc.

headline: IC Industries Deal For Ogden Food
abstract: In another move designed to strengthen its position in branded foods, IC Industries, the industrial and consumer products company, said that it plans to acquire the Ogden Food Corporation for $320 million.

headline: BOMBS IN SOUTH AFRICA WOUND 20
abstract: At least 20 people, mostly blacks, were reported wounded today when two bombs exploded in a small town in Natal Province.   In Port Elizabeth, meanwhile, striking workers at the American-owned General Motors plant voted to continue a two-week-old work stoppage, but the company said it would break the strike by using nonunion labor.   The bombs exploded in the coal-mining town of Newcastle, the newest in a series of urban guerrilla attacks since South Africa imposed an emergency decree June 12.

headline: Pennzoil to Lay Off 330 More Workers
abstract: The Pennzoil Company, a diversified energy concern with headquarters in Houston, said that it would permanently lay off about 330 employees in its oil and gas division by early December. The company, which employs about 1,750 in the unit, said that 130 of the workers would be eligible for an early retirement program.

headline: DISCOUNTER PURCHASES B. DALTON
abstract: Barnes & Noble, the nation's leading book discounter and its third-biggest bookseller, has purchased B. Dalton, the nation's second-largest chain of bookstores, which has been faltering lately because of competition from discounters.   Neither the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the parent of B. Dalton, nor Leonard Riggio, owner of Barnes & Noble, would disclose the sale price for the 779-store chain. Analysts, however, estimated the price at between $275 million and $300 million.   Mr. Riggio, whose 35 Barnes & Noble stores are situated mostly in the New York City area, said that he would continue to operate the two chains independently, under their current names. Barnes & Noble's flagship store is at 6 East 18th Street, on Fifth Avenue. Its well-known Sale Annex is across the street.

headline: TALKING DEALS
abstract: THIS may have been one of the largest years for corporate takeovers on record, but it was also the year of the broken deal. Time and again when a company seemed like a goner, it either bought off a corporate raider with the equivalent of greenmail or decided at the last minute that there was a better alternative to getting hitched.   As these stocks plummet, shareholders usually wonder if their management did the right thing and question if they will ever see such lofty heights again. The Beneficial Corporation's rejection of a $1.74 billion takeover by the Transamerica Corporation last week was an especially bitter pill for some of its shareholders because the stock at one point had run up more than 25 points from the mid-40's level on the anticipation of a done deal. Yesterday the stock closed at $54.25, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Shoprite Sale by Big V
abstract: Big V Supermarkets Inc., which owns and operates Shoprite supermarkets, said today that it had sold its Shoprite store and shopping center in Vestal, N.Y., to FGR Realty. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed but the company said the sale would produce a substantial gain in fourth-quarter results. Big V said the sale left it with 32 Shoprite markets and 10 shopping centers in New York State.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1986
abstract: The World    Greater French-Syrian cooperation was evident in what officials in Paris said were efforts aimed at winning aid from Damascus in halting bombings in Paris and in getting French hostages freed.    Page A1    Man in News: Ahmed Zaki Yamani, who has been relieved by King Fahd of his duties as Saudi Arabia's oil minister after serving for 24 years, is one of the shrewdest and most colorful arbiters of Arab power.    D24    A pact on medium-range missiles is possible and the Kremlin will be pressed to separate that issue from its opposition to ''Star Wars,'' the White House said.    A10    The Kremlin expressed optimism about the chances for accords on arms controls, according to Peter Ustinov, a participant at a meeting between a group of foreigners and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: WHITE HOUSE BARS REVEALING DETAILS ON IRAN DEALINGS
abstract: President Reagan, while asserting that no laws had been broken in efforts to free American hostages in Lebanon, today rejected demands that he disclose details of Administration dealings with Iran.   Trying to counter suggestions of a sharp split in the Administration, the White House said the actions toward Iran had the support of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.   It has been reported in the last week that the United States tried to facilitate the shipment of military spare parts to Iran in return for assistance in gaining the release of the American captives.   A White House statement today emphasized that ''no U.S. law has been or will be violated'' and that ''our policy of not making concessions to terrorists remains intact.''

headline: 2 Texas Banks Sign Fed Pact
abstract: The two bank holding companies that have reported the biggest operating losses in Texas this year, the First City Bancorporation and the Interfirst Corporation, said they signed agreements with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas last month to maintain certain lending, reserve and capital standards in their operations.   Spokesmen for both companies said in interviews today that the agreements did not require them to increase loss reserves, tighten lending standards or change any current practices.

headline: LONDON EXCHANGE MAY BAR BOESKY
abstract: The London Stock Exchange is considering blacklisting Ivan F. Boesky by publicly declaring him ''not a fit and proper person,'' a senior exchange official said today. The step, if taken, would caution member firms against dealing with the Wall Street financier who agreed to pay a $100 million penalty for insider trading abuses.   Meanwhile, Mr. Boesky resigned today as chairman and director of Cambrian and General Securities P.L.C., the British investment firm.   The blacklisting proposal, which will be decided in the next few days, would make it extremely difficult for Mr. Boesky to ever again invest in the London markets, even as an individual. That would be a tighter prohibition than his settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which bans him from the securities business for life but allows him to remain a personal investor.

headline: WOMETCO CABLE SALE ACCORD SET
abstract: Wometco Cable TV Inc. signed a definitive agreement yesterday to sell its cable operations for $625 million in cash to a group that includes the Taft Broadcasting Company, the Robert Bass Group and executives of Wometco's cable operation.   Wometco Cable is currently owned by a group of investors organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm that took the company private three years ago.   With 348,000 subscribers, the Wometco operations are viewed by some analysts as particularly attractive because there are systems in the suburbs of such Southern cities as Atlanta, Columbia, S.C., Charleston, S.C. and Raleigh, N.C.   Paul Kagan, a media analyst, estimated that Wometco's 1987 cash flow would be about $60 million. Noting that the Taft group was paying about 10 times that amount, he said the purchase price was very good for the buyer. 1987 Subscriber Estimate Estimating that the company would have about 360,000 subscribers next year, Mr. Kagan said that the purchase price was about $1,730 per subscriber.

headline: Walesa Joins 5,000 to Mark Anniversary of Priest's Killing
abstract: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, joined 5,000 worshipers at a mass today marking the second anniversary of the death of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, who was tortured and beaten to death by the secret police.   The priest's death ''must and will bring the fruit of national reconciliation,'' the Rev. Henryk Jankowski told the congregation in St. Brygida's church here.

headline: How Prices Do on Days That Adjoin a Holiday
abstract: WILL the Dow Jones industrial average move into record territory today? If the history of trading on the day after Thanksgiving is any guide, there is a good possibility. Thanks to a late spurt on Wednesday, the Dow advanced five points, to 1,916.76, less than three points short of its high-water mark of 1,919.71 set on Sept. 4.   Although stock prices do not always go up the day after Thanksgiving, they almost always do. In fact, they almost always go up on the day before Thanksgiving and also on the day before and the day after many of the eight other stock market holidays.

headline: Cornell Financing
abstract: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $149.7 million of refunding bonds on behalf of Cornell University, through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

headline: UNION BANK IN GLOBAL THRUST
abstract: From its beginning in 1912 following the merger of two farm country banks, the Union Bank of Switzerland has prided itself on the conservative nature of its banking style. The disciplined ways of its top executives relate in part to their reserve corps status as senior Swiss Army officers and to their stewardship of billions of dollars of their countrymen's investment funds.   But now Switzerland's largest bank has been been racing to catch up in the international financial arena with a zest that strikes many of its competitors as anything but conservative.   Union Bank, with $87 billion in assets and 300 branches spread throughout the country, has been beefing up its commercial and merchant bank activities around the globe, expanding branches in New York and setting up new operations such places as Tokyo and Australia. It has also been taking a pushy approach to securities trading, using aggressive pricing to elbow its way into the exclusive club that lead-manages big Euromarket bond issues, and becoming this summer the first foreign bank to manage a corporate bond issue in the United States.

headline: 70 MORE DIE AS RIOTING CONTINUES IN PAKISTAN
abstract: Seventy more people were reported killed today as rioting among the city's ethnic groups and clashes with the police and army spread to new sections of Karachi, and army troops used tear gas and gunfire to enforce a curfew.   The new violence brought the death toll to 125 since Sunday in what authorities described as the worst ethnic strife in Pakistan's largest city since independence in 1947.   Hundreds of people were also reported injured in the violence today, and as on Sunday, witnesses gave gruesome reports about people being hacked to death, burned alive or thrown into burning buildings.   The rioting broke out Sunday morning as Pashto-speaking Pathans sought revenge for what they charged was Government harassment. The Pathans were angered by a house-to-house search in their neighborhoods that began last Friday for illegal drugs and arms.

headline: WICKES OPTION FOR 10% OF LEAR
abstract: The Wickes Companies said yesterday that it held an option to buy nearly 10 percent of Lear Siegler Inc., the big West Coast aerospace and automotive producer, as part of what it called a friendly proposal to acquire the company for at least $91 a share, or $1.7 billion, in cash.   Only 48 hours earlier Wickes announced an agreement to buy the Collins & Aikman Corporation, a producer of textiles and wall coverings, for $53 a share, or $1.2 billion, in cash.
