Thus Wickes, the huge building materials, apparel and auto parts company, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in January 1985, is gearing up to spend nearly $3 billion.   Sanford C. Sigoloff, the 56-year-old chairman of Wickes, said that talks with Lear Siegler were under way and that he had asked for an answer by 6 o'clock tonight. Lear Siegler's directors considered the proposal late yesterday, but no announcement was immediately issued.

headline: Emhart Plans Sale
abstract: The Emhart Corporation said that as part of the $150 million restructuring progam it announced Sept. 25, it had selected 16 units for sale and would eliminate 1,100 jobs.

headline: A TRANSFER TO SHAMIR IS PREPARED
abstract: President Chaim Herzog of Israel formally asked Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir to form a new government today.   The move came after Mr. Shamir and Prime Minister Shimon Peres appeared to have resolved the differences that delayed their job switch.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S CORPORATE ACTIVISTS
abstract: FOR American companies operating in South Africa, social responsibility has become a bread-and-butter board room issue. They are under constant scrutiny not only from people on both sides of the apartheid issue here, but from anti-apartheid, pro-disinvestment groups in Europe and the United States. And they have taken on social responsibility projects as both a means of addressing what they see as a need for change and a ticket that allows them to fend off political pressure at home.

headline: TEHERAN'S LEADERS, DELIGHTING IN WASHINGTON'S DISARRAY, PULL TOGETHER AND POINT TO A MAJOR VICTORY
abstract: Iran's leaders are treating the growing foreign policy uproar here as a major diplomatic and propaganda victory, according to American officials, Arab diplomats, and experts on Iran.   One of the Arab diplomats, Ambassador Nizar Hamdoon of Iraq, said:   ''On the American side, there was a misunderstanding of signals sent from Iran, while Khomeini and others consider this the biggest victory in the history of their Islamic revolution.''   Instead of dividing the revolutionary regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the furor over secret American arms sales to Iran - and diversions of cash to the Nicaraguan rebels - has provided the Iranian leaders with a new issue to unite their nation against the United States.   Iranian officials have been mocking the United States as a country willing to apologize for past sins and desperate to re-establish contacts. Public Questioning Suppressed The only public questioning in Iran of the wisdom of dealing with the United States, popularly portrayed as the world's greatest Satan, has come from eight members of Parliament, prompted by a group calling itself the Students Following the Line of the Imam, which seized the American Embassy in 1979. Imam is a title given to Ayatollah Khomeini.

headline: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: TRIAL STARTS IN PARIS FOR THE 'KING OF FENCES'
abstract: Maurice Joffo had it all - apartments in Paris, Cannes and Geneva, a country home, real estate in France and Brazil, and a certain notoriety in the slightly seedy world of nightclub habitues and people of suspicious wealth.   He also had, according to the Paris police, some $10 million in stolen jewels stashed in cellars, attics, under floorboards and in safe-deposit boxes. Dubbed the ''King of Fences'' by the press, Mr. Joffo went on trial here this week. His defense: having been deprived of everything by the Nazis as a child, he has an uncontrollable urge to own beautiful and valuable things.

headline: PUSHING FASHION IN THE FAST LANE
abstract: FASHION just doesn't move fast enough for Mohan Murjani.   ''Why should it take years for a designer to become a sensation?'' he asks. ''Why should a line grow slowly, when it can be big from the start?''   Mr. Murjani simply refuses to play that waiting game. It was Murjani International, his company, that made Gloria Vanderbilt jeans an overnight sensation that has become a $400 million-a-year retail business. It is Murjani that has catapulted Tommy Hilfiger, the young designer, from obscurity to virtual notoriety.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SALVADORANS TELL OF TEARS AND TURMOIL AFTER THE QUAKE
abstract: Michele Hidalgo, a 25-year-old Salvadoran, seemed to symbolize all the anxiety and sorrow this country has withstood since the earthquake last week as she stood in front of the Ruben Dario building with tears streaming down her face.   ''My husband worked there,'' Mrs. Hidalgo said, looking blankly at what remained of the five-story building that collapsed like an accordion when the earthquake struck. ''They won't tell me anything.''   On Wednesday, as international crews continued their work, Vice President Bush and the Salvadoran President, Jose Napoleon Duarte, stopped in front of the office building to talk to the press.

headline: LORENZO IS NAMED EASTERN'S CHAIRMAN
abstract: Frank Lorenzo, the head of the Texas Air Corporation, was named chairman of Eastern Air Lines Inc. today in a management shake-up that strengthens his hold over the carrier.   Separately, Texas Air received the approval of a Federal bankruptcy court to acquire the assets of Frontier Airlines Inc. for $158 million. Pending final approval of the Transportation Department, Texas Air plans to begin service to some of Frontier's routes as early as Nov. 1.   In addition to electing Mr. Lorenzo, Eastern's board of directors replaced Joseph B. Leonard, president and acting chief executive, with Philip J. Bakes, 40 years old, who has been president of the Continental Airlines Corporation since 1984. Mr. Lorenzo will assume the presidency of Continental, which is owned by Texas Air.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 17, 1986:

headline: DEATH OF BLACK POLITICAL DETAINEE IS REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: A South African civil rights group said today that a black political detainee, held under an emergency decree, had died in a hospital soon after being transferred there from prison.   The reported death of Simon Marule, aged 20, was the second in detention reported since the proclamation of the state of emergency last June 12, according to the Detainees' Parents Support Committee.   The independent body monitors the number of detainees and the conditions under which they are held. It has estimated that more than 22,000 people -mostly blacks - have deen detained for varying periods over the past six months.

headline: China Traveler's Checks
abstract: The Industrial and Commercial Bank in Beijing will start issuing traveler's checks valid in 11 Chinese cities starting Jan. 1, the official New China News Agency said today. The checks will have face values from 100 yuan, about $27 at current exchange rates, to 1,000 yuan and are limited to personal use. People bearing the checks can withdraw money from savings banks in any of the 11 cities within a month after they purchase the checks.

headline: Armstrong Rubber Has Talks on Plant
abstract: The Armstrong Rubber Company said a management group represented by Marigold Enterprises Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., had expressed interest in buying Armstrong's truck tire manufacturing plant in Natchez, Miss.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Dollar's Decline    Trade analysts and other currency-watchers saw the dollar jolted last week by a larger-than-expected drop in durable goods orders, a key indicator of business activity, and by the resignation of President Reagan's national security adviser. The dollar's sharp fall cut short a recent strengthening that followed renewed optimism about America's economy and a cut in Japan's discount rate.   Soon, says Michael Gaffney, a senior economist for Merrill Lynch, the currency may dip even lower. ''The dollar will probably stay at current levels until United States interest rates fall further,'' said Mr. Gaffney, who expects that to happen shortly. ''We expect the Federal Reserve to cut the discount rate again by the end of the year,'' he said.

headline: PRETORIA EXPELS A U.S. JOURNALIST
abstract: The Government said today that it had refused to renew the work permit of the correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, and told him to leave South Africa by Dec. 31.   The journalist, Michael Parks, is the fifth foreign correspondent to be ordered out of country since a nationwide state of emergency was imposed June 12. The Department of Home Affairs would not give a reason for his expulsion.   In a related development, representatives of South African newspaper publishers met with a Cabinet committee today about Government plans for tighter press controls. One anti-apartheid group, Black Sash, urged the publishers not to become ''a party to fascism.''

headline: Bond Issues: A Scorecard
abstract: Voters across the nation approved $7.49 billion of new bond issues on Tuesday, out of $8.73 billion of proposals, according to data compiled by The Bond Buyer, a newspaper specializing in the tax-exempt securities market.   California led all states in approvals, with $1.8 billion of new bonds authorized for new elementary and secondary schools, colleges and universities, correctional facilities, and local water systems.

headline: I.B.M. Contract At Social Security
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation's Federal Systems division in Houston said that it has been awarded a seven-year contract from the Social Security Administration to supply computer terminals, controllers and printers for 1,300 offices.   The company said that the contract, valued at $40.4 million for the 1987 fiscal year, calls for a total of 33,000 units to be delivered. The first would be installed in 30 days, with all installations expected by the end of 1988.

headline: Washington Watch; Tax Overhaul: New 1987 Panel
abstract: THE House Ways and Means Committee is going to look considerably different when the 100th Congress convenes in January, even if all of the members seeking re-election tomorrow are successful.   Democrats James R. Jones of Oklahoma and Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia are running for the Senate, so they will not be back. Nor will Republicans Carroll A. Campbell Jr., who is running for Governor of South Carolina, and W. Henson Moore of Louisiana, who is vying to capture the Senate seat now held by Russell B. Long. And Democrat Cecil Heftel, who resigned to make an already unsuccessful bid for Governor of Hawaii, was replaced at the tail end of the last session by Michael A. Andrews of Texas.

headline: Japan Trading at High
abstract: Japanese trading of foreign securities set record highs in August, while foreign trading of Japanese bonds also set records, according to figures released today by the Ministry of Finance. Japanese investors bought a record $2.38 billion and sold a record $1.78 billion worth of foreign stocks in August, the ministry said. Officials attributed the upsurge to the yen's sharp appreciation against the dollar.

headline: GLAD BAG 'GIMMICK' PAYS OFF
abstract: The whole idea was to make a better bag.   The Dow Chemical Company's Ziploc bag commanded more than half of the market for ''reclosable plastic food storage bags'' - the kind with two narrow tracks at the top that pinch shut. And Glad Products was struggling to cut into that lead.   For a year, a team of 20 scientists and engineers working for Glad in Chicago experimented with dozens of colors to put on the tracks of its bags, so that when the tracks were squeezed together, the seal would turn a different color. They finally settled on a combination known to every kindergartner: yellow and blue, which would turn to green. The closure on Ziploc and other brands is clear.

headline: G.M.-HUGHES: A SMOOTH FIT
abstract: When the General Motors Corporation paid $5.2 billion for the Hughes Aircraft Company a year and a half ago, Roger Smith, the chairman of G.M., said that Hughes's wizardry in electronics would lead to ''redefining the basic car or truck.''   It may be too soon for the Hughes-defined vehicle of the future to be rolling off G.M.'s assembly lines, but the company founded by Howard Hughes 54 years ago has settled under the wing of its new parent much more smoothly than G.M.'s other major acquisition of last year, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.   H. Ross Perot, the founder of E.D.S., was ousted from G.M.'s board this week after openly criticizing G.M.'s progress in streamlining itself and improving its products. G.M. also bought out his stake in the company for $700 million, a move that brought even more allegations of mismanagement from Mr. Perot. Hughes's Chairman's Views    By contrast, Hughes appears relatively docile. ''Our relationship with G.M. has gotten off to a good start,'' said Allen E. Puckett, the chairman and chief executive of Hughes Aircraft, in an interview this week. ''I'm not about to tell Roger Smith what's wrong with G.M.''

headline: CHARITY LINKS SEVERED AS A RESULT OF INQUIRY
abstract: For many years, Ivan F. Boesky has not only given generously to charities, universities and cultural activities, but also involved himself personally in their operations. Now, he is severing at least some of his links to several prominent institutions.   For example, Princeton University's president, William G. Bowen, announced yesterday that a Boesky gift of $1.5 million promised last April would not be forthcoming. Half the funds had been pledged for a planned Center for Jewish Life, and half for a new building for the Department of Economics and the Center for International Studies.

headline: CTS Has Received 2 Acquisition Bids
abstract: The CTS Corporation, a maker of electronic components, said it had received two acquisition proposals from the Dynamics Corporation of America. Dynamics did not disclose the terms of its offers but said both proposals were greater in value than a proposal from the AVX Corporation, which earlier this week offered securities valued at $35 a share for CTS.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: IN THE WAKE OF 'BIG BANG'; Can Wall St. Still Afford Its Specialists
abstract: BRITAIN'S recent deregulation of its securities markets, the ''Big Bang,'' has been billed as a catching-up with the United States. It is that, and more. The London Stock Exchange not only ended fixed commissions and membership restrictions, as our exchanges did more than a decade ago, but took decisive steps to adapt to the new technological and competitive realities of the world securities markets. If the New York Stock Exchange fails to match the British reforms, it risks losing business, particularly in well-capitalized issues of international interest.  The London exchange dealt decisively with two crucial issues that have not been resolved by the Big Board: the system to be used for the trading of listed securities and the role of stock exchanges in the present era of international securities markets and advanced technology. Consider the American system, and compare it with the new British approach.

headline: SUPPORTERS OF AQUINO KEEP FAITH
abstract: Yellow balloons rose against a gray sky the other day as supporters of President Corazon C. Aquino gathered in the rain for a rally meant to revive the popular support that forms her political base.   Huddled under umbrellas in the city's financial district, middle-class women in yellow T-shirts joined in the chant from the election campaign last winter: ''Cory! Cory! Cory!''   And they added a new slogan, ''Give peace a chance.''   These women, who formed the core of Mrs. Aquino's support in ousting the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, faced a new challenge in a growing agitation against her Government from the right wing.

headline: General Cinema Rebuffs Offer
abstract: The General Cinema Corporation, the largest shareholder in Carter Hawley Hale Stores, said yesterday that it would not support the $55-a-share cash offer for Carter Hawley proposed Tuesday by a partnership of The Limited Inc. and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation.   In a statement from its headquarters in Chestnut Hill, Mass., General Cinema, which holds one million cumulative preferred shares of Carter Hawley that are convertible into 12.2 million common shares, said, ''General Cinema has no intention of accepting such a proposal if it is, in fact, made.'' Pivotal Role Two Years Ago    The nation's largest film distributor and a major soft-drink bottler, General Cinema played a pivotal role in thwarting The Limited's first run at Carter Hawley two years ago. That bid was defeated by Carter Hawley's repurchase of 15 million of its shares and General Cinema's purchase of the Carter Hawley preferred stock, a move that gained it seven of the 22 seats on Carter Hawley's board.

headline: Sears Officer Named
abstract: Coldwell Banker, the real estate unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, said yesterday that James J. Didion had been named chairman and chief executive of its commercial group, effective Jan. 1.   Mr. Didion, 46 years old, will succeed J. Frank Mahoney 3d, 59, who is retiring. Mr. Didion joined Coldwell Banker in 1962, 10 years after Mr. Mahoney did. The commercial group is based in Los Angeles.

headline: END OF BOESKY'S FIRM MAY BE NEAR
abstract: Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator who traded stocks on illegal insider information, will, for all practical purposes, go out of business this Friday, according to Wall Street sources.   In settling charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Nov. 14, Mr. Boesky had been allowed to take up to 18 months to wind down the activities of the $880 million investment partnership he managed.   But, according to several Wall Street executives who have talked with some of Mr. Boesky's employees in recent days, the firm bearing his name will dismiss most of its research and secretarial staff and will cease to have traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange after this Friday. The firm's name and any reference to Mr. Boesky have already been removed from the building directory at 650 Fifth Avenue. Portfolio Transformed    In addition, these sources, who requested anonymity, say the stock portfolio of the investment partnership, Ivan F. Boesky & Company L. P., has been almost entirely transferred into cash-equivalent fixed-income securities for distribution to partners soon.

headline: New Securities Coming: 'Certificates of Accrual'
abstract: Salomon Brothers yesterday announced plans to expand the market for zero coupon tax-exempt securities with the introduction of new issues created by stripping interest and principal payments from outstanding bonds.   The new issues, called Municipal Certificates of Accrual on Tax-Exempt Securities, will bear a close resemblance to zero coupon Treasury securities except that investors will not be taxed on the accrual of value.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Dominion Resources, Richmond, elected Thomas E. Capps president, succeeding William W. Berry, who remains chairman and chief executive.    * Eli Lilly & Co., Indianapolis, a pharmaceutical concern, announced that Cornelius W. Pettinga would retire as executive vice president Nov. 30.

headline: An Unusual Phone Pledge
abstract: The Putnam Management Company, the big money management firm that was temporarily forced out of its offices by an electrical explosion and fire Tuesday night, has formed an unusual partnership to keep in touch with clients.   Needing a large bank of phones, Putnam turned to WGBH, the public television station here, which has just begun a televised pledge drive.

headline: Deutsche Bank In U.S. Offering
abstract: The Deutsche Bank made its public debut in the American bond market yesterday with a $200 million offering of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.577, to yield 7.603 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   The notes, which are not callable and are rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., yield about seven-tenths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.

headline: JWT Group Increasing Its Board by One, to 12
abstract: The JWT Group, parent company of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising, and Hill & Knowlton, public relations, announced yesterday that it was increasing its board by one, to 12, which, because of three retirements, will mean four seats to fill.   Doing the filling - if elected - will be Joseph W. O'Donnell, chief executive and chairman-elect of the ad agency; Robert L. Dilenschneider, president and chief executive officer of the public relations firm; Ronald A. Kovas, executive vice president of the JWT Group, and Strephen M. Salorio, executive vice president and general counsel of the group.

headline: Marriott in Polish Deal
abstract: The Marriott Hotels Corporation has joined with the Polish airline LOT and an Austrian company to establish the first joint venture in Poland under a law passed last April, the official P.A.P. press agency reported. The joint venture will complete the construction of the LOT terminal in Warsaw. The joint venture law was passed last April to attract Western capital.

headline: Article 841086 -- No Title
abstract: Revlon Group Inc. has begun an unsolicited bid of about $4 billion to acquire the Gillette Company, a company well known for products ranging from Trac II razors to Papermate pens.   The $65-a-share tender offer, disclosed in newspaper advertisements today, followed heavy buying of Gillette stock late yesterday. Some Wall Street arbitragers thought the buyer was Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's chairman.   The arbitragers speculated that Mr. Perelman had bought about $175 million of Gillette stock. This would represent about three million shares, or about 5 percent of the company's 65 million common shares outstanding, at yesterday's closing price of $57.75 a share. They said that the purchases, made through Bear, Stearns & Company, might have been sufficient to raise Mr. Perelman's stake in Gillette to 10 percent.

headline: PHONE CALLS LINK U.S. AIDES TO CONTRAS
abstract: Telephone records from Nicaraguan rebel ''safe houses'' in El Savador show a series of calls on the same days in September to the former White House offices of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, as well as to the company run by a retired general involved in dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels.   They also show calls to a telephone in Costa Rica that appears to belong to an American intelligence operative.   The telephone calls were from a safe house in El Savador used by American crews secretly flying weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels during a Congressional ban on such aid, and the calls appear to offer the strongest circumstantial evidence so far that there was close coordination between the rebels, Colonel North, American officials in Costa Rica and someone in Stanford Technology Incorporated, of which Gen. Richard V. Secord, retired, is a leading member.   Senior Administration officials had previously contended that the rebel supply operation was ''strictly private'' and therefore did not violate the Congressional ban on delivering arms to the guerrillas. It appears increasingly likely, however, that the program may have been prompted by American officials, financed by secret arms sales to Iran and then monitored by American officials in Central America.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adamas Carbide Corp., Kenilworth, N.J., a subsidiary of Panatech Research and Development Corp. that makes cutting materials and devices for the machine tool industry, named James F. McCain president.    * Adaptec Inc., Milpitas, Calif., a developer and supplier of input-output components used to control the flow of computer data, named John G. Adler, president and a director, to the additional post of chief executive.

headline: Mortgage Bonds
abstract: The Home Owners Savings and Loan Association is offering $80 million of 7 3/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds, which are not callable before maturity, yield about nine-tenths of a percentage point more than comparable Treasury issues. The bonds, rated Aaa by Moody's, are collateralized by Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participation certificates worth 131 percent of the bond issue.

headline: Markets Idle Yesterday
abstract: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Stock and commodity markets, Government offices and banks will be open today. Some businesses, however, will be closed.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Arvin Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $200 million of debt securities.    * Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Co. has filed for a shelf offering of $60 million of first mortgage bonds.

headline: OPEC PACT MAY BE FLAWED MIRACLE
abstract: The agreement announced Saturday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries represents an ambitious bid by the 13-nation group to regain its former role as the price-setting manager of the world oil market. But to achieve that goal, OPEC will have to display a measure of unity, production discipline and political will that the aspiring cartel has often lacked during its 26-year history.   The production-cutting accord is expected to lift free-market oil prices up toward the OPEC target of $18 a barrel during the next few days, analysts say. But in the longer term, OPEC's ability to enforce fixed prices is uncertain.

headline: Hunts Save Some Land
abstract: A tract of foreclosed land owned by the Hunt brothers was kept in the family on Tuesday when a company owned by two of their siblings bought the 48 acres from the banks. The Hunt Petroleum Corporation, owned by the trust estates of Margaret Hunt Hill and Haroldson L. Hunt Jr., paid $3.8 million for a two-thirds interest in the land.

headline: DARMAN CATCHES A BIT OF FLAK
abstract: In a speech on Friday, Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, criticized big corporations for being bloated, risk-averse, inefficient and unimaginative and for not spending enough on research and development. Corporate executives were paid too much for doing too little, he suggested. Perhaps the unkindest cut was his likening corporate culture to the Federal Government's bureaucracy.   Whether Mr. Darman was simply being mischievous or defending his role in designing the new tax policy -which will raise the tax bill for much of big business - he caught people's attention. He drew kudos from some unlikely allies, including John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist.   On the other hand, being called ''bloated'' was undoubtedly a surprise to the likes of Chrysler, Exxon and General Electric and dozens of others that have put themselves and thousands of their employees through the wringer in the name of raising their efficiency.

headline: PATENTS; 3-D Pictures On Color Television
abstract: Three-dimensional color television broadcasts are proposed in a patent granted this week to Alvin M. Marks, an inventor in Athol, Mass.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.   The reports of changes follow:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE  GELCO CORPORATION-Michael J. Morris, director, bought and exercised option of 15,000 shares giving him directly a balance of 19,000 shares.

headline: Bid for Papers In Milwaukee
abstract: The company that publishes Milwaukee's two major newspapers said today that it has rejected a $600 million takeover offer from the owner of The Boston Globe.   Thomas J. McCollow, chief executive officer of The Journal Company, said the rejection is a clear signal to anyone thinking of acquiring the company, which in May will celebrate the 50th anniversary of an employee-ownership plan.

headline: Quaker Oats, Sara Lee Gain
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company and the Sara Lee Corporation today reported profit gains. Both companies cited strong performances in their food operations.

headline: FEDERATED REPURCHASES A 4.6% BLOCK
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and other retail chains, said yesterday that it had repurchased nearly 2.2 million of its shares from a single investor that it declined to identify. The block represented about 4.6 percent of the company's outstanding stock.   But Wall Street sources, who asked not to be identified, said the seller was the Dart Group Corporation, a company controlled by the Haft family of Maryland. The company, which operates a group of discount auto supply and book stores, has been used in the last year as a vehicle for corporate takeover raids.

headline: Bernie & Walter Team: Some Self-Promotion
abstract: Bernie Most and Walter Cohen have been advertising creative partners for 18 years, first at Benton & Bowles and then at MCA Advertising. Since July 1 it has been as Bernie & Walter, which is based at whichever of their homes they happen to be in. Mr. Most resides in Scarsdale and Mr. Cohen in White Plains.

headline: 180 REPORTED DROWNED IN SINKING OF FERRY BOAT OFF COAST OF HAITI
abstract: A 50-foot ferry boat sank off Haiti's west coast today, and at least 180 people drowned while 20 were rescued, the United States Embassy reported.   Jeffrey Lite, an embassy spokesman, said he received the information from the Haitian Navy.   Radio Soleil, a Roman Catholic station in Port-au-Prince, reported tonight that its correspondent on Ile de la Gonave, an island 30 miles west of the capital, reported the vessel was apparently overloaded.

headline: THE C.I.A. ROLE IN SALVADOR: AIR BASE DESCRIBED AS THE KEY
abstract: Behind the high concrete-block walls that keep the Ilopango air base here from the public's view is a drab two-story building. Over the last three years, the building has served as the waiting room for agents working for the Central Intelligence Agency, leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels, mercenaries and American military advisers, according to American officials and Nicaraguan rebel sources.   Now more than ever the base is the center of C.I.A.-supported operations to supply Nicaraguan rebel forces, according to an American shot down in a supply plane over Nicaragua.   American men in civilian clothes often pass through the base's gates and American officials say privately that it is the center of C.I.A. and other clandestine operations here.

headline: Shelterless Partnerships
abstract: LIMITED partnerships, an investment category that provides direct pass-through of earnings in such fields as real estate, oil and gas, and equipment leasing, will lose much of their appeal as tax shelters next year.   That could be bad news for many of the five million investors in such limited partnerships. Those who now want to switch their funds to other investments may have trouble getting all their original capital out.   Under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, income received by individuals is divided into three categories: active (such as salary and business profits), portfolio (interest, dividends, royalties and capital gains) and passive (such as income received from a limited partnership). Starting next year, both the income and the losses received by a limited partner will be considered passive activities, even for existing shelters.

headline: DERELICT S.I. HOSPITAL IS NOW A 'CASTLE' CONDOMINIUM
abstract: There was no joy in the New Brighton section of Staten Island seven years ago when the Staten Island Hospital pulled up stakes and moved to a new building miles away. The fear of neighboring homeowners was that the hospital's departure would leave a derelict property in their midst.   And so it did, until this year. In the interim, the property changed hands three times. At one point, the late Robert Olnick, a major developer based in Manhattan, tried to redevelop it as condominiums. But he backed away, according to associates, when he found a lack of enthusiasm among Staten Island banks for providing financing in the area.

headline: F.T.C. to Challenge Purchase by Kidde
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission voted to seek a court injunction to block the purchase by the nation's leading supplier of mobile hydraulic cranes of the No. 2 provider of such equipment.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: DEPARTURE STATEMENT BY MOSCOW OFFICIAL
abstract: Following are excerpts from a departure statement by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze here today, as distributed in translation by the Soviet delegation:   Saying goodbye to Vienna and to you, I would like to say a few words. First of all about the Vienna meeting. It started at a very important moment for Europe . . . The question is how will its content correspond to the importance of the moment.

headline: Glass Supplier To Louis XIV
abstract: Saint-Gobain was founded in 1665 as a supplier of glass to Louis XIV. It now has major operations in more than two dozen countries and conducts business in about 100 more.

headline: Report of AIDS Jokes Roils San Franciscans
abstract: Officials from San Francisco said today that they were offended by jokes attributed by The Washington Post to President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in which they reportedly discussed sending the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to San Francisco and giving him AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome.   The Post, quoting a source it did not identify, said in today's issue that the comments were made at a White House meeting on a plan to undermine the Libyan Government.

headline: Uganda Kills 65 Rustlers
abstract: Ugandan troops have killed 65 cattle rustlers in the northeast of the country in the last few weeks, a Government statement said today. The troops battled with rustlers in two incidents near the towns of Soroti and Mbale, the statement added.

headline: Filing by Lindner
abstract: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, the financier, who together hold a 9.9 percent stake in National Convenience Stores Inc., said they were seeking clearance to purchase up to 25 percent of the company's shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Lindner said the group had no ''present plans to acquire control'' of the Houston-based food store concern but added that they ''may change their plans depending on future developments.'' National Convenience's stock closed today at $10.125, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: SHARP DROPS AT 3 OIL CONCERNS
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, and the Unocal Corporation, reflecting the continued depression of crude oil prices, reported steep declines in third-quarter earnings yesterday. The Pennzoil Company, which also cited a debenture buyback program, posted a small loss.   Arco's net income dropped 74.6 percent, to $102 million, or 56 cents a share, from $403 million, or $1.98 a share, for the 1985 quarter. Revenues fell 36.4 percent, to $3.5 billion, from $5.5 billion.

headline: Norfolk Southern Acts to Trim Staff
abstract: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said its railroad units are seekng to speed normal attrition among train and engine-service employees by offering them a one-time separation allowance.

headline: Canadian Tire Gets an Offer
abstract: Cara Operations Ltd., the Toronto-based food-services concern, has offered to buy the Canadian Tire Corporation under a plan that would pay holders of the company's common stock $100 (Canadian) a share. The total deal is estimated to be worth $1.58 billion (Canadian), or $1.14 billion (American).

headline: Norway Closer To Gas Sale
abstract: Norway appeared headed today toward compromise with France in a dispute over Norwegian plans to sell natural gas to Western Europe. The plan to develop the huge   North Sea gas fields would make Norway the main supplier of natural gas for Western Europe into the next century and would sharply reduce the region's reliance on the Soviet Union.

headline: THE SPURT IN FASHION SHOWS
abstract: One retail buyer remembers the year, not too long ago, when she wore through a pair of shoes traveling from one designer showroom to the next. She had scheduled a meeting for every working hour of her visit, and left with a hole in one sole, courtesy of the sidewalks of New York's garment center.   These days, buyers' soles spend more time on carpeted convention floors than on concrete streets. Trade shows, though common in other American industries, were, until recently, a rarity in the fashion world here. Now they are the accepted business arena.   ''New shows keep popping up and all of them are crowded,'' said Ruth Finley, publisher of the Fashion Calendar, a daily listing of fashion and trade shows. ''And the ones that have been around for years have grown and improved a great deal.''

headline: YANKS RETAKE GUADALCANAL, WITH TOOLS OF PEACE
abstract: The grassy hills and the cool coconut groves are quiet now. There are few reminders that here, in 1942, Americans fought one of the fiercest battles of the Pacific war. The battle took its name from the island: Guadalcanal.   To the United States, it was a showdown over an airstrip. Seizing the strip meant stopping the southward advance of the Japanese.

headline: Food Imports
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Looking Abroad to Fill Our Bellies'' (Aug. 3), Keith Schneider makes several points to demonstrate America's loss of competitiveness in food production. He says that an American farm worker picking grapes is paid $10 an hour, while a Chilean farm worker is paid between $2 and $3 per day for the same work.

headline: Ceco Suit Accord
abstract: Ceco Industries, a closely held construction products company, said it had agreed to pay $1 million to settle a class-action suit filed against the company last month. The suit had said the terms of a managment-led buyout were ''grossly unfair and inadequate'' to shareholders.

headline: Waldorf-Astoria
abstract: The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel has brought its advertising account back to New York from Washington and has asked its new agency, Kaufman & Maraffi, to promote its lodgings to corporate upper and middle management, who had previously been awed by the establishment. Soghigian & Macuga of Washington previously had the account. The ad budget is $1.2 million.

headline: REAGAN SEES GAIN IN U.S. SOVIET TIES
abstract: President Reagan today offered a favorable assessment of the year in terms of superpower relations, saying that ''this year, relations between the United States and the Soviet Union advanced.''   In his weekly radio address, the President added that ''1986 has been a good year for the cause of human freedom and good for the cause of world peace.''   Mr. Reagan made the broadcast on the day he arrived here from Washington for a weeklong vacation in Los Angeles and Palm Springs, Calif.   Before he left Washington, the White House issued a statement in which the President urged the Soviet Union to offer a ''realistic timetable'' for the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan. He said in the statement that the United States strongly endorsed ''resistance'' efforts by the Afghan people.

headline: Leader of Beverly Plans to Keep Post
abstract: Robert Van Tuyle, the energetic, 74-year-old chairman and chief executive of Beverly Enterprises, says he has no thoughts of stepping aside from the top post of the nation's largest nursing home company.   ''As long as the bookkeeper upstairs doesn't close the book on me, I'll keep doing it,'' Mr. Van Tuyle said in an interview from Beverly's headquarters in Pasadena, Calif. ''What else could I do that I would enjoy more, and still be a major part of?''

headline: AVX Offer for CTS
abstract: The AVX Corporation said it was offering $35 a share, or a total of $197.8 million, for the CTS Corporation, which makes electronic components and metal products.

headline: Takeover Stocks Surge As Dow Rallies by 11.39
abstract: Stock prices rallied yesterday on a new wave of takeover and restructuring news, allowing Wall Street to recover some of the losses from the previous session.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.39 points, to 1,873.59, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange advanced to 172.1 million shares, from 164 million shares the day before.   The blue-chip index had been down about 10 points at the start of trading, following a drop of 31.50 points on Thursday that resulted from speculators' retreat from supposed takeover stocks, as well as program selling. 12.94-Point Drop for Week For the week, the Dow fell 12.94 points, after adding 8.72 points the week before.   Harold A. Mackinney, chairman of the invesment policy committee of the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I., pointed out that the Dow once again failed to penetrate the 1,900 level.

headline: PARTY PARLEY DUE, ALBANIA CLUES ARE SOUGHT
abstract: In Bucharest, Belgrade and other Balkan capitals the question on the minds of the small groups of specialists who keep a close eye on Albania is when and if Ramiz Alia, the Communist leader in Tirana, can develop his own style of leadership, distinguishing himself from his predecessor, Enver Hoxha.   The specialists - Government officials, journalists and scholars, some of whom have worked in Albania - are therefore waiting with considerable anticipation for the congress of the Albanian Communist Party that is to open in Tirana in the first week of November.   Emerging from talks with five of these specialists in Bucharest and Belgrade is a consensus that a key to gauging the freedom of Mr. Alia, the Secretary General of the party, is what happens to Mr. Hoxha's widow, Nexhmije, who is 71 years old.   Mr. Hoxha ruled Albania with an iron fist for 40 years until his death in April 1985. At that time, Mrs. Hoxha was a member of the party's Central Committee and director of the Tirana Institute for Marxist-Leninist studies.

headline: BUSH STAFF GOT CALLS ABOUT CONTRA PLANE
abstract: A day before the Nicaraguan Government announced the downing of a rebel supply plane in October, Vice President Bush's staff received word that the plane was missing, Mr. Bush's office announced tonight.   The information was contained in a four-page statement that shows a much closer relationship than previously acknowledged between the Vice President's staff and the secret private network that was supplying arms to the rebels, known as contras.   The statement is the first indication that the United States Government knew of the downing of the plane before it was announced by Nicaragua. The information was passed on to high-ranking officials of the National Security Council, Mr. Bush's office said.

headline: MORE THAN GRIEF FOR TRANSKEI KIN OF DEAD MINER
abstract: For the last five years or so, Nowebile Ntoba has been used to seeing her son Nkosinam just once a year. That was when he returned from his job in the mines to visit for a month at the end of a contract.   Now she will not see him at all, except at his funeral. For her 23-year-old son was one of the 177 men - 172 blacks and 5 whites - who were killed Sept. 16 in the country's worst gold-mining disaster.   Elsewhere, a mining disaster might evoke pity for the bereaved, and then silence. But here, in a corner of the nominally independent tribal ''homeland'' called Transkei, other issues seem to weave themselves among the details and sadnesses of personal loss.

headline: P.L.O. DECIDES TO SHIFT PRIORITY TO ARMED STRUGGLE
abstract: In a shift in strategy, the Palestine Liberation Organization under Yasir Arafat has decided to give armed struggle against Israel priority over the peace process, P.L.O. spokesmen say.   The change was reflected in a grenade attack last month in Jerusalem and in statements by P.L.O. spokesmen that the violence will be stepped up.   One person was killed and 69 were wounded when Soviet-made grenades were thrown at Israeli Army recruits and their relatives near the Wailing Wall in East Jerusalem. The P.L.O. was quick to take responsibility, and its spokesmen in Cairo, Baghdad and Tunis said one of its units had carried out the action.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A Peking dispatch Oct. 13 on Queen Elizabeth's visit to China misidentified the Chinese emperor who ruled at the time of George III. The emperor was named Qianlong, and he was the fourth ruler in the Qing dynasty.

headline: Hercules Promotes Executive to Chief
abstract: Hercules Inc., a producer of chemicals and aerospace products, said yesterday that David S. Hollingsworth would become chairman and chief executive on March 24, when Alexander F. Giacco retires.   The company, based in Wilmington, Del., also announced that Fred L. Buckner would become president and chief operating officer and Arden B. Engebretsen would become vice chairman.   Mr. Giacco, 67 years old, has been with the company for 44 years and extended his tenure in 1983 when he reached the company's normal retirement age.

headline: MEXICO DEBT LINK SEEN AS PRECEDENT
abstract: Bankers said today that the Mexican lending agreement would set a precedent for debt talks with other nations.   The bankers and other finance experts said that, although both sides had achieved successes, on balance the Mexicans had been victorious. Mexico could get as much as $13.7 billion in new money.   And while key details must be resolved, there was a sense of relief in the banking community that the negotiation had averted a crisis. ''This takes some pressure off the banking system,'' said Konrad Rumpold, a board member of Landerbank, Austria's second-largest commercial bank.

headline: Britain and Guatemala Renew Diplomatic Ties
abstract: Britain and Guatemala have decided to resume diplomatic relations, broken by Guatemala in 1963 in a dispute over neighboring Belize, the Foreign Office said today.

headline: Scripps Deal Completed
abstract: The E. W. Scripps Company and the John P. Scripps Newspaper Group have announced the completion of their merger.

headline: CHADIAN FIGHTERS ARE SAID TO GAIN
abstract: Chadian guerrillas have badly mauled a Libyan armored column, killing at least 100 Libyan soldiers in fierce fighting in the mountains of northern Chad, diplomatic sources said today.   The Chadian Government reported today that the guerrillas killed 400 Libyans, destroyed 3 tanks and 14 armored personnel carriers, and captured 4 armored personnel carriers with their Libyan crews.   The Government said one guerrilla was killed and three were wounded. In this capital, 400 miles south of the fighting, it was impossible to verify these reports. Attack on Rebel Strongholds    The most recent fighting is reported to have started Saturday when, after extensive aerial bombardment, three Libyan columns of about 700 soldiers apiece attacked four mountain strongholds of guerrillas loyal to a northern chief and former President of Chad, Goukouni Oueddei.

headline: CHIRAC HAS TAKEN THE REINS OF POWER FROM MITTERAND
abstract: After nearly eight months of the power-sharing arrangement known as ''cohabitation,'' real authority and initiative in France have fallen into the hands of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, officials and others say.   They add that President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, has come to play a secondary role to the conservative Prime Minister.   The events of recent weeks, in particular the intense French efforts to deal with terrorism, have seen Mr. Chirac moving to the forefront in France's unusual two-headed ruling arrangement, which began when a coalition of conservative parties led by Mr. Chirac won a parliamentary majority in elections in March.   Mr. Mitterrand, by contrast, has remained largely in the background, speaking only once in recent weeks to indicate apparent disagreement with some of Mr. Chirac's policies.

headline: CHINESE AS IT'S WRITTEN: WILDLY DIFFERENT STROKES
abstract: Cao Xianzhuo is worried.   Despite his efforts, the efforts of bureaucrats who preceded him and perhaps because of the weight of 3,000 years of history, people in China refuse to write Chinese all the same way.   Street signs, billboards, newspapers, books and the signs over shop windows sometimes use forms of Chinese characters that are irregular, obscure or downright wrong.   Last month Peking Daily published two pages of Chinese characters, the ideograms that make up the written Chinese language, and declared that once and for all this was the way Chinese should be written. It was at least the sixth time in the last 25 years that such a list has been published. A Posse of Schoolchildren?  Earlier this year exasperation with the spread of irregular written characters seemed to reach a fever pitch, and schoolchildren were urged to patrol the streets looking for public signs with incorrectly written Chinese as part of a campaign dubbed ''Let the spring wind drive away wrong characters.''

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: British Caledonian Airways said today that it had placed a $1 billion order for nine McDonnell Douglas MD-11 aircraft, becoming the first carrier to order the proposed wide-bodied jets.   McDonnell Douglas said the decision was a major spur to its efforts to start production of the plane, on which it has spent $600 million for development.

headline: In Perspective; Some New Developments
abstract: The White House said President Reagan rejected the option of granting a pardon to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to encourage them to tell what they knew about the Iran arms affair.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Kearney & Trecker Corporation, Milwaukee, to Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa, Okla., for its modular automation systems and stand-alone machine tools.

headline: Washington Watch; Action Awaited On Transit Bill
abstract: THERE will be no shortage of groups pressing for immediate attention to the Federal highway and mass transit program when Congress returns next month.  The last Congress blocked the distribution of about $13 billion in funds to the states this fall for highway and bridge construction, after failing to agree on legislation to replace a surface transportation law that expired in September.

headline: 5 Gold Miners Killed In South Africa Accident
abstract: At least five gold miners were killed and six were seriously injured today when tons of mining equipment fell down a 2,600-foot ventilation shaft, mining officials said.

headline: Former Head of NL Unit Designated for Vernitron
abstract: John R. Slowik, who resigned as president of NL Chemicals in August when the parent company, NL Industries, was taken over, has been designated to become the chief operating officer of the Vernitron Company by the investment company that is seeking control of Vernitron.   ''Fundamentally, I am leaving the corporate life and moving to the venture side of business, and looking forward to it,'' said Mr. Slowik, 49.   Vernitron, of Lake Success, L.I., makes electromechanical, scientific and health-care products. It is the object of a tender offer by the SB Holding Corporation. The offer will not be completed until Nov. 19, and Mr. Slowik will first join SB Holding as its chief operating officer.

headline: TIMES CO. BROADCAST EXECUTIVE
abstract: C. Frank Roberts has been named vice president for broadcasting of The New York Times Company. The announcement was made yesterday by the company's chairman, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger.

headline: ADDRESS BY SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER
abstract: Following are excerpts from Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's address here today to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, as distributed in translation by the Soviet delegation:   Mr. chairman, ladies and gentlemen, comrades, the Vienna meeting has opened in a new frame of time. The time is for vigorous and immediate actions. Europe is capable of accelerating developments by channeling them along the lines of new political thinking.   The recent lessons of Geneva, Budapest, Bern and Stockholm show that this is possible. The lessons of Reykjavik urge that is necessary.   Reykjavik has shown that a maximum of positive results can be achieved within a minimum of time. Reykjavik has also proved that a maximum of dissappointment can be caused in a minimum of time.

headline: Volcano in Japan Erupts And Another Subsides
abstract: Mount Mihara subsided today after a fiery eruption that forced 11,000 people to flee the small island of O-shima south of Tokyo late last week.

headline: IRAN MONEY REPORTED DIVERTED IN '85
abstract: The first diversion of money from United States arms sales to Iran took place in late 1985, months earlier than acknowledged by the Reagan Administration, according to people here and abroad familiar with the transactions.   Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said at a news conference Tuesday that the program to funnel proceeds from the arms transactions to the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras, began in 1986.   But people who are familiar with the transactions say Iran paid millions of dollars to Israel for several shipments of weapons made from September to December of 1985. Much of the money failed to reach the Israeli Government, they said, and was instead used either for commissions to arms dealers or for some other purpose.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article on Saturday about tenants' efforts to buy a performing arts building at 890 Broadway misstated expenditures by two tenants on improvements there.

headline: 22 Rebels Reported Dead In Sri Lanka Clashes
abstract: Government forces killed at least 22 Tamil guerrillas and captured 60 more in an urban battle Friday and today and in a sweep through the countryside, military officials said.

headline: A Sneak Preview Of Computer Products
abstract: The annual fall Computer Distributors Exposition, which opened in Las Vegas Monday, is the industry's biggest gathering and symbolically the start of its new year. An estimated 92,000 manufacturers, dealers, retailers, office information managers and onlookers, from every continent except Antarctica, are in town this week for the show, expecting to get a sneak preview of the products that will be in the stores in 1987.

headline: E.S.M. Figure Gets 30 Years
abstract: The former president of E.S.M. Government Securities, the fraud-ridden firm that collapsed and spurred a run on Ohio savings and loan associations, was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.   Federal District Judge Jose A. Gonzalez fined Nicholas B. Wallace $850 and allowed him to remain free on bond while his attorneys appeal the sentence.

headline: RULING IS LIKELY MONDAY IN FIGHT FOR EASTERN AIR
abstract: The fate of a last-minute union effort to prevent Texas Air Inc. from gaining control of Eastern Air Lines was put in the hands of a Federal judge yesterday.   Lawyers from both sides - the union coalition and Eastern management - concluded their arguments yesterday at a hearing in a courtroom in Miami to Judge Lawrence King. He must soon decide whether there is sufficient legal reason to grant an injunction to prevent Eastern from holding a stockholders meeting next Tuesday. At that meeting, in New York, Texas Air would vote its 51 percent Eastern holding in favor of the merger.

headline: PATENTS; Composition Protects Wood and Textiles
abstract: Protection against insects and fungus is offered for wood and other materials such as paper and textiles by a composition patented this week.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 13, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: KIM IL SUNG, AT 74, IS REPORTED DEAD
abstract: South Korea announced today that North Korean loudspeakers along the border had reported that Kim Il Sung, the North's leader, had been shot to death.   The reports could not be independently confirmed, and the North Korean embassies in Peking and New Delhi issued denials, deepening the uncertainty. The embassy in Peking called the report ''a total fabrication.''   In New Delhi, a North Korean diplomat said, ''In my opinion these reports are not true and are actually South Korean propaganda.'' No U.S. Confirmation    A spokesman for United States forces in South Korea said that they had ''no independent confirmation'' that the North Koreans had made any announcement over the loudspeakers across the demilitarized zone.  [ In Washington, high-level military sources said the Pentagon had received reports of Mr. Kim's death as early as Saturday. They said no special alert had been ordered for American forces in the region. ]  A Cult of Personality The death of Mr. Kim would have a great effect not only on North-South relations in Korea but also on security considerations throughout the region.

headline: 4 IN NEW OPPOSITION PARTY GET MOST VOTES IN TAIWAN
abstract: The four top vote-getters in the legislative elections Saturday were all members of a new opposition party, according to final results made available today.   The opposition group, the Democratic Progressive Party, got an unexpectedly high 23 percent of the vote, more than opposition candidates had received in the past. Political analysts said it was a remarkably good showing over all for a party that was formed two months ago and was still regarded as illegal, although its candidates were allowed to campaign. But the party's successes are not expected to result in any sweeping changes in Taiwan's policies.

headline: Austrian Socialists To Try to Form Cabinet
abstract: President Kurt Waldheim will ask Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, a Socialist, to form a government, the President's spokesman said today.

headline: DOW LOSES 14.62 POINTS AND VOLUME FALLS OFF
abstract: Stock prices fell yesterday for the third consecutive day, turning a week that could have been fabulous into a mediocre one. After the market soared to new highs on Tuesday, traders became increasingly skittish over insider trading, the sale of arms to Iran and the economy.   The Dow Jones industrial average has not closed on the upside since Tuesday's 43.03-point climb to a record of 1,955.57. The average fell 14.62 points yesterday, to 1,925.06. For the week, the blue-chip index gained a modest 10.83 points.

headline: Investor Injury Seen in Scandal
abstract: Manuel H. Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that ''innocent investors are now losing'' in the stock market as a result of the Boesky insider-trading affair.   But he said there was little the Fed could do to thwart the kind of selling that drove the Dow Jones industrial average down 43 points on Tuesday.

headline: Proposal by GCA
abstract: The GCA Corporation said it might have to seek protection under Federal bankruptcy laws if it was not able to successfully complete new talks with its lenders. The company, an integrated circuits concern based in Bedford, Mass., said its management had made a refinancing proposal to institutional lenders that included an infusion of $54 million in cash by the sale of equity securities; the raising of $26 million through previously announced asset sales, and the payment of about $50 million to the institutional lenders, with most of the balance of GCA debt being eliminated.

headline: BankAmerica Sale
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said it had closed the sale of the Banca d'America e d'Italia to Deutsche Bank A.G. for $603 million. The sale of its 98.3 percent stake in the Italian bank, which had assets of $4.2 billion and a book value of $321 million, should give BankAmerica a $282 million pretax gain in the fourth quarter. Analysts have said the sale would give the bank a profit for the quarter.

headline: LEBANON FIGHTING CONTINUES
abstract: Heavy fighting broke out again today in southern Lebanon around Maghdusheh, a village near the port city of Sidon that Palestinian forces captured from Shiite militiamen on Monday.   The Shiite militia, Amal, mounted a dawn offensive and announced after six hours of fighting that its forces had regained complete control of Maghdusheh.

headline: REPUBLICAN LEADER IN SENATE ASSERTS IRAN-NICARAGUA AFFAIR HURTS G.O.P.
abstract: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the departing Republican majority leader, said today that the Republican Party was beginning to suffer political damage from the Reagan Administration's sale of arms to Iran and the transfer of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels.   Mr. Dole said the crisis had to be dealt with quickly, before the party's prospects in the 1988 elections were permanently impaired.   Mr. Dole, a likely candidate for his party's Presidential nomination, made his comments after he met at the White House this morning with Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's chief of staff. At the meeting, Mr. Dole said, he urgently repeated his suggestion that Mr. Reagan call a special session of Congress that would appoint a select committee to assume control of the spreading Congressional investigation of the Iran affair.

headline: OPEC, IN OIL OUTPUT CUT, TO LIFT BVARREL PRICE TO $18
abstract: After days of acrimonious deliberations, the accord reached at dawn today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries - to cut oil production and to raise prices quickly to $18 a barrel -was in line with previous reports from private ministerial sessions.   The reports from last week's sessions drove open-market oil prices up by roughly $2 a barrel, to more than $16 a barrel. But the production cuts of more than 7 percent for the first six months of next year exclude Iraq.   The Iraqi exclusion underlines the degree to which OPEC decisions are influenced by the six-year war between Iran and Iraq. It also raises doubts about whether the agreement to trim output will be sufficient to defend a price of $18 a barrel.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1986
abstract: The World    The White House set up secret lines of communication with the United States Ambassador in Beirut on talks for the release of American hostages without informing Secretary of State George P. Shultz, he said.     Page A1    The President has rejected the pleas of friends that he ask two former officials to tell him the details of the shipments of American arms to Iran and the funneling of profits to Nicaraguan rebels, officials said.    A14    Nine U.S. helicopters ferried Honduran troops to the border with Nicaragua, where fighting was said to have taken place between Honduran and Nicaraguan units. There were conflicting reports on whether the clashes were continuing.

headline: THE CANADIAN LINK: A NEW ELEMENT
abstract: A business associate of two Canadians who helped finance secret United States arms shipments to Iran has been identified here as a major figure in the World Anti-Communist League, which is believed to have raised at least $10 million to aid Nicaraguan rebels.   The associate, John Gamble, told reporters last week that he knew nothing about the secret arms deals with Iran that were financed in part by his business partners here, Ernest Miller and Donald Fraser. But his involvement in the Anti Communist League seemed likely to raise questions about whether the Canadian investors knew that part of Iran's payment for the weapons was being diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: Chargit Credit Service
abstract: Chargit, a telephone ticket reservation company, said yesterday that it is trying to restore immediately, at least on an interim basis, credit-card processing services. The services were halted after the Bowery Savings Bank announced earlier this week that it would end an arrangement under which Chargit processed Visa and Mastercard credit-card transactions for the Bowery.

headline: KIDDER TAKEOVER FUND SEEN
abstract: The General Electric Company has agreed to provide several billion dollars to Kidder, Peabody & Company, which it acquired earlier this year, to help fund a move by the firm to invest aggressively in corporate mergers and buyouts, according to sources close to the two companies.   On Friday, Kidder announced internally a reorganization of its investment banking division that sharply escalates its commitment to such merchant banking activities.   The sources said that the fund, voted on by G.E.'s board late last week, would be in excess of $2 billion, and would probably grow over time. Shift in Direction    These steps culminate an important shift in direction by both Kidder and G.E. It also pits them more directly against the other major players in merchant banking, which is becoming the hottest, and most competitive, area on Wall Street, even with the huge risks it involves.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1986
abstract: The World     Moscow ousted five Americans. The diplomats, according to Tass, were engaging in ''impermissible activities.'' The group of American diplomats was the largest expelled by Moscow at one time.  [ A1:6. ]   A flurry of U.S.-Soviet traffic   A8    An appeal for 2 dissidents

headline: A BRAZIL-ARGENTINA CAR GIANT
abstract: Despite the contrasting market conditions in Brazil, where new cars are in great demand, and in Argentina, where the automotive industry is in a slump, the Ford and Volkswagen subsidiaries in both countries have one thing in common: they are operating deeply in the red.   Hoping to forge strength out of weakness and, above all, profits out of losses, the two giant corporations announced plans in November to pool their resources and merge their subsidiaries in South America's two leading economies in what some industry analysts have described as a creative attempt to remain in business.   Owned 51 percent by Volkswagen and 49 percent by Ford, the new company will be known as Autolatina, potentially the world's 11th-largest car manufacturer, with a productive capacity of 900,000 vehicles a year, and a market share of 61 percent in Brazil and 34 percent in Argentina. The combined auto company will have assets worth $1.8 billion, annual sales of $4 billion and 75,000 employees working in 10 factories in Brazil and five in Argentina.

headline: Israeli Court Grants a Delay In Trial of Nazi Camp Guard
abstract: A three-judge panel agreed today to a four-week delay in the trial of a retired American autoworker accused of killing thousands of people as a guard in a Nazi death camp.   Justice Department spokesmen said the judges accepted a request from a lawyer for the defendant, John Demjanjuk, to postpone the war crimes trial from Jan. 19 to Feb. 16.

headline: MANILA WILL SHIFT DISSIDENT OFFICERS
abstract: The new Philippine Defense Minister said today that he would reassign rebellious officers associated with his predecessor and was investigating reports that a coup had been planned against President Corazon C. Aquino.   The minister, Rafael M. Ileto, said members of the military might face disciplinary action for their role in an apparently planned move against the Government on behalf of Juan Ponce Enrile, whom President Aquino dismissed as Defense Minister on Sunday.   Mrs. Aquino also said Sunday that she was giving the Communist insurgents seven days to agree to a truce. Communists Ready to Talk   Today, a Communist negotiator, Saturnino Ocampo, said in a television interview, ''With the removal of Enrile, we can meet with the Government panel again. As a matter of fact, we have sent word to meet very soon.''

headline: Platinum Again Drops As Gold Holds Steady
abstract: Platinum futures continued to slump on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, plunging $13 an ounce after a decline of $20 in the previous two sessions.   Traders said there was little news to provoke such a fall, but that speculators who follow trends on price charts seemed to be unloading the metal, pressing the price to its lowest level since mid-August.   Don Tierney, an analyst in New York with Stanley B. Bell, said platinum ''fell apart, taking out levels that were seen as key support.''

headline: STRONG GAIN POSTED BY APPLE
abstract: Buoyed by increased acceptance among business users and continued strength in educational sales, Apple Computer Inc. today reported a 46.9 percent increase in earnings for its fourth quarter ended Sept. 26.   For all of the fiscal year 1986, the company's net income more than doubled from depressed results of the previous year.   Another company in the computer business, Honeywell Inc., said yesterday that its quarterly profits were hurt by the slump in capital spending and fell nearly 42 percent.

headline: Israeli Leader Rejects Hint By Reagan of Role in Aid to Contras
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today publicly rejected President Reagan's apparent assertion that Israel helped to channel money to the Nicaraguan rebels.   Israeli officials were deeply disturbed by remarks attributed to President Reagan in an interview with Time magazine, in which Mr. Reagan suggested that an unnamed third country sold arms to Iran for a large profit and then knowingly put the excess cash in Swiss bank accounts controlled by the rebel leaders.   At first Israeli officials thought, and hoped, that the President was referring to Saudi Arabia. But after they ascertained from Israeli diplomats in the United States that he was referring to Israel, the Israeli officials sent a formal request for clarification from Washington late last night.

headline: JUSTICE CHIEF SEES NO HASENFUS PARDON
abstract: The Nicaraguan Justice Minister says he opposes any pardon for Eugene Hasenfus, the American air-cargo handler who was sentenced to 30 years in jail Saturday after admitting that he helped fly weapons to anti-Government rebels.   The minister, Rodrigo Reyes, served as chief prosecutor in the Hasenfus trial. In an interview distributed by the official Nicaraguan press agency today, he said he expected the United States to use ''maneuvers or reprisals'' to win ''the freedom of its agent.''

headline: 'Junk Bonds' Stir Concern
abstract: THE taint of scandal at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., now a central focus of the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading case, has alarmed many participants in the market for high-yielding, low-quality securities, or ''junk bonds,'' where prices declined steeply yesterday.   ''Prices were down two points across the board,'' said one official at Interactive Data, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation that evaluates bond prices for various investors.   The quality of the junk bonds held by investors is the same as before, but managers of mutual funds heavily invested in such issues are worried about the effects of unfavorable publicity about Drexel -the Wall Street leader in the trading and selling of such issues - and the junk-bond market. The ultimate result, they fear, could be shareholder redemptions, which could require the funds to sell bonds from their portfolio. A flurry of selling by bond funds, in turn, might depress prices even further, perhaps exacerbating the problem.

headline: Clabir-Atlantic Bid
abstract: The Clabir Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., and its General Defense Corporation subsidiary said they hold a 7.4 percent stake in the Atlantic Research Corporation ''as a step to acquire all of the outstanding shares'' of the diversified high-technology concern. Clabir said it had purchased all of its 559,200 Atlantic common shares on the open market, at prices ranging from $23 to $23.25 a share.

headline: MATCHING ISRAEL :SYRIAN GOAL SEEN AS UNLIKELY
abstract: Western diplomats based in Damascus say Syria appears unlikely to be able to achieve its stated goal of attaining strategic military parity with Israel in the foreseeable future.   ''The Israelis and the Syrians are simply on two different escalators,'' one diplomat said. ''They're both going up, but one, Israel, is going up much faster.''   Israeli officials have expressed fears that Syria is trying to approach military equality. They have cited several factors, including a speech by President Hafez al-Assad last February that declared strategic parity as a goal, and the replacement by Moscow of Syrian fighter planes and surface-to-air missiles destroyed during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982.

headline: F.B.I. Director Talks Of Reagan and Inquiry
abstract: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William H. Webster, said today that there was ''no indication'' that President Reagan failed to tell the truth about the sale of American weapons to Iran and the subsequent diversion of money to Nicaraguan rebel groups.   While noting that he was ''not in the position to make categorical statements,'' Mr. Webster said there was ''no indication that it's any different than what the President said.''   ''I'm just going on that basis,'' he added.   President Reagan has denied that he had any advance knowledge of the potentially illegal diversion of as much as $30 million to the rebels, known as contras, from the sale of arms to Iran. Mr. Webster's comments were made at a breakfast meeting with reporters.

headline: NOT ENOUGH, OPPOSITION SAYS
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid today proposed changes in electoral laws and a reorganization of Parliament that he said were aimed at greater democracy.   In response to a message to Parliament containing these proposals, an opposition coalition charged that the governing party was seeking to preserve its hold on the Government, and introduced its own proposals for changes.   The rival proposals are expected to be debated in coming weeks, but since the governing party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, has an overwhelming majority, its proposals are almost certain to become law.

headline: U.S. Official In GATT Job
abstract: Charles R. Carlisle, the chief United States negotiator on textile trade, today was named Deputy Director General of the 92-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

headline: Banks to Get Stake in Mexico's Alfa
abstract: In the largest restructuring of private-sector debt of Mexico's debt crisis, about five dozen foreign banks will acquire a majority stake in Grupo Industrial Alfa S.A., the nation's largest privately held conglomerate, according to Mexican Government and banking sources.   Under the complex arrangement, the creditor banks would also be paid $25 million in cash by Grupo Alfa and obtain $200 million in Mexican Government debt, known as United Mexican States paper, the sources said. Grupo Alfa would also be required to divest itself of an undisclosed number of companies that are not part of its core businesses.   In return for the stock, cash and Government bonds, the banks would forgive the conglomerate's $920 million in debts.

headline: Swiss Company Pledges 'Gigantic' Effort on Rhine
abstract: The chief executive of a Swiss chemical concern pledged today to organize and finance a ''gigantic'' campaign to clean up chemical damage to the Rhine River.   The executive, Marc Moret of Sandoz, said the company would call on environmentalists and technical experts for the project.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: An obituary in some editions on Monday about Kate Warmack McKay, a copyright reference librarian at New York University Law School, gave the day of her death incorrectly. It was Saturday, not Sunday.

headline: New President At Ashton-Tate
abstract: The Ashton-Tate Company said today that Luther J. Nussbaum had been named president and chief operating officer of the microcomputer software company based in Culver City, Calif.   Mr. Nussbaum, 39 years old, assumes those duties from Edward M. Esber Jr., who will remain chairman and chief executive. Mr. Nussbaum, who has worked in several senior executive positions at Businessland Inc. since 1983, will take his new positions at Ashton-Tate by Nov. 1, Mr. Esber said.

headline: Navy Seeking Competitive Bids
abstract: For the first time in memory, the Navy has spent more than half its annual procurement budget on contracts for which more than one supplier bid -an apparent sign that the disciplines of cost control are gaining ground in the Pentagon.   Rear Adm.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Company, elected Robert T. Budenbender senior executive vice president, Alan Langley to the additional post of treasurer and Ian Jardine deputy treasurer.    * Bloomingdale's named Dennis Shea senior vice president, finance.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A headline on Sept. 16 about the financial plight of the Muslim Mosque in Manhattan characterized its members incorrectly.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: USX to Shift Division's Assets
abstract: The USX Corporation, the old United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it was transferring most of the assets of its chemical division into a new company, the Aristech Chemical Corporation, and expected to raise between $500 million and $570 million from selling stock in the new company.   USX said the shares, to be sold by a group headed by Shearson Lehman Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company, would cost between $17 and $20 each and be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.   David M. Roderick, chairman, called it ''another major step in the company's longstanding restructuring program.''

headline: 116-DAY STRIKE AT USX AFFECTS ECONOMY LITTLE
abstract: For 116 days now, the steel operations of the USX Corporation have been idled, rivaling a strike in 1959 as the longest shutdown in the industry's history. But despite the closing of the nation's largest steel producer, there has apparently been little effect on the nation's economy.   To be sure, delivery patterns have been altered and customers have been inconvenienced by being forced to find alternate sources of steel. Still, the ready availability of steel amid the absence of USX - which commanded nearly a fifth of the market in the United States - underscores the dramatic overcapacity in the industry and illustrates anew what many analysts have long contended: There is simply too much steel being made in this country.

headline: Interest Rates Drop Modestly
abstract: The Treasury securities market benefited from expectations of good foreign demand and lower oil prices yesterday as interest rates fell modestly for short-term and long-term issues.   ''A generally optimistic feeling based on the strong dollar and weaker oil prices seems to have crept into the market in advance of the refunding,'' said one Treasury note trader.   The head of trading at another securities firm said, ''There was not much activity today, but the market was helped by lots of reports that the stronger dollar is encouraging foreign buying, and people are anticipating good demand at the upcoming Treasury auctions.'' New Seven-Year Notes    By late in the day, the 7 1/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2016 were offered at 94 22/32, up 19/32, to yield 7.71 percent. In advance of today's $7 billion auction of new seven-year Treasury notes, dealers in Government securities offered the issue on a when-issued basis with a yield of 7.16 percent, down from 7.24 percent Friday.

headline: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise
abstract: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds climbed yesterday, despite profit taking by day traders late in the session. Dealers said the cashing in of profits came after prices weakened just before the close of the Treasury bond futures market in Chicago.
