One result of the profit taking was that the key long Treasury bond, the 7.5 percent bond of 2116, traded late in the session at an offered price of 100.26, up 19/32 on the day.

headline: Closings for The Holiday
abstract: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges, banks, Government offices and most businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas.

headline: Carbide-GAF Accord Is Set
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, one of the nation's leading chemical companies, today signed an agreement with the GAF Corporation, which had tried to take over the company last year.   The two companies said that under the agreement, GAF would not buy any more shares in Union Carbide for 10 years.

headline: Advertising; Ground-Breaking Set For New Ogilvy Home
abstract: The Ogilvy Group's world headquarters will be moving crosstown in 1989. But William E. Phillips, chairman of the agency, plans to be at the ground-breaking ceremony at the old Madison Square Garden site, 49th Street and Ninth Avenue, along with the Mayor and William Zeckendorf Jr., tomorrow.   Ogilvy plans to occupy 15 of the 45 floors in the tower of the $500 million Zeckendorf complex.

headline: Hamilton Job Cuts
abstract: The Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corporation said it planned to eliminate about 1,000 jobs from its salaried work force during 1987.

headline: A Power Behind Offer For BankAmerica
abstract: For many years Richard C. Blum has been a behind-the-scenes power in San Francisco, not the least of the reasons being his marriage to Mayor Dianne Feinstein. But Mr. Blum's name hit the headlines this weekend with the news that he had made a proposal to raise $1 billion to try to help save the ailing BankAmerica Corporation.   Mr. Blum has said he offered to raise the money to help keep BankAmerica independent and in San Francisco. His proposal was made in early October, about 10 days before the board decided to replace the chief executive, Samuel H. Armacost, with A. W. Clausen. The decision to shift managers is seen as a rejection of other offers, although the new management might eventually decide to raise capital.

headline: Ex-Chemical Engineer Taking Bacardi Private
abstract: Managing a liquor business was a new challenge for Manuel L. del Valle when he became president of the Bacardi Corporation seven years ago, but he learned quickly. And when the San Juan, P.R., rum maker goes private in the near future, he will remain as president and chief executive.   Mr. Del Valle, a chemical engineer by trade, listed several reasons in a telephone interview for Bacardi's recent decision to buy up some of its stock in a tender offer and go private.

headline: Wall St. Saw a Tough 'Arab'
abstract: Ivan F. Boesky has become the symbol of a fast-money era: a time when high-stakes mergers make front-page news and turn Wall Street deal makers into multimillionaires.   And he has changed the face of arbitrage.   Through his relentless publicity campaigns, Mr. Boesky became a Wall Street superstar and put the spotlight on a business that had profited royally by remaining in Wall Street's shadows.   Now, by agreeing to pay a record $100 million fine for illegal insider trading, he has brought shame to himself, scandal to his industry and shattered the legend of a man whose financial skills seemed invincible. 'A Throwback'    ''Boesky is a throwback to the speculators of the 1920's,'' said Samuel L. Hayes 3d, investment banking professor at the Harvard Business School. ''He represents a new layer of arbitrage that is not traditional arbitrage, but is really speculation. He's been able to mobilize a great deal of money that looks for profitable deals.''

headline: Korea Crash Kills 3 Soldiers
abstract: Two helicopters collided today over western South Korea, burst into flames and then crashed, the police said. Three United States soldiers were killed and three others were reported injured in the accident, which occurred over the town of Sosan 65 miles southwest of Seoul. The bodies of the three Americans were burned beyond recognition, according to the police.

headline: American's Trial Ends In Yugoslav Court
abstract: The trial of an ethnic Albanian with dual United States-Yugoslav citizenship on charges of anti-Yugoslav activity and propaganda ended today and the verdict will be announced Wednesday, court sources said.

headline: SHAMROCK'S SLIDING FORTUNES
abstract: Be patient. That is Diamond Shamrock's request to investors as it continues to weigh an unsolicited $2.03 billion takeover bid from the oilman and corporate raider T. Boone Pickens. Today, the company said it had still not decided on its response but would meet again within a week.   But even before the Pickens bid, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation and William H. Bricker, the company's determined chairman, chief executive and president, had been asking for shareholders' indulgence. Ever since Mr. Bricker transformed the Cleveland chemical company into a Dallas-based oil and gas company in the early 1980's, he has had trouble making the restructuring pay off.   That does not necessarily indicate, however, that Shamrock is interested in being acquired. Early in 1985, for example, the company pulled out of a purchase by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, a deal that some on Wall Street viewed as a good deal for Shamrock, but not for Occidental.

headline: 3 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The South African police shot and killed three black men when a crowd stoned a security force vehicle in the township of Nzanany, near Bethal in Transvaal Province, the Government reported today.   One policeman was wounded in the incident and one black man arrested, the official Bureau for Information said in a report on racial and political unrest in the last 24 hours.

headline: IN A CRISIS, 'TELL IT ALL AND TELL IT FAST'
abstract: ''Communicating When Your Company Is Under Siege,'' by Marion K. Pinsdorf. Lexington Books, D.C. Heath & Co., Lexington, Mass. 171 pages, $21.95.    FIRED employees are not the only people who develop blinders about impending disaster; so too do business executives who think they can handle a corporate crisis by stonewalling or dissembling.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Am-law Newspaper Corporation to Korey, Kay & Partners for consumer and trade promotion of its nine-paper operations.

headline: Results Mixed For Retailers
abstract: Several of New York's largest retailers had average November sales gains of 5.2 percent in the city and 7 percent in suburban areas, compared with the comparable period of 1985, according to a spot-check of merchants on Friday.

headline: OPPOSITION BOYCOTTS BANGLADESH VOTE
abstract: Bangladesh held a presidential election today that was boycotted by the opposition to President H. M. Ershad but was still seen as strengthening his grip on the country after he lifts martial law, as he said he intends to do next month.   General Ershad has ruled Bangladesh since seizing power in a coup in 1982, but he has now formed his own political party and resigned as army Chief of Staff with the intention of winning a five-year term as the country's elected President.   Because of the opposition boycott, General Ershad was considered certain to be declared victor in the race even before the votes were counted. Early returns this evening showed him receiving 90 percent of the votes against 11 lesser known aspirants.

headline: Marsh in Deal For Lippincott
abstract: The Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc, the holding company for the world's largest insurance and reinsurance brokerage concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lippincott & Margulies, a pioneer in corporate identity consulting.

headline: Advertising; J. Walter Thompson Wins 6 Gold Medals
abstract: The J. Walter Thompson Company walked away from the International Film and TV Festival at the Sheraton Centre Hotel Friday night with six gold medals - four won by the New York office and one each by London and Tokyo.   Chiat/Day and DDB Needham Worldwide were good for five apiece, Yellowhammer of London got four and Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn not only took three but also was honored with the grand prize for best TV spot: the Pepsi-Cola ''Copier'' commercial starring Michael J. Fox.

headline: Pravda Says Kohl Tries To Revive Cold War
abstract: The Soviet Union fiercely criticized Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today, accusing him of showing hostility to Moscow and trying to revive the cold war.   The Communist Party newspaper Pravda, in an unsigned article equivalent to an official statement, said Mr. Kohl had poisoned relations between the two countries with ''indecent conduct'' and ''crude attacks on the Soviet leadership.''

headline: AQUINO TO APPEAL ON THE ECONOMY
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that her Government had completed the groundwork for an economic recovery and that it was now up to the private sector to become more active.   Speaking to a conference of business leaders, she said her economic policy emphasized private enterprise and told her listeners, ''It is now your turn at the bat.''   Though she said the Philippines' economic recovery could not be based on foreign aid, she said she was ''probably the most relieved person in this hall'' at the passage last week by the United States Senate of a $200 million aid package.   ''You can't imagine how much heartache that $200 million gave me,'' she said, referring to an initial rejection of the bill by the Senate. ''I was just so upset and so sick when people were saying, 'All Cory got was applause.' ''

headline: LIGHT WAVES ACROSS THE SEA
abstract: DEEP in the marshlands of New Jersey, engineers of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are piecing together the initial segments of the first trans-Atlantic underwater fiber-optic cable. When it is completed in 1988, at a cost of $335 million, the light-wave communication system will stretch 3,600 nautical miles from Tuckerton on the New Jersey shore to Britain and France, beginning a new era in trans-Atlantic data communications.   The fiber-optic cable system, called TAT 8, will be able to carry up to 40,000 simultaneous telephone conversations, more than twice the number of undersea circuits now available. In comparison, the newest undersea copper cable, TAT 7, built in 1983, can carry only about 9,000 calls.

headline: BEIRUT CHRISTIANS PURGE OPPONENTS
abstract: A widespread purge of opponents of the main militia commander in Christian parts of Lebanon has been going on for the last two weeks, and 60 men have been killed so far, according to reports published in the press here.   The reports, quoting the police and Christian religious sources, said the victims had been summarily executed, and that in one Christian village the local authorities had discovered a mass grave.   Bullet-riddled bodies have been found in several quarters of East Beirut and other Christian districts, the state-controlled press agency reported. It said two bodies were recovered Friday near a bridge in a northeastern suburb of the capital. This raised to 23 the number of victims discovered in the last 10 days, the agency said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Lomas & Nettleton In Deal for Mnet
abstract: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the country's largest mortgage banking concerns, said it had agreed to buy Mnet, a retail financial services company, for $300 million in cash and securities. The companies said that the deal was subject to approval of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

headline: AN ARTICLE BY KOCH FUELS A POLITICAL FIRE IN GREECE
abstract: An article by Mayor Koch accusing the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of being anti-American and anti-Semitic has caused widespread anger here. It has also been condemned as an intervention against the governing Socialist Party in local elections across Greece next Sunday.   The article, which appeared in The New York Post on Sept. 17, sharply denounced the Government's failure to announce where and when it will restore a statue of President Harry S. Truman to its Athens pedestal. The monument was blown up by leftists in March. Mr. Koch also attacked Mayor Dimitris Beis, a Socialist seeking re-election, for remarks about Jews.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Riding the Transport Index    The Dow Jones industrial average soared to a record 1,955.57 last Tuesday, unleashing optimistic predictions that the popular index would reach 2,000 within a few months.   But Gene Jay Seagle, vice president at Gruntal & Company, is basing his optimism about the stock market on the parallel rise of another index, the Dow transport average. The transportion index, made up of airlines, railroads and trucking, also broke a record last week, when it hit 858.84.   ''When the two indexes confirm one another, it means the economy is in balance,'' he said. It indicates that the output of factories represented by the industrial average is being distributed by industries covered in the transportation index - which means there's the expectation of continued growth.

headline: Marriott to Sell 198 Pizza Outlets
abstract: The Marriott Corporation said it had agreed to sell 198 Straw Hat Pizza restaurants to Pepsico Inc.'s Pizza Hut subsidiary.

headline: Canadian Entrepreneurs Get Information Center
abstract: Seeking to increase its role in the global information marketplace, Canada is building a $57 million information technology center where Canadian entrepreneurs and emerging companies can display their inventions and obtain financial, marketing and management advice. The center, called Exploracom, will also contain a large exhibition area where corporations that manufacture, market or use information technology can demonstrate its applications.

headline: Gillette Charge Is $190 Million
abstract: The Gillette Company, recently shaken by an unsuccessful takeover attempt by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's Revlon Group, said today that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $190 million in order to restructure.   The company said it would cut its work force, sell several small units and consolidate others.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Honda International Finance B.V. is issuing $70 million of 7 1/2 percent Eurobonds due in 1991 at 101 3/4, through Nikko Securities Co.

headline: Henri Bendel Gets New Chief
abstract: Mark Shulman's fast rise in the retail business shows no signs of slowing down.   The 37-year-old executive has been named president and chief executive of Henri Bendel, the 57th Street specialty store acquired last year by The Limited Inc. He replaces Geraldine Stutz, 62, who left in July after having been president since 1957 and who transformed the store into the symbol of New York chic.   Mr. Shulman comes to Bendel from Ann Taylor, a woman's specialty store that is a division of the Allied Stores Corporation.

headline: THE BINGHAMS, AFTER THE FALL
abstract: ON the Bingham estate overlooking the Ohio River outside Louisville, Ky., Barry Bingham Sr. and Barry Bingham Jr. live in houses separated by a short walk across a tended lawn. But each rarely crosses that short space to visit the other's home. ''It's like the green line in Beirut separating the Christians and the Moslems,'' said Joan Bingham, an in-law.   The father and his only living son have barely spoken since Barry Sr. announced last Jan. 9 his decision to sell the family's media empire, including The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspapers that had been in the family for nearly 70 years. Barry Jr., who had managed the enterprises for the last 15 years, denounced the sale as ''a betrayal'' and, almost overnight, the Binghams became a public archetype of a family destroyed in a struggle over business.   The year since then has been a period of lingering bitterness, grief and unrepentance. Barry Jr. crossed the lawn on Thursday to bring Christmas presents to his parents, a gesture he described as ''correct.'' The whole family has not gathered for Christmas since 1983, and this year will be no exception.

headline: CAPE COD POTATO CHIPS: A 'LUXURY' JUNK FOOD
abstract: Cape Cod Potato Chips are not sold in many places, but in the stores that carry the product, it is frequently the top-selling chip.   A thick and very crisp potato chip made by old-fashioned methods in this seaside resort town, Cape Cod Potato Chips are going the way of David's cookies, Ben & Jerry's ice cream, Dove Bars and other new versions of traditional snack foods that have recently risen from the ranks of junk food to the status of ''premium'' or ''gourmet'' treats. More Expensive Than Rivals    Like their counterparts in the ice cream, cookie and candy world, Cape Cod Potato Chips cost more than their competitors ($1.49 for a seven-ounce bag compared with, say, $1.29 for an eight-ounce bag of mass-produced potato chips); they are made without chemical additives (just potatoes and oil); and, to many, they taste better.   John O'Shaughnessy, a consumer behavior expert at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, says the chip company is part of a growing coterie of small food entrepreneurs tapping a special pocket of consumers willing and eager to treat themselves to a $2 piece of chocolate or $1.75 ice cream cone.   ''There are a lot of little luxury segments out there,'' Professor O'Shaughnessy said, ''and big manufacturers do not cater to them. They're not big enough.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1986
abstract: Companies    A.W. Clausen was chosen to lead BankAmerica, marking a return to the company that he left for a post at the World Bank. His selection by the board followed the resignation of Samuel H. Armacost on Friday.  [ Page A1. ]  Analysts said that even with the best of skill and luck, it will take years to revitalize the company that is the parent of the nation's second-largest bank.  [ D1. ]

headline: KEY ADVISERS ON THE PRINCIPAL ISSUES
abstract: Arms Control Group Paul H. Nitze: Ambassador and special adviser to the President and the Secretary of State on arms control matters . . . 79 years old . . . Arms control negotiator and member of United States teams at talks that led to the first strategic arms pact in 1972 . . . Opposed ratification of 1979 arms treaty.   Viktor P. Karpov: Head of Soviet Foreign Ministry's new Department on Arms Limitation and Disarmament . . . 57 years old . . . Involved in negotiations with the United States since 1970's . . . Was principal deputy, later chief negotiator, at strategic arms limitation talks in Geneva . . . Head of Soviet arms control delegation in 1982-83 . . . Given title of Ambassador at Large in 1984 . . . Has headed Soviet delegation at Geneva arms talks since 1985.

headline: SOVIET CANCER PATIENT AND MOTHER REUNITED IN U.S.
abstract: A cancer patient who has sought to leave the Soviet Union for eight years arrived in New York yesterday and, amid tears and bouquets of pink carnations, was reunited with the mother she thought she would never see again.   ''Mama, it's O.K.,'' the patient, Rimma Bravve, the 32-year-old emigre from Moscow, said as she brushed back tears and embraced her sobbing mother, Khanna Anbinder, 65 years old, a retired Rochester pediatrician who left the Soviet Union in 1980 after the death of her husband.   ''It is the happiest day of my life,'' Mrs. Bravve said at a crowded afternoon news conference later at Kennedy International Airport. Speaking in English, she added, ''I was waiting for this day to come for eight years.''

headline: Meese Defends Conduct of Justice Dept. Inquiry
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today vigorously defended the Justice Department investigation of the diversion of money from Iran to the Nicaraguan rebels. He disputed accusations that investigators had moved too slowly to preserve sensitive documents in the case.   Mr. Meese also indicated that he stood by earlier statements that only one White House aide appeared to have full knowledge of the diversion of funds paid by Iran for American arms. The aide, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, was dismissed from the National Security Council staff last week.

headline: U.S.-SALVADORAN TIES CALLED STRAINED
abstract: Public disclosures about El Salvador's involvement in supplying arms to the Nicaraguan rebels have strained relations between the United States and the Salvadoran Government and jeopardized future efforts to aid the rebels, according to officials of both countries.   El Salvador is one of several countries in Central America that have been helping the rebels. American officials said the effort had been expected to continue as the United States gears up to deliver $100 million in aid.   But Salvadoran and American officials said El Salvador's help was likely to be cut, at least temporarily. Officials said El Salvador's dependence on American aid would eventually force it to resume support of the rebels.

headline: Kentucky Chicken
abstract: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it and Pepsico Inc. closed the previously announced sale of Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation to Pepsico for about $840 million.

headline: Tax-Exempt Dealers See a Test in Illinois
abstract: Securities dealers in the tax-exempt market are watching closely a $111.05 million bond financing by the Illinois Scholarship Commission because interest on the bonds is subject to the alternative minimum tax on personal incomes.   The bond issue, which was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, is the largest sale to date of tax-exempt bonds that are tainted by the possibility of taxation under rules of the new tax bill approved by Congress.   Yields for the new issue range from 4.5 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.2 percent in 1991, 7 percent in 1996 and 7.2 percent in 1998. Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bonds are backed by government-guaranteed student loans.

headline: U.S. Financings Limited to Bill Sale
abstract: Today's regular weekly auction of Treasury bills is the only government sale scheduled this week, leaving government securities dealers free to concentrate on distributing the $29 billion of notes and bonds auctioned last week.   In advance of today's bill auctions, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 5.46 percent, while the six-month issue was at 5.56 percent.   Looking ahead, the Treasury is expected to auction two note issues this month besides the regular weekly bill sales. Based on the Treasury's regular financing schedule, government securities dealers expect the regular monthly issue of two-year notes to be announced next Wednesday and auctioned on Nov. 19. On the day of the two-year auction, they expect the Treasury to announce a five-year note issue for sale the following week.

headline: A FAMILY'S REJOICING IS TEMPERED...
abstract: The family of David P. Jacobsen celebrated his release today, but relatives said their joy was tempered by thoughts of the six Americans who are still missing and their lack of confidence that the Reagan Administration has done all it could to obtain their release.   Mr. Jacobsen's son Eric told a group of reporters in front of his home: ''I think we have to look at how long it takes to get the other hostages out. We want to make sure that people just don't celebrate my father's homecoming and then forget about those other men.''   Eric Jacobsen, 30 years old, has previously accused Washington of a lack of effort in obtaining his father's release. Even when he was notified by the State Department at 1:30 A.M. today that his father had been released, Mr. Jacobsen said he was not confident the information was correct.

headline: Realignment at Turner
abstract: Ted Turner, the chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System, has reorganized the management of the company, giving greater authority to a five-member executive committee, according to one board member.   The move, according to a source close to Mr. Turner, will formally recognize a management structure that has been in place for several months. The new management team will take responsibility for finance, programming and marketing.

headline: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON ROAD TAX
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments by the trucking industry that Pennsylvania and several other states are exacting discriminatory taxes from out-of-state trucks, in violation of the Constitution's protection of interstate commerce.   The Court will hear a challenge to past and present Pennsylvania taxes that the plaintiffs say were ''manipulated'' to place a disproportionate burden on trucks registered outside the state. The current state ''axle tax'' of $36 per truck axle raises about $68 million a year.

headline: NO XEROX MOVE YET ON PRETORIA
abstract: The Xerox Corporation, citing the need for further study, declined today to say whether it would sell its South African operations and join the exodus of major corporations from the country.   The photocopier, printing, computer and financial services conglomerate said last May that it would decide by year-end whether to sell its South Africa operations. But today it said no decision had yet been reached and declined to say when one would be.

headline: Afghans Shake Up 2 Cabinet Ministries
abstract: The Afghan radio announced a Government shake-up today, including the demotion of the Foreign Minister in an apparent move by the country's leader, Najibullah, to strengthen his control.   The radio said Brig. Gen. Mohammad Rafi had been appointed Defense Minister to replace Col. Gen. Nazer Mohammad, who was promoted to First Deputy Prime Minister.

headline: GERMAN VIEW CITED
abstract: Dealers in foreign currency resumed selling dollars yesterday and buying West German marks after an official of the Bundesbank said that the recent European interventions were aimed at softening the dollar's decline, not reversing it.   Moreover, Klaus Koehler, a director of the West German central bank and a leading European economist, told a group of bankers that no moves would be taken to arrest further declines in the dollar as long as the currency markets remained orderly.   Yesterday, the dollar finished lower in Europe and was down against all major currencies, except the Canadian dollar, in American trading. Tokyo Market Closed    The orderliness and light trading in yesterday's markets was attributed to the fact that many dealers in New York had closed their books for the three-day Columbus Day weekend. Also, the Tokyo market was closed yesterday for a holiday. As a result, few London dealers were taking positions.

headline: REXNORD PLAN SETS RESTRUCTURING
abstract: Rexnord Inc., a Milwaukee-based maker of industrial components and equipment, said yesterday that its board had approved an estimated $500 million recapitalization plan and a restructuring program aimed at increasing shareholder return and employee ownership.   Under the plan, each share of Rexnord common stock would be exchanged for $20 cash and one new common share in the recapitalized company.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article in Business Day on Monday about a company that designs mountains for skiing misidentified the owner of Vail Associates Inc., the Colorado ski resort. It is owned by Gillette Group Inc. of Nashville, which is primarily a communications company, not the Gillette Company, which produces personal care products.

headline: FIAT BESTS FORD IN BID FOR ALFA
abstract: Italy's largest privately held corporation, Fiat S.p.A, won the battle for control of Alfa Romeo S.p.A. today, defeating a bid from the Ford Motor Company.   The two state enterprises through which the Italian Government owns Alfa, announced this afternoon that their boards had voted unanimously to accept Fiat's offer to fully purchase the debt-ridden auto maker.   Fiat executives said they proposed an investment of about 8 trillion lire, or $5.7 billion, to purchase Alfa's assets, pay its debts and turn around its fortunes.

headline: U.N. Asks Independence For New Caledonia
abstract: Over strong French objections, the General Assembly adopted a resolution today placing New Caledonia on a list of ''non-self-governing territories.'' The vote was 89 to 24.

headline: NEW TRUMP PLAN: MAKE 2 BUILDINGS LOOK LIKE 1
abstract: Against all the odds, Donald Trump is getting his way - sort of - at the corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Central Park South.   The real estate developer owns two buildings there - 100 Central Park South, a 15-story rent-regulated building, and the former Barbizon Plaza Hotel, a 38-story Art Deco structure that wraps around the rental. He bought the two in 1981 with the hope of tearing them down and erecting one typically Trumpian structure of palatial proportions.   But he gave up that strategy when tenants in the rental fought to a standstill his efforts to evict them. His solution? To sink a ''monumental'' sum, as one assistant put it, into making the two buildings look like one grand new building. A model of the renovation, designed by Frank Williams Associates & Architects in Manhattan, shows the exterior of the buildings tied together with the same pale beige hue, identical windows and gold trim.

headline: A Religious Issue
abstract: To the Editor:   No other article in the business section specifies the religious beliefs of the personalities involved. Why, then, is it necessary to specify that these two men are Jewish but not whether others are Catholic or Protestant or Mormon business leaders?  I. HERBERT GORDON  New York, Sept. 14  An Editor's Note on this subject appears today in section 1, page 3.

headline: Canada Plans to End Sanctions Against Soviet
abstract: Canada plans to lift the limited sanctions it imposed against the Soviet Union six years ago after Soviet troops swept into Afghanistan, because the sanctions have not worked, Joe Clark, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, has announced.   Mr. Clark said Wednesday that the Government would meet with Soviet officials to renew scientific, technical, educational and cultural ties.

headline: Advertising; 'Ideas' Help Appliance Campaign
abstract: TODAY Black & Decker will start the television wave of its $11 million fourth-quarter assault on consumer consciousness and next month the $6 million in print.   This will all be on behalf of its household products division (recent acquisitions from General Electric) because Ken Homa, vice president-marketing of the division, wants to change a traditionally push-through marketing category to a pull-through one. It happens to be more lucrative for both the manufacturer and the retailer, if you need a reason.

headline: MANILA PROHIBITS A VISIT BY MARCOS
abstract: The Cabinet of President Corazon C. Aquino decided in a special meeting today to prevent the return of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos for the funeral of his sister, who died Sunday, and his expressed desire to spend Christmas here.   The presidential spokesman, Teodoro Benigno, also indicated that Mr. Marcos might be arrested should he decide to return.   As a precaution, the general manager of Manila International Airport put airport security on ''red alert'' today to prevent the former President from entering. Airport operations, however, were normal.

headline: NICARAGUANS EXPECT WAR TO WORSEN
abstract: Unaccustomed to living in fear of the future, Nicaraguans prepared for Christmas this year amid a tense calm that many believe cannot last.   For people here, the reality of the United States-supported guerrilla war is inescapable. It permeates life from the capital to the most remote settlements.   The coming months, diplomats and military officers agree, will be crucial to the contending armies and increasingly difficult for ordinary citizens.

headline: New Chief Elected At Kaneb Services
abstract: Kaneb Services Inc., announced yesterday that John R. Barnes had been elected president and chief executive of the Houston-based energy services company. Mr. Barnes, formerly president of the Stanton Oil Company in Dallas, replaces James R. Whatley, who as chairman of Kaneb had assumed the additional posts on an interim basis.   Kaneb, which owns 81 percent of Kaneb Energy Partners Ltd., a publicly traded limited partnership, has sold a number of non-energy assets in recent years. Through a series of divestitures, which included two petroleum engineering concerns and a Kentucky coal-mining unit last year, the concern has pared its long-term debt to about $155 million, from $375 million in 1984, according to Robert T. Pando, a company spokesman.

headline: BEIJING TO OFFER VOTERS A CHOICE IN CITY ELECTION
abstract: In a dramatic change in the way local elections are held in Beijing, the city government announced today that there would be more than one candidate for each seat in municipal elections.   It did not explain, however, how candidates would be nominated or how any election campaign would be conducted.   ''In order to promote democracy and in order to give the people the opportunity to select the candidates that they will be satisfied with, this time the election will have more candidates than slots available,'' She Diqing, a deputy chairman of the standing committee of the Municipal People's Congress, said in a speech to the committee. Student Protests Banned    The announcement, which appeared in Beijing Daily, follows an official crackdown on the wave of student demonstrations that have swept across China demanding wider democracy. On Friday, the standing committee issued a set of rules that in effect banned any public protest by students in the capital.

headline: HOPE VOICED ON THE REMAINING HOSTAGES
abstract: The Anglican go-between in the Lebanon hostage affair said today that there were ''reasonably strong'' expectations that the release of two more Americans held there might be imminent.   The envoy, Terry Waite, said he expected his Middle Eastern contacts to give him information about a possible release of Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, and Thomas M. Sutherland, dean of agriculture at the American University, ''in the next 24 hours.''   Mr. Waite, a special emissary of the Archbishop of Canterbury, came to Wiesbaden on Monday accompanying David P. Jacobsen, 55 years old, the former director of the American University Hospital in Beirut.   Mr. Jacobsen met members of his family in an emotional reunion after his release from nearly 17 months of captivity.

headline: LAWSUIT DISMISSED ON SHIP THAT STRUCK MINE
abstract: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that sought $1.6 million from the United States Government in connection with a Norwegian cargo ship that was damaged by a mine two years ago in a Nicaraguan harbor.   The owner of the ship and a Norwegian insurance concern had filed the suit on the ground that the Central Intelligence Agency had negligently and maliciously mined the harbor with President Reagan's approval. The Reagan Administration has been supporting rebel forces against the regime in Nicaragua.

headline: Chrysler, A.M.C. Deny Sale Report
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation denied reports in The Detroit Free Press that Chrysler was planning to buy assets of A.M.C., most likely A.M.C.'s assembly plants in Wisconsin and Ohio.

headline: Stock Alerts
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Buying Mutual Funds in a Scary Market'' (Sept. 21) stated that ''Shortly before the market dropped, the Telephone Switch Newsletter . . . told its readers to sell all of their stock funds.''

headline: AMERICAN IS SEIZED, BEIRUT GROUP SAYS
abstract: A Lebanese underground group said today that it had kidnapped another American, and asserted that he is an intelligence agent working for the United States and Israel.   In a statement in Arabic delivered to the West Beirut office of a Western news agency, a group calling itself the Revolutionary Justice Organization said it had abducted the American, Edward Austin Tracy. There were no independent witnesses to the incident.   In other developments today, a land mine apparently planted by French forces exploded in the garden of their abandoned embassy in Moslem-dominated West Beirut, wounding two French guards, and Lebanese radio reported that the British Government announced that it has withdrawn half its diplomats from Lebanon and that Portugal announced that it is closing its embassy in Beirut.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Youth and Taxes    President Reagan is expected to sign the tax bill into law tomorrow. But D. Quinn Mills, professor at Harvard University's graduate school of business, is one of the die-hard minority of economists who say he should veto it.   The bill may be revenue-neutral, says Mr. Mills, but its psychological effect on workers, especially the youngest ones, is decidedly negative.

headline: Documents Are Stolen At Latin Study Center
abstract: The head of a group that has investigated American activities in Latin America said today that documents linked to weapons shipments in Central America were stolen and files ransacked during a weekend burglary at the group's office here.   The official, Robert E. White, a former United States Ambassador to El Salvador and head of the International Center for Development Policy, said politics appeared behind the weekend burglary.

headline: President of Reliance Is Credited With Gains
abstract: John C. Morley, a career executive with the Exxon Corporation whose experience was in oil and chemicals, was given a formidable assignment in 1980: to go to Cleveland and run the Reliance Electric Company.   Exxon had purchased Reliance for $1.2 billion in 1979 amid strong criticism. The oil companies were cash-rich at the time and were making acquisitions outside oil. Mobil bought Marcor, Indiana Standard bought Kennecott and Exxon bought Reliance, to name a few such purchases. It was up to the oil companies to show that they could manage such diverse operations.

headline: SALVADOR REBEL DEFENDS THE USE OF LAND MINES
abstract: A Salvadoran guerrilla leader today defended the insurgents' use of land mines, saying they had proved to be an effective weapon against Government forces.   ''A propaganda campaign has been launched because of the use of mines, trying to make it a human rights issue,'' said Shafik Handal, one of the top commanders in the Salvadoran guerrilla movement. ''This campaign is aimed at forcing us to renounce a weapon that has been very important for us.''

headline: The U.N. Today: Dec. 9, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M.

headline: CAPTIVE AMERICAN RECALLED AS SEEKER OF ADVENTURE
abstract: Eugene Hasenfus, the American captured by the Nicaraguan Government while aiding rebels there, was described today as a tall, red-haired adventurer who loved the outdoors and had a strong sense of competition.   Friends and relatives across northern Wisconsin, the home area of the 45-year-old Mr. Hasenfus, expressed shock today that the laid-off construction worker was apparently involved in a clandestine supply operation in Central America.   His wife, Sally, who is a real estate agent in Marinette, Wis., near here, flew to Managua, Nicaragua, today in the hope of being allowed to see her husband. The Hasenfuses have three children.

headline: HOLIDAY AIR BOOKINGS SHOW SHARP INCREASES
abstract: Attracted by sharply discounted fares and longer holiday weekends, travelers are booking flights on most major carriers for the Thanksgiving-to-New Year's period in much greater numbers than last year.   Such large carriers as United, American and Delta say they expect to fly planes at capacity during the peak holiday periods even though some have added large numbers of flights. The bookings are up 10 to 15 percent at some airlines, a dramatic gain by industry standards, especially for holiday periods, when airlines have always been able to book flights closer to capacity.   For some travelers who did not book months in advance, getting a reservation on short notice is proving frustrating, forcing some people to travel on Thanksgiving morning and come back early on Friday and Saturday when seats are still available.

headline: French Link Lebanese To Strasbourg Attack
abstract: A French judge has formally accused George Ibrahim Abdallah, the Lebanese extremist whose imprisonment prompted terror bomb attacks here two months ago, of involvement in the attempted murder of an American diplomat in Strasbourg in 1984, it was announced today.   The charge will be added to two others already made against Mr. Abdallah, who is expected to stand trial here early next year.

headline: ISRAELI ARMS DEALER DENIES PROFITING IN SALE
abstract: One of the Israeli arms traders reported to have been at the center of Israel's dealings with Teheran publicly denied today that he had made any profits by shipping American weapons to Iran and insisted he had acted solely on ''humanitarian'' grounds.   Yaacov Nimrodi, a former colonel in military intelligence and a military attache in Teheran for 10 years, said he had become involved in the Iran affair only at the request of the Israeli Government and exclusively for the purpose of freeing American hostages in Lebanon.   Mr. Nimrodi made the comments in a prepared statement, which he sent to Israeli newspapers and read over the state radio. He refused to answer any questions after issuing the statement, the first he has made to the press since his name was connected with the Iran affair several weeks ago.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: DEFENSE MINISTER AT SUPREME SOVIET
abstract: Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov, who missed key meetings because of illness, showed up today for the opening of the fall session of the Supreme Soviet.   Mr. Sokolov, who is 75 years old, missed the Revolution Day parade across Red Square on Nov. 7, fueling rumors that he was ill. Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, later confirmed that Mr. Sokolov had been ailing.

headline: House Panel Studies Whether Pentagon Was Adequately Paid for Arms
abstract: The House Armed Services Committee is investigating whether the Pentagon was adequately compensated for the American weapons that were transferred from Army stocks and eventually sold to Iran.   Representative Les Aspin, the Democratic chairman of the committee, said there appeared to be discrepancies in Administration statements about what weapons were sent and what funds were paid to the Pentagon.   ''Something looks wrong,'' he said. ''The numbers do not add up.'' According to Administration officials, 2,008 TOW anti-tank missiles and parts for batteries of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles were taken from Army stocks and sold to the Central Intelligence Agency for $12 million. These weapons were later sold to Iran for much more, and a profit of as much as $30 million was made.

headline: CHINESE OFFICIALS CRITICIZE PROTESTS
abstract: For the first time since the outbreak of pro-democracy student demonstrations four weeks ago, senior Chinese leaders were quoted by name today as denouncing the protesters.   In addition, for the first time students were threatened with jail if they persist in their protests.   Meanwhile, in the bitter predawn cold this morning, university students in Beijing, after six days of quiet, and despite a ban on public demonstrations without a police permit, marched on snow-covered streets with calls for greater democracy.  [  United Press International reported that some of the students marched with torches - brooms dipped in some sort of flammable liquid - and drums. ]  Everywhere in the university district, which is in the northwest corner of the city, policemen roamed the streets in cars and vans.

headline: China Reports Jailing 4 Spies From Taiwan for Up to 8 Years
abstract: China announced jail sentences of up to eight years today for a Taiwan spy who threatened to blow up the site of the Canton Trade Fair and four other convicted agents.   The official New China News Service said one spy, a member of a criminal gang in Hong Kong, went to Canton in 1983 after joining a Taiwan spy organization.

headline: Japan Air Sets Boeing Deal
abstract: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it had agreed to buy 11 airplanes from the Boeing Company for $870 million.   The company exchanged letters of intent with Boeing to buy the airplanes last month, but announced the agreement today after a Japanese newspaper carried an article about the purchase.

headline: Jewish Student Slain In Jerusalem's Old City
abstract: A Jewish student was stabbed to death today near the seminary he attended in the Old City of Jerusalem, and three Arab suspects were arrested, the police said.

headline: PROTESTS BY STUDENTS SPREAD TO BEIJING
abstract: Street protests by students calling for democracy spread to the capital tonight.   Several thousand students from Qinghua University in Beijing poured into the streets in below-freezing temperatures demanding an end to authoritarianism and urging the granting of democratic rights for the Chinese people.   The rally in Beijing, which included a march through the city's northern university districts was the first time this city's students have publicly joined the wave of student protests that has erupted in at least six cities in China over the last three and a half weeks. Catalogue of Students    Demonstrations held in Shanghai in the last week were are the largest to take place in China since the end of the cultural revolution in 1976.

headline: PATENTS; Patent Office Security
abstract: The Patent and Trademark Office is modifying its practice in security controls to follow those of the Department of Defense.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Labor Force Rates Differ
abstract: White, black and Hispanic men, aged 55 to 64, have different labor force participation rates. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, for white men in that age group, the rate dropped to 69 percent last year, from 79 percent in 1973.

headline: G.M. Announces Layoffs
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would indefinitely lay off about 500 hourly workers who build engines at its Flint, Mich., operations, effective next month. The company said the layoffs were linked to the end of production of the Chevrolet Chevette subcompact car at G.M.'s Lakewood, Ga., assembly plant on Dec. 23.

headline: ITT Planning New York Layoffs
abstract: The ITT Corporation, as expected, said it planned to cut by more than half the 850 jobs at its New York headquarters, including clerical employees and executives. The staff cutbacks, which were expected, are intended to save the company about $50 million a year.

headline: A Flurry Of Account Switches
abstract: THE chemistry that causes major disconnections in nature in the autumn seems also to be affecting adland.   Last week ended with a flurry of accounts finding new resting places after having come loose from their previously firm anchorages.

headline: Wall St. Nervously Expects More Insider Shoes to Drop
abstract: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -    Wall Street was awash today with rumors that as many as 40 to 50 subpoenas are outstanding in the Government's insider trading investigation, and that a prominent investment banker would be the next to be charged in a widening scandal.   As stock prices fell on fears of imminent new disclosures from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. took the unusual step of rebutting rumors that Michael R. Milken, head of Drexel's ''junk bond'' operation, was leaving the firm. Both Drexel and a number of its employees, reportedly including Mr. Milken, have received Government subpoenas requesting information.   The rumors became so pervasive that Robert E. Linton, Drexel's chairman, issued a statement calling them ''absolutely ridiculous.''

headline: USX-ICAHN TALKS HELD AGAIN
abstract: Representatives of Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, met in Pittsburgh yesterday with officials of the USX Corporation, the company said.   William E. Keslar, a spokesman for the energy and steel giant, said the discussions were intended to further ''clarify'' Mr. Icahn's $31-a-share, $8 billion proposal to buy the company. Mr. Keslar added that the talks were also intended to cover whether Mr. Icahn would be allowed to look at USX's financial records.   The company, formerly called the United States Steel Corporation, declined to discuss the outcome of the talks and Mr. Icahn did not return telephone calls yesterday.

headline: Impressive Backers At Wellsford Group
abstract: Edward Lowenthal and Jeffrey H. Lynford have formed the Wellsford Group, a private real estate investment firm with some impressive financial backers.   Wellsford's major shareholders include the founders of Wesray Capital, William E. Simon and Raymond G. Chambers, and two principals of Eastdil Realty Inc., Benjamin V. Lambert, chairman, and Joel M. Goldfrank, president.   Wesray is a leading firm engaged in leveraged buyouts of companies and Eastdil is a big real estate investment company.

headline: Toro Assignments Given To Campbell-Mithun
abstract: The Minneapolis office of Campbell-Mithun, a subsidiary of Ted Bates, which is a subsidiary of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, has become the ad agency for a number of assignments from its Minneapolis neighbor, the Toro Company.   The job involves products of the new Home Improvement division, which will be spending about $2 million to promote its outdoor appliances, such as string trimmers, leaf blowers and Christmas tree lights.

headline: DOUBT ON FED RATE-CUT MOVE
abstract: Although the Federal Reserve suddenly has new flexibility to spur further declines in interest rates, it is likely to move slowly, if at all, to do so, market analysts and economists said today.   While they agreed that Japan's decision Friday to cut its discount rate to 3 percent gave the Federal Reserve more maneuvering room, they said recent signs of a pickup in the American economy probably made it unnecessary for the central bank to adopt a more expansionary monetary policy.   ''I don't think they're going to do anything,'' said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor who is now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade group. ''The Fed is looking at signs of improvement in the economy.''

headline: OFFICIALS SAY C.I.A. KNEW LITTLE OF IRAN WHEN ARMS SALES STARTED
abstract: The United States began its covert arms shipments to Iran despite scant American intelligence about its internal political situation, according to Government officials.   The officials said that from the fall of Shah Riza Pahlevi until mid-1985, when the covert dealings were first discussed, the Central Intelligence Agency failed to develop any agents with access to the inner circle of Iranian politics. ''We have had nothing going in Iran,'' said one Administration official.   One indication that the C.I.A. had little in the way of Iran experts on its staff was that the agency was forced to summon out of retirement an operative who spoke Persian to work on the covert project. The former agency employee, who was paid $40,000, was involved in some of the most sensitive aspects of the project. He traveled with Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, when he went to Teheran in May for meetings with Iranian officials, according to a one source.

headline: Times Co. Adds Director
abstract: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., president of the American Express Company, became a member of the board of directors of The New York Times Company yesterday, according to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman. The appointment increased the membership of the board to 13.

headline: Michigan Thrift Merger
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had approved the merger of the Family Federal Savings and Loan Association of Saginaw, Mich., into the Heritage Federal Savings Bank of Taylor, Mich. Family has $361.4 million in assets, while Heritage has $519.3 million in assets. The Bank Board said that to aid the transaction, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation had injected an unspecified amount of cash into Heritage and had indemnified Heritage against undisclosed liabilities at Family Savings and any litigation challenging the merger.

headline: BankAmerica Suitor Is Busy
abstract: The First Interstate Bancorp has begun talks with Citicorp and possibly some other banks that might be interested in buying assets that First Interstate would want to sell if it gains control of BankAmerica, banking sources said.   Having buyers ready for such things as overlapping branches would help First Interstate complete its acquisition quickly, one source said.

headline: Group Raises Stake in Mesa
abstract: The Baupost Group Inc., an investment partnership based in Cambridge, Mass., said Friday that it had raised its stake in the Mesa Petroleum Company to 8.7 percent, or more than 5.9 million shares, from 7.1 percent.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adams-Russell Co., Waltham, Mass., an operator of cable television systems, appointed Neil R. McHugh president and chief operating officer, replacing John J. Lynch, the acting president.    * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., named as directors Martin S. Davis, chairman and chief executive of Gulf and Western Inc.; Sherry L. Lansing, partner of an independent film production company, and Reuben Mark, chairman and chief executive at Colgate-Palmolive Co.    * Baldor Electric Co., Fort Smith, Ark., named Quentin D. Ponder president and chief operating officer, succeeding William T. Kirkpatrick, who will retire at year-end.

headline: 2 Americans Die Off Senegal
abstract: A DC-7 plane crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off Senegal today, killing two Americans and injuring a third, a spokesman at the United States Embassy said.

headline: Choosing Investigators: Outside the Public Eye
abstract: During the next few weeks a handful of people, operating out of the public eye and following no set procedures, will select individuals destined to become key participants in the unfolding drama of the Iran affair.   Three semiretired Federal judges have free rein to choose the independent counsel who will take charge of the criminal investigation.   The leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives will choose the members of the special investigating committees that will do much to shape public perceptions of the affair. The highly visible proceedings could also shape the careers of the panels' members.

headline: Britain in Talks To Sell Off Rover
abstract: The British Government said it was talking to two concerns about a possible bid for Rover, its ailing truck and van manufacturer. Trade and Industry Minister Paul Channon told Parliament that Rover, the Government-run concern formerly known as British Leyland, was in the early stages of negotiations with Paccar Inc., a Bellevue, Wash.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1986
abstract: Companies     A group headed by Revlon made a bid for Gillette. The offer, of $65 a share, or a total of about $4 billion, comes after weeks of heavy stock activity. The announcement came in today's newspapers after heavy buying of Gillette stock yesterday.  [ Page D1. ]    Borg-Warner faces a new takeover threat. GAF disclosed that it owned 4.9 percent of the huge industrial concern plus an option to buy 4.7 percent more. Already, the investor Irwin L. Jacobs has said he owns 7.4 percent of Borg-Warner.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: CHERNOBYL CAUSING BIG REVISIONS IN GLOBAL NUCLEAR POWER POLICIES
abstract: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster is leading to major reappraisals of reactor safety and emergency planning around the world, even for nuclear plants far different from the ruined Soviet unit, nuclear experts say.   Despite statements soon after the April 26 accident that it involved a reactor design different from Western units, experts are now concluding that Chernobyl in fact has important lessons for all nuclear power plants.   This conclusion is evident in a flurry of recent international conferences and local meetings, in a variety of reports on the accident and in dozens of interviews with reactor safety experts. Governments, the nuclear industry, research laboratories and many other groups are assessing the accident. Deadly Potential Realized    It has long been agreed that nearly all reactors have the theoretical potential, albeit a very low one, for a disaster on the scale of Chernobyl. Now that this potential has been realized in one case, the experts now have more solid ground for worry that such an event could be repeated.

headline: Market Place; Hopes for Food Wholesalers
abstract: THE major food wholesalers have enjoyed steadily rising profits in recent years, but even this conservative, low-profile industry is not immune to bumps along the road. Last week, for example, shares of the Fleming Companies sold at a two-year low of 31 - down from their record high of 44 7/8 in the spring. Yesterday, the stock dipped 3/8, to 32 7/8, on the New York Stock Exchange.   Fleming's management has forecast that third-quarter profits will drop to 40 cents a share, from 56 cents in the period a year earlier, reflecting the Southwest's sagging economy, among other factors. Also contributing to the earnings decline, analysts said, was the assimilation of two recent acquisitions of cooperative wholesalers in California and Arizona.

headline: Sea Captain in Refugee Case Is Billed $46,000 by Canada
abstract: The West German sea captain suspected of dropping 155 Tamil refugees from Sri Lanka off the Newfoundland coast in August has received a bill for $46,000 from the Canadian immigration authorities, his lawyer was quoted as saying Friday.   The Globe and Mail newspaper here quoted the lawyer as having said in an interview from Hamburg that the captain, Wolfgang Bindel, had no intention of paying the bill, which is for the cost of processing and looking after the Tamils in the first few days after they were picked up from lifeboats.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1986
abstract: G.M.'s Plant Closings    G.M. will shut 11 U.S. plants that employ about 29,000 people. The auto company said it was also studying the closing of other assembly, stamping, engine and component facilities. The cutbacks had been expected, but the size surprised some analysts. G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, said the efforts would help make G.M. more competitive. The company has lost market share in recent years and has been under pressure to lower costs.  [ Page A1. ]    Michigan will be stung severely by the closings. Seven of the plants to be closed are in the state. Officials in other states also expressed concern about the effect on related businesses and in the communities around the plants.  [ D10. ]

headline: INDIA-PAKISTAN PACT AIMS AT SIKH ISSUE
abstract: Indian and Pakistani officials reached an agreement today to step up coordination of their border security forces to prevent Sikh extremists from using Pakistan territory as a base for attacks in India.   The agreement, reached after two days of talks, was highly limited in scope, but it nonetheless marked the first time in a year that the two nations had found common ground on any steps to reduce tensions.   Relations had seriously worsened in recent months as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India repeatedly charged that Pakistan was aiding Sikh militants. A few weeks ago, he said that India could easily send its troops into Pakistan to wipe out supposed extremist ''training camps,'' but that it had not done so because it would violate international law.

headline: Lucky May Be Selling Gemco
abstract: Lucky Stores Inc., in a move to deflect an unfriendly bid from Asher B. Edelman, is negotiating to sell its troubled Gemco unit to the Dayton Hudson Corporation, Wall Street sources said yesterday.   Mr. Edelman, a New York investor, urged the California-based retail and specialty chain to halt any pending sale and meet with him to discuss a sweetened deal.

headline: U.S. LINKS SYRIA TO A DEFENDANT IN AN ARMS-SMUGGLING CASE
abstract: A man charged with conspiring to sell an advanced air navigational tracking system to countries in the Middle East had a contact in the Syrian Embassy here, a United States undercover agent testified today.   Special Agent Donald Bludworth of the United States Customs Service said Kevin Gilday, who was arrested Tuesday, identified his contact as Souha Jamili, a Syrian Embassy official whom he met in Damascus.   Mark Biros, a Federal prosecutor, told United States Magistrate Jean Dwyer that the State Department has confirmed that Ms. Jamili has been assigned to the Syrian Embassy since 1982.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: Because of an editing error, a report in the Agenda column yesterday about the pending trial of David Fillyaw, accused in an attack on a Columbia University student, incorrectly described the charges against him. Mr. Fillyaw is charged with attempted murder, attempted rape, assault, burglary and criminal possession of a weapon.

headline: Associated Dry Goods Gets Fourth Resignation
abstract: A fourth former top executive of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation has resigned after the recent acquisition of Associated by the May Department Stores Company.   James M. Guinan, 54, is leaving his posts as chairman and chief executive of May's Caldor discount store unit based in Norwalk, Conn. May said that Mr. Guinan would be succeeded by Don R. Clarke, 40, who has been chairman of another May's discount operation, Venture, and that Leonard S. Williams, who joined Caldor from Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1984, will continue as the chain's president.

headline: At Least 10 Reported Killed In Iraqi Air Attacks on Iran
abstract: Iraq said today that its warplanes had attacked an Iranian oil terminal, a tanker in the Persian Gulf and military bases in western Iran.

headline: REAGAN PERFORMANCE ON ARMS IS DEBATED
abstract: The dispute between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev over what was said at Reykjavik has raised new questions about how astutely President Reagan and his advisers conducted the negotiations and how they have characterized them to the public.   The dispute could affect the President's ability to continue dealing credibly with Moscow on arms control and damage his reputation as a political leader at home.   The immediate issue is what he led the Soviet officials there to believe he might agree to: Was it simply the elimination of all intercontinental ballistic missiles, as he and other top Administration officials now say, or did he go further and accept Mr. Gorbachev's proposal to eliminate all strategic nuclear arms, as the Soviet leader and several Administration officials maintain? A Dilemma for Reagan    If Mr. Reagan did agree to the concept of eliminating all long-range nuclear weapons, but denies it, he risks undercutting his credibility in future arms talks with Moscow.   But if he admits it, he runs afoul of most of his own Administration's military advice and faces charges of vacillation and incompetence. These are precisely the accusations he used to make, and made again today, about President Carter's handling of Soviet-American relations.

headline: FIAT VOWS COUNTEROFFER
abstract: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had offered to link up with Alfa-Romeo, Italy's state-owned car maker, presumably by acquiring a substantial interest. Fiat S.p.A. immediately stated that it was preparing a counteroffer.   Alfa, best known for high-performance sports cars and stylish sedans, has registered 13 years of consecutive losses, including a loss of about $130 million in 1985.   Neither Ford nor Alfa would release details of the proposal, but when negotiations between them began on May 21 Ford said it would seek a ''substanital share'' of Alfa's capital ''with an eventual option for the majority.''

headline: TRANSWORLD SELLING HILTON UNIT
abstract: The Transworld Corporation said yesterday that a ''major European company'' had bought its Hilton International hotel chain for $970 million in cash.   Transworld refused to identify the buyer or even to discuss the nature of its business. It said only that it had agreed not to name the purchaser until authorized to do so.

headline: The U.N. Today: Nov. 6, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: PATENTS; Honors for Japanese Inventor
abstract: AJAPANESE inventor who may hold more patents than anyone else, is to be honored by the Inventors Clubs of America at a ceremony in Atlanta on Monday.  The inventor, Dr. Yoshiro NakaMats, believes he holds the world record, with a total of 2,360 patents, which he says exceeds Thomas Edison's 1,093.

headline: JEWISH SPOKESMAN ASKS POPE TO MAKE A VISIT TO JERUSALEM
abstract: The head of a major American Jewish organization asked Pope John Paul II today to visit Jerusalem and lead a day of prayer against terrorism.   Nathan Perlmutter, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, made the appeal during a papal audience for participants in a Catholic-Jewish theological seminar held here this week.   Despite the religious focus of the meeting, a prominent topic of discussion was the Vatican's refusal to establish diplomatic relations with Israel. Another point of controversy was an accusation by some Jewish scholars that liberation theology, an important school of Catholic thinking in Latin America, was tainted with anti-Semitism and anti-Zionism.

headline: MORE U.S. CHANGES ON ARMS PROPOSED
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz appeared to propose a further retreat today from the American offer to eliminate all nuclear ballistic missiles in 10 years.   In a speech in Chicago, he suggested that the United States might wish to retain ''a small nuclear ballistic missile force'' to guard against cheating by the Soviet Union in arms control.   He spoke two days after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said here that President Reagan had agreed not to press the Soviet Union to ban all ballistic missiles by 1996, as he had proposed in Iceland.   Nor, she said, would he seek the abolition of all offensive strategic forces, which he had accepted as a 1996 goal when it was presented by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

headline: CHINESE STUDENTS PUT UP POSTERS CALLING FOR MORE DEMOCRACY
abstract: Students at Beijing University put up posters on campus today calling for more democracy, students said. The action followed student demonstrations in the provinces.   The Beijing students said two posters were put up Friday, but were taken down during the night, apparently by the university. Several more appeared today, they said.

headline: Citicorp Unit Chairman Quits
abstract: Citicorp, which has seen a number of its top investment banking officials resign to take more lucrative positions elsewhere, has lost another.   John C. Botts, chairman of Citicorp Investment Bank Ltd., the bank holding company's British investment banking unit, offered his resignation on Tuesday, effective at year-end.

headline: MANILA BARS POWER-SHARING WITH INSURGENTS
abstract: The Philippine Government rejected Communist rebel demands today. But it said it still hoped for a meeting of minds in peace talks to start Jan. 6.   A presidential spokesman, Teodoro Benigno, said rebel demands for an ultimate share of power, the removal of United States bases, a new constitution and a merging of armed forces were all nonnegotiable.

headline: Continental Air
abstract: Pilots unemployed by the shutdown of Frontier Airlines have approved a plan that would guarantee jobs at Continental Airlines to those who drop claims against Frontier. Continental's parent, the Texas Air Corporation, is seeking to buy People Express and the remaining assets of Frontier. People Express, which owned Frontier, shut it down Aug. 24 and four days later filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for Frontier.

headline: U.S. IS EXPELLING 55 IN LATEST REPRISAL ON SOVIET ENVOYS
abstract: The United States, in a surprise move, today ordered the expulsion of 55 Soviet diplomats by Nov. 1. The action was in retaliation for Moscow's ouster on Sunday of five American diplomats.   It was the largest number of Soviet diplomats ever expelled from the United States.   In Moscow, the Government press agency Tass termed the move ''another step aimed at worsening Soviet-American relations.'' Before the American announcement, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said: ''If the U.S. side insists on a continuation of the game according to the tit-for-tat principle, all this may go on endlessly. It seems to us that it is time this whole affair be rounded off.''

headline: Nigeria Gets Accord on Debt
abstract: The Paris Club, a group of Western creditor nations, has reached an accord with Nigeria to reschedule the country's medium- and long-term debt over 10 years, the French Finance Ministry said today.   The agreement, which diplomatic sources said covered $7.5 billion of Nigeria's $19 billion total foreign debt, included a five-year grace period.

headline: A WHIFF OF HIGH TECH COMES TO CANDLMAKING
abstract: WHEN Mike Kittredge was 17 years old in 1969, he had no money to buy Christmas presents. So he decided to make them. Using milk cartons for molds, Mr. Kittredge made candles on his parents' kitchen stove.   ''The shock came when somebody entered the house, saw the new candles and offered to purchase them for $2,'' Mr. Kittredge recalled. ''That was all the applause I needed. I went right out, bought more wax and sure enough, sold some more candles.''   This year, Mr. Kittredge's company, Yankee Candle Inc., the self-proclaimed largest producer of handmade candles in the world, made some 30 million candles and took in revenues of $6.5 million. Incorporated in 1976, when it had a full-time staff of one and sales of $21,000, the South Deerfield, Mass., company now has 150 employees working in a 40,000-square-foot factory.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 28, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Pledging Conference for World Disarmament Campaign - 3 P.M.

headline: SEOUL SAID TO PLEDGE CRACKDOWN ON DISSIDENTS
abstract: The Government was reported today to have pledged a crackdown on leftist dissidents.   In the capital, witnesses said, about 2,000 anti-Government protesters clashed with riot policemen, who fired barrages of tear gas.   The opposition New Korea Democratic Party, meanwhile, said it would step up its campaign for a new constitution and fight for the release of one of its lawmakers, who was arrested Thursday.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is offering $210 million of new bonds to refund outstanding debt through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   Yields on serial bonds ranged from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.50 percent in 1991, 6.40 percent in 1996 and 7 percent in 2001.

headline: AQUINO GETS JAPAN'S PLEDGE OF SUPPORT AT START OF TRIP
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines, starting a four-day visit, received a pledge from Japan today that it ''would not spare its support to the new nation-building efforts'' of her Government.   Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who met with Mrs. Aquino for about an hour, told her that his Government would also ''cooperate more than ever for the recovery of the Philippine economy.''   His remarks brought expressions of ''profound gratitude'' from the Philippine President, who at the outset set the tone for her trip by asking for increased Japanese Government aid and private investment. Japan is the largest supplier of assistance to the Philippines after the United States.

headline: PUNJAB SEEKS ARMY'S HELP ON EXTREMISTS
abstract: The moderate Sikh leaders who govern Punjab, under pressure to step up the drive against Sikh extremists, agreed tonight to seek help from the army in quelling disturbances and tracking down suspects in several districts in the state.   The Sikh-dominated Punjab government also declared that for six months the state's regular police would be given emergency powers to pursue extremists.   Among these would be the power to detain, question, search and shoot suspects. The army, once deployed, would also be given these emergency powers.

headline: Trade Pace Accelerated
abstract: World merchandise trade grew more rapidly in 1986 than previously predicted because of a sharp recovery in fuel exports, according to a report by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to be published Monday.   Lower crude oil prices have brought unexpectedly strong trading in world oil markets since last summer, according to the GATT report.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about mail-order food gifts carried an incorrect price received from Smith Knaupp's Catch of the Day for its stone crabs.

headline: Students Walk Out At 40 Soweto Schools
abstract: Thousands of students walked out at about 40 high schools in the black township of Soweto today in a coordinated school boycott, but there were no reports of incidents.   Following the instructions on pamphlets distributed throughout Soweto, the students showed up at their schools, then walked out en masse.

headline: F.H.A. Loan Requests Soar
abstract: The lowest interest rates in eight years spurred a record 1.95 million applications for federally insured home mortgages in the fiscal year 1986, the Federal Housing Administration said today.

headline: Curbs Weighed By the C.F.T.C.
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will meet next week to consider barring commodity exchange employees from trading certain futures or options.   The meeting comes amid widely publicized investigations of possible illegal activity on the stock market following the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading scandal.

headline: Tremor Strikes Peking
abstract: A minor earthquake rocked an outlying area of Peking today, but no injuries or damage was reported, the New China News Agency said. A State Seismological Bureau statement said the tremor had measured 3.7 on the Richter scale.

headline: HASENFUS STIRS NICARAGUAN MEMORIES OF '09
abstract: Eugene Hasenfus, the air-cargo specialist whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua last month and who was sentenced to 30 years in jail, is not the first American to be captured and punished for meddling in Nicaraguan revolutions.   So much has happened in the turbulent history of Nicaraguan-United States relations over the last century and a half that nearly every contemporary episode has its historical parallel. Rarely, however, is the parallel so eerily precise as that between the Hasenfus case and that of two Americans arrested here in 1909 for helping rebels.   ''The similarities are really extraordinary,'' said Oscar Rene Vargas, a historian and former Sandinista official. He said he had privately urged Sandinista leaders to remember the events of 1909 when they decide whether to pardon Mr. Hasenfus.

headline: 2 N.S.C. STAFF MEMBERS RESIGN
abstract: Two members of the National Security Council staff have resigned as part of a shake-up ordered by the new national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci, White House officials said today.   One of the staff members, Raymond F. Burkhardt, senior director for Latin American affairs, will return to the State Department and will be sent to the United States Embassy in Beijing, a spokesman said.

headline: FOR POPE, A DAY TO SEE AUSTRALIA, NEARLY ALL OF IT
abstract: Pope John Paul II crisscrossed a continent and its cultures today. In the desolate outback, he defended the civil rights of aboriginal tribesmen, and then many miles later he opened the Christmas season by lighting an Advent candle in a stately town square.   Even for the Pope, a well-traveled person, it was a remarkable day of contrasts, distances, suprises and controversy.   Deep into what is called the ''dead heart'' of Australia, the barren countryside near the town of Alice Springs, the Pope was introduced to the ''dreaming,'' the ancient creation legends that are the basis of aborigine culture and religion.

headline: Railroad Merger Case
abstract: The Interstate Commerce Commission left open the possibility today that it might reconsider its controversial rejection of a proposed merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads. The I.C.C., which rejected the merger because of concern about competition, said it would decide whether to reopen the case in 60 days.

headline: Market Place; Bakery Shares Show Strength
abstract: WALL STREET has focused on the giant food packagers recently, but stocks in a related industry have been better performers. Shares of wholesale baking and snack cake companies have been climbing to record highs, thanks to a mix of stable commodity costs, better pricing and improved earnings prospects. At the same time there have been proposed acquisitions of both publicly owned and private companies in the group.   ''Part of the appeal of this niche industry, too, is that bread and its other basic products tend to be recession-resistant,'' said Leonard Teitelbaum, a food analyst at Merrill Lynch.

headline: Showtime's Chairman Announces Resignation
abstract: Neil R. Austrian said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive of Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc. to pursue his other interests.   He said he would remain in the post until a successor could be found.   ''The basic reason is the job is no longer the job it was when I was hired,'' Mr. Austrian said. ''The clear intent was it would be an independent, public company. Obviously that is no longer the case.''

headline: PRETORIA DETAINS 13 FOES OF DRAFT
abstract: Armed with emergency powers, the South African police detained 13 young white anti-conscription campaigners overnight and clamped restrictions on 12 others in what opponents called a crackdown on white dissent.   The action against the End Conscription Campaign drew widespread condemnation from church groups and opposition figures. ''It is a vindictive act by an increasingly oppressive Government,'' a spokesman from the main white opposition group in Parliament, the Progressive Federal Party, said.   In another development, a crowd of angry blacks pelted Winnie Mandela, the anti-apartheid leader, with garbage today as she left the trial in Cape Town of a friend convicted of murder, witnesses said.

headline: ARGENTINA ACTS TO ACQUIT MILITARY
abstract: The Senate began debate today on a law that would end the trials of military officers for human rights abuses.
