Congress was widely expected to approve the bill, which would bar trials of military or police officers for rights abuses as of 60 days from passage of the law if the officers have not already been arraigned.

headline: STEINBERG SELLS MOST OF BRITISH STAKE
abstract: Saul P. Steinberg, the American financier, sold most of his 15.1 percent stake in the British financial group Mercury Securities today for almost $142 million after the company repeatedly rejected his proposals to increase its earnings.   Mercury, which includes the leading London merchant bank S. G. Warburg, had made it clear that it regarded Mr. Steinberg's involvement in the company as unwelcome.   Mr. Steinberg, who had held his stake through his Reliance insurance company, sold 21.9 million Mercury shares, or just under 15 percent of Mercury, to the Canadian National Railway Company at $6.46 a share, well above the market price.

headline: OPEC SETS EXTENSION OF ACCORD
abstract: Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a frustrating 17-day conference early this morning by agreeing to extend production controls aimed at strengthening prices.   The group agreed to raise its official production ceiling to a total of 14.961 million barrels a day on Nov. 1, and to 15.039 million barrels after Dec. 1. The current accord, reached in August, had limited production to 14.8 million barrels a day.   The global ceiling applies to only 12 of the group's 13 members, excluding Iraq. Officials said that Iraqi oil production is now estimated at somewhat less than 2 million barrels a day.

headline: Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek Returns to Taiwan
abstract: Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, widow of the late Nationalist Chinese president, returned to Taiwan on today for her first visit since she left for the United States in 1975 after her husband's death.

headline: JOURNALISTS DIFFER ON THE LONG-TERM EFFECTS OF THE DANILOFF CASE
abstract: Although journalists welcomed the release of Nicholas S. Daniloff from Soviet custody, they have expressed widely differing views on the long-term effect of the incident and how it was handled.   The journalists generally agreed that Mr. Daniloff's professional stature as a reporter will not be damaged among his American colleagues, but there was disagreement on such issues as the terms of his release, the safety of other foreign correspondents and the overall significance of the incident.   In a spot check, most journalists said they had accepted the near inevitability that it would be necessary to link the release of a Soviet spy in United States custody with the release of Mr. Daniloff, a Moscow correspondent for U.S. News & World Report.   ''I think it was probably the best we could do in an impossible situation,'' said Katherine W. Fanning, editor of The Christian Science Monitor.

headline: Junk Bonds
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Three New Reasons to Fear Junk Bonds'' (Forum, Aug. 24), Louis Lowenstein takes issue with the fact that the market for high-yield securities is thriving. As large as the market is, its potential size is even greater. Only about 600 American corporations are assigned an investment-grade rating by the major rating agencies. That deprives over 19,000 companies with assets of $25 million of an important source of capital, and could have a damaging effect on the country's economy.

headline: 3 Openings At the Top Are Filled
abstract: IN New York yesterday Conde Nast Publications named a new president to replace Robert J. Lapham, 64 years old, who decided to retire from the job he has held for 12 years. And in Chicago, at the Leo Burnett Company, the country's 10th-largest agency, a similar decision was reached by the topmost two in its worldwide organization - John J. Kinsella, 53, and Norman Muse, 52. All go with the year on Dec. 31.  The new man at Conde Nast is Bernard H. Leser, 61, who has 27 years with the company. He will be coming to New York from London, where he led the British subsidiary.   The new duo at Burnett is Hall (Cap) Adams, 53, who will be chairman and chief executive, replacing Mr. Kinsella, and Richard Fizdale, 47, who will be president and chief creative officer, replacing Mr. Muse. The appointees held the same titles in Leo Burnett USA, where William Lynch Jr., 44, will replace Mr. Adams, and Robert Nolan, 42, will replace Mr. Fizdale.

headline: Hasenfus Sentence Confirmed
abstract: A revolutionary appeals court today confirmed the guilty verdict and 30-year prison sentence imposed on the American Eugene Hasenfus.   The decision upheld the Nov. 15 decision by the three-member People's Revolutionary Tribunal convicting Mr. Hasenfus of helping to fly weapons to United States-backed anti-Sandinista rebels, known as contras.

headline: Campeau Can Buy Allied Shares
abstract: Federal Judge Pierre N. Leval allowed the Campeau Corporation to buy 48 percent of the common stock of the Allied Stores Corporation but ruled that the Canadian developer cannot vote the shares until litigation is resolved.   Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission said it would file a brief with Judge Leval arguing that Campeau's purchase of the 28.5 million shares through Jefferies & Company was an illegal tender offer. The S.E.C. said that Campeau's $1.73 billion stock purchase, which came after it withdrew its tender offer, was a ''de facto'' continuation of the offer.

headline: NOW, THE AGE OF FAST-BUCK BANKING
abstract: Snapshots of American banking practices, 1986:    * The Chase Manhattan Bank sells a list of its customers to the Combined Life Insurance Company, which uses the list to sell insurance by mail. As part of the deal, the return address is Chase's good name, and a note inside from a Chase officer urges the consumer to buy the ''low-cost'' insurance.    * A psychologist from upstate New York, earning $3,500 a month, owes $121,000 on credit cards from 11 banks, including Chemical, the Bank of New York and Citicorp. She found herself unable to resist offers of ''pre-approved'' credit card appliations, which came in her mail. Now she goes to a counselor for help.    * The Bank of Boston and the Bank of New England are operating under constraint agreements with the Massachusetts Attorney General's office requiring them to fully explain their mortgage-pricing policies in their advertising. A former state official accuses them of offering misleading ''teaser'' interest rates to lure customers to variable-rate mortgages.

headline: Bank Board Nominee
abstract: President Reagan will nominate an economics professor, Lawrence J. White, to be a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, it was announced today.

headline: Associated-May
abstract: Shareholders of both the May Department Stores Company and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation approved the $2.47 billion acquisition of Associated by May. Associated holders will receive 1.72 shares of May common for each Associated common. May shareholders also approved an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 350 million, from 200 million.

headline: Schlumberger Chairman Replaced
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd., in a surprise move, announced last night the election of Euan Baird to the posts of chairman, president and chief executive officer. Mr. Baird, who is 49 years old, will replace Michel Vaillaud in those posts.   Mr. Vaillaud, 54, apparently was ousted by the board after only one year at the helm.

headline: MUBARAK FIGHTS A FUNDAMENTALIST TIDE ON CAMPUS
abstract: When the medical school of Asyut University held examinations recently, the bearded student recalled, the building was ringed with policemen.   ''They were looking for those of the Islamic tendency,'' he said. ''They had about 60 names. They are arresting and torturing.''
